HEADLINE: Business Digest

The Economy
The American economy nearly came to a standstill in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported, with the meager growth being far worse than previously thought. [Page A1.]
Many Americans believe a recession has arrived, but they are being told by Government officials to put their worries aside for the moment because other economic issues, mainly inflation, have to be dealt with first. Economic Analysis. [D1.] 
Seidman proposed sweeping changes in the nation's banking industry, including the repeal of the three main Federal regulatory laws, to ease the financial stress on the industry. [D1.]
The full scope of the case against Michael Milken began to come to light in court for the first time. [D1.]
A Government witness supported Neil Bush's contention that his fellow directors at Silverado knew he had an interest in a partnership that was given a $900,000 line of credit. [D2.]
Rebates and year-end clearance deals helped sales of cars and light trucks. [D6.] The Senate failed to cut off debate on a bill to require auto makers to improve fuel efficiency greatly. [A12.]
With a budget compromise still out of reach, the White House and Congressional Democrats prepared doomsday scenarios. [A1.]
 
Companies
Matsushita confirmed it was in talks to acquire MCA. The price is reportedly $85 to $90 a share, or up to $7.5 billion. [D1.]
The Pentagon waived its ban on awarding new contracts to a Northrop division. [D26.]
Kobe Steel and Alcoa said they would form a venture in Japan to produce aluminum for cans and autos in Asian markets. [D5.]
Chase Manhattan's debt ratings were reduced by Moody's, which cited the potential losses that Chase could suffer. [D16.]
 
Business Technology
A renewed attempt to develop superconducting computers is being advocated by some researchers, inspired by promising discoveries in the last few years. [D9.]
Living plants would be essential aboard any long space flight, but even the simple act of watering presents a challenge. [D9.]
 
Markets
The oil trading pit at the New York Merc has been no place for slow reflexes ever since Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. [D1.] The price of oil dipped after three days of large increases. [D4.]
Stocks headed up after four down days. The Dow jumped 32.67, to 2,485.64. [D10.]
Prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates eased, as Government growth numbers and falling oil prices outweighed other factors. [D16.]
The dollar advanced against all leading currencies except the yen, which took center stage on world markets. [D17.] Gold futures prices held nearly steady. [D17.]
Uncovered Nasdaq short sales increased almost 4.5 percent for the month ended in mid-September. [D8.]
 
International
President Bush announced formation of a steering group to coordinate aid to nations hit by oil-price rises. [A8.]
 
Today's Columns

White House cheering on a victory on textile imports may prove premature. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]

HEADLINE: In the Oil Trading Pit, Reflexes Must Be Fast

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
At 8:30 yesterday morning, Albert H. Helmig Jr. figured that world crude oil prices were about to head downward. He had the reasons all worked out, based on his assessment of supply and demand, his experience as a broker and his studies of economics and finance.
A little more than an hour later, as he prepared to lead a team from Energex, his oil and petroleum products brokerage firm, into the crude oil trading pit at the New York Mercantile Exchange on the eighth floor of the World Trade Center, he was putting his projections out of mind. In the trading pits, theories can inhibit reflexes. Ever since Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, the oil trading pit at the New York Merc has been no place for slow reflexes.
''The only thing that matters is where people put their money,'' said Mr. Helmig, a 38-year-old who first visited a commodity trading floor as a child to watch his father trade wool. ''You have to let the market tell you what's happening and not think too much, or you can lose a lot of money.'' 
The Merc's crude oil pit is home to the world's largest market in oil futures, which are contracts to deliver oil at specific dates from next month - the practical equivalent of a spot oil price for immediate delivery - to dates up to 18 months away. The November contract lost 72 cents yesterday to close at $37.53.
In the early 1980's, most oil was sold under long-term contracts geared to prices posted by OPEC overseas and by the leading oil companies in the United States. But that has changed.
Today, most oil users buy in the spot market, and the New York Merc has emerged as the place investors, Governments and consumers alike track the spot market. In some cases, price jumps in Merc futures contracts have kicked off immediate price increases for end products like gasoline, as skittish retailers try to build up profits in anticipation of higher costs.
The Merc contract specifies delivery of 1,000 barrels of West Texas Intermediate crude, or one of nine domestic and foreign oils of a similar quality, to Cushing, Okla., a big oil storage and distribution center. Less than 2 percent of the Merc trades actually result in such deliveries. But each trade gives an instant snapshot of the value of the benchmark crude, the clearest price signal available anywhere in the oil market. As a result, traders off the exchange adjust their actual deals, depending on whether the crude they are trading is more or less valuable than the Texas crude and the costs of delivering it to other terminals.
Merc contracts for other petroleum products, including unleaded gasoline, heating oil, propane and natural gas, also act as benchmarks.
 
World's Meeting Place
Thus, although it is smaller than a modest street intersection, the Merc is, in effect, the meeting place where all of the world's major buyers and sellers of oil and oil products come together.
''We don't set prices here, but this is where the market discovers the price,'' said Z. Lou Guttman, chairman of the exchange's board.
These days, with oil prices seen as a key factor in the vulnerability of the United States and other industrial countries to recession, the Merc's trading day is closely followed by stock markets, bond traders and other markets around the world.
To the uninitiated, the trading pit is bewildering. At 9:45, in a tornado of screaming and waving arms, the crude oil pit erupted into its trading day. Some 200 men and a smattering of women, most of them considerably younger than the tall, balding Mr. Helmig, crowded into the trading ring. Telephone clerks in booths nearby added to the pandemonium, trying to get the buy and sell orders to their brokers.
 
Price Swings Begin
As the first deals were struck, brokers ripped off tickets recording them and tossed them into the center of the ring, where they were collected by exchange employees and sent off to be entered into computers. Copies were also being handed off to runners to take to telephone clerks for confirmation. Soon the ''Novee'' crude oil price - crude oil for November delivery - was sliding, down to nearly $37 a barrel. Then a number of large ''trade'' customers - oil companies, refiners and others that actually have or want oil supplies - jumped in with buy orders, and the first of a number of price swings began.
Throughout the day, Mr. Helmig and other participants, including brokers connected to the crowded floor by telephone, kept one eye on the activity and another on news headlines. Everyone was on edge in case of an event that might suddenly change the outlook for oil prices.
Much of the trading involves balancing price spreads between different products. In recent weeks, for example, futures contracts for home heating oil have been surging in anticipation of winter demand. But events in the Persian Gulf have overshadowed every other trend.
''Your nerves get frayed in markets like this,'' said Richard D. Donovan, the Shearson Lehman Hutton vice president who oversees Shearson's international energy department. ''The fundamentals of supply and demand aren't as useful as usual, and you are reduced to trading headlines, the most difficult type of trading.''
The Merc introduced energy futures trading with a contract for home heating oil in 1978. Gasoline was added in 1981, crude oil in 1983, propane in 1987, residual oil, or boiler fuel, in 1989, and natural gas this spring.
 
The Main Attraction
In every case, the main attraction of a futures contract for corporate traders, from oil producers to major consumers like airlines, is to hedge against risks that prices will change. Some buy futures contracts to guarantee that they will have supplies at a predictable price. Producers may sell contracts to lock in a profit margin.
As the contract becomes due, its price and the actual spot price for immediate delivery of the oil come together. In calmer times, the price for futures in oil and oil products typically increases with the length of the contract, reflecting the greater uncertainty over what the distant spot price will be.
Since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, however, the short-term prices have been highest. Oil experts say there is plenty of oil in the world, which serves to hold down long-term prices, but everyone is afraid that war in the Persian Gulf could drastically interrupt supplies in a matter of weeks.
''The higher the price goes, the more dramatic the eventual fall will be,'' said Mr. Donovan, whose Shearson team is the largest in the Merc market. ''This market would drop $10 a barrel in a week if there was some quick end to the Kuwait situation in sight.''
On Monday, the short-term price, which is the only contract that trades without any limit to how far it can rise or fall in a day, climbed so rapidly that all of the contracts for ''Deece'' (pit talk for December) and later months hit their limit of $2 in the crude pit. Trading in those contracts was frozen. Yesterday, some of the contracts rose the limit again to close the differential with the ''Novee'' contract, then softened enough for trading to resume.
 
An 11-Minute Break
Mr. Helmig had a fairly typical day in many respects, given the market's extreme volatility. He managed an 11-minute break before the 3:10 closing, which he used to call a customer. (''Lunch is for wimps,'' said one of his employees.) And Energex was among the busiest independent brokers, ending up arranging trades for 10,000 contracts, accounting for crude and oil products worth $400 million.
But it wasn't all smooth by any means. Late in the day, a client asked Energex to trade 30 lots for a number of delivery dates far into next year. The farther out a contract is, the harder it is to find anyone to trade with, so Mr. Helmig and his staff found themselves forced to turn down the chance to handle 400 other potential contracts to concentrate on the earlier order.
''It can be brutal,'' he said wearily at the end of the day, noting that about 40 percent of the floor brokers depart within two years.

HEADLINE: When Is It a Recession?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
At a time when many Americans believe that a recession has descended on the country, they are being told by Government officials to put their worries aside for the moment because other economic issues, mainly inflation, have to be dealt with first.
This message is coming from the Federal Reserve, but the Bush Administration is not openly challenging the thesis. And the top financial officials of the six other major industrial nations, meeting in Washington this week, have also declared that recession, or the threat of it, is still a second-rung issue.
The Group of Seven industrial nations - the United States, West Germany, Japan, France, Britain, Canada and Italy - even issued a communique calling recession talk too pessimistic. The communique spoke of ''solid growth'' in the industrial world, ignoring the obviously sluggish economies in the United States, Canada and Britain. 
Millions of Americans, in particular, are experiencing unemployment, wage freezes, bankruptcies and falling real estate prices, and concluding that what they are living through constitutes a recession. How can their perception, reported in public opinion polls, differ so strikingly from that of the Federal Reserve and its counterparts elsewhere?
The answer is that the central banks remain more worried by the threat of inflation than of recession, and that to ignore the inflationary dangers now will only mean a deeper recession later. The Middle East crisis is the principal reason for the anti-inflationary consensus, mainly because it pushed up oil prices so sharply.
Apart from the oil price shock, the Federal Reserve is keeping interest rates up to slow a sharp fall in the dollar since July. A weak dollar is inflationary because it pushes up the price of imports and the Federal Reserve tries to counteract this by keeping interest rates high enough to convince holders of foreign currency to buy dollars and invest them in American securities.
The problem with this strategy is that high interest rates, the tool used by Western central banks to fight inflation, tends to make weak economies, like that of the United States, even weaker, by discouraging the borrowing that finances purchases and investment.
''The Federal Reserve, in particular, is admitting, in effect, that under the current strategy, it cannot avoid a contraction in the economy over the next one or two quarters,'' said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services. ''Most of us consider that to be a recession.''
 
A New Definition
No wonder, then, that Alan Greenspan, in testimony last week before the Joint Economic Committee, argued for a definition of recession that is more stringent than the traditional public concept of one. The popular view is that a recession occurs when the gross national product - the total value of the new goods and services that the nation is constantly producing - shrinks for six consecutive months.
Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that the economy was very sluggish, so much so that the G.N.P. grew at an annual rate of only 1 percent during the first six months of 1990, including a minuscule four-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. Without much change in the public's current sense of malaise, the G.N.P. could easily slip into negative growth for two quarters, he says.
A true recession, Mr. Greenspan argued, is a ''cumulative unwinding of economic activity,'' and not simply a few months of mildly negative G.N.P. growth that might be reversed when the Commerce Department issues its annual revisions of earlier statistics.
The Greenspan formula requires a steep, widespread decline in economic activity, the sort of trouble that develops when stockpiles of unsold goods build up as consumer spending drops. As a result, factory orders are canceled, corporate profits fall, capital investment is cut back and the unemployment rate shoots up. Looking for Elbow Room? Many economists accept this process as a key cause of some postwar recessions. But some note that by raising the issue now, Mr. Greenspan might be trying to give the Fed elbow room to keep interest rates high, even during a quarter or two of negative G.N.P. growth.
''The Fed declares that there is no recession, so there is nothing that requires drastic policy changes,'' said Alan Levenson, an economist at the WEFA Group, an economic consulting firm. ''But an individual can look at what is happening to himself and end up behaving as if he were in a recession.''
If the Federal Reserve is seeking elbow room, it is doing so largely out of concern that rising oil prices, if not countered with high interest rates, will produce a situation in which workers successfully push for wage increases to offset the higher costs of gasoline, heating fuel and numerous petroleum-based products. The resulting wage-price spiral, Mr. Greenspan argues, would force the Federal Reserve to counterattack by pushing up interest rates very sharply, in the end provoking greater economic weakness than exists today. Something like this occurred after the Arab oil embargo in October 1973.
The Group of Seven's communique, signed by Mr. Greenspan and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, made the same argument, stating that ''stability oriented monetary policies'' - a euphemism for high interest rates - would ''reduce the risks of lower economic growth'' in the future. And Mr. Brady joined in the recession putdown, stating at a news conference that the American economy still has ''underlying power.''
Nevertheless, the danger for the Fed, and for the nation, is that the United States will fall into recession while Mr. Greenspan and the 17 other Federal Reserve policy makers are still maintaining rates at present levels. The interest payments on mortgages and most other consumer loans are at 10 percent or more.
 
'You Hear of Real Weakness'
No economist knows how long it might be before the oil price shock wears off and the Consumer Price Index, which jumped in August, subsides to an annual rate of less than 5 percent, the level that has prevailed for most of the last five years. But even if the oil shock inflation does not subside soon, the recession danger has prompted some economists to urge the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates anyway. A minority among the Federal Reserve's policy makers favor this approach, including Martha Seger, a governor.
''If you talk to people who are real business people and not economists sitting in a library or the Federal Reserve, you hear of real weakness,'' she said. ''And if you talk to people in construction and housing, it is really terrible.''
That raises the definition question again. The National Bureau of Economic Research, a prestigious private institute that has become the nation's official arbiter of when recessions begin and end, offers a definition that seems closer to the Greenspan view than the popular one. It says a recession is ''a recurring period of decline in total output, income, employment and trade, usually lasting from six months to a year and marked by widespread contractions in many sectors of the economy.''

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Can Banks Survive a Recession?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
While economists disagree on whether a recession has started, many large American banks are concluding that by some measures their loan portfolios are already in the worst shape since the end of the 1974-75 recession. That fact has helped to create the gloomiest investment outlook for many of these banks in more than a decade.
''Heading into a recession, we're worse now than we were coming out of the last major recession,'' said Thomas H. Hanley, a bank analyst for Salomon Brothers, referring to the level of nonperforming assets at large banks. He forecast that loan problems would increase substantially over the next few years. 
By his calculation, problem loans at 35 large banks, excluding those to developing countries, amounted to 2.6 percent of total loans at the end of last year. He estimates that they will rise to 3.5 percent by the end of this year. Problem loans include those listed as nonperforming, which normally means payments are overdue or likely to become so, and loans renegotiated to provide breaks for the borrower, as well as real estate loans on foreclosed property.
 
Highest in a Decade
By contrast, the problem-loan ratio in the 1980's peaked at 3.4 percent in 1984, as the country recovered from the 1981-82 recession. The expected 1990 level would be the highest since 4 percent in 1977 and 5.3 percent in 1976, after the most severe postwar recession ended in 1975.
At the moment, rising real estate problems are the biggest concern to many analysts. In the last three years, the amount of troubled real estate loans at the nation's banks almost doubled even before the Chase Manhattan Corporation said last week that real estate problems were the largest single cause of a $1 billion charge against earnings that will cause the bank to report a loss for the current quarter.
Yesterday, Moody's Investors Service cited the real estate problems in lowering the rating on Chase's bonds, putting its subordinated debt just below investment grade - an area that is commonly referred to as ''junk.''
Despite such problems, there remains optimism that the commercial banks will not follow the path of the savings and loan industry, where losses mounted until a huge Government bailout was required.
''The data suggest it will take further weakening of the economy, to the point of massive defaults in other than the real estate sector, before the banking industry could be pushed from its present uneasy state into massive insolvency on the scale suffered by the S.& L.'s,'' said Warren Heller, the president of Veribanc Inc. in Wakefield, Mass., a company that monitors bank safety.
At the end of March, the most recent date for which comprehensive data are available, banks counted $48.6 billion in nonperforming real estate loans, including foreclosed lands, up 37 percent from a year earlier and up 91 percent from 1987.
In the first quarter of this year, Veribanc estimates, all banks together lost $1.3 billion on real estate activities, as profits from mortgages that were being paid were more than offset by losses on loans that went bad.
With real estate problems now appearing in the South as well as the Northeast, the general expectation is that the level of bad loans is likely to rise if business activity continues to slow. Typically, many real estate developers manage to hang on for a time, making payments on loans even though their projects are not providing sufficient cash flow, but eventually they are unable to meet their obligations. That is why problem-loan levels usually peak after a recession and why the rise this early has sounded alarms.
Most of the losses being recorded stem from loans for commercial real estate and property development. Losses on single-family mortgage loans remain very low, although that could change if more homeowners cannot meet payments on loans that are larger than their property is now worth.
Over all, the banks followed by Salomon charged off as uncollectible a total of $7.60 out of each $1,000 in loans in 1989. Mr. Hanley expects that to rise to $10.20 this year, a figure that would be higher than in any year since he began compiling the data in 1971.
The real estate problems vary widely, and one disturbing fact is that while the situation seems to be improving in some of the worst-hit areas, including Texas and Oklahoma, Veribanc says levels of nonperforming loans are rising in most other states. Banks in all six New England states saw the level of such loans at least double in the 12 months through March, and there were also sizable increases in many Middle Atlantic and Southern states.
Bank accounting is both complicated and full of discretion, which is one reason many investors apparently fear that the reality may be worse than the figures indicate. Although most bank stocks rose yesterday as the stock market rallied, most bank shares are down well over 50 percent over the last 12 months.
''We've got a mini-panic out there'' in the bank stocks, said Mr. Hanley, who thinks the bottom in such stocks is approaching but is not yet here.
An encouraging fact is that banks are generally better capitalized than they were a decade ago. The Salomon figures indicate that the average large bank had shareholder equity equal to 5.5 percent of assets at the end of last year, compared with 4.5 percent in 1973, before a recession began. In 1979, before higher oil prices helped set off a small 1980 recession and a more severe downturn in 1981 and 1982, the equity ratio was 4.2 percent.
But while banks are generally better capitalized today, many borrowers are not. The leverage boom of the 1980's left many companies with debt levels far above those of earlier eras. Consequently, they are probably more vulnerable to a recession.
While commercial real estate is now getting most of the attention from worried bank watchers, loans to what bank regulators now officially call ''highly leveraged transactions,'' such as leveraged buyouts, are also of concern. Investor worry over those loans is one reason banks now hesitate to make loans that will be included in that listing.
Exposure to such loans varies widely. Mr. Hanley calculates that Bankers Trust has 41 percent of its loans in one of the risky categories -commercial real estate, highly leveraged transactions or medium- to long-term loans to developing countries. By contrast, Republic New York has just 7 percent of its loans in those areas. Most other major banks are in the range of 15 percent to 30 percent.
The fact that a loan is in a risky category, or even that the borrower has stopped paying interest, does not mean that it will prove to be a bad loan. But at the moment, investors are fearful that as the economy weakens, many more loans will end up appearing to have been unwise.

HEADLINE: Bank Law Overhaul Proposed

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed sweeping changes in the nation's banking industry today, including the repeal of the three main Federal regulatory laws, to ease the financial stress on the industry and on the Federal fund that insures deposits.
The chairman, L. William Seidman, told the House Banking Committee that Congress should drop significant portions of the Glass-Steagall Act, which restricts investment banking activities of commercial banks; the McFadden Act, which limits interstate banking, and the Bank Holding Company Act, which generally limits non-banking institutions from controlling banks.
 
Other Remedies Needed
''We can only hold the fort if we do substantial restructuring of the industry,'' Mr. Seidman said. ''You can't cure this problem just by charging higher insurance premiums.'' 
While Mr. Seidman's proposal would permit banks to diversify into other businesses and enter new geographic regions, and would make it easier for other industries to acquire banks, he emphasized that it would not deregulate the banking industry. By permitting banks to enter other industries, Mr. Seidman said investors would be more likely to add capital to these institutions.
Mr. Seidman is the second important banking and finance official in recent days to tie changes in the strained deposit insurance system, which lawmakers and regulators agree are urgently needed to avoid its collapse, to an overhaul of the entire banking system.
 
Greenspan Urges Repeal
Two weeks ago, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, told Congress that it should repeal the 57-year-old Glass-Steagall Act. In recent years, banks have been allowed through regulatory action to enter a variety of securities-related businesses, eroding Glass-Steagall restrictions. That trend continued last week when the Fed permitted a unit of J. P. Morgan & Company to engage in limited underwriting and trading of corporate shares.
As far back as 1987, Mr. Seidman has suggested significant modifications to the three Federal laws he discussed today, but his latest proposal comes as the Bush Administration and Congress are studying ways to prevent the depletion of the F.D.I.C. fund that insures bank deposits, which is at its weakest level since it was created during the Depression. The fund, which has $13.2 billion, lost money in the last two years and is expected this year to post another loss of at least $2 billion.
Bank regulators and auditors from the General Accounting Office have said an economic downturn or the failure of one or a few large institutions could exhaust the insurance fund, forcing a taxpayer rescue similar to the bailout of the savings and loan industry, whose insurance fund was depleted last year.
 
Significant Changes
Efforts over the last few years to overhaul the laws, particularly the Glass-Steagall Act, have failed. But the growing fear on Capitol Hill and at the White House that the banking problems could start to resemble those plaguing the savings and loan industry have fueled strong views among lobbyists and legislators that significant changes could be made when Congress returns in January.
While the Treasury Department has not yet announced its views on reforming the deposit insurance system, senior Treasury officials have said insurance changes should be linked to an overhaul of the banking system. The Treasury Department is required by the savings and loan bailout legislation of last year to produce a comprehensive plan for all deposit insurance by early next year.
In a speech on Monday before the Institute of International Bankers, Under Secretary of Treasury Robert R. Glauber said such an overhaul was necessary ''to make U.S. institutions more competitive.'' He also said that by increasing shareholder risk, more stringent capital standards would be useful in ''bringing a marketplace discipline'' to institutions that have come to rely too heavily on the Federal insurance fund.
 
Bill to Restrict Insurance
The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, introduced a measure today to restrict deposit insurance coverage. Federal law protects deposits up to $100,000, but as a practical matter the F.D.I.C. has been reimbursing most depositors with more than $100,000 in accounts at both banks and savings and loan associations that fail.
Mr. Seidman defended that practice today, saying it is often cheaper to have a failed institution transfer all of its deposits to another institution rather than closing down and having all depositors paid by the insurance fund.
Mr. Seidman said that as part of his proposal significantly greater limits would be placed on what types of investments could be made by that part of a company that holds insured deposits.
Mr. Seidman said, for instance, that rules should be adopted restricting the ability of banks to use Government-insured deposits to make loans for raw land, speculative investments like ''junk bonds,'' loans to lesser-developed nations and many other types of long-term lending, except for home mortgages.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Apparel Makers' Last Stand?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE sighs of relief from the White House were almost audible last week when the House went along with the Senate, voting for sharper restrictions on imports of clothes, textiles and shoes. While Administration economists view the measure as a horror show of protectionism, to their delight the vote fell short of the two-thirds needed to override President Bush's expected veto.
But the cheering may prove premature. Textile makers, who led the charge to limit import growth to 1 percent annually, reportedly did not expect to win this time around. And the close call will force United States diplomats to watch their backs as they negotiate away import restrictions on apparel and textiles in return for much-desired concessions on business services and agriculture. 
Economists have agreed to disagree over the proposition that freer trade is always better trade. An articulate minority argues that protection of strategic high-technology sectors - electronics, perhaps - would increase America's future income. But it is hard to find an independent analyst who believes that America should protect ill-paying jobs and fat profits in textiles and apparel.
Under the ''temporary'' international Multi-Fiber Arrangement created 29 years ago, America negotiates import quotas by fabric and by country in the third world. The restraints, calculates William Cline, a researcher at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, are equivalent to a 50 percent tariff: consumers now pay an extra $20 billion annually for apparel.
A bit of this cash, about $250 per American family, ends up in the United States Treasury as added revenue from tariffs and corporate income taxes. But much of it, Mr. Cline estimates, goes directly to the manufacturers' bottom lines. Ironically, a good chunk of the windfall is scooped up by foreign producers, who are able to charge more because the system protects them from competition from more efficient third world countries that have already filled their quotas.
Trade barriers do mean more work in the domestic industry, Mr. Cline concedes. But the benefits to working America are limited; wages in the apparel industry average about $6.50 an hour, 40 percent less than the average manufacturing wage. And there is little reason to believe that the loss would raise unemployment for long: Most states where apparel and textiles are produced suffer from shortages of semi-skilled labor, and the labor market is apt to tighten more as the baby boom generation grows old.
The bill passed by Congress would have further painted the textile and apparel industry's protectionist lilies. Cutting the rate of growth of imports from about 7 percent to 1, Mr. Cline estimates, would raise Americans' annual bill for clothing and cloth by another $30 billion by the year 2000. And the poor would suffer most: Higher prices for clothing would cut the purchasing power of the poorest fifth of Americans by 8 percent.
An additional 250,000 apparel workers would have to be hired to replace roughly the same number reaching retirement age over the decade. But each of these jobs - relatively low-wage jobs -would cost consumers about $190,000 a year.
With President Bush's veto, the measure will be dead. But it may yet rise from the grave to deal a mortal blow to plans for trade liberalization in the so-called Uruguay Round negotiations, scheduled to end this year. The Administration is asking Europe to eliminate restrictions on American farm exports. And it wants third world countries to give a fair shake to exporters of services - banking, insurance, computer software and the like. In return, the American team has offered to phase out textile and apparel quotas over the next decade.
But the proposed deal is no more credible than the Administration's ability to win ratification by Congress. Under United States law, the trade package can be presented to legislators for a single up-or-down vote. And the White House is counting on the muscle of exporters who stand to gain from trade liberalization to neutralize the textile, apparel and shoe lobbies.
That is a plausible strategy. Legislators from North Carolina, for example, who routinely carry water for the textile industry, would find themselves under pressure from local farm groups to vote for liberal trade. But the strategy is by no means a sure winner.
Much depends on the willingness of Democrats to break with organized labor, which has decided to treat a threat to apparel jobs as a threat to the union movement. And much turns on the determination of the agriculture and service business lobbies to put trade liberalization at the top of their political agendas. Consumers, who would benefit from an end to apparel and textile quotas no matter what happens to exporters, hardly count at all.

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Dip Slightly After 3 Big Increases

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
After three trading days of large increases, the price of oil dipped yesterday, with crude for November delivery off 72 cents a barrel, to $37.53, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Gasoline and heating oil for October delivery were also down slightly.
Traders attributed the modest drops to profit taking and technical factors.
Crude and heating oil for delivery this winter and next spring, however, increased in price again yesterday. Gasoline rose for delivery in November and December but fell for delivery in January through April. 
No clear consensus on oil prices emerged, and the market remains susceptible to sudden rallies and plunges, said Michael Wilner, the president of the Hilltop Trading Company, a trading and brokerage firm on the floor of the Merc.
''It's like a car skidding on ice,'' he said. ''There's no predicting what it will do.''
 
Effect on Consumers
Consumers are already feeling the effects. The American Automobile Association said yesterday that its nationwide survey of service stations found an average price of $1.31 a gallon on Monday for self-service regular unleaded gasoline. That was up 23.5 cents since Aug. 1, the day before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait - still below the 1981 record of $1.388, which adjusted for inflation would be comparable to $2 a gallon today.
Wholesale gasoline for October delivery fell 2.18 cents a gallon, to $1.0205, while heating oil slipped 2.72 cents, to $1.0120.
After the close of trading, the American Petroleum Institute, a trade group, reported that the nation's stocks of gasoline had risen sharply last week, to 222.3 million barrels from 217 million the week before. Supplies of heating oil and diesel fuel also rose. Crude oil stocks fell slightly, but supplies in all three categories were above last year's levels.
Less than 1 percent of the oil consumed each year in the United States is bought or sold on the New York Merc. But because the exchange represents competitive bidding by everyone from producers and refiners to professional traders and small investors, the resulting prices are used as benchmarks for the many private deals in which most of the world's oil changes hands.
 
Price Fluctuations
The cash price for immediate delivery in the United States tends to fluctuate within two to five cents of the nearest Merc contract, although the difference can widen if traders expect market conditions to change greatly before the contract's delivery date, said Peter C. Beutel, an oil price analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., a consulting firm in Hoboken, N.J. And while the Merc contract is for 10 low-density, low-sulfur grades that are easily refined, like West Texas Intermediate, grades that are heavier or more sulfur-laden tend to trade at certain discounts or premiums.
''The Merc is basically the central point of reference for everybody trading West Texas Intermediate, and everybody trading crude oil in the whole country,'' Mr. Beutel said.
Futures trading of the light, low-sulfur Brent blend on the International Petroleum Exchange in London provides the benchmark for trading in Europe, while East Asian futures contracts tend to be based on the heavy, high-sulfur Dubai blend. Trading of Brent and Dubai blends influences trading on the Merc and private deals in the United States.
 
When Prices Were Posted
Until a decade ago, most oil-producing countries posted official prices for their exports and signed long-term supply contracts with oil companies calling for delivery at the price prevailing when the oil was loaded. But this system collapsed when world markets became glutted with oil and producing countries were reluctant to reduce posted prices, quietly undercutting them by striking barter deals with international brokers instead. The brokers then resold the oil for cash to oil companies.
Today, oil-producing countries have generally abandoned posted prices, and have reduced the possible profits for middlemen by selling most oil under long-term supply contracts with oil companies. But the contracts call for the price to be set at the market level when the oil is delivered to the refinery, not when the oil is loaded aboard the tanker, said Theodore R. Eck, the chief economist for the Amoco Corporation in Chicago. The oil-producing country usually owns the oil until the tanker arrives.
As a result, an increase in oil prices on futures markets affects the cost of oil for refineries on the same day or the following day. It then takes five to seven days for the refinery to process the oil and deliver it to service stations and heating oil companies.

HEADLINE: Midmonth Vehicle Sales Decline by 4.7%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Rebates and year-end clearance deals helped sales of cars and light trucks in mid-September, but sales for the period were still 4.7 percent below the unusually strong volume of last year.
Cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.9 million between Sept. 11 and Sept. 20, well above the 7.1 million rate for the first 10 days of the month. But the mid-September volume was below last year's comparable rate of 8.2 million. Through August, cars sold at an annual rate of 6.9 million. 
The sales results for mid-September surprised analysts, but several cautioned that auto makers would have difficulty sustaining them at current levels.
''We expected sales to go sideways instead of up or down,'' said Scott Merlis, an automotive analyst with Morgan Stanley in New York. ''These numbers suggest that the drop in consumer confidence we are seeing in surveys does not spell an immediate collapse of the car and truck market.''
 
'Too Good to Pass Up'
''Even skittish consumers are finding the model year closeout bargains too good to pass up,'' said Tom Webb, an economist with the National Automobile Dealers Association. ''The next test will be harder, though. Will sales survive falling real income levels? I doubt it.''
Philip K. Fricke, an analyst with Prudential-Bache, said ''the next 30 to 60 days will be key in terms of telling where the floor is going to be in the car and light-truck market.''
Analysts offered several theories for the sales results, including the possibility that mid-September sales may have been overstated unintentionally by the formula developed by the Commerce Department to correct for seasonal variations in auto sales activity. The formula renders a seasonally adjusted annual rate by dividing raw sales data by a correction factor, which is based on prior years' sales activity.
''But rebates have not been consistent with the seasons, making seasonal factors kind of suspect,'' Mr. Fricke said.
 
Car Sales Down 1.1%
The 10 companies that manufacture vehicles in the United States sold 209,663 cars between Sept. 11 and Sept. 20, down 1.1 percent from 211,966 cars a year earlier. Light-truck sales, which account for about one-third of vehicle sales, declined 10.6 percent since last year to 115,830 units.
Sales gains were posted by most Japanese car companies, while the Big Three domestic auto makers reported a collective decline of 10.1 percent in sales of cars and light trucks. In cars alone, Japanese auto makers with plants in the United States captured 15.6 percent of the domestic market, compared with 9.8 percent in the comparable period a year earlier.
The Chrysler Corporation continued to post the largest sales declines of any manufacturer. Chrysler's car sales fell 12.1 percent, to 24,700 cars, and light-truck sales dropped 18.5 percent, to 20,172 units.
The General Motors Corporation's car sales fell 6.4 percent in mid-September, to 99,924 cars. G.M.'s light-truck sales dropped 16.3 percent, to 50,969 units.
 
Escort Sales Help Ford
The Ford Motor Company sold 52,255 cars, a decline of 7.3 percent, while Ford's light-truck sales dropped 7.9 percent, to 38,750 units. Ford's car sales were helped by a rise in demand for the Escort subcompact in mid-September.
The No. 2 auto maker's light-truck sales were helped by continuing strong sales of the Explorer four-wheel-drive vehicle. However, sales of the company's popular F-series pickup truck slipped.
The Honda Motor Company sold 13,364 cars manufactured at its plant in Marysville, Ohio, a gain of 21.1 percent over the similar period last year.
The Toyota Motor Corporation's sales of cars made in Georgetown, Ky., more than doubled, to 11,596 cars.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Making Computers a Million Times Faster

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25

 BODY:
In 1983, the International Business Machines Corporation dropped an ambitious project to develop blazingly fast computers using superconducting circuits, concluding that such machines would never be economically feasible. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Sperry Corporation scaled back similar research efforts, and American work virtually halted on superconducting computers, which would operate far faster than today's machines because electrical resistance is eliminated.
Now some researchers are advocating a renewed attempt to develop superconducting computers, inspired by promising discoveries in the last few years.
But as American researchers contemplate entering the field once again, they find themselves well behind the Japanese, who have continued their efforts all along. And again questions are being raised about whether the United States, by not maintaining long-range research, has blown another opportunity. 
''As a result, we have allowed the Japanese to get ahead of us in some of these device areas,'' said Herbert Dwight, president of Superconductor Technologies Inc., a Santa Barbara, Calif., start-up company that develops electronic devices from superconductors.
Superconductors are materials, either metal alloys or ceramics, that lose all resistance to the flow of electricity. That means that microelectronic switches made from superconductors can switch on and off far faster than transistors made from silicon, the usual material for computer chips. In addition, because of the lack of resistance, superconducting circuits can be packed close together, allowing computers to be smaller. Silicon circuits must be far enough apart that machines will not overheat.
The call for a greater effort in superconducting computers is included in a report recently completed by the National Commission on Superconductivity, which Congress established in 1988 to advise the Government on superconductor industrial development. The report said that superconductors might be used to develop computers that would operate a million times faster than today's fastest computers, enabling them to solve scientific problems beyond the ken of today's machines.
 
'Fresh Look' Sought
Another study, sponsored by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, a Pentagon research agency, is also drawing up recommendations for a renewed effort in superconducting electronics.
''I just think we have to take a fresh look at this,'' said Bruce Murdock, senior scientific program manager at Tektronix Inc., a Portland, Ore., electronics company, who is heading the Darpa study.
By proving the basic concepts, the Japanese ''have minimized the risk for us,'' Mr. Murdock said.
Superconductor circuits can outperform circuits made not only with silicon but also with gallium arsenide, a material that is faster than silicon.
The superconductors used by I.B.M. and others until the early 1980's were metal alloys that had to be frozen to near absolute zero, a theoretical point about 460 degrees below zero Fahrenheit where resistance to electricity is lost.
 
New Materials
But in the last few years, new ceramic materials have been discovered that achieve superconductivity at higher temperatures - up to minus 235 degrees Fahrenheit, permitting the use of smaller and less costly cooling systems. That gives rise to a renewed hope that superconductors could be put to more practical uses.
But as work started gearing up in new ''high temperature'' superconductors, interest also began to revive in the older lower-temperature materials.
That is especially true in computer chips. Researchers have found they cannot use the new materials to make superconducting digital switches known as Josephson junctions, which are the superconducting equivalent of silicon transistors.
There is some fear that this problem could stem from fundamental characteristics of the new materials and might never be overcome, said Theodore Van Duzer, professor of electrical engineering and computer science at the University of California at Berkeley.
Instead of using Josephson junctions, researchers are beginning to explore another technique known as flux quantum logic that could allow computer chips to be made with the high-temperature superconductors.
Still, most work for now in superconducting computers is focusing on the low-temperature materials. These materials have also improved a great deal since I.B.M. abandoned its work. New compounds with niobium, which the Japanese have been using, have proved more reliable than the lead alloys I.B.M. was using.
 
Steady Progress in Japan
The Japanese program, backed by Government financing, has involved a handful of researchers at each of three companies - Fujitsu, Hitachi and NEC - as well as at the Government-run Electrotechnical Laboratory. Yet progress has been steady. At a semiconductor industry conference in San Francisco earlier this year, Fujitsu described a signal processor chip it had developed that can perform one billion operations a second, at least 10 times faster than any similar silicon device.
Nevertheless, many contend that superconducting computers will never be practical and that fears about the Japanese progress are unfounded. They argue that silicon chips continue to improve in speed, and thousands of them can now be used in parallel to provide even greater speeds, making it less and less likely that superconducting computers will ever be economically feasible.
I.B.M. officials, for instance, stand by their decision. The company dropped its work not because of the expense of cooling or because of problems with lead-based alloys, officials said, but because silicon technology was advancing so fast as to make it unlikely that superconductors would be competitive.
''We just didn't think it worth it to work on this exotic technology when you can get almost the same performance from one of the most conventional technologies,'' said William J. Gallagher, manager of exploratory cryogenics at I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y.
 
A Key Obstacle
One problem was producing superconducting memory chips with a meaningful capacity, he said, and that obstacle has still not been surmounted. Japan's best superconducting memories still store only 1,000 bits, while silicon memory chips can now store four million bits. And some specialized silicon memory chips are almost as fast as superconducting memory chips.
Others also point out that the Japanese, despite their laboratory progress, do not seem to be moving quickly to develop commercial computers using superconductors.
But supporters of a new push in digital superconductors say the problems in building memory chips can be overcome by combining a small amount of superconductor memory with a larger amount of slower semiconductor memory. Others say that while superconducting electronics might not be appropriate for an entire mainframe computer, which was I.B.M.'s goal, it might be useful in making individual chips that would handle, say, high-speed calculations in a computer, or feed telecommunications signals onto an optical fiber.
The report by the National Commission on Superconductivity said superconducting processors, arranged in parallel, could be used to build a ''petaflops' computer, a machine capable of performing one million billion operations a second.

LENGTH: 776 words

HEADLINE: Dow Climbs 32.67, Reversing a 4-Day Slide;
By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
After four down days that toppled the market 118 points, or close to 5 percent, stocks headed up yesterday as traders and investors opened the spigot. Program traders helped spark the rally, but many expect the rise to be short-lived.
By the end of the session, the Dow Jones industrial average had jumped 32.67 points, to 2,485.64.
 
Big Lift From MCA
Many said that MCA, the media giant, gave the market a big lift, also helping other media and leisure stocks. Matsushita, the Japanese electronics giant, said it was holding merger talks with MCA although the Los Angeles-based company said there was no assurance anything would come of it. 
The market seemed willing to believe something would happen. MCA soared $19.50 a share, to $54, with 3.7 million shares trading. It was the most active stock on the Big Board, and if the deal actually happens, it will be the first really big one the market has seen in a long time, possibly involving as much as $7.5 billion.
Even so, one trader said: ''Everybody wants to sell and nobody wants to buy. The fact that somebody wants to put money into our stock market helped a lot, psychologically.''
''The market got itself into a slightly oversold condition,'' said Kenneth P. Ducey, senior vice president in the trading department of S. G. Warburg & Company, ''and some of the selling seems to be exhausted.''
 
'We've Gone Down So Much'
''We're bound to have a rally,'' said Greg A. Smith, chief investment officer for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., ''simply because we've gone down so much. But I don't think it'll last very long or go very far.''
The traders contended that the rally could be brief because most buying came from short-term traders rather than long-term investors. Many sought bargains among the hundreds of depressed stocks or rushed to buy back stock they had sold short in expectation of buying it back later for less.
As a result, the rise in the Dow, while a big relief, was small in light of recent losses. Advancing issues only narrowly outstripped declining ones, 770 to 745, and while 5 stocks set new highs, 314 hit new lows. With many investors on the sidelines with an enormous bundle of cash, trading fell to 155.9 million shares, from 162.2 million on Monday.
Although oil prices dropped slightly, among the few stocks reaching new highs was Louisiana Land, the oil and gas company. Among the many hitting new lows were J. P. Morgan, Sears, Roebuck, Sony and UAL. Among the issues advancing on short covering were Fannie Mae and Disney.
Fannie Mae, which packages and resells mortgages, rose 1 3/8 in heavy trading, to 27 5/8. Disney rose 1 5/8, to 90 1/8, in sympathy with another media company, MCA. Paramount and Time Warner jumped for the same reason, with Paramount climbing 3 1/4, to 34 7/8, and Time Warner 1 1/4, to 70 7/8.
 
Another New High
Louisiana Land, which hit a new high on Monday, reached another yesterday, of 53 5/8, but it ended at 52 7/8, down 3/8. Morgan fell to a new low of 30 5/8 before closing at 31 1/4, up 1/8. Sears fell to a new low, 26, before ending at 26 1/2, up 3/8. Sony, another Japanese electronics giant, hit a new low of 45 3/4 before closing at 46 5/8, up 1/8. UAL hit a new low of 87 1/4 and ended at 89, down 3 1/4, as sentiment mounted that a union buyout seemed to have faltered.
About the only people who seem to be constantly in the market on one side or the other were the program traders, working the percentages between, say, the price of the Standard & Poor's average of 500 issues and of the 500 stocks themselves. Birinyi Associates, which tracks such activity, said that one selling wave and five buying waves throughout the session raised the Dow 20 points.
 
Jumps 10 Points at Opening
The Dow jumped 10 points at the beginning of yesterday's session, quickly fell 14, then steadily climbed the rest of the day.
''People are starting to live with the Middle East crisis,'' said Mr. Ducey of S. G. Warburg. ''But if the market goes up any further, it'll run into resistance and the selling will start again.''
Mr. Smith of Prudential-Bache argued that the rise might not last ''more than a week or so or more than 50 or 100 points.'' He said that still to be dealt with were the Federal budget deficit and ''more bad news on inflation.''
As shown in the averages, the gain seemed most pronounced among the big stocks. The S. & P. 500 rose 1.2 percent, to 304.59, up 3.67 points. In the smaller stocks, the American Stock Exchange's market-value index rose a tenth of 1 percent, to 312.84, up 0.33 point. The Nasdaq composite rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 352.16, up 2.62 points.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates eased yesterday, as a surprisingly large reduction in the Government's reading of second-quarter economic growth and a decline in oil prices outweighed other factors that could have sent prices lower.
The drop in the Commerce Department's second-quarter growth figures - to four-tenths of 1 percent from 1.2 percent previously -showed that the economy was on the brink of recession even before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, private analysts said.
''We have had a year of growth that was not really growth, with profitability under strain,'' said Neil M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. ''Now we face what probably will be a long but rather shallow recession.'' 
Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J. research firm, said: ''The G.N.P. number told me that the worst still lies ahead as far as the economy is concerned. In looking at the data, it is extremely difficult to find any sources of growth.''
 
Comments Erase Gains
The report on the gross national product pushed up prices early, but some of those gains were erased later when comments by a Federal Reserve Board governor, Wayne Angell, flashed across trading screens.
Mr. Angell said that in spite of the lower growth figures, he saw no reason for the Fed to ease interest rates soon.
In a speech to a farmers group in Orlando, Fla., Mr. Angell said that ''attempting through an easing of policy to somehow avoid or postpone the implied real adjustments of the oil shock would only serve to undermine the credibility of policy and lead to potentially more severe adjustments over the longer run.''
A strong auto sales report, which showed that auto makers sold at an annual rate of 7.8 million units in the middle 10 days of September, also came as a negative surprise.
In addition to the drop in oil prices and the downward revision of second-quarter gross national product, traders said the market was buttressed by a successful auction of $11.5 billion worth of two-year Treasury notes.
The notes were sold at an average yield of 8.18 percent, virtually unchanged from the 8.19 percent average yield at the last two-year note sale on Aug. 28. 4-Year Notes at 8.52% In advance of today's auction of four-year notes, the securities were offered late yesterday on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.52 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds due in 2020 were offered at a price of 96 1/8 late yesterday, up 13/32, to yield 9.12 percent. That compared with a yield of 9.16 percent on Monday.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 98 14/32, up 7/32, to yield 8.98 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 13/32, up 2/32, to yield 8.63 percent.
Mr. Angell's comments helped push up short-term Treasury bill rates, which are usually very sensitive to changes in Federal Reserve policy.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.35 percent, up 4 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by 7 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.39 percent.
 
Finance Companies
In the secondary market for corporate bonds, traders said that worries over outstanding commercial bank obligations were spreading.
''People are worried about all finance company paper, not just the banks,'' one corporate bond trader said. ''This is like the Salem witch hunt. People are looking for something to worry about, and I think it will continue.''
In addition to securities issued by major commercial banks like Citibank, whose bonds dropped sharply again yesterday, traders said that bonds of companies like the General Motors Assistance Corporation and the Marriott Corporation were also hammered.
Away from the financial sector, prices of most corporate bonds dipped by 1/2 point to 3/4 point.
Among the new issues priced yesterday was a two-part, $400 million offering from the Coastal Corporation.
The first $250 million piece consists of 10 3/8 percent 10-year notes. The notes were priced at $99.875, to yield 10.395 percent, 1.375 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $150 million worth of securities are 10 3/4 percent 20-year bonds.
These securities were priced at $99.59, to yield 10.80 percent, 1.65 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020.
Lehman Brothers acted as sole manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB-by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar and Yen Show Gains; German Comments a Factor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced in the United States yesterday against all major currencies except the Japanese yen, which took center stage on world foreign exchange markets.
Gold prices declined slightly in domestic trading but moved sharply higher abroad.
Strength in the dollar came largely as a reaction to a selloff Monday against every major currency but the yen. A rebound on Wall Street, combined with a steadying in oil and gold prices in New York, also renewed interest in dollars. 
Comments by an unidentified West German Finance Ministry official, carried by news services, contributed to the purchases of yen, which dealers have tended to dump in favor of European currencies lately because of concern about the impact of rising oil prices on the Japanese economy, which depends heavily on imported oil.
In an interview with reporters, the German official said the yen could appreciate further against the mark. He also said that he did not foresee a ''free fall'' in the dollar, a statement that tended to increase the demand for dollars.
The dollar's trading day began in Tokyo with a decline to 136.70 yen from 137.33 at Friday's close. Japanese markets were closed Monday for a national holiday. Later, the dollar was quoted at 136.50 yen in London and at 136.70 late in New York, down from 137.50 late Monday.
The British pound lost ground, falling to $1.8765 late in London from late Monday's $1.8810. A pound was quoted at $1.8785 late in New York, down from $1.8805 late Monday.
Against the German mark, the dollar was trading late yesterday at 1.5735, up from 1.5595 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, were: 1.3080 Swiss francs, up from 1.2980; 5.2665 French francs, up from 5.2210; 1.15055 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14975, and 1,177.00 Italian lire, up from 1,167.75.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Nearly Steady; Other Precious Metals Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices held nearly steady yesterday, despite a drop in energy prices and similar reversals in other markets that usually are regarded as signposts for the precious metals.
Silver and platinum futures fell sharply, though, lending support to the growing perception that gold is losing its traditional appeal as a store of value in times of rising consumer prices and international political turmoil.
Gold futures settled 50 cents to 70 cents lower on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in September off 60 cents at $402.40 an ounce. 
Silver futures ended 8 cents to 8.8 cents lower, with September at $4.834 an ounce.
Platinum futures fell $7.70 to $8.90, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where the contract for September delivery finished at $451 an ounce.
Analysts had no problem explaining the declines in silver and platinum as reactions to the Government's report that the economy grew at a barely perceptible annual rate of four-tenths of a percent in the second quarter.
The white metals are used in a variety of manufactured products, so the report of unexpectedly slow growth led to expectations for reduced silver and platinum consumption, said Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
Harder to assess was gold's relatively strong performance in light of sharply lower oil prices, sharply higher stock prices and a stronger dollar against European currencies - all reversals of the factors that were viewed as contributing to gold's strong advance on Monday.
John Jonat, a precious metal trader with the New York-based metal and currency dealer Deak International Inc., said gold's stubbornness was further evidence of a change in investor attitudes toward the metal.
But he and others were at a loss to define what Mr. Jonat called a new school of thought about gold. Some believe investors are turning to other markets as havens against inflation. Some concede they just don't know. ''It's a real confusing market to call,'' Mr. Jonat said. ''Something's changing here - it's not the same old rules.''

HEADLINE: TALKS ON BUDGET TURN TO INDEXING OF CAPITAL GAINS

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept 26

 BODY:
Under pressure from moderate Republicans in Congress, White House budget negotiators today signaled a willingness to drop their demand for an actual cut in the capital gains tax rate and instead accept a plan that would index capital gains for inflation.
The plan is a variation on President Bush's demand for cutting taxes on the profits on investments. It would allow investors who sell assets to exclude from their income taxes the portion of their profits solely attributable to inflation.
''Indexing is becoming their new bottom line,'' said a Democratic official who spoke on condition of anonymity. But he added that Democrats still viewed this arrangement as one that would primarily benefit upper-income taxpayers, and said the tax break would have to be offset by higher taxes on the wealthy. 
 
Unlocking the Impasse
Nonetheless, negotiators from both parties said that they remained optimistic and that there had been more movement in the talks over the last two days than there had been in weeks.
Some political strategists see the indexing proposal, or some derivative of it, as a way to unlock the budget impasse. Indexing capital gains could allow the President to say he had lowered taxes, but in a somewhat watered-down form that could also permit the Democrats to say they had prevented a disproportionately large windfall for the very rich.
Despite this shift and signs of progress on other issues in the budget negotiations, Mr. Bush and the Democrats intensified their public posturing over who is responsible for blocking agreement on a budget deal and who should get the blame if automatic spending cuts take effect as scheduled on Monday.
 
Bush Sticks to His Plan
Even as White House budget negotiators were signaling a shift on capital gains in their private meetings with Congressional negotiators, Mr. Bush continued publicly to stick to his original plan for an outright cut in the capital gains rate. Campaigning for Republican candidates in Akron, Ohio, he threatened to stump all 50 states to argue that his proposal to cut the capital gains rate was not the real sticking point.
The real problem, he told reporters while flying to Ohio, is recalcitrant Democrats who ''have not come forward with a package'' even after the White House took ''political heat'' for agreeing to consider new taxes.
''And if and when the ax falls, the Democratic Congress knows that it will be held accountable,'' the President said in Akron. ''I will take that message to every state in the Union. It is their fault for holding up a budget agreement.''
Furious Democratic leaders, noting that they had exchanged a series of budget offers with Administration negotiators over the last 24 hours, quickly moved to counter Mr. Bush's charges and hurl some of their own.
''He should get off Air Force One and the campaign trail and join us,'' said Representative William H. Gray 3d of Pennsylvania, the House Democratic whip. ''We ask him to stop acting like a party chairman and start acting like a President.''
The House Speaker, Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, called Mr. Bush's comments ''damaging to the negotiating process and not helpful to the result.'' But he was particularly critical of the President for ''the suggestion that he is somehow waiting on the outside for other people to reach an agreement.''
''He is a party to the negotiations,'' Mr. Foley said. In a later speech in Chicago, Mr. Bush apologized for saying the Democrats had not come forward with a budget package. ''I accept the fact that in private negotiations there have been such proposals,'' he said.
But he said Administration officials had ''yet to see a comprehensive plan'' that encompased spending cuts, changes in the budget process and incentives for economic growth.
 
How the Talks Are Divided
The spectacle of Mr. Bush attacking the Democrats while his Treasury Secretary, budget director and chief of staff huddled with them over the bargaining table illustrated that the most important division in the budget battle was not between Democrats and Republicans, but between the White House and Congress. And even as the political charges were flying, Congressional leaders and the White House officials seemed to be edging closer to a final compromise.
The high-level talks in the Capitol are expected to continue late into the night, but if no agreement is reached Democrats will have to decide whether to proceed with a House vote Thursday on a stop-gap spending measure that would keep the Government running after Sept. 30 and delay the automatic cuts that would take effect on Oct. 1.
Democrats are also considering an alternative strategy to push their own budget plan through Congress. All proposals under consideration in the talks aim to cut $50 billion from the deficit in 1991 and $500 billion over five years.
The plan that party strategists say the Democrats contemplate would return to a position they held before the latest narrowing of differences. It would closely resemble an offer they made last week, and cut more from military spending, less from domestic programs and raise more in new taxes than Republicans would accept.
 
Differences Are Narrowed
According to officials close to the budget talks, the negotiators substantially narrowed their differences on spending cuts in military and domestic programs in a nine-hour session that ended early today. Still at issue are the components of the tax portion of the package, intended to raise about $130 billion in new revenue over the next five years.
Besides the issue of capital gains taxes, Republicans want the package to include extension of a number of popular tax breaks scheduled to expire at the end of this year. While the tax breaks have support in both parties, the money they would cost the Treasury would have to be offset with deeper spending cuts or other tax increases.
Democrats, mindful that a cut in the capital gains tax rate enjoys strong support among some factions in their own party, have floated their proposal for a narrowly defined version of the cut aimed at promoting long-term investment in small, high-risk businesses. Officials familiar with the proposal say it would provide a capital gains tax break only for future investments, thus reducing the revenue loss to the Treasury.
 
Focus on Automatic Cuts
For lawmakers not directly involved in the negotiations, the threat of automatic spending cuts starting on Monday, initially totaling some $85 billion, remained the main focus of concern.
In the Senate, lawmakers voted to include their own salaries and those of top officials in the executive branch, including Vice President Dan Quayle, in the automatic cuts from which they would otherwise be exempt.
In the House, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, said he would introduce legislation giving the President authority to exempt essential services involving public health or safety from the automatic cuts.
Mr. Gingrich insisted that his legislation did not amount to abandonment of the spending discipline required by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law. ''This action will make Gramm-Rudman manageable so the American people will not have to suffer because of the incompetence of Washington politicians,'' he said.

HEADLINE: SOVIETS' WARNING TO IRAQIS ON WAR PRAISED BY WEST

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other Western diplomats praised the Soviet Union today for its warning to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that a war in the Persian Gulf may be imminent if he does not pull out of Kuwait.
The Western officials said in separate conversations that the speech at the United Nations General Assembly by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on Tuesday marked a significant shift in Kremlin policy.
Only two weeks after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, at a news conference after meeting in Helsinki with President Bush, stated his categoric opposition to any use of force, his Foreign Minister surprised a United Nations audience not used to such surprises by suggesting that if the boycott failed to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait, Moscow would not shrink from supporting a military operation sanctioned by the United Nations. 
 
Loss of Help From West Feared
Interpreting the speech, a top Administration analyst of Soviet affairs said: ''Shevardnadze was telling the Iraqis something more than just 'don't count on us to veto a use of force at the United Nations.' He was saying, 'You'd better count on us to support, and maybe even participate in, such an effort by the United Nations.' I think the Soviets may have concluded that the indirect pressure of the embargo is running its course, and when it finally grinds to a halt, they don't intend to be the odd men out.''
On the Soviet warning to President Hussein, analysts of Soviet affairs say they believe Moscow decided to sharpen the tone of the military threat because of two other concerns, as well. First, the Soviets are clearly worried that the longer this crisis drags on, the more damage will be inflicted on Western economies and the less they can be expected to help Mr. Gorbachev's economic efforts.
 
Anxious About U.S. Buildup
Second, the Soviet military is clearly anxious about the buildup of American forces 800 miles from the southern Soviet borders. When concern is already high about Soviet vulnerability in Europe, the massing of American troops, armor, missiles and other advanced weapons in the gulf is something that cannot be ignored by Soviet military planners.
Mr. Shevardnadze said that while diplomacy had to be given every chance to work, ''War may break out in the gulf region any day, any moment.''
He added: ''In the context of recent events we should remind those who regard aggression as an acceptable form of behavior that the United Nations has the power to 'suppress acts of aggression.' There is ample evidence that this right can be exercised. It will be, if the illegal occupation of Kuwait continues.''
Mr. Baker began his meeting today with Mr. Shevardnadze by praising his speech. From the start of the gulf crisis, American officials have feared that there was a potentially serious contradiction between their efforts to assemble an international consensus to isolate Iraq diplomatically and their desire to keep the military option open. Finding partners for an embargo of Iraq was one thing, and finding partners for a shooting war quite another.
 
Concern of Administration
The Administration's concern was that the fragile international coalition would break apart - beginning at its Soviet-American core - the minute it was concluded that a boycott would not move Baghdad and that therefore the only option was war. What Mr. Shevardnadze's speech at the United Nations on Tuesday suggests, officials said, is that it may actually be possible to maintain a large degree of American-Soviet consensus if a resort to arms is deemed necessary.
 
Bluntness of the Message
But American officials also calculate that either as a result of a Chinese veto, or Soviet reluctance to commit troops abroad in the wake of their Afghanistan debacle or some other complication, the Security Council may find it difficult to actually agree on a military operation. In the event of such a deadlock, and depending on the actions of the Iraqis, Administration officials increasingly think that the Soviets may be ready to quietly acquiesce in an American-led operation.
''The speech says to me that the Soviets feel that this guy, Saddam, has to be brought to heel,'' said an Administration official. ''At worst, I think the Soviets would mildly criticize our use of force outside the U.N., if it becomes clear that diplomacy cannot work.''
A senior British diplomat also found the Soviet policy a significant change that can only result in additional pressure on Mr. Hussein. The Iraqis have already attacked the Soviet Union for Mr. Shevardnadze's speech.
By being so blunt, said Ghassan Salameh, a Middle East expert at the University of Paris, ''Shevardnadze was telling Saddam: 'Don't have any illusions that I will mediate some compromise for you. Shevardnadze's comments remind me of an old Palestinian proverb: 'I will cry and then walk away.' When war comes, he told Saddam: 'I will cry for you and then walk away, so you better withdraw before it is too late.' ''
 
Evolution in Attitudes
Traditionally, the Soviets have understood the relationship between force and diplomacy much better than the United States, argued Martin Indyk, director of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. President Hussein is only going to be persuaded to leave Kuwait, argued Mr. Indyk, ''if he is convinced that the alternative is a war which he will lose.''
There has been a steady evolution in Soviet attitudes toward the use of military force in the gulf, with the idea becoming more conceivable with each passing week. In the joint American-Soviet statement issued on Aug. 3, immediately after the Iraqi invasion, the Soviets resisted American appeals for a reference to a possible use of force if Iraq does not pull out of Kuwait.
At the Helsinki summit on Sept. 9, the Soviets agreed to a final communique that said if the economic sanctions did not work ''additional steps'' would have to be considered. But during the news conference after the meeting, Mr. Gorbachev strongly affirmed that it was too early to discuss a military option and that diplomacy had to be given a real chance to succeed.
 
Coordination Stressed
In his address to the United Nations yesterday, Mr. Shevardnadze apparently decided that it was time to let the Iraqis know that an internationally sanctioned military operation was now a real live possibility.
A senior State Department official said that in the four-hour meeting between Mr. Shevardnadze and Mr. Baker today, the Soviet Foreign Minister emphasized to the Secretary of State the need for their two countries to continue closely coordinating on the gulf and, at the same time, to make sure that they are steadily increasing the pressure on Mr. Hussein. Mr. Shevardnadze said it was important that the Iraqi leader see a clear trend mounting against him.
Besides the Persian Gulf, Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze discussed the remaining obstacles to a conventional-arms-reduction treaty in Europe and a United States-Soviet treaty limiting long-range nuclear weapons.
A senior State Department official said that the two Cabinet ministers exchanged some new ideas, but that there was still no breakthrough. Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze are planning another meeting on Thursday.
