From the left were Douglas Hurd of Britain, Roland Dumas of France, Gianni de Michelis of Italy and Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany. (Reuters) (pg. A11)

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans Sale Of Reserve's Oil To Lower Prices

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Complaining that there is ''no justification'' for the recent run-up in oil prices, President Bush announced last night that the United States would sell five million barrels from its Strategic Petroleum Reserve as a test.
The sale is a token amount in the oil market and will have little effect on total supplies since the United States imports that much oil every 18 hours. But after weeks of speculation in the industry and among economists about whether the reserve would be used, industry experts said last night that the announcement would be, in effect, a warning that market participants who are tempted to pay high prices for oil could end up holding barrels that could soon decline in value.
 
Hint of Further Sales
Indeed, President Bush hinted that if prices did not stabilize, he would consider larger sales from the reserve, presumably in a coordinated effort with America's industrial partners that also hold oil reserves. 
''I'm prepared to take additional steps, if necessary, to insure that America stays strong here at home,'' President Bush said in a speech at a fund-raising dinner last night for a Senate candidate from Illinois.
The Administration's decision to tap the oil reserve seems to have been motivated as much by politics as by economics. The sharp rise in oil prices during the late 1970's, political analysts note, damaged not only the American economy but also the Presidency of Jimmy Carter and the Administration seems eager to avoid a similar oil-related political setback, if possible.
Commenting on the recent advance in oil prices, a senior White House official said last night, ''From a political point of view, as well as an economic standpoint, we cannot let this go on.''
Earlier in the day, more than three dozen Republican and Democratic members of the House of Representatives urged the President to begin tapping the reserve. Citing the price climb, they said that ''it was for just such circumstances that the Strategic Petroleum Reserve was created.''
 
Coordination Urged
The lawmakers urged that the United States coordinate the releases with Japan and West Germany, which have almost 400 million barrels in their stockpiles. ''Just as our military efforts require equitable burden sharing, so do our economic efforts to reduce the impact from the loss of oil,'' they said in a letter.
The signers included Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Misssouri and the House majority leader; William H. Gray, Democrat of Pennsylvania and the Democratic whip; John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, and Norman F. Lent of Long Island, the ranking Republican on the Energy and Commerce panel.
The price of oil has approached $40 in recent days, more than double the level at the beginning of the summer, putting increasing pressure on the President to tap the 590-million-barrel reserve, which is in salt caverns along the Texas and Louisiana coasts, and was assembled over 15 years at a cost of about $16 billion. It is designed to deliver oil at rates of up to 3.5 million barrels a day.
 
Net Loss of 1.7 Million
In contrast, the embargo against oil from Iraq and Kuwait cut world supplies by about 4.3 million barrels. The Department of Energy said yesterday that because other oil-producing nations had increased their pumping, the net loss was now about 1.7 million barrels a day, and could shrink to one million barrels a day by November.
The current global shortfall could be met by the reserve for more than 400 days, and if the global deficit fell to one million barrels a day, the reserve could make up the difference for nearly two years.
But prices are at their highest levels since 1980, and in his remarks at the fund-raising dinner, Mr. Bush said there was ''no justification for the intensive and unwarranted speculation in oil futures.'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said that recent price rises ''cannot be explained by market forces.''
The announcement, which was made after the close of futures trading yesterday, caused a price drop last night in the spot, or cash, market for oil sold for immediate delivery and is likely to depress the oil market at least briefly.
At Cargill Investor Services, Arnold G. Stifel, a broker, said, ''We could back off a dollar, maybe $2 or $3. But that is not a whole lot, considering that we move so much daily. This market is so scared that these prices are going to hold.''
Daniel C. Yergin of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, said, ''This is more like a test drive, to demonstrate that it works.'' Mr. Yergin, the author of a major report on the reserve for the Council on Foreign Relations earlier this year, said in a telephone interview last night that ''there has been a lot of skepticism about how it will work physically, and in market terms.''
 
Different From Imported Oil
The oil differs in some physical characteristics from the kind of oil that the United States imports.
Mr. Yergin added, ''You don't want to do a test drive when everybody's in a total panic, and have something not go right.''
Some traders reached last night were skeptical that the test would have much value. ''I wouldn't expect it to have a big impact - I still think it's a fear market, not a supply and demand market,'' said Michael Wilner, the president of the Hilltop Trading Company in New York. The sale, he added, could ''get lost in the bigger picture.''
Driving the market in the last few weeks, according to experts, is a desire by everyone who uses oil to increase inventories well above normal levels, as a hedge against future shortages. Pushing demand up at a time when supply is down, the result has been sharply higher prices.
 
Expected to Happen
Another broker, Andrew B. Shasha of Star Supply Inc. in Englewood, N.J., said that ''the sentiment has been that it was expected to happen.''
But the White House is clearly hoping that the prospect of large new supplies hitting the market will depress oil prices, which are a big factor in the economy, and the economy is already weak. Figures released by the Commerce Department on Tuesday indicated that the United States was very close to a recession in the second quarter, before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the subsequent convulsions in the oil market.
In his remarks last night at the dinner for Representative Lynn Martin, the Illinois Republican candidate for the Senate, Mr. Bush said: ''Today, it's especially important that America is economically healthy and militarily strong. At home and abroad, let me caution those who might take advantage of the current crisis in the Persian Gulf, those who might seek profit by subverting the sanctions or, here at home, those speculators who might try to drive up the price of oil.''

HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA TO GET TOUGHER AIR RULES

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26

 BODY:
California, which has long had the nation's toughest air-quality rules, is on the verge of approving an even stricter set of regulations intended to create a new generation of less-polluting fuels and vehicles, including electric cars.
The plan, which is expected to be approved Friday by the California Air Resources Board, would have an immense impact on the types of cars and fuels sold in California, the nation's biggest and most influential car market. As they have in the past, the rules adopted in California could serve as models for other states and for Federal clean air legislation.
 
Changes Will Add to Cost
''It's the most far-reaching set of emissions regulations the state of California has ever proposed,'' said Joseph Calhoun, the assistant director of the emissions control program at the General Motors Corporation. G.M. and other auto manufacturers say they are concerned that the new standards and the timetable for meeting them may be technologically unrealistic. 
Consumers would eventually pay for the technology required by the new rules, as it is certain to add to the cost of cars, although no one could say how much.
Under the rules, automobile manufacturers will have to begin introducing models starting in 1994 that emit no more than half the hydrocarbons allowed for 1993 models under current California regulations, which are already the nation's strictest. Hydrocarbons are a primary component of smog.
The regulations would require that by 1998, two percent of all the automobiles sold in the state would have to have zero emissions, meaning the sale of electric cars. By 2003, 10 percent of all cars sold in the state would have to have zero emissions, and most of the rest would have to meet emission standards 70 percent below the 1993 level.
For the first time, the rules would also set standards for less-polluting gasoline as part of an effort to insure that there are cleaner-burning fuels available for the more advanced automobiles the plan requires.
 
Reduction by 50 to 80%
The ultimate goal of the plan is to reduce pollution from automobiles by 50 to 84 percent.
''Our program has historically set the pace for the country and created the technology that has made reducing emissions feasible, said Bill Sessa, a spokesman for the Air Resources Board, which has drawn up up the regulations. ''This proposal lays the groundwork for a whole new generation of cars and technology.''
The air resources board is an agency comprised of nine appointed officials with jurisdiction over all air-quality regulation in California. The panel's actions do not require legislative approval and there is no process by which opponents can appeal the board's regulations, although they could challenge them in court. Since the board was formed in 1968, none of its rules have been challenged in court.
The board has long enacted stricter rules than the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, and the rules now being considered would go further than clean air legislation now before Congress. The board will hold two final days of public hearings on the plan in Los Angeles on Thursday and Friday, with the formal approval expected on Friday. Mr. Sessa said the board did not expect to make any substantive changes.
Environmentalists said they generally supported the plan, although they said the board was moving too slowly in some respects.
''We absolutely agree that there's no way to meet clean air standards without introducing clean vehicles in significant numbers,'' said Lynne T. Edgerton, a senior attorney with the Natural Resources Defense Council in Los Angeles. ''Having said that, we think the plan for phasing in the low-emissions vehicles and the zero-emissions vehicles is too slow.''
 
Board Consulted Industry
The board has consulted closely with the automobile industry and the oil industry in developing the rules. The oil companies have expressed reservations about some elements of the plan, although they support its basic thrust. The car companies, however, say they are concerned that the plan requires emissions improvements based on technology that does not yet exist, and that the timetable it sets may be unrealistic.
''The plan is asking the industry to take on responsibility that it is not in any shape to fulfill at this point,'' said Marcel Halberstadt, the director of the environmental department at the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association in Detroit, a trade group.
Mr. Calhoun of General Motors said that if the proposals are adopted, ''Obviously G.M. will try to meet them.'' He said the company would like the plan to be modified to allow reviews of the technological progress being made by industry, and to permit a postponement of the timetable if it is warranted.
''We may start down the wrong road with a technology and realize that and head in another direction,'' Mr. Calhoun said. He said it was impossible to say what effect the regulations would have on retail car prices, but that ''if new technology has to be developed it's going to be costly.''
The new regulations come at a time when Californians and others are starting to question whether stricter environmental controls are worth the economic price they impose, especially as the national economy seems to be headed into a recession. Economic concerns have been one factor in the reduced public support in California for an initiative on the November ballot that would impose a host of new environmental restrictions.
 
Tension Between Industries
There is also some tension between oil companies and the car makers over the plan. The oil companies would prefer that gasoline remain the primary fuel for automobiles, and they are investing heavily in research into cleaner-burning gasolines. The auto companies, however, have some incentives under Federal legislation to develop vehicles capable of running on a methanol-based fuel.
Methanol is made most often from natural gas, and a widespread shift to the use of methanol as an alternative fuel would require huge investments by the oil companies in new refining equipment and additional natural gas pipelines. A methanol-based fuel is also likely to be more expensive at the pump than a reformulated conventional gasoline, said George Babikian, the president of ARCO's refining division. Mr. Babikian and other oil industry executives are pushing for development of cleaner-burning gasolines that would work in conjunction with improved catalytic converters in vehicles to reduce emissions.
California's plan has already prompted the oil companies and the auto makers to begin cooperating and coordinating to a much greater degree than ever. The two industries have jointly financed a $15 million research project exploring how best to match improvements in fuels and engine technology to reduce emissions.

SECTION: Section A; Page 8, Column 5; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: THE REJOINING OF GERMANY - EUROPEAN VOICES;
Finding a New Weak Link

BYLINE: By Martin Gilbert/British Historian: MARTIN GILBERT, 53, a British historian, wrote two volumes of the official biography of Churchill. Among his other books are ''Final Journey: The Fate of the Jews of Nazi Europe,'' and ''Auschwitz and the Allies.''

 BODY:
I always thought the division of Germany after 1945 was unnatural. The wartime allies, at Teheran and Yalta, were clearly thinking of Germany as a whole, even while demilitarizing and deindustrializing it to make sure that it could not start another war. In a sense, what is happening on Oct. 3 is what might have happened shortly after the war, if the United States and the Soviet Union had not been at odds. 
I was always taught to look for the weak link in the chain, the cause of potential trouble in the apparently stable order of things. As it looks now, potential trouble lies not in a united Germany, but in a disintegrating Soviet Union. The phase of history that is opening with the unification of Germany is, in a sense, the reversal of processes that began in 1918 with the overly severe Versailles Treaty terms against Germany.
One must assume and hope that for most Germans, Germany will be complete once its two parts are united; that it will have no more unresolved territorial claims. The problem in the future will not then be the eastern border of Germany, it will be the western border of Russia. The issues to be resolved are not those between Germans and their eastern neighbors; they are between Russians and Ukrainians, Poles, Hungarians, Lithuanians, and their other western neighbors, and they stem from the way Stalin created the western border of the Soviet Union in 1940.
In the next decade, a united Germany could be a lifesaver, a source of economic strength and political stability for all the countries of central Europe, and it could continue to be the driving force for the unification of Europe.
Now that the Germans have acknowledged and paid for their war crimes, they can put behind them the last great question from their past. But the Russians are still agonizing over their past, and living uncomfortably through its still-emerging consequences. The questions the Russians are asking are things like, ''Father, what were you doing during Katyn?'' And, ''Uncle, how can we justify and legitimize the annexation of the Baltic states, of East Prussia, and the Polish-Russian border?''

CORRECTION-DATE: October 3, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a biographical note on Thursday, with a symposium of commentaries about German reunification, referred incorrectly to some works of Martin Gilbert, a British historian. He wrote six volumes of a biography of Churchill, not two.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Newest Tanks Are Included In U.S. Arms Sale to Saudis

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
President Bush, in the first phase of a planned $21 billion arms sale to Saudi Arabia, has decided to include the most modern M-1 tanks and other sophisticated weapons worth $7.5 billion as an immediate response to the Iraqi threat, Administration officials said today.
The officials said Congress was being notified this evening of the proposed sale, which they said would include M1-A2 tanks, Patriot anti-aircraft missiles, Bradley fighting vehicles, multiple launch rocket systems and Apache helicopters.
The Administration will seek Congressional approval for an additional $14 billion worth of arms in January, including F-15 fighters.
Though the Bush Administration bowed to Congressional pressure by deferring the biggest part of the sale until next year, Mr. Bush's decision was debated on Capitol Hill. One Congressional staff member said the proposed sale was generally ''in keeping with the consultation process'' and reflected the will of lawmakers to limit the initial sale to immediate Saudi defense needs, with the exception of the proposed sale of M1-A2 tanks. 
 
Question of Immediate Need
The reported inclusion of M1-A2 tanks in the first phase drew particular criticism from some lawmakers. They said that, because production of the M1-A2 tank is not scheduled to start until November 1992, it would not be used for immediate Saudi needs. But one Congressional staffer suggested that production could be accelerated.
The proposed sale includes about 150 M1-A2 tanks, 6 Patriot antimissile batteries, 200 Bradley fighting vehicles, about 150 TOW-2A antitank missiles, about 10 Apache helicopters and less than a dozen launchers for the Multiple Launch Rocket System. These launchers would be equipped with more than a thousand missiles.
Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, the majority whip, has said he was particularly concerned about the proposed sale of sophisticated weapons, like the M1-A2 tank.
Other lawmakers who have been supportive of Israel said that they thought an understanding had been reached with the Administration to provide items in the first part of the sale that would meet Saudi Arabia's immediate needs while postponing until next year consideration of other, longer-term items that were likely to cause more debate. But some lawmakers said the nature of some of the weapons the Administration is now proposing to sell shows that such an understanding has not been reached.
''They certainly gave us the impression when they decided to divide the sale that they were doing it as a result of our concerns and were trying to meet our concerns,'' said Mel Levine, a California Democrat.
''If they can make a convincing case that the items are needed immediately they will not face opposition,'' Mr. Levine said. ''I would still be concerned if it appears that they are continuing to use this crisis as a fig leaf for racing through the process items that do not meet that criteria,'' Mr. Levine said.
 
'Disappointed,' He Says
Earlier today, based on preliminary reports of the planned sale, Representative Larry Smith, a Florida Democrat, said, ''I am disappointed that what they have put in this package does not accord with my understanding of what would be done in the short term and the long term.''
A Bush Administration spokesman declined to comment on the sale, saying that he could not discuss the proposal until formal notification was transmitted by the White House.
Other Bush Administration officials who defended the sale said that only a limited number of the sophisticated ground weapons would be sold in the first phase.
One senior Administration official said the sale of M1-A2 tanks was a ''necessary complement'' to the items that needed to be delivered immediately to take care of Saudi Arabia's defense needs. He suggested that the order for the tanks needed to be made soon to keep to a schedule for delivering the tanks years from now.
 
New Saudi Transfers
The proposed sale came as the Pentagon was considering a new step to improve the military abilities of the United States forces in Saudi Arabia.
Maj. Peter Keating, an Army spokesman, said the Pentagon was considering the transfer of M1-A1 tanks from Western Europe to American Army units in Saudi Arabia. The American units being sent to Saudi Arabia only have a small number of this model of M-1A1 tanks, currently the most modern version of the M-1 tank in the Army arsenal and the shipment of the M-1A1 tanks would beef up the Army's capabilities there.
The M1-A1 tank has the 120-millimeter gun, a bigger gun than the M-1 model and better protection against chemical weapons. The Pentagon's consideration of the new tank deployment was disclosed in The Washington Times today.
Regarding the air embargo voted by the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the United States does not plan to use military force to enforce the new sanction.
''We've not been given any such instructions and I don't expect that we would be,'' Mr. Cheney told a meeting of the National Association of Business Economists.
'' I think the intention, in terms of how it will operate, is that the nations around Iraq will deny overflight rights to flights that are headed for Baghdad,'' Mr. Cheney said.
''And as I say, we may have seen, with his threats in the last couple of days, that he may resort to military force in response to the sanctions, the first beginning evidence that in fact he's really beginning to feel the pain,'' Mr. Cheney continued.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: OPTIONS FOR BUSH;
If There Is No Provocation by Iraq, The U.N. May Offer a Route to Unity

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 26

 BODY:
If Iraq should sanction a major terrorist strike, harm American hostages or attack a United States warship or warplane, President Bush would certainly respond with military action, citing ''provocation'' by President Saddam Hussein to explain his decision.
''That much is clear,'' said a senior White House aide. ''If we have a pretext, a casus belli, we go. But the much more difficult question is how we proceed if the weeks and months go by, and there is no provocation.'' 
President Bush has suggested, without ever actually saying so, that at some point soon, if United Nations economic sanctions do not persuade Iraq to pull its troops out of Kuwait, he will use force to get them out. But it is not as simple as issuing an order to his commander in the Persian Gulf, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. There is the matter of Congressional acquiescence. Key Democrats on Capitol Hill insist that their support for Mr. Bush's policies in no way constitutes a mandate for offensive operations against Saddam Hussein.
This time, there will be no hastily passed, open-ended measure like the Gulf of Tonkin resolution, which Lyndon B. Johnson and later Presidents used to justify their military actions in Vietnam. Indeed, some influential lawmakers, including a few Republicans, are searching for a formula that would give Congress a major say in deciding when or whether to go to war.
There is the matter of public support. All the evidence in the opinion polls suggests that the President has the backing of the overwhelming majority of the American people for what he has done so far. So does the warmth with which he has been received on his political forays out into the country, such as the one he began today in Akron, Ohio and Chicago.
But so far Mr. Bush has sought support only for defensive action: guarding Saudi Arabia and other Gulf nations. Neither the White House nor anyone else really knows how enthusiastic the public would be, and for how long, about a desert campaign against the Iraqi Army or an air offensive.
Interviews with Bush partisans who turned out for a fund-raising lunch here today suggested that their support is highly conditional. Stuart Giller, an Akron businessman, said: ''People are solidly behind Operation Desert Shield, but they have their doubts about an Operation Desert Strike. They'd support a short war - a week or so - but beyond that, heavy losses, body bags, he loses support quickly, especially if we fire the first shots.''
 
Playing in Paris
A dental assistant who declined to give her name said, ''I'm afraid they've thought a lot in Washington about how to get into battle and not enough on how to get out.''
Finally there is the matter of allied participation. ''This administration has made a basic decision that it can't handle this alone,'' says one of its principal policymakers, and Mr. Bush is well aware that a justification for war that may sell on Capitol Hill and in Peoria may be much less effective in Paris, Damascus and Moscow. So the search is on for a predicate that would allow the preservation of allied unity, or most of it.
The route, it appears, may lie through the United Nations.
French diplomats are making it clear that despite President Francois Mitterrand's fury over Iraqi penetration of the French embassy in Kuwait, and the dispatch of crack French troops to the Gulf, Paris has little enthusiasm for a war policy. Other European countries that have backed Mr. Bush are firmly opposed to a unilateral United States decision to attack, even if it were dressed up with a round of ''consultations'' about the next step.
''Bush has three choices,'' said a minister from one European country who is visiting the United States. ''He can do nothing, he can risk our opposition or he can use the U.N. None perfect, but that's the way it is.''
The trouble with the United Nations in this context, from the Administration's point of view, is that it is too slow and it is too public. But Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d made it clear last Sunday that an appeal to the international organization to authorize military action has by no means been ruled out.
 
Taking Stock Before Christmas
Describing himself as ''extraordinarily pleased'' by the role of the United Nations to date, Mr. Baker said on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' ''If the President felt it was necessary to use force, I think he would want to move in a manner that would seek to preserve as much of the international consensus as we could, and hopefully all of it.'' The Administration has been thinking hard, he said, about ''how to implement U.N. resolutions'' calling for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait ''in the absence of some specific act of provocation.''
Tom King, the British Defense Minister, said in Washington last week that his country had placed no limitations on its support for Mr. Bush. But in New York on Tuesday, a senior British official, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said that when Mr. Bush and his allies ''take stock of the situation'' sometime before Christmas, war would not be the only option; the decision might be to give the sanctions more time.
Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union indicated in a General Assembly speech that, however cumbersome the United Nations Military Staff Committee might be, giving it a major role might be Moscow's price for participation in any military operations against Saddam Hussein. If it had been working properly, he said, ''there would be no need now for individual states to act unilaterally.''
That could cause problems in Washington, which is reluctant to put United States forces under a United Nations flag, but a compromise might be reached under which the United Nations authorized but did not control military action. Such a deal was worked out to permit the imposition of a naval blockade.
A United Nations mandate might also make it easier for the Egyptians, Moroccans and Syrians to commit their troops to battle alongside the Americans, despite the opposition that might arouse from the Arab masses in their capitals and elsewhere.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
At the U.N., Many Issues Are Called, but Only One Is Chosen: Persian Gulf

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The Security Council's backing of an air embargo against Iraq and the current preoccupation in the United Nations with the Persian Gulf crisis have overshadowed the range of other issues and statements that usually get heard during the opening of a General Assembly meeting.
Heads of state, prime ministers, foreign ministers and ambassadors have trod across the emerald green carpet in the General Assembly hall to the imposing granite podium and held forth on topics ranging from safeguarding the environment to the condemnation of the occupation of East Timor.
But the statements on these topics, and the normal pomp and circumstance that surround the arrival of such visitors, has caused barely a ripple this year.
''The Iraq-Kuwait crisis has dominated everything that is happening here,'' said Francois Giuliani, the spokesman for the Secretary General. ''It has upset the balance and the focus. Usually heads of state speak about everything under the sun and maybe they are doing so now, but nobody listens.'' 
Ambassadors from several countries, especially those in the developing world, said they accepted that the crisis in the gulf must be a priority, but not to the exclusion of other issues that threaten their own stablity.
 
'A One-Issue Assembly'
''I applaud the speed with which the Security Council has been acting in recent weeks, in more or less united fashion, to deal with this very serious crisis'' said Chinmaya R. Gharekhan, the Indian delegate to the United Nations. ''This is as it should be. But I wish the Council would act with equal dispatch to deal with some of the other concomitant consequences of this crisis, like the economic crisis. For India the net impact will be upwards of $4 billion.''
''There are other issues, particularly development, the debt problem, the reverse transfer of resources and the environment that are not receiving the attention they should,'' the Indian delegate said.
''It looks like a one-issue Assembly,'' Mr. Giuliani said, ''which is regrettable because there are many other serious problems.''
Several diplomats, however, said that if the United Nations could play a pivotal role in solving the gulf crisis it might have beneficial ramifications for their own regional disputes.
''Every diplomat has issues that are very important to their own country,'' said a West European diplomat who asked not to be identified. ''When one issue absorbs the whole meeting it is difficult. But for the first time the United Nations is united to face a crisis and resolve it. If we manage to resolve this crisis it will probably be one of the biggest successes of the United Nations. It will create a climate to solve other regional conflicts.''
 
Meetings Upon Meetings
Diplomatic missions, confronted with visits by high-ranking Government officials, have been putting in 12- and 14-hour days to arrange schedules, reserve tables at New York's best restaurants and book hotel accommodations.
There are about 28 heads of state, including President Bush, who are scheduled to arrive at the United Nations, along with some 15 prime ministers and 72 foreign ministers.
Much of the work during the opening of the 45th General Assembly, as is the case every year, goes on behind closed doors. The visiting political leaders hold numerous rounds of bilateral meetings on a range of issues.
''Much of our mission activity is devoted to setting up bilateral meetings,'' a Western diplomat said. ''Our job is to call the Japanese or the Kuwaitis to see if they can have lunch with us at the Waldorf.''
India's Foreign Minister, I. K. Gujral, has more than 50 scheduled bilateral talks, according to the Indian delegate.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has more than a dozen bilateral meetings, a Group of Seven dinner and two breakfast meetings, one with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the other with the Gulf Cooperation Council.
 
Little Time for the Lofty
''These bilateral meetings are as important as the General Assembly meeting itself,'' said Nicolaos Dictakis, a member of the Greek Mission.
Diplomats in the missions frequently have little time to pursue the loftier apsects of their calling.
''I have been so busy organizing the visit of our Foreign Minister that I haven't had time to follow the debate in the Security Council and the General Assembly,'' Mr. Dictakis said.
United Nations chief delegates, when they accompany their bosses to the General Assembly or Security Council, give up their seats to the higher ranking visitors.
On Tuesday night, the American delegate, Thomas R. Pickering, sat behind Secretary of State Baker at the Security Council, as did the 13 other United Nations delegates who accompanied their Foreign Ministers to the session.
''I don't think our Foreign Ministers would like it described that they take our seats,'' said Mr. Gharekhan, while admitting that Foreign Minister Gujral, now sits in the chair that is usually reserved for him as head of the Indian mission in the General Assembly.

HEADLINE: AIDS Rising Fast Among Black South Africans

SERIES: A CONTINENT'S AGONY: A PERIODIC REPORT.

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN; Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Nthato Motlana, a prominent doctor in the black township of Soweto, was visited recently by a young man suffering from a venereal disease. When Dr. Motlana proposed that his patient also be tested for signs of AIDS, he recalled, the young man scoffed.
''That's white man's propaganda,'' the patient told Dr. Motlana. ''I'm not homosexual.''
AIDS in South Africa, which first appeared among white homosexuals, has now begun spreading among black heterosexuals at an alarming rate. 
Doctors hope the country can head off the kind of epidemic that is devastating neighboring countries like Zambia, Malawi and Zimbabwe. With its modern medical system and economic resources, South Africa appears better equipped than those nations to resist AIDS, even with its inequities between health services for blacks and whites.
The Black Mistrust Of White Rulers But the preoccupation of leaders, black and white, with the current political violence and black mistrust of the white minority Government could erase this advantage, doctors fear. There are already signs that some conservative whites are trying to use the epidemic to further inflame racial tensions.
The incidence of AIDS in South Africa is still modest compared to that in some other African countries. Only about 500 outright AIDS cases have been reported so far among 37 million inhabitants, of whom 5 million are white.
But it is estimated that 1 percent of the country's black adult population is carrying the AIDS virus and that this number is rising fast. Two Johannesburg researchers have forecast that as many as 446,000 adult South Africans, almost all of them black, could be infected by the end of next year.
''There is a window of opportunity that is very short, of perhaps a couple of years,'' said Dr. Paul H. Grundy, an American physician who has tracked AIDS as the State Department's regional medical officer in southern Africa. ''Unless some way is found to reach the masses of people likely to become affected, South Africa will be in the same situation as its neighbors.''
In several countries to the north, including Malawi and Zambia, infection rates among urban adults have soared to over 20 percent over the last several years, and there is evidence that more than 10 percent of urban adults in Zimbabwe may carry the AIDS virus.
Is It Too Late To Stop Epidemic? Other specialists wonder whether South Africa has already missed the chance to head off a major epidemic. ''I'm not too sure whether it's not too late already,'' said Dr. Ruben Sher, an immunologist who heads the AIDS center at the South African Institute for Medical Research in Johannesburg.
The Government's decision this year to open its formerly segregated hospitals to all races has not eliminated the disparity in medical care for blacks and whites, because black patients still rely on the overcrowded hospitals and clinics near their homes in the segregated townships rather than the under-used hospitals near the white suburbs.
An AIDS epidemic among blacks could quickly overwhelm the medical system available in the townships like Soweto, where patients have already been sleeping on floors for lack of beds at its Baragwanath Hospital. The strain will be felt even faster in the ethnic homelands where medical installations are often rudimentary; for example, the Zulu homeland of KwaZulu in Natal has one doctor for each 15,000 inhabitants, which is seven times the national ratio.
Moreover, some blacks may be afraid to come forward for diagnosis and treatment of AIDS for fear of losing their jobs. In a policy supported by the Government, the mining industry since 1987 has screened prospective foreign mine workers for the AIDS virus, rejecting those found to be infected. The Malawi Government refused to allow the testing of its citizens, so no new workers from that country are being admitted. Migrants already working in the mines who are found to be infected during routine medical examinations are not sent home as long as they can work.
Some blacks now fear that the same policy could be applied to migrant workers from the four ethnic homelands of Bophuthatswana, Ciskei, Transkei and Venda, which South Africa treats as ostensibly independent.
First Isolation, Then Migrant Labor The disease first appeared here among white men who contracted it through homosexual contacts in the United States and Western Europe. Of 215 South Africans who died of AIDS, 26 were flight attendants for South African Airways. The first case in a black heterosexual was not diagnosed until December 1987.
Although the country's relative isolation because of its apartheid may have helped protect its people from contact with AIDS, truck drivers and guest workers from countries to the north are believed to have introduced the disease into the black population, researchers say. The spread has been accelerated by the country's internal migrant labor system, which forced blacks to leave their families in rural areas and seek work in mines and factories around the white cities. This has caused a breakdown of the traditional family and an increase in prostitution and other promiscuity.
''The pillar of the educational program is one sexual partner,'' Dr. Sher said. ''But with the migrant labor system, it's condoned for a man to have a sexual partner where he's working.''
Black suspicion of Government motives has undercut the effectiveness of its limited AIDS education program. There has been widespread resistance to the use of condoms, which has been perceived as a Government trick to suppress the black birth rate.
''The Government isn't credible in the townships. Even where the Government has made a contribution, it's been minimal,'' said Dr. Nicky Padayachee, an epidemiologist who is national AIDS coordinator for the South African Health Workers Congress, a professional organization allied to the African National Congress.
Infection May Hit The Workers Hard ''The worst kind of scenario would be infection of about 30 to 40 percent of the black community,'' Dr. Padayachee said. ''At best, with the best program in the world, we would look at 5 percent,'' he said. But he added, ''I think once you hit 5 or 6 percent of the population, you're really in trouble.''
A report by the AIDS Economic Research Unit, a private group that advises South African businesses on the potential impact of an AIDS epidemic, concluded this year that a 10 percent incidence could devastate the country's economy, which is based on cheap black labor.
Among South African white heterosexuals, the incidence of AIDS has been so low as to be statistically insignificant. With the limited apparent threat to white families, the Government has been slow to respond. Last year, South Africa budgeted a little over $2 million for AIDS education and research, or half of what was spent by its war-ravaged neighbor Mozambique.
The Government has also been unwilling to introduce sex education in schools or let condoms be mentioned on state-controlled television, which some physicians say perpetuates the ignorance of AIDS.
''Bring AIDS out of the closet,'' said Dr. Motlana, the Soweto physician. ''Bring sex talk out of the closet.'' He and other physicians receive condoms from the Department of Health to distribute free to patients, but these do not reach healthy young people. Dr. Motlana wanted condoms made available in the shebeens, or township taverns, and minibus taxis.
Unpopular Condoms And Scare Tactics Condoms are commercially available, but a 60 percent import surcharge imposed on condoms, which are not produced locally, increases their cost to about 35 cents each. ''The guy would rather buy a beer than buy a condom,'' Dr. Padayachee said, The Conservative Party and other right-wing groups have exploited AIDS as a racial scare issue. Although South Africa has a reliable blood screening program, the Conservatives have asserted that there were dangers in not labelling blood donations by race. They also warned against integrating hospitals once restricted for whites only. The World Apartheid Movement, an extremist group, circulated a leaflet claiming that whites could catch AIDS if blacks sneezed or used the same hospital beds.
Politically motivated sanctions against South Africa have restricted its access to information about strategies used to combat AIDS in other countries. In keeping with United Nations resolutions, the World Health Organization, for example, does not cooperate with the South African Government. But South Africa has recently asked for technical assistance in fighting AIDS and the agency is now exploring the possibility of providing it, possibly by using a private group as an intermediary, according to Dr. Gottlieb L. Monekosso, W.H.O.'s regional director for Africa.
''South Africa is going to be forced to repeat the mistakes that other countries have made because they're out of contact,'' Dr. Grundy said. ''They don't lack money or resources. They lack experience.''
Dr. Padayachee said a joint effort was needed by the Government, white business and township organizations loyal to the African National Congress, to stop AIDS from spreading.
Plenty of Politicking; Health Is Ignored The African National Congress has said it takes the AIDS threat seriously. Some members died from AIDS after contracting the disease in Zambia, the headquarters of the A.N.C. in exile. With the prospect of sharing political power on the horizon, the congress does not want to inherit a health nightmare. Its secretary general, Alfred Nzo, stated that his liberation movement ''stands committed to support the programs and strategies that will alleviate the suffering of the AIDS victims and at the same time control the transmission of HIV infection.''
Yet after being banned for 30 years, the A.N.C. has been too involved organizing for open political activity to devote more tangible resources to the threat. Its leader, Nelson Mandela, has yet to address the AIDS issue publicly.
Despite rumors that returning exiles may be asked to undergo testing for the AIDS virus, the Government has not raised the issue formally with the African National Congress. Gill Marcus, a spokeswoman for the A.N.C., said the organization would never agree because such testing would discriminate against its members. Besides, Miss Marcus said, ''it's a total infringement of individual rights.''
In the absence of broader dialogue on the issue between blacks and whites, immediate political concerns will keep taking precedence over a concerted effort to forestall an AIDS disaster.
''We need the leaders,'' Dr. Sher said. ''We need Mr. Mandela to get up and stress the need for safer sex. But I can see he'll have political problems with that.''

CITY: JOHANNESBURG, SOUTH AFRICA (93%);

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports Poverty Is Down but Inequality Is Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The Census Bureau reported today that there had been a slight decline in the proportion of Americans living in poverty but confirmed, more explicitly than ever before, that inequality in the distribution of income has increased substantially in the last two decades.
Last year, the bureau said, 12.8 percent of Americans had income below the official poverty level, which was $12,675 for a family of four. The poverty rate for 1989 was the lowest in the 1980's but was higher than for any year in the 1970's. The rate was 13 percent in 1988 and 13.4 percent in 1987. 
The bureau estimated that the number of Americans living in poverty declined to 31.5 million in 1989, from 31.7 million in 1988.
But, in releasing its annual report on poverty, the bureau said, ''There seems little doubt that the income distribution has become somewhat less equal over the past 20 years.''
 
Women Narrow the Gap
Today's report does not take account of economic developments since December. Many economists say poverty may rise this year, since the unemployment rate and the number food stamp recipients have been increasing amid signs of a recession after seven consecutive years of economic expansion.
The Census Bureau reported that the earnings of women who worked year round in full-time jobs increased 1.8 percent last year, after adjustment for inflation, while the earnings of men decreased 1.8 percent.
The median earnings for women, $18,780 last year, were 68 percent of the earnings for men, $27,430. The gap has been narrowing slowly since 1980, when it was 60 percent, the bureau said. The median is the midpoint; the number of people with income above the median is the same as the number below it.
Edward J. Welniak Jr., a Census Bureau statistician, said in an interview: ''A possible explanation for the increase in the earnings of women is the movement of the baby boom generation into its peak earning years, which tends to occur earlier for women than for men. The peak occurs from age 35 to 44 for women, while for men it occurs in the 45-to-54 age bracket.''
 
Household Income Compared
The bureau reported that median household income rose 1.3 percent last year, to $28,906, with black households showing an increase of 5.1 percent, to $18,083.
Household income was substantially higher for Asian-Americans than for whites: $36,102, as against $30,406. One reason was that Asian-American households tended to have more people than white households.
As used by the Census Bureau, ''Asian'' is a racial category that includes people from Japan, China, the Philippines, Korea, India and Vietnam.
Last year half the nation's poor were either children or elderly. ''The poverty rate for children continues, as it has since 1975, to be higher than that for any other age group,'' the report said.
The rate was 19.6 percent for children under 18 years of age and 22.5 percent for those under 6. Half of black children under 6 were living in poverty. Forty percent of Hispanic children and 17 percent of white children under 6 were poor, the bureau said.
 
The Poverty Level Defined
A family of four was classified as poor if it had cash income of less than $12,675 last year. The poverty level is adjusted each year to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index. The official poverty statistics are based exclusively on cash income. They do not reflect the value of a person's assets or of noncash benefits like food stamps, Medicaid, public housing and fringe benefits provided by employers.
If such benefits were counted as income they would reduce the poverty rate. But Census Bureau officials said the trend in poverty over the last decade would be very similar to that reflected in the official statistics.
Representative Lee H. Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat who is chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, said, ''The figures released today paint a discouraging picture of recent trends in poverty and income distribution.''
The Census Bureau observed that the share of all income going to the most affluent fifth of all households last year was ''significantly higher than the comparable figures for 1979 and 1969,'' while middle-income and poor households received ''somewhat lower shares.''
For the most affluent 5 percent of all families in the United States, average income rose to $148,438 in 1989, from $120,253 in 1979, the bureau reported. In the same 10-year period, it said, the average income for the poorest one-fifth of all families declined to $9,431, from $9,990.
Income distribution is an emotional issue in politics. Changes in such distribution from year to year are small. The Census Bureau has been much more cautious than many economists in commenting on the changes. But bureau officials said the trend was now clear, so they had no hesitation in writing about ''the growing inequality of the income distribution,'' as it was called in today's report.
The bureau said the reasons for the increased inequality of American incomes were not entirely clear. It listed several possibilities, including growth in the number of elderly people, in the number of people living alone and in the number of families headed by a woman, with no husband present.
Median household income for the elderly is about half that for the nonelderly, even though the poverty rate for the elderly, 11.4 percent, is lower than for the nation as a whole, the bureau said. Because of Social Security, many elderly people have incomes just above the poverty level, the report said.
The poverty data were based on interviews with 60,000 households chosen to be representative of the nation's population.

HEADLINE: President's Tax Plan: Benefits for the Not-So-Rich

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The latest White House proposal to break the deadlock in the budget negotiations would be less beneficial to the very rich and help people who are moderately affluent more than would the Bush Administration's initial plan to cut the tax rate on capital gains.
But the new proposal, to adjust the capital gains tax so that profits attributable only to inflation would not be taxed, would still disproportionately cut the taxes of high-income taxpayers.
For that reason, Democrats in the budget talks oppose this proposed indexing of capital gains for inflation unless the Administration agrees to an offsetting higher tax on the wealthy. So the impasse remains. 
 
New Movement on Old Issue
Nevertheless, the new proposal has at least produced some movement on the issue that has been the sticking point in the budget talks: how to treat capital gains taxes. Many of the negotiators, including the Republican leaders, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas and Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, have suggested that if this hurdle could be cleared, the negotiators could reach the finish line in their negotiations before across-the-board spending cuts become automatic on Monday, the first day of the new fiscal year.
Capital gains are the profits from the sale of investments like stocks, bonds and real estate. Since 1986, they have been taxed at the same rate as salaries and wages.
In his election campaign, Mr. Bush promised to lower the capital gains rate. He said the change would generate more investment and savings, create new jobs and lead to greater national prosperity. Moreover, he has recently suggested that such a cut is especially important now to stimulate a flagging economy.
The Democrats in the budget talks maintain that most of the beneficiaries of a reduction in the capital gains tax, whether from a lower rate or from indexation, would be the well-to-do, a hardly arguable point, since affluent people make the vast majority of their profits from the sale of investments.
Studies show that about two-thirds of all capital gains are received by taxpayers with income above $200,000 and that more than three-quarters goes to those with incomes above $100,000.
With the new proposal, the White House is taking a somewhat different tack. It is saying that it is unfair to tax people on gains that are solely due to inflation.
 
Details Are Not Disclosed
Economists doubt that the advantages of indexation would be much different from those that would be obtained from a lower capital gains tax rate.
The details of the Administration's proposal on indexing have not been made public, and may not have been completely worked out.
Consequently, it is not clear whether the measure would apply indexation to all capital gains or just some, how capital losses would be treated and whether it would apply to investments bought in the past or just new investments.
Lowering the capital gains rate and tying the tax owed to inflation would both be more favorable to investors than would the existing tax law.
Under the current law, if taxpayers buy stock for $4,000 and sell it five years later for $8,000, they pay tax on the full 100 percent profit of $4,000. But under indexing, if the rate of inflation over the five-year period was 25 percent, they would pay tax on only $3,000, the 75 percent of their profit that represents a real increase in purchasing power and is not due just to inflation.
Capital gains taxes are indexed ins ome other countries, including Britain and Australia. The idea has been discussed here for years by scholars but has never seriously been considered in Congress.
A study published last month by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office concluded, ''Because capital gains are received primarily by higher-income taxpayers, any tax reduction could be expected to benefit higher-income taxpayers disproportionately.''
But the study went on to show that the tax reductions from a lower capital gains rate ''would be concentrated to a greater degree among higher-income taxpayers than would the reductions from indexation.''
 
Study Shows Rich Are Taxed More
Using 1981 tax returns of people who sold common stock, the budget office found that taxpayers with incomes below $100,000 would pay less taxes with indexation than with a 30 percent lower tax rate, while those with higher incomes would be better off with the lower tax rate.
An income of $100,000 in 1981 would be equivalent to an income of about $130,000 today.
The inflation rate was especially high in the late 1970's and early 1980's, which might have skewed the study. But the budget office said the same results were obtained when tax figures from other years were examined.
The budget office did not speculate on why indexation seemed to be more favorable for the very rich and less favorable for those less well off.
C. Eugene Steuerle, a top tax official in the Reagan Administration who is now a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a research organization here, suggested that the richest people were probably better at playing the markets and that those less affluent were more likely to buy stocks that did not appreciate so rapidly.
The reason is not, Mr. Steuerle and other scholars emphasized, because the rich tend to buy and sell stocks rapidly, while the less affluent hold stocks longer.
First, they said, over almost any long period of time examined, the stock market tends to outperform inflation. Second, capital gains are not taxed when the owner of the investment dies, so the wealthy have an incentive to hold property for their heirs.
 
Large Loss of Revenue Is Seen
The budget office said the economic effect in terms of stimulating investment and saving would be about the same with indexing as it would with a lower rate.
But it suggested that the loss of revenue to the Government might be much larger under indexing.
That is another reason why lawmakers might not find the suggestion appealing.
An attraction of the original Bush plan to cut the tax rate was that it would actually generate more revenue for the Government in the first year, since people would be encouraged to sell property. That would make it easier to reduce the Federal deficit at first.
Over five years, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation, it would cost the Government more than $20 billion.

HEADLINE: College Tuition Costs Increase at Slower Pace

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
The cost of a year of college in the United States rose in a range of 5 to 8 percent this year, marking a modest slowing of increases in college tuition and fees for the country's 12 million undergraduates, according to a College Board survey that is to be released today.
The average rate of increase was lowest among public two-year instutitions and highest among two-year and four-year private colleges and universities. In dollars and cents, students this academic year are being charged an average of $884 for tuition and fees at public two-year schools and $9,391 at private four-year colleges and universities, the survey reported. 
The previous year, the average costs of entering a four-year public college rose 8 percent, while four-year private institutions showed a 9 percent average increase. Comparative information for two-year institutions last year was not available, said Janice A. Gams, a board spokeswoman.
''It's not a big drop,'' said David W. Breneman, an economist and visiting professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education. ''If it keeps going up by 8 percent a year, the cost will double in nine years.''
But Richard F. Rosser, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, called the slight drop a ''welcome sign of moderation.''
College students are also paying more for housing. Average annual costs for students living on campus rose to $4,150 from $3,160 for room and board, a 5 to 7 percent increase over last year, the survey found.
Precise reasons for the overall increases are unclear, economists said yesterday. But a recent study prepared for the American Council on Education and the College Board found that, since the early 1980's, public institutions have been getting declining state support, while private or independent schools have required higher tuitions and student fees to pay for improved services, faculty salaries, services and increased student financial aid.
But Dr. Breneman speculates that the rapid inflation rates of the 1970's caught college administrators off guard, so to catch up, they began increasing tuition and fees.
''They found that it was good money,'' Dr. Breneman said. ''The colleges started putting the extra money into quality improvement and ways to make themselves more competitive. It has achieved a momentum now.''

CORRECTION-DATE: September 28, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A chart yesterday showing the 10 most expensive colleges for 1990-91 misidentified the 10th-ranked entry.
It is Johns Hopkins University, at $22,200, including tuition, fees, books, and room and board. Harvard ranks 11th, at $22,160.

HEADLINE: Rinfret Snubs G.O.P. Peace Session

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EASTCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 26

 BODY:
The New York State Republican Party rented Alex and Henry's Roman Gardens catering hall today for a political wedding. They hired a Dixieland jazz band, prepared a slide show, enlisted attractive women with Rinfret for Governor signs and even offered a choice of chicken or steak for the guests.
Then, the bridegroom, Pierre A. Rinfret, the party's candidate for governor, did not show up. Just as he was stood up on Friday by a half dozen Republican leaders when he called a meeting, he stood up 40 of them today. 
Instead of attending the session here, Mr. Rinfret, whose public feud with Republican leaders has embarrassed the party, sent an ultimatum. In it he demanded recognition as the ''undisputed leader'' of the party. He only recently became an enrolled Republican.
He also called on party leaders to endorse his fiscal programs, including one calling for a 20 percent cut in the state work force in his first term, even though many Republican legislators receive contributions from the Civil Service Employees Association, which represents most state workers.
 
Republicans Don't Cry
The result was more attention for Mr. Rinfret than he received when he suggested privatizing the subways. It also meant more attention for a party in so much turmoil that its leaders were reduced to laughter here today because, several said, men, particularly Republicans, do not cry.
The party's state chairman, J. Patrick Barrett, had prepared them for what was supposed to be a love fest aimed at repairing the damage caused when Mr. Rinfret called Republican Senate leaders bedmates of his Democratic opponent, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Mr. Rinfret's son, Peter, his associate in an economic consulting firm, presented a letter from his father and a resolution that Pierre Rinfret wanted passed intact before he would fly from Manhattan to the meeting.
Pierre Rinfret wrote that the Republican leaders had tried to ''buy me off with a hand full of money.'' He said he was offered the ''grand total of $40,000 to shut up, go away and run a dismal campaign for governor.''
 
Lots of Chicken Uneaten
While most Republicans picked at their chicken and steak, several, led by Joseph N. Mondello, the Nassau County Republican chairman who had offered Mr. Rinfret $25,000 of the $40,000, spent 50 minutes negotiating with Pierre Rinfret, by telephone, and Ralph J. Marino, the State Senate majority leader.
The negotiations failed, at least for now, and the ceremony ended with a lot of chicken uneaten, the band unheard and the slide show unseen.
Mr. Mondello, in an interview later, sounded as if he were trying to get President Bush and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq together, saying that he was confident that somehow, somewhere, he would get Pierre Rinfret and Mr. Marino ''in a room together.''

HEADLINE: New York Told To Hire Advisers On Drug Abuse

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
William Bennett, the nation's chief drug policy official, said yesterday that New York City was not doing enough to combat the cocaine and heroin epidemic. He recommended that the city hire three or four special consultants.
Mr. Bennett said Mayor David N. Dinkins must ''get control of the streets.'' 
''He should take the best three or four minds in the business and put them on the payroll as consultants,'' Mr. Bennett said in a conversation with several reporters at a midtown hotel. ''You've got an emergency situation. You've got to grab for all the help you can get.''
In response, Mr. Dinkins said: ''I'm pleased to have Secretary Bennett's advice and counsel. Perhaps he's unaware of that which we have already done.'' Mr. Bennett is a former Secretary of Education.
''What we need,'' Mr. Dinkins added, ''is a little more help out of the Federal Government.''
 
New Drug Policy Director
At the same time, Mr. Dinkins announced the appointment of David Condliffe as director of the city's newly created office of drug abuse policy. The post was recommended last spring by a mayoral study group on drug abuse.
Mr. Condliffe, 42 years old, a former City Hall aide in the Lindsay administration, has been special adviser to the city's Human Resources Administration since late 1989.
Mr. Bennett made his remarks at the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza after a news conference in which the Institute for a Drug-Free Workplace, a Washington-based coalition of business organizations, reported that in a survey of professional and blue-collar workers in New York state, 62 percent said they thought their employers should set up drug-testing programs.
Mr. Bennett said that other studies have shown that 70 percent of the regular drug users in the United States hold full-time jobs and that he considers the workplace to be one of the important fronts in fighting drugs.
In the new survey, in which 501 people were interviewed by telephone by the Gallup Organization Inc., 64 percent said employers should have the right to test employees suspected of drug use; 58 percent said they favored testing job applicants for drugs. The employees were almost evenly divided, 45 percent to 40 percent, on whether employers should be able to test workers randomly for drugs.

HEADLINE: President of Colombia Tours A Drug Center in New York

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
The President of Colombia visited a Queens drug-treatment center yesterday and told the residents that their addiction is taking a terrible toll on his country.
''Thousands of Colombians are losing their lives because of the narcotics traffickers,'' President Cesar Gaviria Trujillo told the residents of Phoenix House in Long Island City. ''A lot of their money comes from the streets of the United States and Europe. And some of that money goes to terrorists, people who kill police, judges and politicians. Three hundred police in Colombia have been killed this year.'' 
President Gaviria, who was elected in May on an anti-drug platform, emphasized the need for increased efforts to reduce drug consumption.
''We have to work on the problem of consumption, not just interdiction,'' he said after an hour tour of the 300-bed residential treatment center.
Phoenix House, which was founded in 1967, operates five other centers in New York and four in California.
 
Renouncing Drug Addiction
Mr. Gaviria, who arrived in New York on Tuesday night and will address the United Nations today, praised Phoenix House for its work in rehabilitating former drug addicts, and said that drug abuse had to be fought with ''individual principles.''
The 43-year-old President, who was inaugurated on Aug. 7, became a candidate after another Presidential candidate, Luis Carlos Galan, an outspoken critic of the country's drug cartels, was assassinated in August 1989. Mr. Gaviria, an economist, had been Mr. Galan's campaign chairman.
Mitchell S. Rosenthal, the president of Phoenix House, said: ''The solution to the drug problem is on the demand side. President Gaviria saw a solution here, because as individuals renounce drugs, the nation renounces drugs.''
Larry Grant, one of several Phoenix House residents who escorted the Colombian President and his wife, Ana Milena Munoz, through the center, was impressed by his warmth and interest in the program. ''He asked us how it prepares us when we leave,'' he said.
Leslie Alvarado, another resident who accompanied Mr. Gaviria, said: ''He was interested in how a person who uses drugs comes into a treatment program and changes. I think he was surprised that we as individuals really want to change.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Cesar Gaviria Trujillo of Colombia, left rear, visiting the Phoenix House drug treatment center in Queens yesterday. He talked about how narcotics-related violence has affected Colombian lives. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Magazine for Every Child

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
WHEN John Papanek was an editor and writer at Sports Illustrated, he was well known in certain circles. But no one ever sent in a T-shirt asking for his autograph.
But since Mr. Papanek began editing Sports Illustrated for Kids last year, he has felt like a celebrity. Besides numerous requests for his autograph, he receives more than 100 letters a day filled with cartoons, personal stories and even jokes, like the one from Kristi Geise, age 11, in Yuba City, Calif. She wrote: ''What do you get when you spill soda pop in a golf bag? Ickey Woods!''
Randi Hacker also receives passionate letters from the children who read the new magazine she publishes, P3, which is dedicated to the environment. ''Children are using their letters to tell us how they feel about earth, and how scared they are,'' Miss Hacker said. 
Magazines for children is hardly a new idea: Highlights for Children, which is 45 years old, is thriving, leading the field with its circulation of three million. But in the last two years, dozens of new ones have started as publishers try to appeal to a growing, economically powerful and loyal audience.
Although the overall magazine business is losing advertising these days, publishers of children's magazines believe they are in a better position because the number of children has been growing and because they are not seeking ads in categories that have been declining, like alcohol and cigarettes.
The range of magazines is evident in Magazines for Children, a guidebook with 123 entries that was published last year by the Educational Press Association of America in Glassboro, N.J., and the International Reading Association in Newark, Del. The editor, Donald R. Stoll, has the names of 30 new magazines for the next issue.
Magazines sometimes appeal more to children than books do, said Mr. Stoll, whose organization began publishing the guidebook as a way to promote literacy. ''It seems to be a more exciting kind of learning experience that's not associated with the classroom,'' he said.
Magazines for children, like those for adults, are targeted to diverse and specialized interests. There are glossy, trendy publications as well as serious, literary ones. Budding consumer activists can get shopping advice from Zillions, put out by Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports. Young writers can publish their poems and stories in Merlyn's Pen, a literary magazine made up solely of their contributions.
And like adults, children seem attracted to magazines that fill some particular need or desire. ''I like scientific stuff,'' said Kelly McInnis, a 9-year-old in St. Charles, Mo., who reads National Geographic World, a publication for children.
Spencer Wolff, who is 10 and lives in New York, reads several magazines, including Nintendo Power. ''It gives me hints about how to win games.'' Ashley, his 7-year-old sister, reads Ranger Rick, a nature magazine published by the National Wildlife Federation, because it has stories about animals. She also reads the magazines that come to her mother in the mail. ''I like to look at the clothing,'' she said.
Akilah Nelson, a 9-year-old who lives in Lawnside, N.J., reads her mother's copy of Ebony. ''Sometimes I cut out pictures and put them on paper,'' she said. ''Pictures of Janet Jackson and Nelson Mandela.'' She said she likes children's magazines that give her facts about people and tells her what other children are doing.
The children's magazine field, although growing more crowded, still seems appealing to publishers. New this month is Ladybug, a magazine with stories, puzzles and poems for children age 2 to 7. It is being put out by Open Court Publishing the publishers of Cricket, a similar magazine for 6- to 14-year-olds.
Walt Disney Publishing in Burbank, Calif., will begin publishing Disney Adventures, a 132-page digest-sized publication for children age 7 to 14 on Oct. 9, with nearly a million copies scheduled to be printed. The magazine will have profiles, nature and science stories, games and, of course, cartoons.
In its November issue, Field and Stream will include a junior version as a prototype. Time has been considering a similar plan,and Fortune, too, is studying the possibility of publishing a Fortune for children or teen-agers. ''There's so little out there that's sophisticated,'' said Emma Dockendorff, a spokeswoman for Fortune.
One publisher came to that conclusion eight years ago and has profited by it. Donald E. Welsh, president of Welsh Publishing Group in New York, decided to start a magazine when his daughter, who was then 9, asked for a subscription to People magazine for Christmas. Wondering why, he looked at what was available for children.
''They all talked down to kids,'' Mr. Welsh said. ''It was all about little lambs and bears, like being in 1950.'' His four magazines, devoted to Barbie, Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles, Mickey Mouse and the Real Ghostbusters, have a circulation of almost four million.
Many publishers have been inspired by the success of Sports Illustrated for Kids, which has attracted a great deal of advertising and reached a circulation of 850,000 since starting in January 1989. Surveys show the readers are so loyal that they go through each monthly issue seven times, said Ann S. Moore, the publisher.
''The demographics for kids are terrific,'' said Michael Lynton, the vice president of marketing for Walt Disney Publishing. ''There are more of them, and they are more active in making decisions.'' Children not only have their own money to spend; they are also influential in deciding what foods, drinks, vacations and even cars the family will buy.
But children present both advantages and disadvantages for publishers. Being in tune with what they want is the first challenge for adults who are used to writing for their peers. At Sports Illustrated for Kids, editors frequently sit behind one-way mirrors and watch as children have discussions with moderators about what they are interested in.
Still, children's interests can be difficult to know. Alden Nusser, an 8-year-old New Yorker, reads Sports Illustrated for Kids and Zoobooks. But he dislikes some children's magazines even though their editors believe he is part of the target age group. ''I don't really like the ones for little kids, like Ranger Rick,'' Alden said. Sometimes, he added, he looks at magazines like National Geographic and Conde Nast Traveler.
Because children outgrow magazines directed at them, publishers have a constant need to find new subscribers. ''There is going to be a turnover every three years,'' said Mr. Stoll of Magazines for Children.
Since it is so expensive to replace subscribers, some publishers say advertising is a better way to finance operations.
But some publishers find the idea of advertising distasteful. Mark Diamond, who started Atlanta Kids in June 1989 with his wife, Francine Kaplan, quickly found that each issue needed 10 pages of advertising to make a profit. That bothered him, so he has suspended publication while he looks for financing.
''I have an opposition to hype, and that's what advertising is,'' Mr. Diamond said. ''Many kids have not been taught to be wary.''
 
Current Reading
THERE is an enormous range of magazines available to children. Here are some of the articles they are offering:
The winter issue of BARBIE, a quarterly, will include a profile of the Simpsons, a piece called ''Move It'' about fitness, and one called ''Bow Wow,'' a fashion spread about velvet dresses in which dogs wear some of the accessories.
The current HIGHLIGHTS has fiction, puzzles and nonfiction, including a profile of the baseball player Jim Abbott; ''What Happened to the Dinosaurs?,'' written by a member of the National Academy of Sciences, and an article about Africans who use dolphins to track fish.
P3, about the environment, has a story about how seals are killed by plastic garbage; a profile of the Ranger of the Month; and stories about the Earth Patrol, people the magazine says are making the earth a better place to live.
ZILLIONS has ''Everything You've Always Wanted to Know About Twinkies'' and ''The Inside Story on L.A. Gear.''
SPORTS ILLUSTRATED FOR KIDS has stories on Christian Okoye, a top N.F.L. running back, and the adventures of ''Jack B. Quick, Sports Detective.''
CRICKET has a recipe for pumpkin muffins, a haunted-house maze and articles about Japan.
The Magazines for Children directory is $5.25 and can be ordered from the International Reading Association, Order Department, P.O. Box 8139, Newark, Del. 19714-8139.
