LENGTH: 1007 words

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The Argument That Japan Guides the U.S. Economy

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Agents of Influence
By Pat Choate
Illustrated. 295 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.
Here's a book highly critical of Japan that all but dares its readers to accuse it of Japan-bashing. For anyone tempted to accuse his provocative ''Agents of Influence'' of being biased against Japan, Pat Choate would cite Chapter 10, ''Japan's Six Excuses,'' where he lists the major ''themes'' that Japanese ''propaganda'' now stresses in dealing with critics of what he characterizes as Japan's manipulation of America's political and economic system. 
Here Mr. Choate writes: ''Although Japan has dozens of excuses to justify its closed markets'' - by which he means what he sees as its refusal to allow American companies to sell their goods in Japan's domestic market - ''they can be grouped into six general themes. (1) 'Japan creates jobs for Americans.' (2) 'Japan's critics are racists.' (3) 'It's America's fault.' (4) 'Globalization.' (5) 'Japan is unique.' (6) 'Japan is changing its ways.' '' Obviously, Mr. Choate contests each of these assertions.
Yet once having freed himself to speak by saying, in effect, that one can criticize the Japanese without being anti-Japanese, whom does he level his main fire against? None other than his fellow Americans.
To him it's a given that Japan has always aimed to capture the United States' markets without allowing penetration of its own. That's the way things have been, he argues, ever since the end of World War II, when American banking and business interests with holdings in Japan prevailed against Gen. Douglas MacArthur's plan to break up ''the family-owned super-conglomerates that dominated Japan's prewar economy and fueled its militaristic and imperial ambitions.''
To begin with, Mr. Choate maintains, Japan ''destroyed the American television industry,'' by first creating ''an anti-competitive cartel'' and then reinforcing it with ''diplomacy, fraud, and the influence of Washington insiders in a direct assault on the American consumer electronics industry.'' Then came ''victories'' in ''supercomputers, machine tools, ball bearings, optical fibers, satellites, rice, biotechnology, air transport, telecommunications, semiconductors, legal and financial services, among dozens of others.'' Today, the author concludes, ''no American industry - regardless of how competitive - is safe.''
What distresses Mr. Choate is that Americans are permitting this invasion of their economy to proceed apace. ''In a sense,'' he writes, ''this book is not about Japan or any other foreign interest. It is about a fundamental problem with American governance - one that allows foreign interests to assume a dangerously large role in America's politics and policymaking through political manipulation.''
The list of the United States' vulnerabilities is extensive, in Mr. Choate's view: The country is too dependent on foreign capital. States and localities compete too vigorously to attract foreign corporations. These companies are too free to participate in American elections. Too many loopholes exist in the laws requiring registration of foreign agents. Most damaging of all, ''a revolving door'' permits too easy passage from public service to the payroll of foreign interests. (A prominent feature of this book is an appendix identifying 207 former American officials of the decade just past, including diplomats, members of Congress, C.I.A. personnel and White House staff members, who have gone on to represent foreign governments and corporations in Washington.) These flaws in the system make America pregnable to Japan's corrupting cultural and economic influence, Mr. Choate concludes. It is not that thinkers are paid to believe that free trade is best for Japanese-American relations. It is that those who believe in free trade can be promoted by subtle means. It's like the invasion of the body-snatchers, as Mr. Choate depicts things; they come in the night and their victims don't even know they've been possessed.
Unfortunately, Mr. Choate's argument is weakened by irritating flaws in its presentation. His text is haphazardly organized and choppily written. Only once or twice does he settle into a case history that truly absorbs the reader. On the one hand, he blames the budget deficit for making the country prey to Japanese influence; on the other hand, he dismisses Japan's blaming of the budget deficit for America's trade imbalance.
He makes occasional statements unattributed to any source. Discussing Japanese reaction to his earlier book ''The High-Flex Society,'' he refers to officials of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry getting in touch with ''executives in the Tokyo office of my corporate employer,'' but never identifies that employer, a lapse of tact in a book about hidden influence. A biographical note describes Mr. Choate as a political economist, lecturer and writer living in Washington.
For a book that purports to be about ''our'' problem, he throws a remarkable number of rotten tomatoes at ''them.'' But then, one can see what he is getting at. ''They'' have become ''our'' problem, if he is right, and at the rate things are going, we are in danger of becoming theirs. Despite all its fireworks, this book really does raise the level of the debate above mere name-calling. Most tellingly, it identifies what may be a flaw in our society that goes deeper than Japan's purported economic infiltration. Mr. Choate writes: ''The lobbying game is played by 'lawyers' rules.' . . . The lawyer-client relationship of the adversarial court proceeding has been grafted on to the lobbyist-client relationship. In the process, many lawyer-lobbyists have learned to adhere to the adversarial standards of the courtroom. They proceed as if they had a fiduciary and ethical responsibility to help their client win at all costs, even when winning for a foreign company or government runs counter to the interests of the nation.''
This has a ring of truth about it that makes the issue of Japan-bashing really beside the point.

LENGTH: 1152 words

HEADLINE: Treasury Urges Restrictions On Bank Deposit Insurance

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The Bush Administration said today that restrictions should be placed on insurance coverage of deposits at banks and suggested that the insurance premiums paid by the banks be pegged to the risk involved in their investments and loans.
In presenting the Administration's latest views before the Senate Banking Committee today, Treasury Under Secretary Robert R. Glauber said the current level of deposit protection, $100,000, should not be lowered. But he added that the Government should close loopholes that permitted virtually unlimited coverage through multiple accounts held by individuals, pension funds and institutions.
Mr. Glauber thus joined a growing debate in Washington among lawmakers and regulators about the necessary steps that must be taken to avoid the collapse of the weakening bank insurance fund, which now stands at $13.2 billion. 
In July, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady signaled in Congressional testimony that the $100,000 amount of insurance coverage should not be lowered. But he said then that the Administration was leaning toward limiting individuals and businesses to a maximum of $100,000 in deposit insurance, whether in one or several accounts.
Mr. Glauber said today that ''adverse trends in both the banking industry and the bank insurance fund are clear causes for concern,'' but he emphasized that the difficulties encountered by the banking industry were smaller than those plaguing the savings and loan community.
Nearly a dozen proposals to ease the financial stress on the banking industry have been introduced in Congress, ranging from drastically cutting insurance coverage to increasing significantly the premiums paid by banks to overhauling the whole banking system.
The ratio of insurance to deposits is now about 70 cents for every $100, its lowest level since the fund was created during the Great Depression. Regulators have warned that an economic downturn or the collapse of one or several large banks could exhaust the fund. The fund has declined by $5 billion in the last two years, and it is expected to lose at least $2 billion this year.
The worsening condition of the fund comes as many large banks are struggling with growing real estate portfolios in softening markets, continued problem loans to lesser-developed nations and borrowings by corporations with their own financial difficulties. As a result, many larger banks are finding it increasingly difficult to raise additional capital.
 
F.D.I.C. Seeks Maximum
In response to these problems, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has proposed increasing bank premiums paid to the fund by 30 percent, to 19.5 cents per $100 in deposits, the maximum amount allowed by law, beginning next year.
Senior Republicans and Democrats in Congress, as well as the Treasury Department, have agreed in principle to eliminate caps that prevent the insurance agency from further raising the premiums. They expect that a measure removing the limits will be adopted before Congress takes a recess next month.
But strong concern has also arisen among regulators and lawmakers that too steep an increase in insurance premiums could create more problems by causing more banks to collapse. A study released this week by the Congressional Budget Office starkly posed the difficulties confronting the bank insurance fund.
The study concluded that premiums would have to rise to 43 cents for every $100 in deposits to get the insurance fund to the level required by Federal legislation adopted last year - $1.25 per $100 in deposits by 1995. But a levy that high, the study said, would cause as many as 40 large institutions to become insolvent.
Treasury officials expect to complete a report by the end of the year describing what steps should be taken to overhaul the nation's banking system. The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., said Congress would be willing to put aside much of its regular business to get the changes implemented quickly.
The remarks of Mr. Glauber today before the banking committee reflected how the Treasury's report had been evolving.
As a practical matter, deposit insurance coverage is now virtually limitless. A customer avoids the limitations by taking out multiple accounts, each insured for up to $100,000. In a majority of bank failures, the F.D.I.C., in effect, protects accounts of more than $100,000 by transferring the deposits of the collapsed institutions to a solvent one, giving it a cash infusion.
Mr. Glauber told the committee that limiting the number of accounts protected by insurance would be a formidable but not insurmountable administrative problem.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, has said that the most likely method of keeping track of multiple accounts would be through Social Security numbers, although he did not elaborate.
 
Insurance on Other Accounts
Mr. Glauber also said the Administration was committed to limiting the number of insured accounts for each depositor. He also questioned whether ''pass-through'' accounts - like pension funds, brokered deposits and other funds that are placed in bank accounts to gain the benefits of bank insurance - should be federally insured.
He added that the Administration had also supported the concept of ''risk-based'' premiums, so that the contributions to the insurance fund would be based on an institution's financial condition.
 
A 'Useful Complement'
Mr. Glauber acknowledged that it would be difficult to determine levels of risk in setting the premiums on deposit insurance, but he said that such premiums would be a ''useful complement to capital in deterring excessive risk at the margin.''
He also told the banking committee that the Administration was studying the idea of encouraging private insurers to become involved in deposit insurance. But he expressed concern that such companies ''would not step up to bat when they're really needed'' should a major catastrophe occur.
Bank lobbyists and Government officials have said that a critical issue yet to be determined is whether to abandon what is known as the ''too-big-to-fail'' policy. Under this tacit policy, in effect for years, the Government has made whole all of the depositors of some large institutions, even those with deposits greater than $100,000, as well as other creditors of a failed bank.
Mr. Glauber did not address the policy at today's banking committee hearing. But in an afternoon appearance in Washington at a private meeting of world bank regulators, he said the policy should not be removed by Congress because regulators should continue to have the authority to handle bank collapses that jeopardize the entire financial system.
In recent days, Mr. Riegle, Democrat of Michigan, and the chairman of the House Banking Committee, Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, have come out against the ''too-big-to-fail'' policy.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 27, 1990

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1033 words

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A G.M. Car With a Japanese Feel

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The Saturn, the soon-to-be-introduced car that General Motors has for five years heralded as an import fighter, lives up to the company's game plan: It feels and drives very much like a Japanese car.
A test drive and close examination of the Saturn, which the General Motors Corporation has continued to keep under wraps in the weeks before its Oct. 11 introduction, reveals a car with none of the parts or styling flourishes that signal a model from the company that builds Chevrolets, Pontiacs, Oldsmobiles, Cadillacs and Buicks.
For example, Saturn's windshield wiper wand, radio and gauges do not resemble those used on every other G.M. car, and indeed give the impression that one is driving a Japanese car. And the G.M. logo does not appear anywhere on the car and will not appear in its advertising material. 
The Saturn's ride and handling have a Japanese feel. The manual shifter on the SC coupe moves through the gears with the buttery smoothness of a Honda shifter, which is regarded as the world's standard by many in Detroit. And unlike many domestic cars that sway or roll in turns or over bumps, the Saturn has a more precise, tightly controlled feel like the Japanese cars it is intended to imitate.
G.M. executives say they want Saturn to sell at least 80 percent of its cars to customers who normally would buy imports like the Toyota Corolla and Honda Civic. Merely to entice Pontiac and Olds owners to buy Saturns would accomplish little. Hence, the intended resemblance to Japanese cars.
The $100 million task of selling Saturn to the public is in the hands of the San Francisco advertising agency Hal Riney & Partners, which gave a preview of its campaign in Los Angeles yesterday. [Page D21.] Times have changed: Where the Japanese once came to the United States to learn how Americans build cars, the Saturn project is the boldest example so far of how the Americans are now learning from the Japanese.
G.M. in recent months agreed to allow a few outsiders to test the three Saturn models. This week a New York Times reporter was allowed to drive the three models over a hundred miles of country roads near the auto maker's proving grounds in Milford, Mich. However, the company is embargoing until next month any official photos or specific details about the car's performance, including its fuel-efficiency rating and horsepower.
General Motors has been trying for three decades to build a small car that is competitive with small, efficient and high-performing imports. Among G.M.'s unsuccessful attempts to blunt the surge of imports were the Pontiac Sunbirds and Chevy Cavaliers of the early 1980's and the Chevy Vega of the early 1970's. The Corvair, introduced in 1960, was G.M.'s first response to cars like the Volkswagen Beetle.
In the last decade G.M.'s share of the United States market has fallen to 35 percent from roughly 45 percent, translating into lost sales of about 1.5 million cars and trucks annually. Japanese car makers now hold about a third of the United States market. Moreover, the erosion has occurred mostly among younger buyers, whose loyalty is critical to any auto maker's long-term success.
The three Saturn models to be introduced next month are the SL 1, a sports sedan; the SL 2, a more luxurious sports sedan, and the SC sports coupe. Saturn executives have not decided on a price yet, but they say all three base models will start at between $10,000 and $12,000.
The cars will be distributed through a limited number of Saturn dealers, only 30 or so of which will be open when cars start arriving from the factory in Spring Hill, Tenn., on Oct. 25. Within a year that number should rise to more than 100. The first cars will be shipped mostly to California, where import buying is strongest, providing the truest test of the car's appeal.
 
Prospects for Success Uncertain
But as with any new vehicle model, Saturn's prospects for success are uncertain at best. The situation in Iraq and concern over the economy and energy prices have cast a shadow over an already-crowded automotive market. Indeed, a diplomatic or military crisis close to the time of the public introduction might overshadow advertising and promotional efforts.
Saturn executives say production and sales of the car will rise slowly over the next year. Depending on demand, production could exceed 200,000 cars annually. If Saturn reaches full production - and sells 80 percent to import buyers - it could win back as much as 1.5 percentage points of G.M.'s lost market share.
The new car's looks have already fooled some Americans. ''We were testing the car out on the street in Fort Lauderdale and some guy drove by yelling 'Buy American,' '' said Stan Sowler, chief of vehicle development for Saturn. ''We got a kick out of that.''
While the car seems different from other G.M. models in many ways, some people who have seen it say Saturn's exterior styling vaguely resembles that of other G.M. cars. Mr. Sowler acknowledged that many who have seen the car remarked on a strong resemblance to the Geo Storm sold by Chevrolet. Saturn stylists at first had considered bolder, more expressive lines, but surveys of potential customers convinced them it was a bad idea.
The SL 1 sedan, designed to compete with the Toyota Corolla and the Honda Civic, features many of the little touches that come as a result of careful engineering, such as a door that opens a few inches more than normal to allow easy entrances and exits.
Saturn's exterior, unlike its Japanese competitors, is mostly made of plastic panels bolted to a steel frame. The plastic is resilient, as a Saturn engineer demonstrated with a few swift kicks and no apparent damage.
The Saturn project was announced as a new G.M. subsidiary in 1985. Roger B. Smith, who retired in August as chairman, dedicated it to reinventing the way cars are designed, built and sold.
Before developing the car, Saturn executives had to create a new manufacturing organization and a new factory complex in Spring Hill. Engineers and managers were picked from within G.M., but the operating procedures were designed with less bureaucracy and far more flexibility than at regular G.M. divisions.

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Orders Down 0.8% in August

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Durable goods orders to manufacturers slid eight-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Government reported today. Analysts said the report indicated that there were cutbacks in business investment plans because of Middle East uncertainties.
The Commerce Department reported that the orders for durable goods, relatively expensive items expected to last more than three years, totaled a seasonally adjusted $127 billion after a revised 2.7 percent rise in July. 
Analysts saw special significance in the 11.2 percent drop, to $35.4 billion, in nonmilitary capital goods orders, which are often a barometer of business plans to expand and modernize.
 
Effects of Oil Rise Cited
''On the surface it seems to suggest that producers are wary about the economic outlook,'' said Gilbert Benz, an economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. ''There's no way that producer investment won't be affected by oil prices, particularly if they stay above $35 a barrel.''
Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, oil prices have soared from less than $15 a barrel to nearly $40. The price shock has further weakened an already sluggish economy that some economists say is slipping into a recession.
William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director for the United States Chamber of Commerce, said the decline in both new and unfilled orders meant the economy ''will fall into a recession in the fourth quarter.''
 
Rise in Consumer Spending
Another Commerce Department report today showed that consumers' spending and income grew at a sluggish pace last month. The department said August consumer spending was up five-tenths of 1 percent from July, but the June and July figures, at sixth-tenths of 1 percent and 1.2 percent, respectively, were slightly stronger than first reported.
Consumer spending represents about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. The report said personal income grew three-tenths of 1 percent in August.
In durable goods, military orders, which are often volatile, jumped 12.4 percent, to $8.4 billion, after a 5.6 percent decline in July. ''My guess is that almost all of that was due to the Persian Gulf,'' Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc. in Washington said. Excluding the military category, orders fell 1.6 percent.
Both electrical machinery and transportation categories posted gains while orders for nonelectrical machinery and primary metals fell.
 
Transportation Increase
Orders for transportation equipment rose 1.3 percent, to $35.2 billion, mostly for motor vehicles. Aircraft orders fell about $3 billion. Excluding the transportation category, durable goods orders fell 1.6 percent. Transportation orders jumped 4.5 percent in July.
Electrical machinery orders rose 2.6 percent, to $20.8 billion, after a 1.5 percent gain a month earlier.
But nonelectrical machinery orders fell 6.1 percent, to $21.2 billion, after rising 3.5 percent in July. Orders for primary metals slipped 1.7 percent, to $11.6 billion, after rising 2.8 percent the previous month.
Shipments of durable goods rose 2.9 percent, to $128.7 billion, in August, most of which consisted of motor vehicles. Shipments had fallen 1.8 percent in July.
Unfilled orders edged down three-tenths of 1 percent, to $499.3 billion, after rising six-tenths a month earlier.

HEADLINE: Spending And Income In Slow Rise

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The incomes and spending of Americans grew at a sluggish pace in August, the Commerce Department said today, adding fresh evidence that consumers pinched by rising energy prices are worried about a slowing economy.
Personal income went up by three-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.68 trillion, after an increase of five-tenths in July. It was the smallest income gain in four months, since a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in April. 
Spending picked up by only five-tenths of 1 percent last month, after rises of six-tenths in July and 1.2 percent in June. Spending in May was unchanged from a month earlier.
After adjusting the figures to eliminate the effect of inflation, spending fell by one-tenth of 1 percent in August, after gains of three-tenths in July and 1 percent in June.
 
Impact Since Iraq Move
The August spending drop showed the impact of higher inflation since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 that sent oil prices soaring.
Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, so reduced personal consumption eventually shows up in lower factory output.
Today's figures also showed that lower personal spending did not mean more money was going into bank accounts or investments, because personal savings fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $171 billion in August, from $179 billion in July and $182 billion in June.
As a percentage of disposable income after taxes, the personal savings rate went down last month, to 4.3 percent, from 4.5 percent in July and 4.6 percent in June. Commerce Department officials said that was the lowest savings rate in nearly a year, since a decline to 4 percent in September 1989.
 
Pool for Expansion
In many other countries, high personal savings rates create a pool of investment capital that can be borrowed for economic expansion. For example, Japan's savings rate is 15 percent and Canada's is 10 percent.
Total personal consumption spending dropped in August to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.69 trillion from $3.67 trillion in July.
Spending on durable goods was down to an annual rate of $480 billion, from $486 billion in July, but spending for nondurables went up slightly, to $1.2 billion from $1.19 billion. Spending on services increased to $2.01 billion last month from $2 billion in July.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
NCNB and Meridian Hurt by Bad Loans

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The NCNB Corporation and Meridian Bancorp yesterday joined a growing list of banking companies admitting that problems with real estate loans would hurt earnings in the third quarter.
Analysts are expecting many such reports. Already, the Chase Manhattan Corporation said it expects to lose $625 million in the third quarter because of losses on real estate loans and expenses associated with cutting its payroll by 5,000 workers. 
''This is shaping up as a wasted year for bank earnings,'' said Rai Archibold, a New York-based banking analyst at Fox-Pitt Kelton, a securities firm. ''Bankers are deciding that if they have problems, it is better to take action now rather than wait.''
NCNB, based in Charlotte, N.C., is the seventh-largest banking company in the country. It said that problem loans would reduce third-quarter profits to between $55 milliion and $65 million, down from $137.4 million in the second quarter. It said the loan problems required that $145 million be set aside as a reserve for losses in the third quarter, and that it would charge off as a loss $75 million to $85 million in loans.
Meridian, based in Reading, Pa., is the fourth-largest banking company in Pennsylvania. It said bad real estate and business loans were the primary reason for an expected third-quarter loss of about $35 million to $39 million, down from a profit of $21.1 million in the second quarter.
''The economy is getting worse before it gets better, and we decided this was a time to focus on our basic banking businesses,'' said Samuel A. McCullough, chairman of Meridian.
Besides setting aside a large reserve to cover its losses on real estate loans, Meridian plans to sell $300 million of credit card loans, about $300 million of automobile loans and its American Title Insurance subsidiary.
The stock of NCNB and Meridian fell sharply yesterday. NCNB, which did not announce its plans until late in the day, fell by $2.125 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, to $23.25, its lowest price of the year. Meridian's stock fell $1.50 a share in over-the-counter trading, to $11.75, also its lowest level of the year.

HEADLINE: Bankers, in Washington, Curb the Lavish Parties

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
When Citibank took over Union Station here last year for a party for hundreds of the world's most powerful bankers, it was a circus - literally.
''We hired a small European circus, and there were some acrobats, some jugglers and several other acts, including a guy in a bear outfit,'' said John Maloney, a Citibank spokesman.
But as international bankers and finance ministers gathered in Washington this week for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, the theme has been austerity - relatively speaking.
Major commercial banks are in trouble. The economies of several third world nations are nudging closer to collapse and a former World Bank executive created a stir by accusing the agency of waste and inefficiency in Washington Post articles. 
But the hosts and guests assembled this week in Washington appear to understand the public relations risk of extravagant entertaining.
 
Chase Sits It Out
Citibank says it will hold a few dinner parties to coincide with the annual meeting, but nothing like last year's lavish bash. The parent company of the Chase Manhattan Bank, which last week announced layoffs of nearly 5,000 people and a $1 billion charge against earnings, is not sponsoring any major public events.
The entertainment cutbacks may be helping the bankers' images, but it is hurting the limousine companies and catering services, who say that their business is off by as much as half compared with last year. Expensive restaurants like the Jockey Club, once known as Nancy Reagan's favorite Washington bistro, have tables available at short notice.
''It isn't a question of everything stopping,'' said William Brannigan of the World Bank. ''There is still quite an active social schedule. But obviously a lot of the big commercial banks, which were the big entertainers in years past, have either canceled or reduced their entertainment this year.
''It's probably only appropriate. I suppose if I were one of the 5,000 people let go by Chase and then I saw that Chase had thrown a big party, I'd be a little annoyed.''
 
Hotels Are Exception
One major exception to the new relative frugality is that the city's luxury hotels report that they are booked solid through Thursday, the last day of the three-day annual meeting.
''We have nothing available - no rooms, no suites, no broom closets,'' said a front desk receptionist at the Grand Hotel, known to be a favorite of Japanese and German bankers visiting the capital. The Grand's rates start at $200 a night, with two-bedroom suites costing $850.
While the bankers are making an effort to curb their public displays of big spending, they apparently drew the line at doing without the private luxury of a well-appointed hotel room. The catering departments in the hotels report far fewer cocktail receptions and formal dinners, however.
For many of the bankers, the emphasis is on the appearance of austerity in tough times. ''What they want to do is have a lower profile,'' said Keith McKoy, manager of the Washington office of Dav-El Limousine.
 
Limousines Go Begging
Instead of hiring a $50-an-hour stretch limousine, he said, many bankers are instead requesting his chauffeured Lincoln town cars, at $38 an hour. The price difference may not seem huge, but ''they don't want to be perceived as spending a lot of money on perks like limousines,'' he said.
Mr. McKoy did say that one group of clients did not cut back on long limos this year: bankers from the Middle East. Despite the turmoil in the Persian Gulf and the threat of war after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, he said, ''my clients from the Middle East are ordering cars and using them as much as last year.''
One of the week's more elaborate receptions was sponsored Monday night by a state-run bank from South Korea, the Korea Development Bank.
As guests entered the mammoth ballroom of the Omni Shoreham Hotel, they were greeted by a reception line of well-dressed Korean bankers who bowed as each guest passed through the ballroom doors and by a 10-foot-high ice sculpture of a pagoda. A placard with the bank's logo was imbedded in the fast-melting ice.
 
Luxury Not Up to Snuff
All manner of alcohol, including fine champagnes, flowed freely for the Koreans' guests. A rainbow of hors d'oeuvres, spread out over several tables, included smoked salmon, freshly shucked oysters, roast beef, vats of steak tartare and a variety of Korean delicacies served by young women dressed in traditional Korean robes. The guests were serenaded with Schubert by a trio brought in from the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore.
Yet even this was below the standards of years past, several bankers said, somewhat wistfully.
''It's a very nice little reception, but it's really not the sort of event that we'd been used to,'' said a British banker, holding a glass of champagne and laughing at what he insisted was his ''feigned pomposity.''
''I do remember the days when caviar was de rigueur at banking functions and there would be a dozen parties like this each night and they would be followed by dinners in the most wonderful restaurants,'' he said. He refused to give his name for fear of alienating his Korean clients.
''We certainly live well now,'' said a portly Italian banker who stood nearby, admiring the Korean ice pagoda as he nibbled on fresh shrimp and canapes. ''But I assure you, we lived better before.'' Citicorpd (Citibank)

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 25.99 on Signs of Weak Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks turned around again yesterday and continued to burrow deeper into negative territory as investor sentiment darkened, the price of oil rose another notch and new data showed that the economy was still weakening.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which slid as much as 42 points by noontime, was off 25.99 at the close, to 2,459.65.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said six waves of selling starting within an hour of the opening bell chopped 29 points off the Dow. 
A.T.& T., the nation's most widely held stock and one of the weakest of the blue chips today, dropped 3/8, to 31 1/2, after Joel D. Gross, telecommunications analyst for the Wall Street firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, trimmed his earnings estimates because of the weak economy.
It was the most actively traded stock on the New York Stock Exchange, with 7.4 million shares changing hands, and gave further confirmation that investors were abandoning even solid blue chips at the first sign of weakness.
Trading activity on the Big Board fell slightly, to 155.6 million shares, from 155.9 million a day earlier.
In another sign of the daily erosion of stock prices, 1,119 stocks dropped in price and 309 fell to new lows, while only 421 issues advanced in price and only 2 rose to new highs.
While much of Wall Street seemed to feel that a huge pool of capital was waiting to jump into the market, Ronald J. Hill, investment strategist for Brown Brothers Harriman, argued that the cash level was ''not so high.''
One thing that would lift the market quickly, he said, would be a resolution of what he called ''the stalemates.''
''Investors are giving up on the stalemates,'' he said. ''There's a stalemate in the Iraq crisis. There's a stalemate on the budget and there's a stalemate on lower interest rates. The longer the stalemates continue, the more likely the negative effects move deeper into the economy.''
In New York, the price of oil continued to move higher, ending the day at $38.67 a barrel, up $1.14. But in London, some analysts urged clients to get out of oil shares, arguing that even if war broke out, crude prices might not move much higher.
Although several analysts are still bullish on oil, nearly every leading oil stock fell yesterday. Among the Dow stocks, Chevron sank 1 1/8, to 76; Exxon 5/8, to 49 7/8; Texaco 5/8, to 62 5/8, and USX 3/8, to 31 5/8. Among other oil issues, ARCO fell 1 7/8, to 137; Unocal 1 1/8, to 32 1/8, and Pennzoil 2, to 77 5/8.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Commitment by Sumitomo For Denver Airport Project

 BODY:
The City and County of Denver, which are building the first new large airport in the United States in the last 20 years, closed a $319 million commitment from the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company yesterday for a tax-exempt variable rate financing to be used for the airport project.
Sumitomo Trust, one of Japan's premier financial institutions, is providing a letter of credit to support the Denver Airport System subordinate revenue bonds, with the initial issue providing $200 million and a subsequent one providing $100 million. 
The bonds will be issued next Wednesday as commercial-paper-type instruments, with the interest rate fixed for anywhere from overnight to 180 days at various rates. Goldman, Sachs & Company was the lead underwriter and remarketing agency for the transaction.
Goldman, also the lead undrwriter for a $700 million fixed-income issue for the airport's financing earlier this year, said the variable rate issue carried the highest short-term rating of P-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and of A-1+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The long-term debt is rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA by S.& P. According to some brokers outside the deal, this may be the largest tax-exempt financing to receive a letter of credit from Sumitomo.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
4-Year Treasury Notes Sell Well

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The Treasury held an unexpectedly successful auction of four-year notes yesterday, despite growing concerns about oil-fed inflation, Washington's failure to produce a budget agreement and a Government securities market that was otherwise uncommonly dull with minimal price changes.
Dealers said the market was surprised by the excellent reception given the $8.25 billion of 8.5 percent four-year notes because there was relatively little retail interest on Tuesday when the Treasury auctioned $11.5 billion of 8 1/8 percent two-year notes.
Not only was the ''cover'' unusually high - there were $28.3 billion in bids for the $8.25 billion of four-year notes - but dealers were also surprised by the absence of a ''tail,'' which is the difference between the high and average yields.
 
Highest Since March Sale
The bids produced an average yield of 8.53 percent, compared with 8.50 percent at the last auction of this maturity, on June 27, and was the highest since last March's sale, when the average yield was 8.58 percent. Meanwhile, the yield on the two-year notes fell to 8.14 percent, from the average of 8.18 percent at the Tuesday auction. 
''What the absence of a tail and the high cover tell us is that many small banks and other financial institutions were interested in the four-year notes,'' said Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of the giant Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo. ''The large amount of noncompetitive bids, $1.4 billion, also tells us that many individual investors were interested.''
One factor that may have drawn individual investors is that the four-year notes are issued in units of $1,000, compared with $5,000 for the two-year Treasury maturity. Another incentive was that the current average yield on money market funds, where many investors have been placing funds shifted from the stock market, is roughly 7.75 perent.
 
Concern on Funds Rate
Earlier in the session, many market participants were concerned about the persistently high Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans. Despite the Fed's infusion of reserves into the banking system, the funds rate held at 8.25 percent for most of the day before easing to 8 3/16 percent near the close. At 8.25 percent, the funds were 25 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, above the Fed's perceived target level.
Mr. Braverman said the firm funds rate was caused in large part by the reluctance of some large banks to borrow in the commercial paper market or through certificates of deposit. ''It is still far less expensive for banks to tap the funds market than issue commercial paper or C.D.'s,'' he added.
For example, he noted that while the 90-day commercial paper rate for ''top name'' banks ranged between 9.10 and 9.30 percent, many banks were being asked to pay more. Many banks are also paying substantially more on 90-day C.D.'s than the 8.35 percent quoted by dealers.
Meanwhile, many banks are charging Wall Street brokers 9.5 percent for temporary, often overnight, loans.
 
'Window Dressing' Seen
Robert H. Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank, said some of the upward pressure on the Federal funds rate could be attributed to ''some third-quarter window dressing'' by portfolio managers here and in Japan, where Sept. 30 marks the end of the fiscal half-year. Mr. Chandross also noted that the firm funds rate might also reflect the hesitancy of some smaller banks to lend reserves to the larger banks, which had considerable publicity later about their problems.
But the firm funds rate had little impact on the discount rates of Treasury bills until late in the day, when demand swelled. As a result, the discount rate on 90-day bills fell 6 basis points, to 7.31 percent; six-month bills lost 6 basis points, at 7.35 percent, and one-year bills declined 3 basis points, to 7.30 percent.
The closely watched Treasury long notes, the 8.75 percent issue due in August 2000, were offered late in the session at 98 18/32, up 2/32 on the day, while the yield held at 8.97 percent. The 10-year notes are increasingly being used as a comparison with the longest maturities of Japanese and West German Government securities because of the rising global demand for capital.
 
Japanese Yield Increases
The yield on the 10-year Japanese long bonds rose to 8.72 percent, from 8.68 percent the day before and 8.60 percent at the end of last week. The yield on the 10-year West German long bonds held steady at 9.11 percent, but it was still above the 9.03 percent of last Friday.
As for the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in August 2020, they were offered late in the day at 96 6/32, up by 1/32, while the yield held at 9.12 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Rise on Rumors Of Fighting in Middle East

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices overcame early choppy trading yesterday and settled higher amid unconfirmed rumors of fighting in the Middle East and worries that an already sluggish economy is giving way to inflation.
Gold settled $4.20 to $5.80 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in September at $406.60 an ounce. The December contract jumped as much as $10.80 before settling lower. 
Demand for gold was prompted by an uncomfirmed rumor around midday that an Iraqi jet had been shot down in the Persian Gulf. Higher crude oil prices and investor worries of inflation also helped the market along, analysts said.
 
Higher Gold Price Expected
''With oil prices approaching $40 and inflation, that changes the picture for gold,'' said Peter Cardillo, director of commodities research at Jesup, Josephthal & Company in New York. ''It puts gold at a higher level. We may see it trading at $435 to $440 in the coming days.''
On the New York Mercantile exchange, crude oil settled 3 cents lower to $1.14 higher, with November at $38.67 a barrel.
Analysts said platinum and silver extended losses from Tuesday on signs of weakening economic activity in the United States and a further decline in the Tokyo stock market.
Platinum futures settled $4.10 to $3.80 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with October at $448 an ounce.
Silver fell 4.2 to 3.6 cents on the Commodity Exchange, with September at $4.798 an ounce.
 
Effect on Farm Commodities
Agricultural commodities were also affected by the Middle East rumors. On the Chicago Board of Trade wheat rose, corn settled mixed and soybeans were lower.
Choppy trading throughout the day reflected a growing nervousness that the Middle East crisis could not be solved diplomatically, said John Frazier, director of the agricultural division for Gerald Inc.
Rumors that the Government might be interested in offering subsidized flour to the Soviet Union also contributed to wheat's gain.
Corn was mixed after large purchases of futures contracts by a big grain dealer prompted speculation of impending export sales of corn, Mr. Frazier said.
Soybeans extended Tuesday's losses as traders expected a bumper harvest and waited for the release of the Agriculture Department's quarterly grain stocks report after today's trading closes.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trading in Dollar Is Mixed After a Lackluster Session

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed yesterday against major currencies in thin and choppy trading.
Japanese and American banks refrained from heavy trading in the foreign exchange markets. Dealers said the institutional investors were catching up on paperwork because the first half of Japan's fiscal year as well as the calendar-year third quarter both end on Sunday. 
''It was a rather lackluster day in terms of liquidity,'' said Scott Horwitz, a trader at the Bank of Boston's office in New York.
The dollar closed in New York near its lowest levels of the session against the German mark, at 1.5660, down from 1.5735 late Tuesday. Renewed speculation about a possible interest rate rise in Germany after the two Germanys unite on Oct. 3 lifted the mark.
High oil prices continued to weigh down the Japanese yen. Worries about how Japan's oil-dependent economy will cope caused a big selloff on the Tokyo stock exchange yesterday and eroded confidence in the yen.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose, closing at 137.40 yen, up from 136.70 yen on Tuesday. Later, in London, it fell to 137.20 yen. The dollar traded at 136.855 yen late in New York, higher than late Tuesday's 136.70 yen.
Fresh news confirming the sluggishness of the United States economy, including durable goods, personal income and consumer spending data, was virtually ignored.
European currency dealers, meanwhile, said the dollar gained there on news that the United Nations Security Council had adopted a resolution to tighten its economic embargo against Iraq by halting air traffic into that country.
The dollar is usually seen as a haven in times of international tension.
The British pound fell to $1.8635 in London, from $1.8765 there late Tuesday. A pound fetched $1.8718 late in New York, compared with $1.8785 late Tuesday.
Against the German mark, the dollar was up late in the day in Europe, to 1.5715 marks, from 1.5630 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Sorry, I'm No Crime Fighter

BYLINE: By Janusz Glowacki; Janusz Glowacki is a playwright.

 BODY:
A day after Mayor Dinkins revealed his strategy to fight crime in New York with the ''city's greatest resource -our pride and collective will'' - I was stopped by a neighbor on my Lower East Side street.
This elderly lady grabbed my hand and, following the Mayor's appeal, demanded that I dismantle the iron window gates behind which my family and I had been hiding, and that I join a neighborhood block patrol.
With an insincere smile, I started to make excuses: I wear glasses, I never scored high in knife fights, I have a deadline for my play. The old lady looked at me scornfully and warned me that if anything should happen to her or to anyone on our block, the responsibility would be mine. 
Though brief, this encounter moved me, for it brought forth a flood of memories from my youth. Growing up in Poland, I was made to feel responsible, along with my fellow citizens, for the inefficiencies of our Communist Government. I was told that the shortage of food was caused by the voracious appetite of the Polish people, and that the lack of housing was the result of the Polish tendency to procreate.
Indeed, from time to time the Government introduced special strategies to solve economic problems. For example, surgeons were forced to help farmers with the harvest, and farmers were sent to hospitals to assist in the emergency room. Later, on TV, they would embrace and thank each other, and point out that socialism will prevail. However, unofficially, the farmers whispered that it often took a week to repair the damage caused by the surgeons during a single day. The surgeons whispered back that they needed much more time to make up for well-meaning farmers. The point of view of the sick was never released.
When Mayor Dinkins began his term by reducing the police force, I was a bit surprised, but not overly concerned. On my street, I am considered the lucky one. I've had two encounters with muggers. Once I managed to escape. The second time, though, I was caught and robbed. I sustained only a few bruises, which evoked the envy of all my neighbors.
When Mayor Dinkins recently called upon the ''good people'' of New York to take to the streets and wage war against crime, I was a bit more surprised. So far the police had appealed to New Yorkers not to do the job of the police, as often such attempts had tragic endings. The enthusiasm of good people, I suspect, is rarely efficient when confronted with guns and skillful criminals.
I would like to point out, for example, that President Bush didn't ask the Saudis to arm themselves with baseball bats and walkie-talkies and stand on their border. The President applied a more traditional strategy: he mobilized the Army, Navy, Air Force and the Marines. I'm ashamed to admit that this kind of solution appeals to me more.
Perhaps I am allergic to the strategies forced upon good people by authority. These strategies never worked in Poland. But perhaps I am wrong, and pessimistic, and the good people in New York are better than the good people in Poland, and New York will prevail.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.S. Pledges a Vigorous Response If Iraq Attacks Israel, Officials Say

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 27

 BODY:
United States officials have told Israel and its supporters in recent days that any Iraqi attack on Israel would set off a vigorous American response.
Administration officials have avoided stating categorically that if Israel were attacked, the United States would be prepared to commit American forces to Israel's defense, but Israeli officials said today that they had been left with this impression.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told Israel's Foreign Minister, David Levy, on Wednesday that the Bush Administration ''remains committed to Israel's security and you can count on that fact'' if Israel is attacked by Iraq, an Administration official said.
The American assurances, which came in a wide-ranging discussion about Israel's security requirements, followed a threat on Sunday by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to strike Saudi Arabia and Israel if the United Nations boycott ''strangled'' the Iraqi people.
But Israeli officials said that even though they appreciated the American assurances, they were concerned that, at a time of sharply increased threats to Israel, the Administration had yet to produce any new economic or military aid. 
Mr. Baker did not go into any detail about how the Administration would respond to an Iraqi attack, and Mr. Levy did not seek such details, Israeli and American officials said.
The United States and Israel do not have a mutual defense treaty, but successive American administrations have made a general commitment to maintain Israel's security and qualitative military edge over the Arabs. This is apparently the first time, however, that the United States has indicated that it might take direct military action in Israel's behalf.
One reason the United States has avoided commiting itself militarily in Israel's behalf was concern that this would compel the Soviet Union to enter the fray on the side of Israel's Arab enemies, provoking a global war. But in the current crisis, the Soviet Union has joined in condemning Iraq, and has warned Iraq that it runs the risk of being attacked if it does not pull out of Kuwait.
Speaking of Israel, an Administration official said, ''They have some legitimate concerns and we want to address them.''
The reason that President Bush has not publicly made this general assurance to Israel, officials explained, is that Washington does not want to ''give Saddam an Israel issue'' to rally Arab support. At the same time, though, the Administration does not want the Iraqi leader to believe there is any ambivalence in its commitment to Israel.
 
Fighters in the Skies
For this reason, American officials were also reluctant to discuss the substance of the American assurances.
One reason they want to put Israelis at ease is that they would prefer that Israel not become involved alone in a conflict with Iraq. President Hussein could exploit such a situation, turning the gulf crisis into a case of Iraq against Israel instead of Iraq against the world.
American officials said that Israel took the threat from President Hussein seriously enough to maintain a group of fighter aircraft in the skies over Israel 24 hours a day to defend against any Iraqi missile that might be launched.
It is not immediately clear how the United States would respond to an Iraqi attack on Israel. It would be unrealistic to expect that Saudi Arabia would allow American fighter jets and troops based in Saudi Arabia to come to the defense of Israel. But the United States has an aircraft carrier in the eastern Mediterranean, several squadrons of advanced fighter jets in Turkey and B-52 bombers based in Diego Garcia, in the Indian Ocean. American officials declined to speculate on how they might respond.
Officials said that in his 90-minute meeting with Mr. Baker, Mr. Levy explained that before last Sunday, President Hussein was talking about ''retaliating'' against Israel with chemical weapons for any Israeli attack on Iraq. But Sunday, he changed his threat and began talking about an Iraqi first strike against on Israel.
 
Low Profile Is Called Hard
Mr. Levy said that given the new threat, the Israeli leadership could not be expected to sit idly and maintain the low profile Washington prefers at this time.
He said that when all of Israel's neighbors were either getting American, Japanese or European funds or new American weapons to bolster their ability to resist Iraq, Israel was getting nothing from anyone. The Israeli official also asserted that Israel was the most likely primary target for Baghdad.
Mr. Baker responded, according to officials, that Washington appreciated Israel's low profile, which was making it easier for the United States to assemble an Arab coalition against Iraq. But he said that Israel should keep in mind that the United States has 200,000 troops stationed in the region and that these constituted a deterrent to any Iraqi attack on Israel.
''Levy indicated that there was some urgency to our needs,'' a senior Israeli official said. ''Our impression is that there is no urgency on the Administration's part. We get a lot of nice messages about what good boys we are for keeping a low profile, but no money yet and no arms. Everyone is being looked after but us.''
As far as Israel's aid requests, Mr. Baker said that the Administration was prepared to deal with them sympathetically, but in a ''phased manner.'' That is, he explained, given budgetary constraints in Washington, the United States was not in a position to suddenly produce a multibillion dollar arms and economic aid package for Israel. Unlike the Saudis, who purchase their arms in cash, the Israelis are dependent on American grants and easy credits.
 
Surprise from Arens
Two weeks after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, when the United States was asking Israel to stay as much out of sight as possible and not send any ministers to Washington, David Ivri, the director general of the Israeli Defense Ministry, met in Washington with Reginald Bartholomew, Undersecretary of State for Security Assistance, and Henry S. Rowen, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs. He asked that Israel be given two batteries of Patriot anti-missile missiles and 15 F-15A fighter planes, which the United States is retiring from its stocks in Europe. Mr. Ivri was told that both requests would be met, Israeli officials said.
A month later, on Sept. 17, Israel's Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, asked to see Defense Secretary Dick Cheney at the Pentagon. Mr. Arens surprised American officials by saying that in addition to the F-15A's and the Patriots, Israel needed an emergency infusion of $1 billion in aid to buy advanced American fighter planes, as well as an increase in its annual military assistance grant from $1.8 billion to $2.5 billion.
Mr. Arens argued that Israel's oil import costs had increased by $500 million a year as a result of the gulf crisis, that its need to keep more aircraft in the air had sent its military budget out of kilter and that, in light of the new weapons being acquired by its Arab neighbors, the only way Israel could maintain any kind of qualitative edge would be through purchases of the most advanced fighter jets, not F-15A's that were produced in 1976.
 
Some Private Complaints
Mr. Cheney told Mr. Arens that the Israeli request would be ''considered,'' but made no promises. Israeli officials said they came away from the Cheney meeting with the impression that their requests would be treated more sympathetically if they did not complain publicly about the proposed $21 billion in arms sales to Saudi Arabia, which has now gone ahead in two packages. American officials said that an earlier article in The New York Times saying that the United States was preparing to transfer $1 billion in military equipment to the Israelis was inaccurate.
Meanwhile, Israeli officials have begun to complain privately that even the promised Patriot missiles and F-15A's don't seem to be forthcoming.
Pentagon officials say they are not dragging their feet. There is a great deal of competition for the surplus of F-15A's between Turkey, the Philippines and the American Air National Guard, and that trying to satisfy everyone's requests takes time to coordinate. Approval for the Patriots, which would be given to Israel, is working its way through the bureaucracy.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
KUWAITI EMIR ASKS U.N. TO STAND FIRM

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 27

 BODY:
The Emir of Kuwait came before the United Nations General Assembly today to plead for his country's liberation from Iraq, urging the organization to stand by the sanctions it has imposed on Iraq as he offered poor third-world countries relief on debts to Kuwait.
Dressed in traditional Arab robes, the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, received an ovation as he arrived in the packed Assembly hall just in time to see the Iraqi delegation ostentatiously stalking out. He was also applauded loudly at the end of his speech, spoken in Arabic and lasting barely 10 minutes.
Speaking softly and rapidly, as is his fashion, the Emir said that ''the multitude of resolutions'' the United Nations Security Council had passed condeming and punishing Iraq showed ''the rock-solid international rejection of the assassination of the norms of international law, rules of good-neighborly relations and established customs and practices at the hands of armed military invaders whose tanks rolled over and crushed these concepts.'' [Excerpts from speech, page A7.] The Emir of Kuwait, who is not often seen in public and rarely travels outside the Middle East, came to the United Nations with several other members of his government in exile, Arab diplomats said, to dramatize his country's plight, lobby for support and establish his position as head of his country's legitimate Government. 
Iraq, which occupied Kuwait on Aug. 2, has annexed it, but that action has met with worldwide condemnation, and other countries continue to recognize the Emir's Government as the legitimate one.
He is scheduled to travel to Washington on Friday to meet President Bush and return to New York on the weekend to attend the World Summit for Children organized by the United Nations Children's Fund.
 
International Tragedy
His General Assembly address today, though short and low-key, was strenuously endorsed by Arabs who oppose Iraq. Syria's Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, said afterward that the Emir's address ''reflects the agony that the Kuwaitis are feeling about the Iraqi invasion.''
Prince Saud al-Faisal, Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister, said the Emir had ''stressed not only the tragedy to the country of Kuwait but the tragedy to the whole international community from this crisis.''
Saudi Arabia's Ambassador in Washington, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, said the Emir had ''spoken to the conscience of the world.'' The address showed ''Kuwait's generosity in talking about haves and have-nots and debt forgiveness,'' Prince Bandar said.
Urging the General Assembly and the Security Council to stand fast and maintain pressure on Iraq to withdraw, the Emir said, ''We trust that you will not waver in deciding on the measures needed to compel the invading aggressors to restore the legitimate authority and put an end to their barbaric acts and deviations.''
On a day when representatives of several of the world's poorest nations, including Bangladesh, also addressed the General Assembly, Sheik Jaber sought to counter Iraq's attempts to portray Kuwait as a rich and selfish princedom and the invasion as a blow struck on behalf of millions of poor Arabs from lands without oil.
He said Kuwait had always been generous with its assistance to poorer countries, adding that the nation had the highest ratio of aid to gross national product of any donor nation in the world.
''From the earliest years of independence, my country has been privileged to be in the forefront of states that gave development aid to other countries,'' he said.
Recalling a plea for more debt relief for poorer nations he made to the General Assembly two years ago, Sheik Jaber said the Kuwaiti government in exile, which he heads, would forgive the world's poorest countries interest payments on loans it had made them.
 
'Terror and Torture' the Rule
He also hinted that Kuwait might be willing to write off some of those debts completely, saying, ''Kuwait will consider with the poorest nations arrangements regarding the principal of its loans with a view to easing the burden of their debt.''
Sheik Jaber presented Kuwait as a small, peace-loving country that had been suddenly and brutally attacked as it was trying to negotiate a solution to Iraq's complaints against it.
Iraq, he said, was ''bent on sweeping through the entire territory of Kuwait, violating its sovereignty and violating the sanctity of Kuwaiti citizens' lives and property.''
''Rape, destruction, terror and torture are now the rule of the day in the once peaceful and tranquil land of Kuwait,'' he said. ''Hundreds of thousands of Kuwaiti citizens, along with nationals of various other countries who were our guests, have been homeless, and many of them have had their life savings robbed. Hundreds have lost their lives. Others have been made hostage.''
 
Changes in Nicaragua
In her address to the General Assembly, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua said her country had experienced ''a new taste for liberty and respect for human rights'' since she defeated the Sandinistas in United Nations-supervised elections seven months ago.
During that time, she said, the Nicaraguan Army has been reduced from 96,000 to 34,000, compulsory military service abolished and 18,000 rifles belonging to various political parties ''buried in concrete.''
Bangladesh's President, Gen. Hussain Muhammad Ershad, who has sent armed forces to Saudi Arabia, emphasized the economic hardship that the gulf crisis was causing for his country and many other of the world's poorest nations.
He mentioned the cost of repatriating and housing thousands of workers fleeing from the gulf, the loss of their remittances, reduced exports and higher oil bills.

HEADLINE: WITH ACCORD NEAR, BUDGET TALK FOCUS IS SOCIAL SECURITY

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept 27

 BODY:
White House and Congressional budget negotiatiors, in substantial agreement on most elements of a budget deal, today returned to the politically explosive subject of cuts in Social Security benefits in a search for the final savings needed to meet their deficit reduction goals.
Both sides have agreed that savings in Social Security are needed, but differences remain on how to apportion the burden. The decision to even look for savings in the Social Security program is so perilous for both parties, particularly in an election year, that it could risk the collapse of any chance for compromise.
 
Differences Are Narrowed
The negotiators, who planned to meet late into the night, have narrowed their differences to two basic issues: the Social Security savings and a way to pay for an Administration proposal that would exclude the portion of the profit on capital gains attributable to inflation.
White House negotiators formally advanced the proposal, known as indexing, today as an alternative to the outright cut in the capital gains tax rate that President Bush has sought. The emergence of the indexing proposal Wednesday injected new optimism into negotiations that had virtually deadlocked on the tax issue. 
The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said he hoped a deal on the budget package was imminent. He said that the negotiators have ''tentatively agreed'' to much of the budget package. Democratic leaders have scheduled a rare Sunday session of Congress to vote on a stop-gap spending bill needed to keep the Government running after Sunday, the end of the fiscal year, with or without a budget agreement.
 
Great Pressure on Democrats
However, Social Security cuts were so unpopular with older voters in the 1982 and 1986 Congressional elections that no one on Capitol Hill was flatly predicting that a deal would take place or that Social Security would be in the final package.
But the Democrats, who have held themselves up as champions of Social Security, are under great pressure. Officials involved in their deliberations said the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, told his House counterparts today that he was not certain that he could deliver enough votes from Democratic senators to assure passage of an alternative Democratic budget. Democrats had hoped that if negotiations with the White House failed, they could get a plan of their own through Congress.
The Republicans' Social Security proposal is a one-time delay of two months in the annual cost-of-living adjustment in Social Security benefits. But Democrats argue that such a delay is unfair because it would amount to lower benefits for even the poorest retirees.
 
Democrats Would Raise Tax
The Democrats have proposed an increase in the tax that Social Security recipients now pay on a portion of their benefits, arguing that this would require wealthier retirees to bear a bigger share of the burden. Under current law, Social Security beneficiaries who are single and have incomes above $25,000 a year are taxed on 50 percent of their benefits, while married recipients with incomes of more than $32,000 are taxed on 50 percent of their benefits. Democrats are discussing raising that level to 85 percent.
''Increasing the tax is one giant step towards making Social Security a means tested program,'' said Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the senior Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee. Such a tax increase may prove nearly as unpoular with rank-and-file Democrats, which is one of the reasons the Democratic leaders spent much of today huddled in meetings trying to decide if they were prepared to even contemplate it.
The discussion of increasing taxes on Social Security benefits represents a sharp turnaround from discussions only a few months ago about cuts in Social Security taxes. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat, caused a political firestorm in earlier this year with a proposal to reduce the payroll taxes that finance the Social Security system.
Mr. Moynihan has long complained that surpluses in the Social Security trust fund that were intended to pay benefits to the generation of babies born after World War II after they retire in the early part of the 21st century were being improprerly used to mask the size of the Federal deficit. He has argued that unless the Government removes the Social Security trust fund from its deficit calculations, the surplus should be returned to workers in the form of a cut in the Social Security payroll taxes.
 
Looking for $50 Million Cut
Officials close to the deliberations said Democrats could not meet the budget neogtiators' goal of reducing domestic spending by $120 billion over five years unless they found savings in the Social Security program. Over all, the negotiators are seeking to cut the deficit by $50 billion in the fiscal year 1991 and $500 billion over five years.
Democrats must also decide whether a stop-gap spending bill would also include a delay in huge automatic spending cuts that take effect on Monday under provisions of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law. President Bush has said that in the absence of a budget accord, he will veto a bill that calls for such a delay.
Negotiators spent part of the day wrestling with the Administration's latest proposal, the indexing of capital gains for inflation. Officials close to the the deliberations said the indexing plan would cost the Treasury about $4.5 billion in lost revenue over five years, considerably less than the $21 billion revenue loss for the actual cut in the capital gains tax rate that Mr. Bush had sought.
The officals said that as currently structured, the proposal would begin the indexing arrangement on Jan. 1, 1991. That means that while it would apply to both current and newly acquired assets, investors would not realize any tax break on their asset sales until they file their returns in 1992. Capitial gains, the profits on the sale of real estate, stock, timber and other assets, are now taxed at the same rate as ordinary income, or 28 percent for most taxpayers.
While Democrats continue to insist that the indexing must be offset by some tax increase for the wealthier Americans, who would benefit most from it, they note that Republicans may have an easier time finding such an offset under indexing because the amount of revenue involved would be so much smaller.
 
Floor on Deductions Proposed
Democrats have suggested an offsetting tax increase that would place a floor on deductions for wealthier taxpayers, a proposal so far rejected by Republicans, who say it amounts to a tax rate increase. Conceptually, the proposal accomplishes the same thing as a ceiling on itemized deductions, essentially reducing the amount of deductions to which wealthier taxpayers would otherwise be entitled.
The Democratic proposal is based on a suggestion by Representative Don Pease, a liberal Democrat from Ohio and a member of the Ways and Means Committee.
A deduction ceiling was, in fact, suggested at one point in the negotiations by the White House Budget Director, Richard G. Darman. But Mr. Pease and other Democrats see the notion of a floor on deductions as more politically palatable for both parties than a ceiling because it would not discourage contributions to charities or raise the anger of the housing industry.
Assuming the proposal applied to married taxpayers with taxable income of more than $100,000, or $50,000 for single taxpayers, it would work like this: A married couple with taxable income of say $200,000 would subtract $100,000 from that amount. They would then take 5 percent of the remaining $100,000, or $5,000, which would become their deduction floor.
