HEADLINE: Anticipation, Not Actuality, Holds Sway Over Oil Prices

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Brushing aside President Bush's decision on Wednesday to tap the Stategic Petroleum Reserve as a test, traders pushed oil prices up to near $40 a barrel yesterday as worries about the conflict in the Middle East continued to dominate the markets. But so far, the run-up, which has more than doubled oil prices since the beginning of summer, reflects expectations, not reality.
''We're not one barrel short yet on a global basis,'' said Anthony E. Reinsch, vice president of the Canadian Energy Research Institute in Calgary, Alberta. ''The price appears to reflect the anticipated impact of a global shortage.''
Moreover, the anticipation could be worse than the outcome. No one knows just what a war would bring, of course, or what the effect would be on oil supplies. Some analysts, looking at the bidding in the oil markets so far, say the price could reach $65 a barrel, maybe more. The former Saudi oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said yesterday that it could reach $100 if his country's fields were damaged. 
Oil prices in New York trading rose 87 cents yesterday, to $39.54, the highest since 1980. Traders took little notice of the decision to test a release from the strategic reserve, a stockpile that could contribute up to 3.5 million barrels a day for months. [Page D1.] One school of experts finds the oil market's anxieties about the Middle East conflict greatly exaggerated. Indeed, they note that depending on the nature of the military action, the price could come down quickly in the event of fighting between the United States and Iraq, largely because nearly half of the current price reflects not actual scarcity but anticipation of war.
Thus the world is already absorbing much of any wartime price increase, without the war. If and when action on the battlefield makes a war effect clearer, the price could plummet, especially if the Iraqis fail to dislodge the 150,000 American troops that stand between them and the Saudi oilfields. One lesson of the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, experts say, is that without control on the ground, it is hard to disrupt oilfields and oil terminals more than briefly.
The initial market reaction to a war might approach panic, however. Thomas R. McHale, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, said that at first ''psychologically, people are going to worry about having inventory; they'll pay anything for it.'' But, he added, ''then it will sink in, the fact that there is sufficient physical oil.''
The popular image of oil in a war zone is from the movies, the submarine skipper sighting the ''nice fat tanker'' in the periscope crosshairs. But in real life, oil targets have proved hard to knock out for any extended period. Colombian guerrillas, for example, have repeatedly bombed oil pipelines in that country but their most recent attacks have shut the lines for only a few days at a time.
Oil tankers, as the Iranians and Iraqis learned in their war, are much harder to set afire than most people had imagined.
In eight years of desperate effort, experts point out, Iraq could not stop Iran's exports, and Iran did not have the help of protection from the United States military as Saudi Arabia and other Gulf exporters do.
The war and the revolution did hurt Iran's production, which now runs at about three million barrels a day, half what the Shah's regime managed. But most of the Iranian shortfall is a result of lack of capital and personnel, a problem that presumably would not afflict Saudi Arabia or Kuwait.
 
Terminals Prove Tough
Export terminals may be hard to disrupt for long periods, too; the Iraqis tried hard but never knocked out Iran's Kharg Island for more than a few days at a time. And Saudi Arabia, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly noted recently, could export 7.5 million barrels a day, or very nearly as much as it could produce, from any two of its three largest terminals. One of those three is Yanbu, on the Red Sea, far out of reach of direct Iraqi attack.
Oil refineries are a more vulnerable target; in fact, they have a tendency to explode in times of peace. But some military analysts say that they, too, would be hard to disable for long periods.
And all this equipment is ancillary to the main asset of the Persian Gulf, oil in the ground.
''You cannot destory oilfields,'' said Charles T. Maxwell, the senior energy strategist at C. J. Lawrence, Morgan, Grenfell. ''You can blow up pieces of equipment on the surface, measuring devices, valves and so on, but those can be flown over from Houston the next day. There's lots of that around.'' He predicted that half of Kuwaiti production could be restored in 30 days, and the rest in three months.
Others see different problems in Kuwait, saying the threat to its wells is not from aircraft above, but from demolition experts on the ground. James R. Schlesinger, who has served as Energy Secretary and Defense Secretary, said, ''If we do come to war, the Kuwaiti oilfields will likely be destroyed for a year or a year and a half.
''Right now, there are explosives on Christmas trees,'' Mr. Schlesinger said, referring to the tree-like array of valves on top of each well. ''And they can put explosives down in the bore hole.'' After that sort of destruction, a well would probably have to be redrilled, he said.
Other experts said that most of the Kuwaiti wells flow by natural pressure, so getting explosives into them would be a technical problem, requiring pumping the oil back down first.
Still, the markets are clearly nervous about damage. ''All you would need is a few headlines saying Iraqi troops are advancing on Saudi oilfields, or a few missiles,'' said George F. Friesen of the Deutsche Bank Group. ''Even if they didn't hit the oil installations, that would build up anticipation.''
 
Some Price Predictions
Mr. Friesen was reluctant to offer numbers. Last week, the World Bank said, however, that if a war did long-term damage to the Iraqi and Kuwaiti fields, oil prices would rise to $65 a barrel, dropping to $45 in 1992 and $20 by 2000. In contrast, the price was less than $20 a barrel before tensions between Iraq and Kuwait began to build in July.
But another school of thought holds that if a war broke out, oil prices would fall quickly and sharply.
''It should shoot up by about $20 on the day of the war,'' Mr. Maxwell said, ''and $5 on the next day. On the day after, when it becomes clear that the American forces are winning and the Iraqi forces are not able to wreak damage on the Saudi refineries with their missiles, it will fall $5, and the next day, fall $15. Within two months of the start of the war, the price of oil will cross back over the $22 line.''
 
Hitting the Water Supply
Mr. Maxwell added that it would not be difficult for American forces to cripple the Iraqi army, by destroying the desalinization plant that supplies 80 percent of Kuwait's water and hitting other vulnerable points, forcing Saddam Hussein to withdraw.
A short war won by those allied against Iraq would remove the threat to Saudi exports, analysts point out, and even if one result of the destruction would be no Kuwaiti or Iraqi oil for years to come, production from other sources is probably now roughly equal to world consumption. Thus, prices would fall. Others are not so optimistic. Mr. Schlesinger contends that at a time of uncertainty, comparing global need with global supply is inappropriate; more relevant, he says, is the reaction of oil companies or even individual homeowners, who will cling to their inventories and seek more.
Mehdi Varzi, an oil expert at Kleinwort Grieveson Securities in London and a former Iranian diplomat, said that the price is now at $40 a barrel and not higher because the market is expecting ''a clean victory; it may be slightly bloody, but it's quick and there's no disruption of Persian Gulf exports.''
''Given the history of Middle East wars, when there is decisive technical superiority on one side, it tends to be over pretty quickly,'' he said.
In the longer term, prices would tend to fall because people will use less, but no one is sure how much less.

HEADLINE: Quebec Mohawks' Standoff With Soldiers Ends in Melee

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Sept. 27

 BODY:
After 11 weeks of armed confrontation near the resort town of Oka, Quebec, the standoff between Government soldiers and a group of Mohawk Indians ended in a melee on Wednesday night.
The Mohawk warriors and about 22 women and children laid down their arms and left the Kanesatake drug and alcohol treatment center, where they had held out against Canadian soldiers who had surrounded them.
But as the Indians tried to walk toward the town of Oka, scuffling broke out, and the soldiers tried to herd them into military tents and buses that were waiting nearby. It appeared that in a last act of defiance, the Mohawks left the center and veered off toward the town rather than in the direction they had agreed to earlier in the day, according to a military spokesman. 
After several minutes of scuffling, the army succeeded in forcing the Indians onto school buses that took them to a military base for questioning. A military spokesman said they would be brought before a Quebec judge who would determine whether charges would be lodged against any of them.
 
Mulroney's Popularity Falls
In Ottawa, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney praised the armed forces for helping to bring about the settlement and added that the Government had made no concessions.
The messy end to the long standoff comes at a troubled time for Mr. Mulroney and his Progressive Conservative Party. According to the latest Gallup Poll, his approval rating among Canadian voters has fallen to 15 percent, the lowest of any Western leader. The country is on the brink of a recession, and the Prime Minister is in a bitter legislative battle over an unpopular value added tax that he is determined to push through Parliament.
Alongside these other more immediate problems, the issue of how Canada will satisfy the demands of its native peoples is growing pricklier for the Government, and some of his opponents say Mr. Mulroney has not even begun to address these demands.
''The Mulroney Government believed it was impossible to negotiate with the people who were behind the lines,'' said Robert Rae, the Premier-elect of Ontario, whose New Democratic Party won an upset victory in parliamentary elections on Sept. 6.
''They decided to tough it out,'' he said of Mr. Mulroney's representatives. ''And that approach has left us with a legacy of bitterness.''
The Oka crisis began in the spring as a municipal disagreement over the town's plan to expand a golf course onto land that the Mohawks claimed as their own. It quickly grew into armed violent confrontation with the Quebec provincial police, and eventually the military was called in. don't cut last graf.

HEADLINE: De Klerk's Trip Lifts His People's Hopes

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 27

 BODY:
President F. W. de Klerk's trip to the United States this week has encouraged South African whites to believe that his policies may be breaking their country out of the international isolation that came about as a result of apartheid.
Even though economic sanctions have not fallen away, the visit, in which President de Klerk was out of the country for only four days, showed whites that his policies of change are being taken seriously in the United States.
Mr. de Klerk flew home on Wednesday night and was greeted at the airport by several hundred supporters, a somewhat smaller crowd than had turned out for Nelson Mandela when he came back from his lengthy foreign tour in July.
''We will soon be accepted back in the international community,'' Mr. de Klerk told the small but enthusiastic crowd. ''There is understanding for what we are doing.'' 
''We will do a thing which will echo through the centuries,'' Mr. de Klerk said, referring to his promise to dismantle apartheid and extend political rights to the black majority. ''We will build a new South Africa.''
 
Another Meeting Sought
Today, the African National Congress asked Mr. de Klerk to arrange another meeting between his Government and the congress leadership to get their negotiating process back on track after the violence that has racked black townships around Johannesburg. Gill Marcus, speaking for the A.N.C., said a third ''summit'' meeting had been requested for next week, before Mr. Mandela leaves on another foreign trip on Oct. 7. The first two meetings took place in Cape Town in May and in Pretoria last month.
Even before his South African Airways jetliner touched down here, Mr. de Klerk was drawing criticism from both political flanks - the congress, which contends he is not moving fast enough, and the Conservative Party, which accuses him of overreaching the mandate given him by white voters last September.
Thabo Mbeki, the congress's secretary for international affairs, said in a speech at the University of Pretoria on Wednesday that the change set in motion was not yet irreversible and that sanctions should not be discarded.
And Andries Treurnicht, the leader of the right-wing Conservative Party, which forms the official opposition in Parliament, issued a statement saying, ''As a white South African, I feel humiliated by both President de Klerk and President Bush.''
 
Gratification over U.S. Trip
Mr. Treurnicht said Mr. de Klerk appeared to be reneging on his promise to submit a negotiated new constitution to white voters in an election or referendum, because Mr. de Klerk said in Washington that the last white election had already been held.
But other white South Africans seemed gratified today that there was some appreciation in the United States for what President de Klerk was trying to do. Though he received a warm welcome in nine Western European nations in May, a trip to the United States was considered essential for setting a climate for South Africa's new acceptance, in part because the most stringent sanctions were set by Congress in 1986.
''The visit was far more successful than what anyone here had hoped,'' said Carl A. Noffke, director of the Institute of American Studies at Rand Afrikaans University.
The Star of Johannesburg, in an editorial Wednesday, said President Bush's acknowledgment that the process of reform was ''irreversible'' would have important consequences for South Africa.
''Irreversible is a code word which could begin to dismantle the machinery of sanctions in America and Europe,'' the newspaper said.
And The Citizen, a pro-Government tabloid, today hailed Mr. de Klerk's visit to Washington. In its editorial today, The Citizen said that ''our re-entry into the community of nations is assured.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: As part of South Africa's pledge to free political prisoners, eight members of the African National Congress were released from Robben Island prison yesterday. They arrived by ferry in Cape Town. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Kaifu Outlines His Proposal For Unarmed Japanese in Gulf

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu unveiled a long-awaited proposal today to send unarmed military personnel to the Persian Gulf in a noncombat role.
It would be the first time since World War II that Japanese military forces would be given a mission overseas. The measure, presented on the eve of Mr. Kaifu's departure for the United States, is designed to counter accusations that despite its $4 billion package of financial aid, Japan is not doing enough in the Middle East.
But it was far from clear whether Mr. Kaifu's proposal could be approved by the Japanese Parliament in the coming months. 
Criticism of the legislation has already begun in the upper house, which is controlled by a coalition of opposition parties led by the Socialists. China and other Asian countries that were the victims of Japanese aggression in World War II are also opposing the plan.
Moving to resolve an unusually bitter debate within his own Government, Mr. Kaifu told a news conference this evening that unarmed defense agency personnel could go abroad to provide transportation, equipment maintenance, communication facilities and medical care.
 
Size Unspecified
''The gulf crisis showed us that Japan has no system whereby it could cooperate with the United Nations to contribute to peace,'' the Prime Minister said, adding that a ''peace cooperation'' team of military people, civilian officials and private volunteers would be based in his own office.
Mr. Kaifu did not specify the size of the force, but other officials have said it would number in the thousands. He said that because the new contingent would neither use nor threaten force, it would not violate the ban on the use of force in the Japanese Constitution.
Mr. Kaifu is to leave on Friday for the United States after an extraordinary period in which he has been troubled by party infighting and a series of blows to his political prestige.
He plans to confer with President Bush and to make several public appearances, including television interviews and a news conference, to counter what Japanese officials fear is a tide of resentment over Japan's role in the Persian Gulf.
''Before this latest crisis, we used to think that the Japan-U.S. relationship had bottomed out,'' a Japanese official said this week, referring to tensions earlier this year over trade and economic issues.
 
A Vigorous Debate
Politicians say Mr. Kaifu will also be trying to repair his own reputation at home, which has been battered by Japan's indecision over the gulf and other embarrassments, including a racist comment by a Cabinet member.
Next week, the Prime Minister will travel to Egypt, Jordan, Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Oman to provide details of its $2 billion emergency package of economic aid to help the countries hardest hit after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
Another $2 billion has been proposed to assist the multinational military effort by supplying housing, medical equipment and vehicles and by paying for the shipment of military supplies other than arms and ammunition.
A vigorous debate has opened in Japan over the wisdom of increasing Japan's role in the Middle East. Some Japanese fear that Tokyo might be drawn into internecine Arab warfare, while others accuse the nation of inaction in the face of a threat to its dependence on foreign oil.
There has also been disarray in Mr. Kaifu's cabinet. Defense agency officials wanted to send personnel to the gulf, but the move was opposed by others. The Foreign Ministry has sought more economic aid, but Finance Ministry officials replied that there was no money.
Mr. Kaifu has been accused of paying too much and too little attention to President Bush's demands. There are jokes about the Prime Minister's ''Bush-phone,'' a play of words referring to the Japanese term ''push-phone'' for a push-button telephone.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
House Panel Backs Bush on Gulf Crisis, but Avoids Endorsing War

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved a resolution today that endorsed President Bush's handling of the Persian Gulf crisis but carefully avoided giving him open-ended support for military action against Iraq.
Mr. Bush has not asked Congress to approve military action, nor would he necessarily do so before sending American forces into combat. But some lawmakers, mostly Democrats, wanted to signal the White House that they are not yet prepared to see the United States go to war in the Persian Gulf. The resolution is not binding. At the same time, lawmakers wanted to make clear to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that Congress opposes Baghdad's invasion of Kuwait. 
The resolution, which was adopted unanimously by the panel and is likely to win quick House approval, praised Mr. Bush's reliance on international sanctions approved by the United Nations Security Council.
''The United States shall continue to use diplomatic and other nonmilitary means, to the extent possible, in order to achieve those objectives and policies, while maintaining credible United States and multinational deterrent military force,'' the resolution said.
 
Arms Sale to the Saudis
As Congress debated the resolution, President Bush sent to Capitol Hill the first part of a $21 billion arms sale to Saudi Arabia. The initial phase, valued by the Pentagon at $6.7 billion, includes 150 M-1A2 battle tanks, 6 Patriot antimissile batteries, 200 Bradley fighting vehicles and 150 TOW antitank missile launchers.
In a much smaller deal, the Pentagon announced the sale of 27 M-60A3 tanks to Bahrain for $37 million.
The Administration originally sought to submit the Saudi sale in one large package, but supporters of Israel on Capitol Hill threatened to fight the deal.
As the Saudi arms sale went to Capitol Hill, senior officials from the State Department, Defense Department and the White House met today in New York and Washington with about 40 prominent American Jews to repeat the Administration's pledge to maintain Israel's military superiority in the Middle East.
 
'Received Assurances'
''We received reassurances across the board that America is committed to Israel's security and considers Israel as a strategic asset,'' Abraham H. Foxman, national director of the Anti-Defamation League, said.
Mr. Foxman said the Administration officials, including Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, made no explicit promises about American military aid to Jerusalem, but left no doubt that the United States would ''continue to keep Israel's qualitative edge.''
Despite the Administration's efforts, some lawmakers continued to express reservations about the Saudi sale, arguing that some of the weapons could not be delivered readily and thus met no immediate Saudi needs. Production of the M-1A2 tank, for example, is not scheduled to begin until November 1992.
''I still have doubts about this since it was my understanding that only truly emergency items would be included in this package,'' said Representative Mel Levine, Democrat of California, a supporter of Israel.
 
Hearing Planned Next Week
A Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, described the arms included in the sale as ''material they urgently need for their defense,'' but Mr. Williams could provide no immediate explanation when the M-1A2 tanks could be delivered.
The Foreign Affairs Committee has scheduled a hearing for next Thursday, at which Administration officials will be asked to explain the urgency of the sale.
Some lawmakers said that by selling a small number of the more sophisticated, and more controversial, weapons to Riyadh now, the Administration was seeking to set a precedent for the larger sale early next year. In the past, critics of American arms sales to Arab countries have argued strenously against introducing new military technology into the volatile Middle East.
''The so-called emergency arms sale to Saudi Arabia raises more questions than it answers,'' Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, the majority whip, said in a statement. He said that Congress should postpone the sale of any weapons that do not meet the Saudis' immediate needs.
In the northern Red Sea today, the American frigate Elmer Montgomery stopped and searched an Iraqi oil tanker after firing shots across the freighter's bow. The vessel, the Tadmur, which was headed away from the Jordanian port of Aqaba, was found to empty and allowed to proceed.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pfc. Donald Austin of Oak Grove, Mont., guarding 155-millimeter howitzer shells yesterday at a depot in Saudi Arabia. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Judge Fines USX $4.1 Million in Conspiracy Case

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 27

 BODY:
A Federal District judge here levied the maximum possible fine on the USX Corporation today and gave prison terms to two top union officials who had been found guilty of conspiring with the company to obtain lucrative pensions in exchange for granting concessions in labor negotiations.
The judge, E. B. Haltom, fined the steel company $4.1 million and ordered it to repay nearly $300,000 to the pension fund, which had illegally paid pensions to the union officials. Judge Haltom said he had chosen the maximum fine in an attempt to punish and deter the company from repeating the offenses. The company was found guilty of 14 counts of conspiracy, violations of Federal labor law and mail fraud in a four-month trial that ended in July. 
The two officials of the United Steelworkers of America, Thermon Phillips, 62 years old, and E. B. Rich, 60, drew prison terms of two and a half and three years, respectively. Mr. Phillips is district director for union locals in several Southern states and he conducted labor negotiations for locals in the region. Mr. Rich was his chief aide.
Each man was found guilty of one count of conspiracy to accept a bribe and one count of violating Federal labor law. Mr. Rich had been acquitted of mail fraud charges; similar charges against Mr. Phillips had been dropped. Although they say they will appeal their convictions, both officials must now relinquish their union posts under Federal labor law.
 
Company Will Appeal
L. Drew Redden, a lawyer for USX, said the company would appeal the conviction and the sentence.
As this phase of the criminal case was ending, lawyers picked up activity in a large civil lawsuit growing out of the accusations of collusion between the union and USX. Today lawyers for rank-and-file union members in the civil case filed motions asking that the company, the union and the pension fund be barred from saying there was nothing illegal in the granting of the pensions to the officials.
Last month a Federal judge certified the suit as a class action, potentially increasing the number of plaintiffs from 38 to 5,500 and raising possible damages from a few million to more than $180 million. J. Vernon Patrick, lawyer for the union members, said the plaintiffs were also charging a violation of the Federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, which allows recovery of triple the damages.
 
Sentences Applauded
The sentences were applauded by some rank-and-file members of the union who had crowded into the tiny courtroom. Lorenzo East, a retired steelworker, said there was some justice in the fact that the company was punished as well.
At the same time there was criticism by officials of the local union as well as officials of the international union who continued to maintain that the case was an attack by the Government on unions in general.
''These are Republicans and Reaganites and they don't miss an opportunity to hurt the unions,'' said Howard E. Strevel, a retired steelworkers union official who was in the courtroom.
The case dates back to a period of upheaval in the steel industry in the early 80's in which factory after factory succumbed to the effects of a recession and foreign competition. It was a time of retrenchment in which Birmingham's huge Fairfield Works, with its 3,500 employees, faced a shutdown.
Mr. Phillips, who sits on the union's international board, was at the center of the scramble to save jobs here. On Christmas Eve 1983, he and Mr. Rich entered into an agreement that kept the Fairfield Works open while granting concessions in the number of jobs and incentive pay and dropping of all pending grievances. The work force was to be cut by 1,500 employees, who would retire and receive pensions.
 
Once Local Heroes
The officials were hailed as heroes locally, and the company said that the cuts and concessions would save them $24 million.
The Fairfield agreement set a pattern for agreements between the company and other locals around the country, especially in the area of job levels.
But the trial here heard evidence that the union officials' acceptance of the concessions was linked to their receiving pension benefits to which they would not ordinarily be entitled.
The international's headquarters in Pittsburgh, in a letter sent out to its staff nationally, called the officials' convictions ''a tragedy'' and maintained that the cases' outcome had implications for all union officials Mr. Patrick, the lawyer in the civil case, said his office would send letters this weekend to 5,500 current and former USX employees in the Birmingham area letting them know that they might end up being entitled to damages.He said that the number represented not only those people employed at the time of the 1983 Fairfield Agreement but also those employed at the plant anytime since then.
''People have worked under the Fairfield agreement from 1983 to now and the corruption of these union officials by the company affects people from then until now,'' said Mr. Patrick. ''They have been denied adequated representation since then.''

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Veteran of Rights and Poverty Wars Tastes Bitter Fruit of Many Battles

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
When the Civil Rights Act of 1990 was proposed in Congress, its backers fervently hoped for a Rose Garden signing ceremony, as a triumphant cap for the long career of Representative Augustus F. Hawkins.
Far from a crowning achievement, the bill's halting progress through Congress and the threat of a veto has been a bitter disappointment for the man who since 1963 has represented not only south-central Los Angeles, including Watts, but also the big government liberalism of the New Deal and the Great Society.
''You could get frustrated by staying here,'' Mr. Hawkins said in a recent interview. ''But I have more confidence in the people outside than I do in public officials inside.''
Now 83 years old, the California Democrat announced in January, a month before the anti-discrimination measure was introduced, that this would be his last term. His frustration is rooted not only in the veto threat the White House renewed this week when the measure emerged from a House-Senate conference, but also in Congress, which has increasingly turned its back on goals he espouses and approaches he advocates. 
 
Irked at Budget 'Obsession'
''This obsession we seem to have with spending cuts as the only way you can balance the budget is to me so devastating and so wrong,'' Mr. Hawkins said. ''And yet, I can't see them changing it.''
Like a cherished elderly uncle who stays too long at dinner telling a story he has forgotten he has told before, he is viewed by many as a relic whose ideas have grown stale.
''He is more wedded to a policy approach that is grounded in the 60's,'' said Representative Thomas J. Downey, a New York Democrat who has battled with him over the best way to finance child care programs. ''That would have been great, but Lyndon Johnson is not going to come back and sign a bill for child care.''
This year's civil rights bill would reverse a series of Supreme Court rulings last year that made it harder for people to bring damage suits against employers charging discrimination. It would also mandate the payment of punitive monetary damages by businesses guilty of discrimination.
But over his objections, the conferees limited to $150,000 the amount juries may award victims of intentional discrimination. Mr. Hawkins wanted any such ceiling to apply only to small businesses, arguing that large corporations ought to be made to pay severely for maliciously denying individuals their civil rights.
 
Disappointment With Caucus
Mr. Hawkins is equally critical of the Congressional Black Caucus, which he helped found in 1970 and hoped would supplement political organizing efforts by financially strapped civil rights groups. The caucus, Mr. Hawkins feels, has yet to act as a cohesive unit.
''It's pretty difficult to get individual politicians, in particular, to subordinate their own egos to group activity,'' he said. ''This, I think, unfortunately, is the outgrowth of early childhood. We are not brought up to act in groups.''
''That's why I'm such a staunch supporter of early childhood education and child care,'' he continued. ''Child care children act differently from other children when they are brought up that way. It's not just blacks - it's Americans in general. But we're the ones who suffer the most from it.''
The 5-foot-5 Californian, so light-skinned that many on meeting him mistake him for a white, remains steadfast in his belief that the programs developed in the New Deal and the Great Society represent the best way to attack the problems of unemployment, poverty and to educate disadvantaged youngsters.
''They have worked,'' he said of the programs he still cherishes. ''I don't see anybody moving to repeal them or to eliminate them. The 'war on poverty' did a good job. It reduced poverty. How better can a thing work than by accomplishing its objectives? Head Start is a wonderful program. The business community favors it. The education community favors it. Social Security worked; deposit insurance for banks worked; aid to elementary and secondary schools works. They'll all on the statute books, and they're all documented successes.
''The biggest problem is that they were never sufficiently funded, and efforts are now being made to sabotage them. So I think that anybody who says you are out of date by supporting these programs is not fully aware of them.''
 
Still an Icon Among Many
Mr. Hawkins, who first won elective office, to the California General Assemby, during Franklin D. Roosevelt's first term, remains an icon among many members, including those who disagree with him, and few will criticize him directly. But even his allies concede that his way of dealing with racial problems and poverty is not today's way.
''He is one of the last warriors of the Great Society'' said Mr. Dixon, another of the 24 blacks in Congress, who considers Mr. Hawkins a mentor. ''But we are now looking for other creative ways to help minorities -economic development and the like.''
Mr. Hawkins's sense of not being fulfilled may also be fueled by his experience on Capitol Hill. When he arrived in 1963, he was assigned to the Education and Labor Committee, then under the chairmanship of Representative Adam Clayton Powell, the flamboyant New York Democrat.
In the early 60's Mr. Powell was at the height of his power. Under his leadership, the committee was a legislative dynamo, churning out bills setting up a $1.25-an-hour minimum wage, increasing aid to higher education, setting up programs for those with disabilities, and establishing the Job Corps, a critical component of the war on poverty.
 
An Impressive Record
Quietly toiling in the legislative trenches, Mr. Hawkins amassed an impressive legislative record. It included drafting Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which bans discrimination in employment; writing the law setting up the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, and playing a pivotal role in the Civil Rights Restoration Act, enacted in 1988 over a veto by President Ronald Reagan, mandating that Federal funds be cut off to any institution if any of its components is found to discriminate.
But when Mr. Hawkins became chairman of the Education and Labor Committee in 1984, he inherited a panel that was a shadow of what is was under Mr. Powell. Dispirited by Reagan-era cutbacks in programs under its jurisdiction and a flow of power from the committees that authorize legislation to the panels the appropriate funds for them, the committee found it hard to fill all its Democratic seats.
''He played the game the way it's supposed to be played, but when he finally got on top, he found he had few opportunities to make any headway,'' said Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution. Disappointment with the direction of domestic policy is not the only reason Mr. Hawkins has decided to retire. Friends say he simply wants to devote more time to his wife, Elsie, and to fishing in Chesapeake Bay on his 33-foot cabin cruiser.
''He's had great success on most of the legislation he has pushed,'' said Representative Don Edwards, a fellow Democrat from California who entered Congress along with Mr. Hawkins in 1963. ''But he's in his 80's. He's got a place on Solomon Island and a nice wife. Maybe he wants a few years of contemplation in his remaining years.''
 
Still Has Political Goals
But Mr. Hawkins has no intention of merely hanging up a ''gone fishing'' sign. He says he intends to rally grass-roots political support - the kind he feels has been sorely lacking on the pending civil rights bill - for more money for education. And he wants to fight what he considers ''crazy ideas,'' like government vouchers that parents would ''spend'' to send their children to public or private schools.
''I think I could do a better job on the outside of calling attention toward what needs to be done,'' he said. ''We've been successful in getting bills through, and that's about all I can do: get laws passed.''
Can the diffident Mr. Hawkins, who has quietly battling for liberal causes in the legislative trenches, rally the troops?
''Unless he gets emotionally charged, he's not one to take to the stump,'' said Mr. Edwards. ''He's not a Jesse Jackson or a Martin Luther King.''
Mr. Hawkins presents no argument to this characterization. ''I'm not built for leadership,'' he said. ''I don't like the frivolities that go along with being out front. It's not a matter of sour grapes. It's just that some individuals are made for certain things. I would rather just enjoy myself and not worry about being a leader. There are others who want to be out front. They want to get the recognition. They love the television cameras.''

HEADLINE: Panel Backs Bill on Puerto Rico Vote

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Taking another step toward giving Puerto Rico the right to choose statehood, independence or a continuation of its commonwealth status, a House panel approved a bill today to authorize a vote next year. The bill would also force Congress to decide within six months of the referendum whether to accept its results.
The bill approved by a subcommittee of the House Rules Committee will probably go to the full committee next week, where approval is almost guaranteed, and then to the full House. The bill was passed by the Interior and Insular Affairs Committee last week. 
House staff members said it was still unclear whether both the Senate and the House could pass legislation and present it to President Bush for signing this year, since Congress was rushing to finish its legislative agenda by the middle of October.
But they noted that House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington and the Republican leader, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, had expressed particular interest in the legislation, which would give Puerto Rico the power of self-determination. President Bush made statehood for Puerto Rico an issue both in his 1988 Presidential campaign and in his 1989 State of the Union message.
 
Years of 'Divisive Debate'
The issue of self-determination for 3.6 million Puerto Ricans living on the Caribbean island and 2.5 million living in the United States has been a thorny issue for both the United States and Puerto Rico.
''For years now, the divisive debate on Puerto Rico's future political status has prevented action on many of the very serious social and economic problems facing our fellow Americans in Puerto Rico,'' said Representative Ron de Lugo, the island's delegate in the House.
Until 1988, the island's three major parties - the Popular Democratic Party, which supports continued commonwealth status, the New Progressive Party, which supports statehood. and the Puerto Rican Independence Party, which supports independence -opposed a referendum.
 
A Vote in 1991
While sentiment for statehood has risen and fallen over time, opinion now runs slightly in favor of it over continuing the commonwealth relationship.
The bill in the House would provide $13.5 million in administrative and educational money to pay for a referendum on Sept. 16, 1991. The bill would require Congress either to approve the results of the referendum and decide on steps to carry them out or to modify them in six months. After that Puerto Rico would vote a second time on ratifying the steps set out by Congress.
One issue that had been a major point of dispute in the bill was whether the 2.5 million Puerto Ricans living in the mainland United States could vote. Experts noted that because those Puerto Ricans tended to favor statehood, allowing them to vote would favor those backing statehood. The bill would leave the decision about whether those Puerto Ricans could vote to the island's three political parties and its Legislature.
 
Statehood Means More Aid
Still, statehood at this point appears to be preferred, primarily because it would mean greater economic aid for the island's residents and give Puerto Ricans, who already have United States citizenship, full political representation, including two United States senators and what Congressional aides estimated was likely to be six members of the House.
But the economic argument appears to be compelling, particularly since United States law does not force the Government to provide Federal aid to residents of territories like Puerto Rico at the same level that residents of states receive.
Half the island's residents receive some form of Federal aid, for a total of $6.5 billion a year, but that group would receive $3 billion more if Puerto Rico became a state.
Favorable tax laws, which could be threatened by a change of status, continue to be a compelling reason for many to support an enhanced commonwealth status. These laws have attracted to Puerto Rico operations by almost one-third of the Fortune 500 companies, leading to the creation of 150,000 jobs. The enhancements would result in greater Federal aid.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 29, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about legislation to permit a referendum on Puerto Rico's political status misidentified the commonwealth's delegate to the United States House of Representatives. He is Jaime B. Fuster. Ron de Lugo is the Virgin Islands delegate.

HEADLINE: Tribes to Hear Proposal to Revamp Indian Bureau

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. Sept. 27

 BODY:
Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. has called American Indian tribal leaders from around the country for a meeting on Friday that he says will point a course toward greater self-determination for the tribes.
At the meeting here, Mr. Lujan plans to outline a proposal to revamp the Bureau of Indian Affairs and to modify the system of delivering Federal funds to the tribes.
''I think this will give them more sovereignty, more opportunity to make their own decisions,'' Mr. Lujan said in an interview this week. ''I think they ought to take as much responsibility as possible.'' 
 
Skepticism Among Indians
A number of tribal leaders voiced skepticism about the meeting, which they said followed a pattern of periodic overhauls by the Federal Government, and which they complained offered little chance for input from the tribes themselves.
The issue of greater self-determination for the tribes is one that has drawn increasing attention in recent years.
''This should be the story of the 90's,'' said Tim Giago, a member of the Oglala Sioux tribe who is editor of The Lakota Times, a weekly newspaper in Rapid City, S.D. ''Tribal sovereignty is the key word in Indian country now.''
A Senate committee report last November proposed greater tribal autonomy after a two-year committee investigation of the current system found widespread corruption and mismanagement of Indian land and money.
The report proposed that tribes be given the opportunity for tighter control over and accountability for their individual shares of more than $3.3 billion in annual Federal grants for education, health, economic development and natural resources development.
The issue remains a complicated one on which the more than 500 tribes are far from united. The steps Mr. Lujan described are incremental and drew advance criticism from some Indian leaders who said they amounted to little more than bureaucratic reshuffling.
 
New Budgeting Control
Mr. Lujan said one of the steps he would outline would be a shift away from the current system in which tribes receive Federal financing for specific uses like law enforcement or economic development.
''What I want to do,'' Mr. Lujan said, ''is take the same amount of money and say, 'O.K., here are the dollars,' but instead of us doing it categorically, say, 'You decide where the money will be spent, just like a state or a city.'''
Last summer, the Interior Department started a pilot program in which six tribes were given greater control over the budgeting and spending of Federal funds for Bureau of Indian Affairs programs.
Mr. Lujan said his second step would involve dividing the bureau into separate sections overseeing trust relations, delivery of services to tribes and education.
He said improving the quality of education on Indian reservations was a cornerstone of future tribal sovereignty, and was one of his priorities.
''For the last year and a half, since I've been Secretary, we have been talking to all the different tribal leaders on an individual basis,'' Mr. Lujan said. ''Now the time has come to sit down with the group as a whole and look at where we are and where we are going.''
Wendell Chino, chairman of the Mescalero Apache tribe for more than 30 years, the longest tenure of any tribal chairman in the country, said he would attend the meeting, but like a number of other Indian leaders he said he had doubts about its usefulness.
 
Secret Motives Are Seen
''I think it is very unfair to invite tribal leaders even from as far away as Alaska for just a one-day meeting,'' the 66-year-old chairman said. ''I think the meeting is going to be used as a guise that 'We have consulted with the Indians and now we are going to go ahead with the plan.' ''
He suggested that Mr. Lujan's proposals might be an attempt to pre-empt the recommendations of the Senate committee.
Sam Deloria, an expert on Indian affairs at the University of New Mexico Law School, said modifications of the current financing system, like those described by Mr. Lujan, had been opposed in the past because of concerns that overall fund levels could be adversely affected.
In addition, Indian leaders have argued that many tribes are not prepared to manage their own financial planning.
''Right now, most of the tribes are looking at survival,'' said Mr. Giago, the Indian newspaper editor. ''When you talk about budget cuts you are talking about something that would absolutely decimate an Indian tribe. We are totally dependent on the Federal dollar.''
 
'An Old Story'
Mr. Giago said he viewed the gathering with a skepticism born of experience. ''Big meetings are an old story,'' he said.
Mr. Deloria said the idea of reorganizing the bureau was also one that had been entertained by most administrations.
''It's a standing joke in Indian affairs that if you can't think of a policy, you reorganize,'' he said. ''The Bureau of Indian Affairs could be reorganized in a variety of ways that all make sense, and this one probably makes about as much sense as any other.''

HEADLINE: Social Security: A Tinderbox Both Parties Handle Gingerly

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
There are few subjects more perilous for politicians, particularly in an election year, than the suggestion that they might be tampering with Social Security.
That is the reality that budget negotiators were dealing with as they gingerly searched for budget savings today in this most sacred of all American benefit programs.
''We've seen that in the past to be a very explosive subject,'' said Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, chairman of the Democratic Governors' Conference.
''We've been up and down that hill many times,'' said Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee. ''There's a concern about doing anything to the elderly.'' 
In the course of the 1980's the issue was highly partisan as well. In both 1982 and 1986 the Democrats depicted the Republicans as a threat to Social Security and made big gains in the elections.
 
Cycle of Negative Campaigns
Indeed, Republicans often cite the 1982 campaigns Democrats ran against Republicans on Social Security as the start of the cycle of negative campaigning that came to dominate politics in the decade.
''The Republicans feel as burned on this issue as the Democrats feel burned on the tax issue,'' said Anita Dunn, communications director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. In a political sense, for the Democrats to agree to changes in Social Security, and thus weaken one of their best issues, is the rough equivalent of President Bush's willingness to abandon his no-new-taxes pledge.
With 40 days until the midterm elections, there are few members of Congress who would voluntarily want to go to their districts to explain any curtailment of Social Security benefits.
America's older citizens are among the nation's most potent constituencies. They vote at higher rates than most other Americans. In addition, their organizations, lead by the American Association of Retired Persons, swing great weight on Capitol Hill.
At least 39 million Americans receive regular benefit checks from Social Security, and millions more have parents or grandparents who receive benefits and plan to receive benefits themselves some day.
The subject is so sensitive that many Democrats rebuffed the suggestion of cutting the payroll tax imposed to pay Social Security because pollsters told them that it made many Americans nervous that the tax cut might endanger their Social Security payments.
 
Selecting an Issue
Tony Coelho, a former Representative from California, was a leading architect of the Democratic strategy to invoke Social Security as an issue.
''In 1982 we were looking for an issue to run the campaigns to try to offset Reagan,'' he said, ''and we decided to take on the issue of Social Security.''
Democratic candidates tried to tie Republicans wherever they could to a budget plan, offered in 1981 by David A. Stockman, a budget director under President Ronald Reagan, that would have cut Social Security.
That issue, combined with a recession that developed in the final weeks of the campaign, led the Democrats to a gain of 26 seats in the House.
But there was a downside, Mr. Coelho said. ''It became a motherhood issue much stronger than we ever expected,'' he said. ''You couldn't even tinker with the system when you needed to.''
On Capitol Hill there is a growing anger toward the elderly. Last year, some older people staged an uprising against a program to provide insurance against the soaring costs of catastrophic illnesses. They were happy to receive benefits, but many objected to premiums. In Chicago, some threw themselves in front of the car carrying Representative Dan Rostenkowsi, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. The program was repealed.
Representative Leon E. Panetta, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said the debacle of the catastrophic health care program was a warning of the storm that would greet any changes in Social Security. ''Whatever happened on catastrophic,'' he said, ''multiply that by two.''

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Capital Gains: Plus, Minus or Neither?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
To President Bush, cutting taxes on capital gains is a matter of common sense: a lower rate, he says, would mean more investment without sacrificing tax revenue. To most Congressional Democrats, a break in the tax rate on capital gains would amount to a windfall for the rich and a giant step back from the goal of taxing all forms of income equally.
But economists are generally less eager to assign the capital gains initiative a permanent place in heaven or hell. A cut in the capital rate would indeed distort economic incentives and enrich wealthy Americans at the expense of the Treasury Department, many argue. But there is still a plausible case to be made for special treatment of capital gains as part of a broader change in the tax system. 
Until 1986 only a portion of the income from profits on the sale of assets were taxed as income, effectively reducing the maximum rate on capital gains to 20 percent. But when the maximum income tax rate was reduced, the capital gains preference was dropped. The effective maximum bracket is now 33 percent.
The architects of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 considered this move toward tax neutrality as a shining achievement. No longer, they argued, would decisions about investment be distorted by considerations of how income would be realized or when.
 
Taxes As Incentives
But like many other Americans, George Bush never abandoned the idea of using taxes as incentives. From his first days on the campaign trail, he has been pressing for capital gains tax relief as an inducement to invest.
A tax cut would induce investors to take profits, the Treasury contends, increasing tax revenue in the short run. And in some instances it would induce investors to sell assets during their lifetime, generating revenue that would otherwise be lost entirely because heirs never pay taxes on capital gains. By the Administration's reckoning, a 30 percent exclusion - the equivalent of a maximum 23 percent bracket - would generate an additional $12 billion in revenue over the next five years.
The staff of Congress's nonpartisan Joint Tax Committee disagreed, saying that while revenue would increase in the first two years, over five years, losses would exceed $11 billion.
Other economists are skeptical that a general tax break on profits from sales of assets would stimulate investment in the sort of high-risk innovations that President Bush wants to encourage. James Poterba, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, points out that the bulk of capital for risky new ventures now comes from sources that would not be affected by tax changes - notably pension funds. Thus to be effective, the tax break would have to draw in investors with little experience in the area of venture capital.
 
Most Benefits to Affluent
Hardly anyone, though, disputes the charge that most of the direct benefits from a capital gains break would go to an affluent minority. By the Administration's estimate, $27 billion of the $49 billion in capital gains this year will be realized by families whose incomes have averaged $200,000 or more over the last five years. Just $4.8 billion in capital gains income will go to families with incomes of less than $50,000.
That raises the prospect of stretching an income gap that widened sharply during the Ford, Carter and Reagan Administrations. For some experts, that is more than enough reason not to change.
''Any kind of differential for capital gains,'' said a senior adviser to Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, ''would erode the carefully balanced reform of 1986 and lead to increased tax rates on ordinary income.''
But others said the current treatment of capital gains income did not really meet a rigorous test of tax neutrality. Taxing capital gains income at regular rates penalizes those who hold assets in periods of inflation. For example, someone who bought an asset for $25,000 in 1978 and sold it today for $50,000 would pay taxes on the $25,000 gain. But since prices have doubled in 12 years, the entire gain is an effect of inflation. That is why budget negotiators are said to be considering a compromise of adjusting gains for inflation, or indexing.
 
One Bias Untouched
One giant catch, says Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, is that indexing would offset only one bias, leaving intact another that effectively reduces the tax on long-held gains. Under current law taxes are deferred until property is sold, allowing gains to compound untouched. Equally important, the law gives investors leeway to realize capital gains in years when their incomes (and tax rates) are low.
Mr. Aaron offers a more general objection to indexing capital gains. Taxes are affected by inflation in myriad ways, he says. Changing one without changing all could produce major distortions in the system.
Tax brackets have been indexed since 1986, ending ''bracket creep'' that automatically increased revenues by billions a year. But taxes on interest income have not been indexed. This year an investor who earns 8 percent on a bank deposit will pay taxes on the entire 8 percent, even though three-quarters of the return will already have been wiped out by inflation.
But inflation works in both directions. Interest paid by homeowners has not been indexed, effectively doubling the tax break on the average mortgage deduction. By the same token, inflation artifically increases the value of business deductions for interest and depreciation.
If capital gains are indeed indexed, Mr. Aaron said, interest deductions had better be indexed, too. Otherwise investors would be able to buy property with borrowed money, get the benefit of inflated interest deductions for years and then pay little tax when they sell the property for a profit.

HEADLINE: Peter J. Ottley, 82, Head of Local In the Hotels and Hospital Union

BYLINE: By JOAN COOK

 BODY:
Peter J. Ottley, a former elevator operator who became president of Local 144 of the Hotels, Hospitals, Nursing Home and Allied Services Union for 37 years, representing tens of thousands of workers, died on Wednesday at La Guardia Hospital in Queens. He was 82 years old and lived in St. Albans, Queens.
He died of pneumonia, a family spokesman said. 
Mr. Ottley was head of the union from 1950 until he retired in 1987. When he joined the local, it was primarily a hotel union with a predominantly white membership. Over the years its membership changed to a majority of black members and expanded to represent nursing-home and hospital workers, as well as licensed practical and registered nurses. #33,000 Union Members Today more than 200 hotels, 100 nursing homes and 40 hospitals, with a total of 33,000 members, are covered by collective bargaining agreements with Local 144 in the metropolitan New York area, according to the union.
In 1950 Mr. Ottley became an officer of the Hotel and Motel Trades Council, a coalition of unions that bargain for employees in the city's large hotels. He became a vice president of Local 144's parent body, the Service Employees International Union, A.F.L.-C.I.O., in 1962.
Two years later he was named director of civil rights and economic opportunity for the international union.
 
Conviction Overturned
In 1973 Mr. Ottley was one of two union officers indicted by a Federal grand jury and accused of embezzling more than $186,000 in union funds. He was convicted the following year of aiding in the embezzlement of union funds and failing to keep adequate expense records covering about $20,000 during a four-year period that ended in 1972.
His conviction later was overturned by an appeals court on the grounds that an improper charge to the jury had been made, and the case was dismissed.
Peter Jerome Ottley was born in Grenada and came to the United States in 1927, where he was employed as an elevator operator in the Caxton Building on West 28th Street. He went to night school to complete high school and attended New York University for a year. The first strike he led was of building workers at the Caxton Building during the Depression in 1933.
Mr. Ottley is survived by his wife, the former Mabel Farrell; a son, Arthur, of Brooklyn, and a grandson.

HEADLINE: When Leaves Fall, Red Sox Do, Too;
Autumn Swoon Pains New Englanders

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
It happens every fall. Or so it seems in New England, where the Red Sox are virtually a religion and good citizens have come to expect the team to collapse in September. The Red Sox have not won the World Series since their owner sold Babe Ruth to the Yankees more than 70 years ago to finance a Broadway musical, and this year the pattern seems to be repeating itself. Ahead by six and a half games in early September in the American League East, the Red Sox have lost 9 of their last 12 games, falling a game behind the Toronto Blue Jays.
 
Her Teeth Ache
But even for the descendants of the Puritans, believers in predestination, there is still pain.
''My teeth ache every morning when I think about the Red Sox,'' a caller said Wednesday evening on the Eddie Andelman show on WHDH radio, the most popular sports talk program in the region. 
''I don't know what to do,'' she said in despair. ''My brother just moved to New York, so I'm almost thinking of becoming a Yankees fan.'' It was a blasphemous statement, and she knew it.
''After all,'' the woman explained, alluding to the angry mood of Massachusetts voters this fall, ''I've already gone from being a Democrat to being a Republican.''
Her thoughts, mixing sports and politics, Bostonians' two favorite passions, were echoed across the Charles River in Cambridge by Henry Rosovsky, the acting dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences at Harvard. ''This is an angry state,'' said Rosovsky, one of the most respected academic leaders in the country and a Red Sox diehard. ''If the people could vote on the Red Sox, they would throw out the manager, the general manager and the owners,'' he said.
''I am terribly saddened,'' Rosovsky added. ''I do feel the curse of the Bambino lays heavily on my shoulders,'' he said, referring to the popular myth that the ill fate of the Red Sox is traceable to the sale of Ruth, the Bambino.
The fans' anxieties and the team's plight have been made worse by the absence of Roger Clemens, the superstar pitcher, who has been out since Sept. 4 with a sore shoulder. The glum feeling about the Red Sox has been exacerbated over the past week by disputes involving players on two of Boston's other professional sports franchises, the Celtics and the New England Patriots. On Friday, Dee Brown, the Celtics' first-round draft pick this spring, was forced by the police in Wellesley to lie face down on the pavement at gunpoint when they mistakenly identified him as a bank robber. Brown contended the police acted simply because he was black and he has threatened to sue the affluent, largely white suburb.
At the same time, The Boston Herald today took the highly unusual step of calling for a boycott of Sunday's football game between the Patriots and the Jets at Foxboro Stadium because of incidents in which several players were said to have made lewd coments to a Herald Reporter, Lisa Olson, who later said she was insulted by the team's owner, Victor Kiam. The trouble began in the Patriots' locker room on Sept. 17 when, Olson said, several unclothed players positioned themselves close to her face and ''dared me to touch their private parts.''
Then on Monday The Herald reported that Kiam, the president of Remington Products Inc., had referred to Olson as ''a classic bitch.'' Kiam has denied making the remark, saying he had only called her an aggressive reporter.
''Stay home this Sunday,'' The Herald said today. ''Don't do it for Lisa Olson, because she'll handle this like the pro she is. Do it for all the women in your life. Do it because it's the right thing to do.''
Controversy over Olson's treatment has almost obsured the Red Sox swoon, with some callers on the radio talk shows suggesting that a female reporter should not be allowed in a men's locker room. But Andelman, the talk-show host, has been strongly supportive of her.
''I'm not a prude,'' he said today, ''but we can't allow this to go unpunished.''
 
Simply 'Gruesome'
To Andelman, a genial, opinionated millionaire businessman who has run his radio program as a hobby for more than 20 years, the recent troubles of the Red Sox, the Patriots and the Celtics have been ''gruesome.''
''You also have to add to this the bad economic news in New England,'' he said, referring to a recession that has hit the region after a decade of spectacular growth. ''It's really been a lot to swallow.''
In commiseration, Andelman began his show Wednesday with the sound of tolling church bells. ''There must be some good news out there,'' he said to his listeners. ''Doesn't anyone have some good news?''
Although the Red Sox still have a three-game series with the Blue Jays in Fenway Park this weekend, many people seem to have already given up. ''If there is a way to lose, we're going to do it,'' said Jeff A. Swartz, who was selling Red Sox hats and souvenirs from a cart outside the ballpark.
''Even when they were in first place, people were waiting for them to lose,'' Swartz said. ''Give them a chance to choke, and they will,'' he said, recalling the playoff game between the Red Sox and Yankees in 1978 when Boston squandered a 2-0 lead and lost, 5-4, on a pop fly home run by Bucky Dent that just cleared the short left-field wall.
Similarly, in 1948 the Red Sox lost the only other one-game playoff in American League history, to the Indians. And in 1949, with the Red Sox one game up on the Yankees with two games to play in New York, Boston lost both contests.
 
Thinning Crowds
Still, this year seems a little different around Fenway Park. After sellouts virtually all summer, the crowds have suddenly thinned, despite the heat of the pennant race. Wednesday night, when the Red Sox actually beat Cleveland, 7-2, the team drew only 28,630 people, fewer than went to games against the Indians back in June.
''I think this year is different because in the past the fans always blamed the players or the manager,'' Andelman said. ''But this year they've realized this is a team without speed, without home-run power, and without pitching beyond Roger Clemens. They know the team has overachieved for the talent it has.
''So the fans have finally started to blame the front office. They see the owners are content because Fenway fills up every night, and they aren't committed to making trades or acquiring top players.''
Andelman said callers to his show were particularly irate after the Oakland Athletics acquired Willie McGee, who was among the National League's leading hitters, on waivers from St. Louis, and Lou Gorman, the Red Sox General Manager, said Boston had no use for him.
''That's because the Red Sox don't want two black players in the outfield,'' Andelman said. The only regular black player on the team now is Ellis Burks, the center fielder. No one from the team was available for comment on Andelman's statement.
Emily Vermeule, a professor of classics and fine arts at Harvard, agreed. ''The owners are a bunch of cheapos,'' she said. ''You could make a distinguished team just from the pitchers they've let go,'' she said, pointing to pitchers like Dennis Eckersley, Bobby Ojeda, John Tudor and Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd.
''In the past I used to really care about the team,'' Vermeule said. ''But these are just like a bunch of Hellenistic mercenaries. All they care about is money.''

HEADLINE: National Gains on Capital Gains

 BODY:
After weeks of bickering about cutting the capital gains tax, and with Monday's deadline looming, budget negotiators appear within reach of a compromise. And not just any compromise. This may be one case in which political posturing is about to produce an economic pot of gold.
The negotiators have been deadlocked for weeks over Mr. Bush's persistent demand for a lower tax on capital gains - the increased value of stocks, bonds and other assets between purchase and sale. The Republicans say that a cut is needed to spur economic growth. The Democrats say no, because the cut would overwhelmingly benefit the rich. 
The deal could still disintegrate. But under the tentative compromise the capital gains tax would be indexed for inflation, meaning that only capital gains in excess of the inflation rate would be taxed. And, some summiteers are proposing, the indexation would apply only to future investments in, say, small companies.
To the summiteers this is the ordinary business of political compromise. Everybody gets only part of what he wants and thinks he deserves. But to the economy, the outcome could be a whole lot more. Indexation, if so targeted, would give a welcome boost to emerging companies struggling to attract investors yet not wreak havoc with the rest of the tax code.
The President has stalled the deficit negotiations by doggedly insisting that the deficit package include a cut in the capital gains tax. His argument that this would spur economic growth strains credulity. By cutting the tax on old and new investments alike, the plan amounts to a fabulous giveaway for his rich supporters. Mr. Bush never answers how handing investors billions more for what they did in the past will cause them to invest more in the future.
Nor does he explain why the tax cut ought to apply to real estate and other tax-advantaged investments. The empty office buildings and half-filled shopping centers across the Southwest are proof that foolish tax subsidies can make wasteful investments profitable.
The sobering truth is that a sweeping capital gains tax cut won't jump-start the economy. The cut wouldn't affect tax-exempt pension funds and foreign investors. To make a noticeable dent, the cut would have to produce a herculean response on the part of taxpaying individuals. Most economists dismiss that possibility.
Mr. Bush is correct, however, when he argues that the capital gains tax imposes an excessive burden during inflationary times. Upon the sale of stocks and bonds, investors are taxed on price increases that, in large part, represent no real profit. Of course, inflation also distorts taxation of interest from bank accounts, deductions of mortgage interest, depreciation allowances on corporate plants and equipment and scores of other tax calculations. Across-the-board indexing of capital gains alone could distort investment patterns even more and wind up doing as much harm as good.
That said, there is a case to be made for tinkering with the capital gains tax. A tax cut that is limited to new investment in venture capital and other risky start-up companies could produce real economic gains because those types of businesses are struggling to survive. But such focused relief is light years away from Mr. Bush's plan.
The Democratic response to that plan has been something less than enlightened. Yes, a capital gains tax cut would shower profit on the rich. Yes, that's unfair. But the important task is to set the capital gains tax to spur investment and growth. Any inequity that might result should then be undone by socking the rich in some other way, as the Democrats have consistently proposed.
Now comes the possibility that from all the political posturing and errant economics, something constructive will emerge. Indexing capital gains for new investments in stocks allows Republicans and Democrats to claim partial victory. And the economy gets to claim complete victory. The process would be weird, but the result glorious.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Capitalism, Soviet Style

BYLINE: By JACK ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
PEMOHT: It may be the most frequently seen word on Soviet streets. What the Cyrillic word says is ''remont,'' what it supposedly means is ''under repair'' and what it really means is ''broken.''
Much is broken in Moscow now, as it was in Europe after World War II. Then, Dondi-like urchins emerged from bombed-out buildings to beg for Juicy Fruit. To wan, exhausted adults, American cigarettes were gold. Food was scarce, water was dangerous to drink and paper napkins, let alone toilet tissue, were rare, and rough. 
There are no bombed-out hulks in Moscow or Leningrad now but there is no end of paint-peeling, cracked and even crumbling buildings behind their ''remont'' signs. Children rush up to foreigners to trade souvenir insignia pins for gum. Cab drivers insist on payment in Marlboros or dollars. Food is scarce, water is dangerous to drink and paper napkins come, if at all, in single-ply sheets four inches square.
But for all these similarities, there's an overriding difference between Western Europe then and the Soviet Union now. In postwar Europe, the people were stunned and exhausted but knew how to rebuild their economies. In the post-cold-war Soviet Union, there's no sense that people have any idea how to get from here to there.
In truth, as economists teach us, no one knows how. No Communist society has ever converted itself to the free market. There's not even a respectable economic theory of how to do so. Yet Soviet laymen and scholars alike lunge for the forms and slogans of the market while giving little sign that they understand where they are going.
The most obvious difficulty is money. Visitors are subjected to five kinds - dollars, Marlboros and three kinds of ruble, worth $1.75 or 16 cents or a nickel. What rational outsider will invest in a society that finds it so hard to answer the simple question, ''How much?'' Ah, Soviets insist, but there's progress on that. For instance, we know how much land will cost, says a scholar occupied with creating a new master plan for the city of Moscow. ''We have developed a complex urban simulation model to set prices on a general scale.'' One hectare of land in downtown Moscow could cost 20 million rubles, but only 2 million outside the 10-mile ring. Fine, but which ruble? Well, he says, that's unclear. These prices are meant only to establish relative values.
There's no trouble stating prices in the few private enterprises already in place. In the cooperative profit-making restaurants, the waiters, captains and singing strings knock themselves out to please patrons able to spend $40 apiece, in dollars, for dinner.
And a literal kind of free market already exists among the people who crowd around the folding tables outside a soccer stadium in Moscow, the Ismailova Market, or in Ostrovsky Square in Leningrad. Dozens of peddlers offer paintings, dolls, lace - while hundreds more walk past whispering ''Militaravotch?'' From seemingly bottomless duffel bags they proffer uniforms, belts, caps. One flashes a Red Army staff officer's leather map case, including a compartment for ''sikret meps.''
There are other touches of a free market. On certain days one official enterprise closes to let employees do ''research''; it sounds more like moonlighting. Still, for all these surface signs of capitalism, Soviet citizens seem impatient for change but uncomprehending of what that will require.
They hail radical economic reform but perhaps more out of impatience than understanding. Pavel Podlesny, a shrewd analyst at the U.S.A. and Canada Institute, says many Soviets do so out of a burning impulse for tak ili syak - one way or the other, fish or cut bait. To do either will require changing the meaning of remont.

HEADLINE: Investment Tax Credit Is Worth Trying Again

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As Congressional leaders horse-trade over income tax increases and capital-gains tax reductions, an opportunity to head off decline into serious recession is being missed: a targeted investment tax credit program.
While a capital-gains tax reduction would free capital for investment, the desired result is by no means certain. We must hope that the beneficiaries of these cuts would invest in activities that create jobs and growth. But the added revenue could also spur a new round of buyouts, mergers and other paper shuffles that contribute little to the overall economy.
Investment tax credits would encourage business and industry to invest in physical plant upgrades, new machinery and high technology. These are the things that create jobs, boost the economy and, ultimately, increase tax revenues.
Investment tax credits worked in the 1960's and 70's, and they can work today.
 
ROBERT W. RYLEY
Jackson, N.J., Sept. 17, 1990
