HEADLINE: Connecticut Pocketbooks Expected to Shape Race

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: MONROE, Conn., Sept. 27

 BODY:
When people here go to vote for a new governor in November, local nightmares like the Alamo are likely to follow them right into the booth. The Alamo is what residents call the pink Southwestern-motif shopping center on Route 111 that belly-flopped in the Northeast's real-estate downturn. It has sat empty, apparently with no survivors, for the last 18 months.
That is not to say that the world has fallen apart in this community of 17,000 people on the eastern edge of Fairfield County. Monroe mostly remains a well-tended, heavily Republican former farming town. What has changed, politicians and residents say, is that Monroe, along with almost every other Connecticut community, has been forced to acknowledge its limitations. 
But in a state and region where the main questions until recently were ''how high?'' and ''how fast?'', the news of mortality has been disturbing enough, and politicians say that how voters express their disappointment is generally expected to decide the election.
In the last 18 months, applications for welfare here have quadrupled. The dollar value of losses from property crimes -particularly burglaries - has nearly doubled, attributed by the police to the rise of crack use in nearby Bridgeport and the resulting need for quick cash.
 
The Hot Button: the Economy
The local construction industry has all but died. Residents twice rejected budgets before approving one that raised property taxes by nearly 6 percent and cut spending for schools. The action followed cuts in state aid last spring.
The votes also deeply divided Monroe along lines of age and economics, with hard-pressed young families joining retirement-age people to force cuts in once-hallowed school spending.
''That's the hot button this year: the economy and the resulting impact on local taxpayers,'' said Kenneth S. Heitzke, a retired Army colonel who runs Monroe's town hall as Selectman. ''We're cutting anything that reeks of being something nice to have. We're down to the real hard nuts.''
Yet in dozens of recent interviews with residents, it was clear that no easy equation would directly link voters' frustration or anger to the success or failure of any candidate.
Though United States Representative John G. Rowland, the Republican nominee, has represented Monroe since 1985 and is expected to do well here, former United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Greenwich Republican running under his own party label, is considered almost a local son.
The questions are the extent to which those candidates will carve up the vote - a result that could benefit the Democrat, United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison - and how much voters will make local issues a basis of how they cast their ballots. All three candidates have vowed to maintain local aid as much as possible next year, but with a projected $1 billion deficit in a state budget of only about $7 billion, many people here are skeptical.
 
Of Beer and Bread
''It's fine and well that they want to keep their commitments, but what are they going to do about it?'' asked Henry W. Cortina, a systems analyst who has lived here seven years.
Patrick C. O'Hara, a native who opened a wholesale nursery this summer, said, ''The thing is, they've got to stop spending our money.''
Mr. O'Hara, in a sentiment echoed by several, said he was bothered that the town had to scrimp on its school budget, while it continued to receive hundreds of thousands of dollars in state money to develop a town park.
''In your house, if you don't have enough money for bread but you go out and buy a six-pack of beer, something's wrong,'' Mr. O'Hara said. He said he would probably vote for Mr. Weicker because he seems ''craftier.''
 
Little Growth in 2 Years
For Monroe, where the population grew by 22 percent in the 1980's alone, one of the most ominous portents for the future is that growth has all but stopped in the last two years. Permits to build new houses are down to a few a month, compared with 30 to 40 a month in 1988, according to town figures.
''That's deadly for this town,'' said Daniel Tuba, Monroe's town planner. ''This town relies heavily on the residential property tax base, and without a reasonable annual growth rate in the grand list, the burden becomes that much worse.''
In some areas, the drop-off has translated into fear.
''I'm scared to death,'' said a woman who, with her husband, planned to move this winter into a condominium at Great Oak Farm, a sprawling development of $300,000 homes that was halted in mid-construction last year.
The project is overgrown, weathered and neglected. The couple, who refused to give their names, have spent thousands of dollars to fix up their condominium, even though the overall project remains in doubt. Foreclosure against the developers began this month.
''There is the need for a change, that's for sure,'' said Joseph Dellaquila, a home builder who said he has seen his business dwindle in the last year.
Mr. Dellaquila said he believed that the next governor should bring new businesses into the state and that the best way to do that would be to cut corporate taxes, which are now the highest in the nation at 13.8 percent. But he added that making up the difference through other tax increases, especially a personal income tax, would be ''devastating.''
All three of the major gubernatorial candidates have pledged to try and cut corporate taxes, but none have set a time table. All oppose an income tax for the state, which currently taxes income on only dividends, interest and capital gains, but only Mr. Rowland has vowed to veto an income-tax bill.
Some people said they feared that whatever happens next year may be too late.
 
'You Just Worry'
Larry Easter, a nine-year Monroe resident who works as a mechanic at Sikorsky Aircraft in Stratford, said he has seen the company cut back its nearly 12,000-member work force by hundreds of employees. ''It's a shame,'' he said. Susan Nikola, who moved here three years ago from nearby Shelton because of the reputation of the Monroe schools, said, ''You see everything being cut and you just worry.'' Mrs. Nikola said she had not thought much yet about the governor's race.
''It can't keep going on the way it is, though,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Tradition Falls as Princeton Club Selects First Women in 111 Years

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 27

 BODY:
A 111-year tradition will end on Friday as the Ivy Club, an eating club for Princeton University upperclassmen, admits women for the first time.
After an 11-year legal battle, a Federal judge ruled on Sept. 19 that the Ivy Club and the Tiger Inn, the only other remaining all-male eating club at Princeton, had to admit women when membership decisions were next made. The Tiger Inn will not have a bicker - the weeklong process of interviews and meetings by which some of Princeton's eating clubs select members - until February, but Ivy went ahead and interviewed more than 20 women in this week's bicker. 
Many of the women say they are more concerned about gaining entrance to the Ivy Club for social reasons.
''I'm not making a political statement at all,'' said Marilyn White, an Albany senior majoring in comparative literature. ''It's just the fact that I would like to be in the club. Almost all the women feel the same.''
 
Ruling Is Appealed
Last week's ruling stemmed from an 11-year-old sex-discrimination lawsuit filed against the two clubs and a third, The Cottage Inn by Sally Frank after she unsuccessfully took part in a bicker at the Ivy Club. The Cottage Inn turned coeducational in 1986.
In 1987 the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights ruled that the Ivy Club and the Tiger Inn were in violation of state anti-discrimination laws by refusing to admit women. This July, the State Supreme Court upheld that ruling, and on Sept. 19, Judge John C. Lifland of Federal District Court in Trenton denied a motion by the Ivy Club to stay the court's ruling while the case was being reopened in a Federal court.
''The issue that's at stake for us is an issue of privacy,'' said Blair Haarlow, the president of the Ivy Club and a senior economics major from Hinsdale, Ill. ''According to the New Jersey Supreme Court ruling, they deemed us an issue of public accommodation which we don't think we are.''
Ivy and Tiger are continuing their Federal Courtappeal even though their undergraduate members voted last spring to admit women. Both clubs require two consecutive years of votes in favor before enacting an official change in policy.
The Tiger Inn, which decided not to hold a fall bicker this year though it has in the past, has irked some students who feel the club is trying to bide time for the Federal appeal.
Stockton Williams, the Tiger Inn president, said a decision was made last spring not to hold a fall bicker because the club is filled nearly to capacity.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Seeks 25% Reduction In 10-Year Plan

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Squeezed between ambitious plans to build schools, modernize hospitals and improve highways and the fiscal constraints of a faltering economy, Mayor David N. Dinkins has called for a 25 percent cut in the 10-year capital spending plan now being drawn up.
City officials said that projects under way would not be affected, but that plans could be scaled back for repairing bridges and parks, building new jails and rehabilitating housing.
In a recent letter sent to city agency heads as they prepare their 1992-2001 capital strategy, Mayor Dinkins said that the weakness of the local economy, coupled with cuts in Federal and state aid, dictate restraint in deciding the timing and financing of projects. 
A spokesman for the Mayor, Leland T. Jones, said yesterday that specific targets for individual agencies have not been established.
 
Growing Debt Service Costs
In the last few years the city has embarked on an ambitious building plan for its schools, begun rehabilitating thousands of abandoned apartments and stepped up repairs of bridges and highways.
''We must control the proportion of future operating budgets allocated to debt service costs by limiting the size of our capital program,'' the Mayor's letter said. It noted that debt service costs, which are paid for with operating funds, are projected to increase to $3.5 billion in fiscal year 1994, compared with $1.8 billion in fiscal year 1991.
''If you talk about a 25 percent reduction you're talking about an impact on sewage lines, rebuilding schools, modernizing hospitals, a new elephant house at the zoo,'' Mr. Jones said. ''Obviously, some projects will go ahead. We're not going to stop the third water tunnel project or sewer treatment programs. Schools are exceedingly important to the Mayor.''
Projects under way, like expansion at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn and the construction of new jail cells, are expected to continue.
''We will remain active on all fronts,'' Mr. Jones said. ''The question is, how active?''
The new City Charter requires that a preliminary 10-year capital strategy be prepared by Nov. 1, although pending City Council legislation could extend that deadline to Dec. 15. The draft will be subject to a public hearing, with a final plan issued next spring.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 29, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about New York City's 10-year capital plan misstated Mayor David N. Dinkins's position on the possibility of cutbacks in spending.
He is considering cuts of about 25 percent; he has not called for them.

LENGTH: 1505 words

HEADLINE: Free Outdoor Fun: Watching Movies Being Made

BYLINE: By ELLEN PALL; Ellen Pall, the author of the novel ''Back East,'' is currently teaching a course in writing about the arts at Fordham University's Lincoln Center campus.

 BODY:
On a quiet evening in Greenwich Village, a hundred or so people stare, fascinated, as a couple leaves a movie theater on Bleecker Street. The couple pauses in the doorway. The man puts his arms around the woman. She smiles at him. They stroll away.
There is a palpable tremor of excitement in the crowd as the couple approaches. Then the two stop, turn around and return to the theater. The onlookers, murmuring furiously, are joined by more passers-by. The couple leaves the theater again, walks away and turns around. And they do it again. And again. And the crowd keep watching.
As the whisky-sodden gangsters in ''Miller's Crossing'' would say: What's the rumpus? Well, these spectators may have stumbled onto the best bargain entertainment in New York City: location shooting - in this case, for ''The Prince of Tides,'' a movie based on Pat Conroy's 1986 best-selling novel. The couple that mesmerizes them is Barbra Streisand and Nick Nolte. 
New Yorkers may enjoy pretending to be unaffected by celebrities, but there are still plenty of them out there willing to wait an hour or two or three on a Friday or Saturday night - arms full of packages, briefcases in hand - for the chance to gaze at a movie star: especially one as elusive as Ms. Streisand, who is also directing ''Tides.'' Even for the most jaded Manhattanites, there's a strange satisfaction in seeing a star's face assume human proportions (and, if it is a glamorous face, display human flaws). For out-of-towners - and there were many this night on Bleecker Street - glimpsing a star up close may be a cherished souvenir long after the Big Apple ashtrays are broken. And it's free. Movie locations are also a chance to see how a film is made - or, at least, to witness an hour or two of the largely incomprehensible conferences and adjustments and delays of people trying to shoot a tiny fragment of one.
 
Patient Spectators
Ted Churchill, a Steadicam operator on ''The Prince of Tides'' - a romantic drama about a Southern football coach and a New York psychiatrist - has worked on many movies in New York, including ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' which finished shooting here in June. He said he was often amazed by the patience of the spectators. ''They're interested in the process,'' he said. ''It doesn't seem to frustrate them that there's no way to tell that, because everything goes so slowly.''
Once a crowd gathers at a movie location, though, a distinctly sociable atmosphere develops. ''A cocktail party without the alcohol,'' as Mr. Churchill describes it.
When the ''Tides'' crew took over a block of Bleecker Street recently, two young men - an Australian and a Welshman - fell deep into conversation with a New York woman. Later they all went out for a drink. A California woman, overhearing three West German tourists, guessed their hometown from their accent and eventually invited the students - two women and a man - to stay with her when they reached the West Coast.
There was even a certain amount of outright propositioning. ''Here I am, you lucky stiff!'' a woman in a car rolling past the set called to Mr. Nolte between takes. The car moved on before the actor (if he intended to) could answer.
Given the distractions crowds can create, many film makers pray their location shooting will escape the public's attention. ''The last thing I want is anybody knowing where I'm filming,'' said Richard Brick, the producer of a low-budget film called ''Hangin' Out With the Homeboys,'' which involved location work in the South Bronx. ''It leads to costs, delays, sound problems. We're slinking around, trying to be unnoticed.''
 
Sometimes Old Hat
But if some productions want to avoid members of the public, the feeling is often extremely mutual - especially in neighborhoods where film crews seem to be present more often than not. The two-block stretch along Prince Street between Sullivan Street and West Broadway in SoHo, for example, could almost qualify as a multiplex. In the past five weeks, ''The Prince of Tides,'' ''What About Bob?'' (a movie with Bill Murray and Richard Dreyfuss) and ''The Godfather Part III'' have used the area as a backdrop.
Even when asked to do no more than walk on the opposite side of the street, residents of photogenic neighborhoods are often less than delighted. The crew members who have most to do with the public are called Production Assistants, or P.A.'s. They stand at the edges of locations and keep passers-by from inadvertently wandering into a shot. It's their job, too, to see that spectators observe film-location etiquette: keep back from the set and be quiet when the cameras are rolling.
New Yorkers might be more cheerful about the inconveniences caused by trailer-jammed streets and megawatt lights shining in their windows at night if they knew location shooting brought more than $2 billion into the city last year. According to the Mayor's Office on Film, Theater and Broadcasting, 110 feature films and 314 television series and specials were at least partly shot here in 1989. Outside the city, location shooting generated an additional $69.5 million for the state. In New Jersey, 354 film and video projects added $24.8 million to the economy. Connecticut trailed in the three-state region with a 1989 income of about $13 million from location shooting last year.
On the other side of the cameras, a day of shooting a major feature film in New York costs about $100,000 - more at night or on weekends. Expenses include the salaries of 75 or so crew members, equipment rental, vehicle rental and the location site rental. For all of that, three minutes of usable film is considered a good day's work.
 
Expensive, but Still Exciting
Yet film makers keep coming back. ''The traffic is murder and it's very expensive,'' said Ted Zachary, executive producer of ''Another You,'' a comedy with Richard Pryor and Gene Wilder now filming around the city. ''But the crews are terrific, and it's still the most exciting city in which to make movies.''
Don Scardino, the director and producer of ''The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd,'' a half-hour series on the Lifetime cable channel, agrees: ''What you get in New York is a detail and a character of the city you can't get in Toronto, you can't get in L.A.''
Among those who linger to watch, most are satisfied with a glimpse of the celebrities on a set. But some feel the need to make their presence known. For the last month, Spike Lee has been shooting his new movie, ''Jungle Fever,'' an inter-racial love story, around New York. (The filming has not gone entirely smoothly: two weeks ago, a store Mr. Lee had rented for the project was vandalized; the police, who say they suspect the incident may have been racially motivated, are still investigating.) Huge crowds have gathered to watch Mr. Lee work, especially in Harlem, and scores of people have tried to funnel notes to the director through his P.A.'s. Sometimes they offer screenplays or audiotapes. Mr. Lee's P.A.'s don't accept notes, however; instead, they give out the director's office address. On ''The Prince of Tides'' set, dozens of onlookers have sent flowers to Ms. Streisand. One offered a yarmulke.
 
Mingling With the Crowd
Even better than sending a message, of course, is meeting a celebrity in person. Mr. Lee is reputed to mingle freely with the public when he has time. But waiting for the right moment can take patience. A few weeks ago, Jacqulyn Frasier (who lives near one of ''Jungle Fever's'' main locations) spent both her days off waiting from 7 A.M. until 5 P.M. to meet Mr. Lee. She says she didn't mind.
''People think he's not a brother because he doesn't have time to give his autograph,'' she explained. ''He is a brother. He's just working.''
For many who stop to watch Mr. Lee direct, of course, seeing him is more than just a chance to brush up against fame: it's an opportunity to feel closer to a man who has managed to raise issues of passionate concern to a wide array of people.
''It's good because he's young, he's black, and we need a black perspective,'' said Pam Decuir, who stood on Lenox Avenue watching the ''Jungle Fever'' crew walk in and out of Sylvia's Restaurant, where Mr. Lee, Wesley Snipes, Annabella Sciorra and the rap artist Queen Latifah were shooting an interior scene recently.
 
From Passer-by to Performer
The ultimate thrill for a spectator on location, surely, is to be drafted into the production. And it can happen. Yaacov Piates, a young man watching ''The Prince of Tides'' filming, said that a few months ago he was asked by a crew member to wear a waiter's white jacket and sell a slice of pizza to Al Pacino in ''The Godfather Part III,'' then shooting in Little Italy. And Steven Smalls, after doggedly following ''Jungle Fever'' from set to set for weeks, finally got his wish and was cast as an extra in a vast crowd scene. Is he an actor? ''Yes,'' Mr. Smalls, a television cable installer before entering show business, answered happily. ''Now I am.''

HEADLINE: Auctions

BYLINE: By Rita Reif

 BODY:

Southeast Asia and India
The most important New York auctions of Southeast Asian and Indian art in many years are to take place next week at Sotheby's and Christie's. Both houses report that the market for such Oriental objects came alive again in London and New York in recent seasons. And after Sotheby's announced in July that it would auction the bulk of what remains in the Pan-Asian collection owned by Robert Ellsworth, a New York dealer, on Oct. 5, other major properties were acquired by both houses for these sales.
When asked this week how Sotheby's expects its two-day sale to do in this economic climate, Carlton C. Rochell Jr., a specialist in this type of art, said: ''A lot of people are asking this question, especially consignors. I am hoping the quality works will sell well. I don't think the best works will be affected.'' 
The Ellsworth holdings - 137 stone and bronze sculptures of the second to 16th centuries - are to be auctioned at 2 P.M. next Friday. This collection of Asian art was formed from the 1950's through the 70's, with Mr. Ellsworth's advice, by the New York financier Christian Humann. After Mr. Humann's death in 1981, Mr. Ellsworth bought the collection of about 1,600 paintings and objects for about $12 million.
He sold many works to museums and collectors. Widespread interest in works from the collection stems in part from the fact that the Humann holdings were exhibited and catalogued, which made the collection immune to claims from the countries of origin that the artworks had been smuggled.
''It was all recorded in museums in the United States by 1972,'' Mr. Ellsworth said, citing the date when the statute protecting archeological sites internationally under the Unesco convention was enacted by Congress.
The works commanding the most interest include a ninth-century red sandstone figure of a voluptuous river goddess, which is estimated to bring $250,000 to $350,000; a dancing study of the elephant-headed god Ganesha from the 10th or 11th century ($80,000 to $100,000); a 13th-century seductive celestial nymph ($60,000 to $90,000); an imposing 12th-century sandstone Khmer Vishnu ($200,000 to $250,000), and a beautifully modeled south Indian bronze of a Bodhishattva from the 12th or 13th century (150,000 to $200,000).
Sotheby's sale is to continue at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. on Oct. 6, with the auction of sculpture from other owners, including a life-size 12th- or 13th-century figure of a divinity from the estate of Richard B. Gump, the San Francisco retailer, who died a year ago. The presale estimate is $60,000 to $90,000.
The sale at Christie's, to be held at 2 P.M. on Wednesday, is the first of Indian paintings and Southeast Asian sculpture at the New York house in eight years.
''The demand for Indian art is slowly expanding,'' said Caroline Blyth, one of Christie's London specialists in Asian art, who helped organize the sale here. ''There is a very strong market in London, and at Sotheby's recent New York sales, prices were improving.''
Among the Indian paintings at Christie's is a previously unrecorded 16th-century Mughal depiction of men battling a sea monster in the Indian Ocean. The whereabouts of this illustration from the book ''Dastan-i-Amir Hamza'' was unknown until the owner submitted a photograph to Christie's in April.
''I knew instantly what it was,'' Ms. Blyth said. ''I took the next plane to Europe to see it in person.'' She said the owner had no idea of the importance of the illustration, which Christie's estimates will bring $150,000 to $250,000.
Outstanding among the bronzes at Christie's is a rare 11th-century figure of two deities - Siva embracing Parvati - standing on a lotus leaf, formerly in the collection of John D. Rockefeller 3d. The 17-inch-tall Chola dynasty sculpture, carried in salvation processions, is ''one of only four or five known works of two such figures in public or private collections in this country,'' Ms. Blyth said.
The presale estimate for this sculpture, being sold by Senator John D. Rockfeller 4th of West Virginia, who inherited it, and his wife, Sharon, is $150,000 to $200,000.
 
Garbo Writes
Twelve letters and a cablegram identified as handwritten by Greta Garbo to the photographer Cecil Beaton are to be auctioned on Nov. 7 by R. M. Smythe & Company of New York at the Dorset Hotel, 30 West 54th Street. Wilmer S. Roberts, a vice president of Smythe, said the anonymous owner of the letters said they were a gift in 1977 from Mr. Beaton, who insisted they not be disposed of until after he and Garbo died.
Only four letters bear dates, from 1946 to 1965, and only seven are signed or initialed with variations of Garbo's pseudonym, Harriet Brown - as Harriet, Harry, H or G. The letters express affection, irritation and, in one case, a threat: ''If you publish more than one permitted photograph, I shall not forgive you.''
The presale estimates range from $1,200 to $3,000 each.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Ray Parker's Piece of the Abstract Puzzle

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRENSON

 BODY:
Ray Parker had talent. His high-pitched, low-key abstract paintings are pleasurable and occasionally eye-opening. He was daring in his color, inventive (although not always successful) in his experiments with line, and capable of easy and expansive surfaces that surely bear the memory of the big spaces of South Dakota, where he was born.
But Parker also underlines the problems facing revisionist art historians whose mission is to make room within art history for artists who have been pushed aside or left out of it. He did not have the force of vision, imagination or personality of a great artist. He deserves a place in the history of American abstraction, particularly in the postwar American effort to reconcile the open-endedness and sweep of Abstract Expressionism with the refined lyricism of Matisse, but it is a modest place - and it is not so easy to define what that place is. 
The mini-retrospective now at Hunter College was planned to commemorate Parker's retirement in 1989 from Hunter, where he had taught for more than 30 years. However, he died in April at the age of 67, and the exhibition became a memorial. The curator is William C. Agee, the noted scholar of American art, who teaches at Hunter. He was assisted by four Hunter students: Douglas Canfield, Michael Rubenstein, and Kate and Caroline Parker, the artist's daughters. The 18 paintings date from 1955 to 1990; there is no trace of the pre-New York years. In the earliest painting, in oil, Parker, like many other painters in New York City in the 1950's, began to pull apart the Cubist grid by enlarging individual sections and turning them into irregularly shaped blocks of color. In an acrylic painting from 1977, he squeezed lines directly from the tube onto a monochromatic ground in a way that predicts the recent webs of Brice Marden. There are lyrical paintings from the 1980's in which colors billow and slide and remain entirely at peace with the colors around them, no matter how different.
In one economical painting, from 1962, a big red vertical brushstroke is suspended and flattened on an off-white ground, an emblem of expressionism that has become an icon and a specimen. In a more elaborate painting, from 1984, two large, boulderlike red forms rest weightless on a blackish horizon with a two-toned blue sky leaning against them or touching them as gently as silk. Here the color, shape and line play with and against one another in a way that eventually negates any impression of pictorial unity.
Parker comes out of modernism. Like Stuart Davis and many other American painters, he loved jazz (he played trumpet) and had faith that an improvisational, musical approach to painting could provide a viable alternative to traditional composition. (Isn't it about time this pictorial faith in jazz is both fully acknowledged and seriously questioned?) He loved Matisse, whose book ''Jazz'' was published in 1947, and continued to be inspired by Matisse's approach to color and shape. Parker's relationship to the Abstract Expressionists was essential. His work has obvious similarities to the paintings of Robert Motherwell and less obvious similarities to the work of Willem de Kooning and Franz Kline. Parker shared the Abstract Expressionist belief in painting as possibility and freedom.
But Parker was not an Abstract Expressionist. His ambition was not heroic. There are almost no signs of struggle, heaviness and brooding in his work. There is no metaphysical longing. Parker was a formalist in his belief that the medium of painting could determine its message.
One reason his work is not fuller is that color and shape can be sufficient in themselves only with an artist of the rarest touch and imagination. Another reason is a conflict within the work. On the one hand, Parker wanted a painting to be a place in which everything fit together. On the other hand, he made paintings in which the pieces of the pictorial puzzle move in so many directions that there cannot be a seamless fit. The work in this show swings between classicism and anti-classicism. It does not come down on one side; unlike the work of an Abstract Expressionist like de Kooning, for example, it is not both together. The paintings of Ray Parker remain at the Bertha and Karl Leubsdorf Art Gallery in the Hunter West Building, on 68th Street at Lexington Avenue, and on the 11th floor of the Hunter North Building, across 68th Street, through Oct. 26.
 
'Eugene Von Bruenchenhein (1910 to 1983)'
Edward Thorp Gallery
103 Prince Street
Through Oct. 13
Was Eugene Von Bruenchenhein really born or was he invented by the romantic imagination? He was a self-taught painter who worked most of his life in a flower shop and then in a bakery, painting passionately whenever he had time, as well as making sculptures (sometimes with chicken bones), writing clipped metaphysical poetry, studying botany and astronomy, and developing quack theories about the origins of life.
When he died in 1983, every nook and cranny of his shacklike house on the outskirts of Milwaukee was stuffed with art; his wife, Marie, had almost no money, and this obsessed, possessed, diminutive artist (too short for the Army), who had warned against the dangers of fame, was unknown.
The Edward Thorp Gallery, ever on the lookout for eccentric visionaries who are true painters, has brought 37 paintings and photographs by Von Bruenchenhein to New York. Most are from 1957 to 1960. This is definitely not art about art. Everything in the work seems to evolve from natural history. Where there are human images, as in paintings inspired by the explosion of the hydrogen bomb in 1954, they are generated by clouds. The mythical creatures looming and hovering within the paintings resemble flowers and plants. This was an artist for whom the National Geographic was a good deal more important than Symbolism or Surrealism.
The bottom line is that Von Bruenchenhein was a good painter. He often applied pigment directly to the surface and then painted with his fingers. He also drew shapes with sticks, cardboard, leaves and combs. His paintings were usually made in a single session or bout, which helps explain their freshness. Von Bruenchenhein had a good idea how to create space, sometimes making the backgrounds seem vast and distant and then pulling the imagery into the foreground plane so that the plant or insect forms seem to erupt. Von Bruenchenhein rarely overplayed his hand. Precision and intuition balance each other. The painting is not finicky.
More than half the works in the show are photographs of Marie. Von Bruenchenhein clearly loved her, and his photographs have an odd combination of voyeurism and purity. He photographed her as his muse, his Eve, his queen, his wide-eyed innocent, his pinup girl, his temptress. He saw her in the same way he saw the universe he painted - as seductive, forbidden, innocent, lovely, overflowing with desire and wonder too great for him, too great for the world.
 
Anish Kapoor
Barbara Gladstone Gallery
99 Greene Street
Through Oct. 6
This fine show of 21 works on paper, from 1987 to the present, is likely to increase the public of the sculptor Anish Kapoor. Although the works are abstract, many suggest nature - plants, or the sun or moon. There is a feeling for the single shape, for its relationship to space, and for the power of light, even in darkness. Throughout the works, there is faith in materials and an attempt to use pigment, ink and paper to arrive at a sensation that is intoxicating and fearsome. The works are economical in form only. A black oval spits white. A black rectangle, like a modernist square, has lines coming out of it like snakes out of Medusa's head. Particularly in the circles and ovals, there is a sense of something unpredictable and irrepressible about to happen.
 
Nick Ghiz
Penine Hart Gallery
568 Broadway (at Prince Street)
Through tomorrow
This is Nick Ghiz's most distilled and pointed show. It consists entirely of wall sculptures, assembled, as always, with found objects: everything here was once part of a chair. They leave no doubt about his ability to make sculpture that activates space through controlled surfaces and through lines that are supple and sure. The titles (like ''Ninevah,'' ''Ozymandias'' and ''Isaurian'') come out of history, literature and myth. In ''Tarquinia,'' it is easy to see in the movement of the sculptural line the memory of bulls' horns and dancing arabesques in Etruscan tombs. Take a look at the way Mr. Ghiz uses light: in ''Maschera,'' the light falling on a black wood chair back, which seems to have just split in the middle, produces shadows like wings around the mask.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
After Eight Years, the Bear Is Back

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
At first, as the stock market tumbled in early August, the denizens of Wall Street talked of ''an air pocket'' or ''a correction,'' reminding one another that the market had quickly recovered after even sharper declines in 1987 and 1989.
But the reality seems to be setting in: After a greedy, giddy, eight-year bull market, the bear is back.
And unlike the short-lived market drops in 1987 and 1989, this market downturn is likely to last long enough to be felt as much on Main Street as on Wall Street, economists say. ''I think this is going to be a long, drawn-out affair,'' said Mickey Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities in New York. ''And from a Main Street standpoint, a bear market hurts, because of the loss in wealth that it causes.'' 
In the vernacular of the investing world, a bear market is one in which stock prices shuffle downward, more or less steadily, for a sustained period. There is no universally accepted rule about how long a downtrend must persist to qualify as a bear market. Like the recessions that often accompany them, bear markets are usually acknowledged well after they have actually begun. And with the Dow Jones industrial average down 19 percent since July, to its lowest level in 16 months, all but the most stalwart Wall Street optimists seem to be bracing for a prolonged bear market.
For the millions of people too young to remember the bear's last visit to Wall Street - from 1980 through the end of August 1982 - this is a whole new world. Bear markets are characterized by pain - and not only for those who raise money and invest on Wall Street. A prolonged bear market darkens the national outlook. People spend less and invest more cautiously, altering how much money is available for corporate expansion, what kinds of companies can prosper, how many new jobs are created and which are eliminated. ''This is not a Wall Street phenomenon,'' Mr. Levy said. ''It is an economic phenomenon.'' Of course, the bear market is already changing the daily business of Wall Street, shrinking revenues and putting new and sometimes unfamiliar demands on a brokerage industry that has been pulling in its belt since the 1987 crash.
For the millions of Americans who have a stake in the stock market through their profit-sharing plans, 401(k) plans and other retirement savings accounts, the first jolt of bear-market pain will come a few months from now, when they get the final tally of their portfolios' performance this year.
''For many of those people, this will be the first time in nine years that they will have lost money,'' said Michael F. Wilcox, a principal with the Wall Street firm of Morgan Stanley & Company. While the Dow took a negative dip in 1984, most broader market barometers like the Standard & Poor's Composite Index were positive that year.
Not that the last three years on Wall Street have been placid. The frenzied declines of Oct. 19, 1987, and Oct. 13, 1989, prompted widespread concern about the stability and strength of America's markets, and led to a host of legal and regulatory initiatives aimed at reducing the volatility that produced such precipitous drops.
But the value of America's stock market at the end of each of those years was greater than it had been when the year opened, and those who had invested broadly in the market without panicking had prospered.
This time, barring a remarkable rebound, people who invested in the stock market will have less money on New Year's Eve 1990 than they had last January.
When that fact hits home, it may intensify the stampede of selling, Mr. Wilcox warned. While many professional investors see a bear market as a vast bargain basement where good stocks can be bought cheaply, he said, ''It is far more likely that most people will say: 'Hey, I got burned on stocks. I'm not going to do that again.' The odds are, they will sell just when they ought to buy.''
And when a bear market is accompanied by faltering economic health and international turmoil, as it is now, investors are even more likely to shun stocks, opting for the safety of Treasury bills or gold, deepening the downward spiral.
Changes in investor preference can have far-reaching effects. For one, they alter the value of the stock that public companies use to reward top executives and compensate their rank and file, giving the rare company that is favored on Wall Street in a bear market an edge in attracting and holding good management. The low stock prices of companies that are out of favor may make them vulnerable to a takeover and they may have more difficulty raising money for expansion and acquisitions.
In a bull market, the companies at risk are typically the weakest and worst managed; in a bear market, the rules of Darwin are suspended and almost any company can become easy prey because of its depressed stock price.
Consumers, too, tend to behave differently in a recession-based bear market like this one. ''Simply put,' Mr. Levy said, ''the stock market decline reduces household financial wealth, which has a negative impact on consumers' propensity to spend.''
Of course, some sophisticated investors make money by selling stock in a declining market. They do so by employing a strategy known as short-selling. Short-sellers borrow shares of stock and sell them, betting that the price of the stock will decline before they have to buy new shares to replace the borrowed ones. The difference between the original selling price and the reduced price of the replacement shares is the short-seller's profit.
But selling goes against the grain of Wall Street, said Jack Sullivan, a money manager at Van Kasper & Company in San Francisco who frequently uses short sales as part of his strategy. ''Most of the investment community is structured to buy stocks, not to sell them,'' Mr. Sullivan said. ''That's why pension funds exist and mutual funds exist and bank trust departments exist - to buy stock.''
Like most individual investors, big institutional investors - pension funds and insurance companies, for instance - are often inexperienced short-sellers either because their rules do not permit it or because the long bull market has given them little reason to use the strategy.
While Mr. Sullivan thinks that more institutional investors will embrace the technique, he said, ''Right now, the institutional deck is stacked in favor of buying stocks, not selling them.''
This lack of experience is likely to mean that the earning power of the nation's endowment funds, pension funds and other pools of communal capital will suffer during a long bear market, meaning that those who rely on that capital - from pensioners to universities - will have less available money.
In any case, because of the risks inherent in short-selling, where losses can rise to stunning levels with any unanticipated gain in stock prices, it is unsuitable for all but the most sophisticated investors, market specialists say, reinforcing the notion that the stock market - despite its historic track record of producing inflation-beating wealth for patient individuals - is a game for the experts.
When a rising stock price is no longer a sure bet, sophisticated investors typically focus on classic measures of corporate health and value. They want to know that the size and terms of a company's debt are manageable, and that enough money is available to pay interest. They look for companies whose stocks are modestly priced, compared with their earnings, whose dividend is generous and reliable, and whose credit is good.
Companies that do well by such measures tend to be older, well-established concerns, rather than ambitious start-ups.
In bear markets, investors also have greater demands for information, which has become scarcer in recent years because of the widespread reductions in the number of Wall Street research analysts.
Those Wall Street analysts who remain employed must now adapt to bear-market pressures. That means they can no longer simply recommend good stocks but must also identify stocks to sell - a move they have traditionally been reluctant to make. Corporate executives have been known to jerk their investment banking business away from a brokerage house whose analysts are unenthusiastic about its shares.
Already, all across Wall Street, executives are beginning to talk of the need to do ''more hand-holding'' in the months ahead. ''In these times,'' one portfolio manager said carefully, ''even a well-structured, defensive portfolio has a more worried and concerned owner.'' Are young retail brokers, caught in their first bear market, up to this new task? One enterprising investment consulting firm, the Selbst Group of White Plains, sees room for improvement. It has recently trumpeted the introduction of a ''kinder, gentler sales methodology'' for brokers. Its training regimen instructs brokers to toss out the ''old hard-sell concepts'' and shows them ''how to become empathetic listeners.''
Just as economists bicker over the definition of a recession, not everyone on Wall Street is convinced that the events of the last two months qualify as a genuine bear market. Mr. Sullivan of Van Kasper thinks such quibbles are silly. ''I hardly think the label matters,'' he said. ''If people don't spend, if companies don't commit to capital expenditures, if banks don't lend and if the sickening sense begins to take hold that debt is nobody's friend anymore - it doesn't matter what you call it, it's a problem.''
And it is a problem that will last until the last glimmer of optimism has been quenched, warns Mr. Wilcox at Morgan Stanley. ''The end of the bear market comes when people are at their most pessimistic,'' he said. ''That's when things can start to get better.''

HEADLINE: Deposit Fund Condition Is Worsening

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
The condition of the fund that insures deposits at banks appeared to be worsening, as regulators today revised their estimates of its losses for the year by 50 percent, to more than $3 billion.
In a report on the Bank Insurance Fund's midyear performance, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said the fund had already experienced losses of $1.8 billion for the first six months of the year from 103 bank failures. For the last few weeks, the agency had been estimating that the total annual decline in the insurance fund would be about $2 billion.
 
Economic Trends Reflected
But today L. William Seidman, the chairman of the F.D.I.C., said the estimates were revised to reflect the softening of real estate markets in many areas of the country and the growing problems in the loan portfolios at a number of large institutions. 
In a pointed example of the financial strains in the industry, especially in the Northeast, the Bank of Boston Corporation, the largest banking company in New England, today announced it was trimming its work force and lowering its dividend. Its action came just a week after the Chase Manhattan Corporation took similar steps. [Page D6.] Regulators were quick to point out today in discussing the bank insurance fund that while it was reaching a precariously low level and could be wiped out by the collapse of one or a few large institutions, the situation did not pose an immediate crisis. As of June 30, the fund totaled $11.4 billion, down from $13.2 billion at the beginning of the year.
''I don't think it's a question of crisis and panic,'' Mr. Seidman said in an impromptu discussion with reporters in a hallway outside where he had just presented the report to a House Banking subcommittee. ''It's a sign of increased stress.''
Only seven months ago, Mr. Seidman told Congress that the fund would probably break even this year. $1.25 Per $100 Considered Safe If the F.D.I.C. forecast for the rest of the year is borne out, the ratio of insurance to bank deposits, already at its lowest level in the fund's 57-year-history, at about 70 cents to every $100 in deposits, will fall to about 50 cents to $100 of deposits by December. The lowest level considered safe by regulators is $1.25 per $100 in deposits.
The report was issued this morning as the F.D.I.C. board approved a proposal submitted last month to raise the premiums that banks are assessed for the insurance fund to the maximum amount permitted under the law. The board's action means that in January, premiums will rise by 30 percent over a previously scheduled increase, to 19.5 cents for every $100 in deposits.
The premiums are now at 12 cents for every $100 in deposits and had originally been scheduled to rise to 15 cents. Last year, banks paid 8.3 cents for every $100 in deposits. $1.2 Billion Drop by December Based on an examination of the 1,034 ''problem banks'' that are among the most likely candidates to fail, the agency estimated that the insurance fund will decline by at least another $1.2 billion by Dec. 31. It has posted losses since 1987, when it was at $18.3 billion.
With declining earnings at many of the nation's leading banks, analysts and industry officials expect that the premium increases will be passed on to bank customers. Depositors will probably see a drop in interest paid on their accounts, while borrowers will likely see an increase in interest and other charges to help the banks pay for the higher premium.
Mr. Seidman said that while some of the difference would be passed on to customers, all of it probably would not. The F.D.I.C. estimated that if it was all eventually paid by bank customers, the annual return on a $10,000 deposit would decline by $4.50.
 
Higher Premiums Expected
There is also a strong view in Washington that the latest estimates, combined with Congressional action that is expected soon to eliminate the limits that prevent further increases, could result in yet another rise in the premiums soon. A measure removing the caps has already passed the House, and similar proposals are in the Senate and have been suggested by the Bush Administration.
''This will be bad news to bankers, but they must begin to put this in their contingency plans,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, the executive director of the Independent Bankers Association, a trade group of smaller institutions.
Mr. Seidman said that once the limits on premiums were lifted, the agency would review the effect of a further increase in bank premiums on the solvency of institutions.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Oil Shock's Blow To Rich and Poor

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THIS year's annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank have been dominated by worries about the crisis in the Persian Gulf, the soaring price of oil and its threat to the world economy.
''Unless quickly resolved,'' said Barber B. Conable Jr., president of the World Bank, the gulf crisis ''will have a serious effect on the world's poor and on developing countries.''
More than two million foreign workers were in Iraq and Kuwait when the crisis broke; with the exodus of about half a million workers, foreign remittances to developing countries have fallen, together with their exports. And their import bills have soared because of rising oil prices. To cover emergency needs, Mr. Conable said, the World Bank would ''mobilize additional resources'' and ''coordinate closely with the I.M.F. and others.'' 
Without waiting for World Bank or I.M.F. emergency actions, the United States hastened to raise additional aid for the ''front-line states,'' which it defined as Turkey, Jordan and Egypt.
There are many other countries hit by the oil shock and the United Nations embargo on trade with Iraq and conquered Kuwait. The United States, after getting commitments of about $20 billion to support the front-line states and its own military operations, insists that the other needy countries also be helped. During the annual meetings here, President Bush set up a steering committee of 17 donor countries to decide how emergency aid should be distributed.
There will surely not be enough to go around. The East European countries, struggling to make the transition from Communism to market economies, are pleading for help, but are unlikely to get it from the I.M.F. or World Bank - and they can scarcely look to Moscow anymore.
Some I.M.F. and World Bank officials say the United States initiative will ''act as a brake'' on contributions to developing countries like India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and the Philippines. But American officials insist they are not forgetting those hard-hit countries. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady urged the World Bank to make immediate grants and loans to many of them and called on the I.M.F. to disburse money more quickly from its Compensatory and Contingency Financing Facility.
Unlike what happened during the oil shocks of the 1970's, this time the private commercial banks, many of which are in deep trouble, short of capital, with weak loan portfolios, are not going to do much of the ''recycling of petrodollars'' from rich oil exporters to poor oil importers - which brought on the world debt crisis.
Yet it is unlikely that governments will come up with enough money to cover the hundreds of billions of dollars in transfers from oil-importing to oil-exporting countries, if the price of oil should stay close to its present price of nearly $40 a barrel or climbs still higher. Even the richest oil producer, Saudi Arabia, heavily increasing its aid and putting up a lot more money for weapons, has begun to complain of a ''negative cash flow.''
It is not just the poor who are in trouble. The skyrocketing oil price has intensified worries in the industrial world about both inflation and recession. But except for the United States, all the other industrial countries insist that inflation should be the main target.
Secretary Brady, while soft-pedaling the Treasury's criticism of the Federal Reserve for being too tight, said that both inflation and recession must be opposed. The communique of the Group of Seven industrial countries called for a ''stability oriented'' monetary policy, a euphemism for an anti-inflationary policy that the United States Treasury could regard as a term covering both an anti-inflationary and anti-recessionary policy (or, as a member of Congress once put it, against inflation, against deflation, for flation).
But the common view of the central bankers is that monetary policy cannot be used to fight inflation and recession simultaneously. The best that can be done, they say, is to aim for a reasonable growth rate of ''nominal'' gross national product, allowing the market to determine the split of nominal G.N.P. between real output and inflation. Characteristically, Karl Otto Pohl, president of the German central bank, said the Bundesbank would not relax its strict anti-inflationary stance, even to ease unification with East Germany.
If Alan Greenspan is looking for international reinforcement for continuing the Fed's cautious anti-inflationary policy, he certainly got it from this meeting of the I.M.F. and World Bank. But the Treasury is not giving up its position that lower interest rates are essential for staving off a more serious recession, reducing the Federal deficit and avoiding a possible catastrophe to financial institutions. And given the softness of the economy, it hopes to bring rates down without increasing inflation. Thus, in the midst of the gulf crisis, the quiet war between the Fed and the Treasury continues.

HEADLINE: Temporary Davis Bid For UAL

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 27

 BODY:
The long and tumultuous struggle for control of UAL Inc. took a new and surprising turn today when Marvin Davis, the Los Angeles-based billionaire, said he would buy the airline temporarily, then turn it over in two years to the employee group that is attempting a buyout of the carrier.
In a letter to Gerald Greenwald, the former Chrysler Corporation executive who is leading the employee buyout effort, Mr. Davis said his idea was to provide the employees with, in effect, two years' worth of breathing room during which time they could line up financing for their own $201-a-share, $4 billion offer for the airline. UAL's board has already accepted that offer, but Wall Street has doubted the employee group's ability to line up financing for the bid.
At the end of the two-year period, Mr. Davis wrote, the employees would have the right to buy back UAL from Mr. Davis at a price that would allow him to earn an adequate return on his investment. 
''Basically, Davis sees an opportunity not only to make money for himself but to facilitate the employees' efforts,'' one person familiar with the situation said late today.
Other than to say that he and his partners would bring $750 million in equity to the deal, Mr. Davis failed to disclose the price he would pay to acquire UAL, making it unclear whether the board would even be amenable to a Davis offer. But any offer from Mr. Davis would probably at least have to match the employees' offer of $201 a share.
The Davis proposal, which follows his $275-a-share bid for the airline proposed slightly more than a year ago, could send UAL's stock soaring. Wall Street's skepticism about the ability of the employees to finance their bid has caused UAL's stock to sag in recent weeks. UAL's stock closed down today at $90.625, off $1.375, in Big Board trading.
Indeed, because the UAL board had given the employee group only until Oct. 9 to obtain financing, the consensus in the investment community was that a takeover of the airline was virtually impossible at this point.
But the Davis offer today changes the calculus of the situation entirely. To use his words, Mr. Davis is proposing to ''bridge the acquisition of United for its labor and employee groups for a period of two years.''
James Fingeroth, Mr. Davis's spokesman at Kekst & Company, the New York-based public relations firm, had no further comment. Peter Rosenthal, the public-relations man for the employee buyout group, also had no comment other than to say that the employee group had received the Davis letter and was reviewing it.
But in his letter, which was sent to the press, Mr. Davis did provide some details of his plan. Specifically, he said that if his plan had the employees' support he would commence negotiations immediately with the UAL board with an eye toward acquiring the company at a price that is prudent ''in the present environment.''
According to people close to the situation, Mr. Davis was referring to the sluggish economy and to the higher fuel costs that all airlines have been forced to pay of late. It thus appeared that Mr. Davis would try to persuade the UAL board to accept an offer lower than $201 a share. That offer was made well before the price of oil began to rise.
Mr. Davis said that if his proposal could be consummated, the employees would be given an immediate 20 percent ownership in UAL in exchange for labor concessions of equal worth. They would also be given minority representation on the new UAL board proportionate to their 20 percent interest in the company.
UAL has been consumed by takeover activity, both real and rumored, since 1987. It first received an offer from the pilots' union, which was followed by Mr. Davis's first offer. Since then, thecompany has received two offers from broader employee groups, including the one now pending.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Large Cutbacks At Laura Ashley

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Laura Ashley said it would sell or close most of its factories and cut its work force by one-fifth in an effort to survive. The retailer of English country-style women's clothing and home furnishings operates nearly 500 stores worldwide, 185 of them in the United States.
The company blamed the strong British pound and high inflation for its problems. Seven of its nine factories in Britain and Ireland will be closed or sold, the company said.

HEADLINE: Bush's Move on Stockpile Brings Some Dissent Overseas

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 27

 BODY:
The world's leading industrial nations will hold a crucial meeting on Friday to consider an American proposal that strategic oil reserves be prepared for immediate use. But a group of oil-consuming countries, led by West Germany and Japan, are opposed to the American initiative, arguing that reserve stocks should be tapped only in an extreme case, like the outbreak of war.
The meeting, under the auspices of the 21-member International Energy Agency, based in Paris, may well be one of the most important gatherings since the little-known organization was conceived in 1973 to shield Western economies from oil-price shocks. 
The debate will involve the best ways to use the estimated 1.7 billion barrels of oil held as reserves by governments and oil companies in the agency's member nations. The United States has given an early signal of the course it favors, announcing on Wednesday that it would sell five million barrels from its strategic reserves.
 
Trying to Influence the Market
''What we want to do is give a signal to world oil markets,'' a senior American energy official said.
Energy Secretary James D. Watkins, however, said in Washington today that tapping the reserve was merely a test of the system, not an attempt to rein in prices.
Still, President Bush's decision to tap the reserve was seen here as a strong signal that the United States wants similar actions from other nations. But West Germany's Economics Minister, Helmut Haussman, said today that his country was not in favor of such a move, arguing that there is no world oil shortage and that ''it is wrong to think it is possible to keep prices artificially low through state measures.''
West Germany and Japan are the two other countries that have enormous oil stockpiles, and the United States' action has put both nations under pressure to come up with alternative strateegies. The United States, Germany and Japan hold nearly a billion barrels in government reserves, and oil companies in the three nations hold several hundred million more.
''Western governments never had the option of recourse to strategic stocks because the reserves did not exist during previous crises,'' said Simon Blakey, a former official of the agency who is an analyst with Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris.
Friday's meeting here will be attended by senior energy officials from all 21 members. Even though the headquarters are here, France is not a member of the agency but it has now applied to join, strengthening the consuming nations' hopes of presenting a solid front in the crisis.
 
Output Below Expectations
The meeting comes amid increasing evidence that crucial OPEC oil exporters, like Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and the United Arab Emirates, have not been able to raise production fast enough or high enough to make up fully for the shortfall from Kuwait and Iraq, estimated at more than four million barrels a day.
Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have not been able to produce more than an additional 2.5 million barrels a day but world oil markets expected their combined extra output to be about three million barrels a day, Arab oil industry executives said today. Venezuela has increased output by 500,000 barrels a day.
Some analysts suggested that by dipping into its reserves, the United States was also telling its allies that it foresees serious shortages in the coming months because of the strong likelihood of war with Iraq and the rising cold-weather demand for heating oil.

HEADLINE: Bank of Boston Is Planning To Cut Jobs and Dividend

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Bank of Boston Corporation announced cuts in its stock dividend and work force yesterday in the face of a deteriorating economy and a loss of $200 million to $250 million in its present quarter.
The announcement by the largest banking company in New England was a reminder that the nearly two-year-old slide in the regional economy and real estate markets continued unabated, causing loan defaults and heavy losses at banks. With bank profits falling, and in many cases turning into losses, bank stock prices fell sharply yesterday as many analysts became more concerned that banks will cut their stock dividends. 
''Banks are being buffeted from every side, with weak real estate markets, tough regulators, and an economic cycle that is turning down,'' said John J. Mason, an analyst at the Interstate/Johnson Lane Corporation, a brokerage in Charlotte, N.C.
Last week, the Chase Manhattan Corporation announced a cut in its dividend and a third-quarter loss of $625 million resulting from bad real estate loans and costs of cutting its payroll by 5,000 workers.
 
Bank Issues Fare Poorly
Bank stocks were among the worst hit in yesterday's decline, with many companies falling by 5 percent or more while the Dow Jones industrial average fell only about 1.3 percent.
Among the New York City banks that analysts said were candidates for dividend cuts, Citicorp fell 75 cents, to $13.75, the Chemical Banking Corporation fell 87.5 cents, to $14.125, and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation fell $1, to $20.25. Chase's stock fell 12.5 cents, to $11.
By reducing its quarterly stock dividend to 10 cents a share from 31 cents, the Bank of Boston will save $43 million a year. The company expects another $100 million in savings annually by cutting 1,500 of its 18,000 workers through a voluntary retirement plan for employees with 10 years or more of experience.
The Bank of Boston said the third-quarter loss of $200 million to $250 million will be caused by the setting aside of $150 million to $200 million in loan-loss reserves and a $35 million drop in the value of real estate the company owned because of bad loans.
The voluntary retirement program will result in a one-time charge of $50 million, and another $40 million charge results from the company's inability to use foreign tax credits.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bonds Soar in Late Rally

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
A late rally sent prices of Treasury bonds soaring yesterday after a further flight from stocks had lifted prices of the shorter maturities earlier in the session.
The late rally, which ignored soaring oil prices and a rising flow of negative developments in the banking industry, was attributed to reports from Washington that Administration and Congressional leaders were expected to announce this weekend an agreement on a plan to cut the budget deficit.
If the reports prove true, dealers said, it could clear the way for the Federal Reserve to cause interest rates to decline - either directly or, more likely, indirectly.
In late trading, the Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in August 2020, were being offered at 97 8/32, up 1 2/32 on the day, while the yield plunged to 9.01 percent, from 9.12 the day before and unchanged from Friday. 
Dealers attributed much of the earlier demand for long-term Treasury issues, which had raised prices as much as 11/32, to a further erosion of prices of bank holding company bonds and stocks and, worse, the lack of liquidity in the market for the debt issues of many parents of leading banks.
''The bids for bank debt issues have dried up to the point where the market has become illiquid,'' said Thomas P. Quigley, senior vice president at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''As a result, many quotes are more nominal than a reflection of normal two-way trading.''
Nominal or not, Mr. Quigley noted that what bids there were tended to shave a further 25 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from the prices of typical 10-year debt issues of such bank holding companies as Chase Manhattan, Citibank, Chemical, Bank of America and others.
''To make matters worse,'' Mr. Quigley continued, ''we are seeing sellers emerge when prices fall, not buyers, which is normally the case with the debt issues of such top names. And the illiquidity in this market is now spreading to many other financial paper markets.''
William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, noted that ''the reports about a budget agreement was what the fixed-income debt market needed, especially at a time when the significance of $40 oil and the troubles of the commercial banking industry are starting to sink in.''
 
Long-Term Treasury Debt
The long-term Treasury debt market had been under pressure since Aug. 2, when the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait sent oil prices climbing and threated to unleash another round of inflation, the bane of the fixed-income market. Since Aug. 2, the yield on the long bonds had risen to 9.01 percent from 8.55 percent.
Meanwhile, prices of the shorter Treasury maturities continued to benefit from the flight of capital from the battered stock market as well as the old habit of many investment portfolio managers of window dressing their quarterly reports with large amounts of cash or other highly liquid instruments.
Largely as a result of these two factors, the discount rate on Treasury 90-day bills tumbled a further nine basis points, to 7.21 percent; six-month bills plunged 14 basis points, to 7.21 percent, while the demand for one-year bills caused the rate to drop 11 basis points.
Among other short-term issues that would most immediately benefit from a cut in interest rates, the yield on the new 8 1/8 percent two-year Treasury notes dropped to 8.02 percent in trading on a when-issued basis, from 8.14 percent the day before. The two-year notes were auctioned Tuesday at an average yield of 8.18 percent.
The yield on the 8.5 percent four-year notes auctioned on Wednesday, at an average yield of 8.53 percent, traded on a when-issued basis to yield 8.38 percent.
Also closely monitored is the yield on the Treasury's long notes, the 8.75's of August 2000, because they are considered to compete with the 10-year bonds ''long bonds'' of Japan and West Germany. The late rally sent the long notes up 19/32, to 99 8/ 32, while its yield fell to 8.86 percent from 8.97 percent the day before.
The yield on Japan's 10-year bonds, their longest maturity, slipped to 8.69 percent from 8.72 percent as a flight from their weakened stock market also caused a flight to quality. The yield on West Germany's 10-year long bonds remained unchanged at 9.11 percent.
Once again the Fed injected overnight reserves into the banking system, partly to accommodate the end of quarter demand for cash from domestic portfolio managers as well as some Japanese banks. Today marks the end of Japan's fiscal half-year, and Japanese portfolio managers, who have sustained heavy losses in their stock market, also wanted to window-dress their half-year accounts with cash.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Offering by Massachusetts Has Maximum Yield of 8%

 BODY:
The Commonwealth of Massachusetts, whose fiscal stability is under siege from a weakening economy, various legal challenges and a tax-cut proposal to be voted on in November, came to market yesterday with a $1.3 billion offering of fixed- and variable-rate securities through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
Proceeds from the sale will be used to clear the state's accumulated deficit of $1.3 billion.
The sale involves four series of bonds, three of which are secured by letters of credit. 
The $1.025 billion series A portion includes serial bonds priced to yield from 7.25 percent for an issue due in 1992 to 7.95 percent in 1996. There are also term bonds due in 1997 priced to yield 8 percent, and zero-coupon bonds, which pay no interest but if held to maturity in 1997 yield 8 percent.
The series A bonds are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and they are secured by a portion of the state's personal income tax revenue that is deposited monthly in a special trust fund and would be insulated from any effects of passage of the tax-cut proposal that the group Citizens for Limited Taxation put on the November ballot.
Underwriters said the series B, C, and D bonds were being issued as commercial-paper-type instruments, with yields ranging from 6.15 percent to 6.75 percent, and maturities running from October 1990 to July 1991.
The variable-rate issues backed by letters of credit are rated accordingly. About $125 million of bonds secured by a letter from National Westminster Bank and short-term ratings of Aaa/VMIG-1 by Moody's and AA+/A-1+ by S.&P. The $100 million of bonds backed by a letter from Union Bank of Switzerland's New York branch are rated Aaa/ VMIG-1 by Moody's and AAA/A-1+ by S.& P. The remaining $50 million in bonds is secured by a letter from Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank Ltd. and is rated Aa-3/VMIG-1 by Moody's and A+/A-1+ by S.&P.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Joins the Price Slide Of Other Precious Metals

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices reversed a three-day trend and fell yesterday, despite modest gains in crude oil prices, as speculators seemed to put aside fears over the Middle East crisis.
Bullion settled $1.90 to $2.20 an ounce lower on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in September down $1.60, to $405 an ounce.
Silver and platinum, meanwhile, extended their losses of the week, which has pushed the metals to their lowest levels in years. Reports of weak economic activity in the United States depressed silver and platinum because they are widely used as industrial material. 
Platinum settled on the New York Mercantile Exchange $10.70 to $11.60 an ounce lower, with October at $437.30 a ounce. Silver fell 3 cents to 2.7 cents an ounce on the Commodity Exchange, with October at $4.771 an ounce.
 
Shift in Strategy
Gold's downturn yesterday could signal that speculators are getting over fears of war in the Middle East and are concentrating more on inflation and a possible recession, where they would be more inclined to hoard their money, analysts said. They said the war fears might have led to gold's rise earlier in the week despite the drop in silver and platinum, which gold usually follows.
''Gold has been trading on the emotion of the market and has always been an emotional safe haven for people in times of distress,'' said Nina Lipton, vice president of Platinum Guild International in New York. ''I think the market is acting on impressions, not reality.''
On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat, soybean and corn futures had an unremarkable day of trading.
Wheat futures prices extended Wednesday's gains after the Agriculture Department confirmed reports that it had offered to sell subsidized flour to the Soviet Union, Morocco and other West African countries.
Soybean futures prices followed wheat's lead after the Agriculture Department also reported the Soviet Union might be interested in buying soybean meal, said Walter Spilka, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York.
Corn futures prices were mostly lower in thin, quiet trading after morning weather reports predicted near-ideal harvest weather over the next week. Good weather holds prices lower because is decreases the fear of shortages.
The Agriculture Department's grain stocks report was also a factor in the thin trading, some analysts said. But Mr. Spilka said after the report's release at the close of trading that it should have little effect on today's market.
''In the past, the numbers have been all over the map,'' he said. ''I wouldn't place great emphasis on the report having much influence.''
The numbers represent the Government's estimate on the stockpile of grains as of Sept. 1.
Meat futures rebounded after three days of losses amid optimism that a Federal budget agreement could be reached by Monday.
