HEADLINE: Tax Compromises Open Way To Pact in Budget Talks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
White House officials agreed in private budget negotiations tonight to a higher income tax on wealthy Americans in return for a lower capital gains tax, officials from both parties said.
The concession was an important breakthrough and could pave the way for a deficit-reduction agreement over the weekend.
''The issues now boils down to numbers and not to principles, and with numbers you can often split the difference,'' a Democrat said.
Until now, the White House has adamantly refused to allow tax rates to be raised, a vestige of President Bush's campaign pledge of no new taxes.
 
Work on Monday
Democrats have refused to allow a tax break for capital gains, which would mostly benefit the wealthy, unless it was accompanied by an offsetting higher tax on upper-income taxpayers. 
If no law is passed by Monday appropriating money for the new fiscal year, most Government activities will be shut down for lack of financing. Congress is prepared to approve a stopgap law, but President Bush has said he would veto it without a budget agreement. The budget negotiators adjourned just before midnight. Richard G. Darman, the budget director, instructed Government agencies tonight to have Federal workers come to work as usual Monday morning, the first day of the fiscal year, but he said most would have to be sent home if no appropriations law had been passed or passage did not seem to be imminent.
 
Exhorting the Troops
Republicans offered several different proposals today involving a tax rate on the wealthy slightly higher than the current 28 percent. Each of the offers was met with a Democratic counteroffer.
Earlier today, backbench lawmakers in both parties said Congress might reject a deficit-reduction deal that would cut Social Security and raise taxes.
Democratic and Republican leaders in the House, trying to stem defections, called their troops into separate party caucuses this morning to try to convince them that a budget deal as a whole would be palatable, even if individual elements were distasteful.
More than half the Republican congressmen have signed a pledge that they will vote against any measure that raises taxes, as every budget deal under consideration does.
 
'No Pleasure in This Package'
Dozens of members of both parties have sworn on the campaign stump that they would not reduce Social Security benefits. And many Democrats have said that as a matter of principle, they could not vote for any measure that cut the capital gains tax.
It was difficult to judge today whether a revolt was gathering against the party leaders or whether the strong talk was no more than the posturing that often precedes a difficult vote.
Whatever the case, this comment from Senator Trent Lott, a Mississippi Republican, was typical: ''Who wants to vote for Medicare cuts? Who wants to vote for Social Security cuts? Who wants to vote for a gasoline tax? I'm frustrated with the leadership, and what I've heard them saying doesn't reflect my views.''
After the Democratic representatives met, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, said he had told them: ''You've got to understand there is no pleasure in this package. But you've got to look at the positive side of getting it done.''
Representative Mel Levine of California was one of many Democrats who was skeptical. ''I hope I'll be able to vote for it,'' he said after listening to Mr. Gephardt's presentation. ''But given what I've heard, I'm not sure I can. I think a lot of people feel that way.''
Representative Jim Kolbe of Arizona said his Republican colleagues went into their meeting this morning ''loaded for bear.''
 
Soothing White House Talk
But John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director, spoke to the Republicans and managed to soothe them somewhat.
Afterward, Representative Jerry Lewis of California, chairman of the Republican Caucus, said, ''I'm not suggesting at all that at this point a majority of Republicans would be willing to vote for a package, but they are very positively wanting to look and make a judgment.''
The chief economic policy makers from the White House and the top Congressional leaders, who have been meeting until midnight or later all week, were trying to resolve the final two sticking points: how to cut Social Security and what to do about capital gains taxes and offsetting taxes on the wealthy.
Little word seeped out of their backroom meeting. But it seemed clear that if an agreement can be reached, Social Security recipients would be affected. Either a higher portion of the benefits of those with moderate incomes and above will be taxed, as Democrats prefer, or cost-of-living increases for all recipients will be delayed, as Republicans want.
Both sides had kept the Social Security issue off stage until this week. But once it became public, intense lobbying from groups of elderly voters began.
One group, Families United for Senior Action, offered today to put reporters and lawmakers in touch with individual residents of their hometowns who would suffer if their benefits were reduced.
The capital gains question was also still in the air. Tonight, staff assistants said, the White House moved closer to the Democratic view that a capital gains tax break would have to be offset by a higher income tax on the wealthy.
Earlier this week, Republicans suggested that instead of lowering the capital gains tax rate, as they initially proposed, that capital gains be taxed in a way that would exclude the portion of profit attributable to inflation, in a process called indexing.
 
Tax Study Shakes Democrats
Some Democrats saw a possible compromise in the new proposal, but many have become more wary as the days have passed. They were shaken by a new staff calculation that showed indexing to be much more costly to the Government than the original Bush proposal after six or seven years.
Capital gains are the profits from the sale of investments.
A study produced today by Citizens for Tax Justice, a union-sponsored research organization, showed that 50 percent of the benefits from capital gains indexing would go to taxpayers with incomes above $200,000 and that 71 percent would go to those with incomes above $100,000.
That is only slightly different from the effects of the original Bush plan. The study was based on figures compiled by the nonpartisan Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation.
At the same time, the American Council on Capital Formation, a business lobby, was working against indexing and in favor of a capital gains tax cut.
Mark Bloomfield, executive director of the organization, said indexing might help investors who play the stock market but would do little to encourage risky ventures in small businesses.
 
Sunday Session Is Planned
Congress recessed this afternoon for Yom Kippur, the Jewish holiday that began at sundown, and will reconvene for an unusual Sunday session.
In their overall plan, the negotiators are seeking to cut the deficit by $50 billion in the next fiscal year and $500 billion over five years.
Before Monday, when the new fiscal year begins, Congress must pass and President Bush must sign legislation continuing appropriations for all Government departments and agencies, in order to keep the Government running normally.
Such legislation is generally routine when, as is usually the case, the regular appropriations bills have not been enacted at the start of the fiscal year.
But this year, Congress wants to attach a provision extending for three weeks the deadline for automatic spending cuts under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law. President Bush has pledged to veto a continuing appropriations resolution if it contains the budget law extension.
Without such a resolution, the Government would have no money to spend Monday. What that means is not certain. The Government has never been without funds for more than a few hours.
 
Dispute Over Authority
Relying on a 1981 ruling by Benjamin Civiletti, President Jimmy Carter's Attorney General, the White House has asserted that the President has the authority to maintain essential Government services.
Congressional lawyers say the President has the authority to maintain guards to prevent looting of Government facilities and to instruct air traffic controllers to allow the planes already in the air to land but can do little more under the Constitution.
The White House has not said how extensive it believes its authority is.
Beyond capital gains and Social Security, the budget negotiators have agreed in a number of areas.
Gasoline taxes would be raised by 8 cents a gallon to 17 cents. A smaller tax would be placed on other forms of fuel.
Insurance premiums paid by the elderly for doctors' bills under Medicare would be raised by nearly $6 a month above the current $28.60. The annual Medicare deductible would be increased to $150 from $75.

Meanwhile, lawmakers of both parties worried about a deal that would cut Social Security and raise taxes. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)(pg12)

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
SACKING OF KUWAIT IS PRESSURING U.S.

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
President Bush's national security adviser said today that the ''systematic destruction'' of Kuwait under Iraqi occupation was shortening the time that the United States can wait for economic sanctions to drive President Saddam Hussein's army out of the Persian Gulf sheikdom.
But the official, Brent Scowcroft, stopped short of an explicit warning of American military action.
After a long White House meeting and lunch in which the ousted Kuwaiti Emir, Sheik Ahmed al-Ahmed al-Sabah, warned Mr. Bush that his country was threatened with destruction, Mr. Scowcroft refused to say how long Mr. Bush would wait before concluding that sanctions against Iraq have failed.
 
An 'Ambitious Dictator'
But ''there is no question that what is happening inside Kuwait affects the timetable'' for that decision, he said. Mr. Scowcroft asserted that the plundering of Kuwait by Iraqi troops made it conceivable that the United States would seek another United Nations Security Council resolution, possibly including an explicit mention of military force.
Mr. Scowcroft spoke as a Congressman disclosed American intelligence reports saying that Iraq has developed biological weapons that could deliver significant quantities of the deadly agents to the battlefield by early next year. [Page 4.] Mr. Scowcroft said the United States would consider it an act of aggression if Iraq carried out a threat to cut off food to foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq on Monday. But he would not say how the United States might respond. 
The President offered a harsh condemnation of Iraq after his meeting with the Emir, calling President Saddam Hussein a ''ruthless and ambitious dictator.''
 
'Off the Face of the Map'
In a statement that he read on the White House South Lawn with the Emir at his side, Mr. Bush said: ''Iraqi aggression has ransacked and pillaged a once peaceful and secure country, its population assaulted, incarcerated, intimidated and even murdered. Iraq's leaders are trying to wipe an internationally recognized sovereign state, a member of the Arab League and the United Nations, off the face of the map.''
Mr. Bush's remarks and Mr. Scowcroft's subsequent comments were intended to send another strong signal to President Hussein after a week of international condemnation of Iraq at the United Nations General Assembly in New York.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today concluded a week of meetings in New York with other foreign ministers. The talks left an impression of increasing concern that only a military solution would force Mr. Hussein to withdraw his troops from Kuwait.
 
Baker Sees Arab Support
After meeting today with the foreign ministers of the Gulf Cooperation Council, which includes Kuwait and some of its Persian Gulf neighbors, Mr. Baker said: ''I do think there are a number of countries that make it quite clear we should not foreclose options. I think there are more countries that are willing now to express that view.''
Administration officials said the Tunisian Foreign Minister, Ismail Khalil, who visited President Hussein in Baghdad on Sunday, told Mr. Baker that the Iraqi leader apparently still believes that the international coalition boycotting Iraqi commerce will eventually erode and that he can hold on to Kuwait by stalling for time.
Kuwaiti officials said before the Emir's meeting with Mr. Bush that the exiled monarch would impress on the President that the Kuwaitis do not believe they can wait for sanctions to take hold on Iraq's economy. They said they would argue that, as one official put it, ''military action is the only way.''
Mr. Scowcroft said the Emir did not specifically urge Mr. Bush to attack Iraq. But he said, ''You could subliminally read between the lines if you wish.''
Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said he believed that the Administration is ''looking more and more favorably on the war option'' to force Iraqi troops out of occupied Kuwait.
But Mr. Scowcroft said, ''I think we need to at least come to sincere judgment as to whether or not there is a peaceful way to resolve this.''
The Senate began debating a resolution today that offers strong support for Mr. Bush's actions in the gulf, but stops short of giving a blanket endorsement for unprovoked military strikes against Iraq. A vote on the resolution is expected on Monday, when the House is expected to take action on a similar measure.
The Senate resolution said, ''The Congress supports continued action by the President in accordance with the decisions of the United Nations Security Council and in accordance with United States constitutional and statutory processes, including authorization and appropriations of funds by the Congress, to deter Iraqi aggression and to protect American lives and vital interests in the region.''
The resolution reflects the difficulty for lawmakers, who endorse the President's action so far and believe it is in their political interest to show support but want to be careful to withhold advance approval of actions.
The resolution ''does not constitute authority for the President to initiate unprovoked attacks against Iraq,'' said Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island and chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, After the meeting today, the Emir offered effusive praise of Mr. Bush in a formal statement at the White House.
Speaking through an interpreter, he said, ''Your principled, courageous and decisive position in the face of the Iraqi aggression on Kuwait is a true expression of the unabated faith and commitment of the American people to the humanitarian morals on which and for which the United States of America was founded.''
Mr. Scowcroft said the Emir ''described in some detail some of the atrocities being committed by Arabs against Arabs as well as the pillaging and systematic destruction'' in Kuwait.
Given the urgency that the Emir assigned to the situation, Mr. Scowcroft was asked whether the United States could afford to wait for the United Nations sanctions to strangle Iraq's economy. He replied: ''There is no question that what's happening inside Kuwait affects the timetable. There's no question about that.''
But he also said: ''The sanctions have not been in place very long. I believe it is in everyone's interest to see whether or not there is a peaceful resolution of this.''
Mr. Scowcroft said there was no specific plan for a new Security Council resolution, but added, ''This whole element of what the Iraqis are doing inside Kuwait to a whole people could conceivably be the subject of another U.N. action.''
 
U.S. GENERAL PLAYS DOWN THREAT
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Reuters) - The commander of American forces in the gulf said today that President Saddam Hussein was using more aggressive remarks to intimidate his adversaries, and he discounted any threat of an early Iraqi attack.
''I don't think he's attempting to trigger war,'' Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf said in a satellite interview from Saudi Arabia on the PBS television program ''MacNeil Lehrer News Hour.''
Referring to Mr. Hussein's threat to attack Israel and Arab oilfields, the General said: ''I think what he's trying to do is turn up the level of rhetoric to get everybody a little bit more concerned about the threat of war. But I think that even Saddam Hussein would have to admit today that that would be an act of national suicide.''

HEADLINE: Doctor Fees Found Higher in U.S. Than in Canada

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Doctors in the United States charge more than twice as much as doctors in Canada for the same work, a study says, adding that this helps explain why this country's health care costs are dramatically higher than Canada's.
The study found that despite the larger fees charged by American doctors, they earn only about one-third more than Canadians. The reason is that Canadian doctors are busier and make up for their lower fees by seeing more patients, the study says. 
Unlike the United States, Canada provides complete, fully paid health coverage for all its citizens. One of every seven people in the United States has no health insurance, and even those with coverage typically have to pay at least part of the bill. Despite these differences, the study found that health care costs 20 percent more per person in the United States than in Canada.
 
Object of the Study
In the study, reported Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine, Victor R. Fuchs, an economist at Stanford University, sought the reasons for the differences in the cost of medical care in the two countries.
Over all, physician fees in the United States are 2.4 times those in Canada. Other factors besides doctors' earnings contribute to the lower cost of medical care in Canada.
If physician fees in the United States were cut in half and lowered to the Canadian level, total health care expenditures would be reduced by about 10 percent, Mr. Fuchs said.
Health care now accounts for about 11.5 percent of the gross national product in the United States; in Canada it is about 9 percent. If American spending could be held to the Canadian percentage, more than $100 billion a year would be saved.
Mr. Fuchs's calculations converted Canadian figures into United States dollars. The study was based on 1985 data; American physicians' pay continues to climb sharply.
These were among the findings:
* Doctors provided fewer services per person in the United States than in Canada.
* American fees for surgery and high-technology services like X-rays and anesthesia were more than three times those in Canada.
* On a per capita basis, Canada had more doctors but fewer specialists than the United States.
* In 1985 net income for office-based doctors was $112,199 in the United States and $73,607 in Canada.
* American doctors spend twice as much as Canadians for rent and other office expenses and generally have more attractive offices.
Billing costs are also higher in the United States because Canadian doctors have to deal with only one insurer, the Government of Canada. Canadian fees are uniform for each service within provinces, and are set through negotiations between doctors and the Government.
Mr. Fuchs said he doubted whether the Canadian system could be administered in the United States. ''There is reason to question whether the quality of our civil services is up to the quality of the Canadian civil services,'' he said. ''There is also reason to question whether the organization and degree of discipline in the profession is as strong as in Canada. We are very much individualists, and that includes physicians.''

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Plug In To Moscow

BYLINE: Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Assorted hints have come from Moscow that the Soviets are willing to supply intelligence about Iraq. This could be of critical importance. Long and intimate involvement with the Iraqi military and police establishments, from the top well on down, gave Moscow information unavailable anywhere else.
It is a reflection of the astonishing, still quite incomplete shift in Soviet-American relations that Washington has reacted coolly. There are some valid reasons for caution. 
For one thing, there has been an energetic K.G.B. campaign for nearly a year now to prettify a deservedly ugly image at home and abroad. ''They want to convince us that not even the K.G.B. is still our enemy, but they are still very busy in the U.S.,'' a retired C.I.A. official said.
It isn't clear if the hints are just public relations, or more serious than such on-the-record statements might suggest. Last week Vladimir Kryuchkov, the K.G.B. chairman, received an Associated Press delegation and said, ''I am convinced that we could really tell each other [the C.I.A.] something valuable.''
Now, Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, chief of the Soviet General Staff, tells American newsmen that he is giving details about Soviet-made weapons used by the Iraqis to the U.S. Embassy, but admits that the C.I.A. already knows most of it. Neither he nor Mr. Kryuchkov indicated if there were any terms for the proffered help, but they complained that Washington hasn't signaled much interest.
Washington's view is that there is still a long way to go before the U.S. is ready to exchange secrets, as it does with allies. But it is ready to receive what is provided, preferably through America's Moscow Embassy rather than in leaky Washington.
A distinction needs to be made between military and political intelligence. The former isn't hard to get from observation and regional sources and its use is only in case of war. But political intelligence could be decisive in preventing war, which requires real change in Baghdad.
Talk about negotiating with Saddam Hussein is an illusion. His threats to fight ''to the last drop of [his people's] blood'' and that he will destroy the whole region show how much he cares about his country. If he were French his motto would be Louis XV's ''after me, the deluge.''
Nor should the U.S. wish to devastate Iraq. Its benighted people are victims, not the perpetrators of the crisis. Apart from humane common sense, it would be geopolitical stupidity, similar to the mistake of indulging Mr. Hussein after the Iran-Iraq war.
The main objective, to prevent any tyrant from controlling over half the world's oil, remains valid and there would be no improvement if Iran or Syria succeeded because Mr. Hussein is made to fall. Outsiders cannot heal what ails the Arab states, but they can avoid creating new monsters with lopsided support.
The consequences of war are incalculable. One way to avoid it is to back off, a victory Mr. Hussein would be sure to exploit. A surprising article in the London newspaper The Independent, linked to the anniversary of World War II's Battle of Britain, showed where that reasoning leads.
Terry Coleman, the writer, went through the archives of British diplomacy from 1940 and condemns Winston Churchill for refusing to probe Hitler's secret peace offers. He cites a message through the British Embassy in Stockholm saying ''The Fuhrer feels responsible for the future of the white race'' and would be willing to settle for ''two economic units - continental Europe, which is Germany's, and the British Empire and America.'' That would have brought a hellish peace - for a while.
The other way to avoid war is to get rid of Mr. Hussein. It is what the embargo is really about, and he knows it. Talk of finding him an ''escape hatch'' or ''saving face'' because his demands are limited is the kind of talk Mr. Coleman thinks Churchill should have entertained in 1940. This time the world has organized against aggression, and its determination should inspire Iraqis.
That is where the Soviets come in. Mr. Hussein has foiled many coup attempts, with brutal aftermaths, but the incentive to try again is much greater now and growing. Moscow knows a lot about who is who in the entourage, what might be possible. It has its own good reasons for wanting the crisis to end without a fight.
Washington should encourage the Soviets to pass along useful information, test what they are willing to provide, and assure that confidence will be repected. There is too much to lose without trying it. Mr. Hussein didn't give us time to get used to the idea of such cooperation, but it's vital.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: Small Business in Peril From Street Peddlers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
New York City's 14th Street-Union Square Business Improvement District has been revitalizing our neighborhood for six years. A persistent constraint on our efforts is the proliferation of street peddlers, most of them unlicensed, who line our commercial corridor daily. These peddlers represent a serious economic threat to small business here and throughout the city. They sell the same wares as merchants who pay rentals of upward of $75 a square foot. These peddlers pay no license fees, no taxes and do not contribute to any positive aspects of city life.
They leave mounds of debris and garbage on the street in front of shops, and sanitation enforcement agents give summonses to the storekeepers for this garbage, further adding to their economic burden. Historically, small business has been the city's largest employer.
There is antipeddling legislation on the books, and stronger bills are being proposed by City Councilmember Carol Greitzer. But enforcement is the key. Peddling as a crime has a very low priority with the Police Department. The question is, Who will we drive out of the city first, the illegal peddlers or the legitimate small-business people?
 
JOAN TALBERT
Exec. Director, 14th Street-Union Sq.
Business Improvement District
 New York, Sept. 18, 1990

HEADLINE: Helping Older Women Enter the Job Market

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The women who raised families in midcentury America deserved better than the economic difficulties faced by older displaced homemakers such as Doris Gibson (''For Elderly Just Hanging On, An Oasis of Jobs Is Shrinking,'' front page, Sept. 1). But she represents a growing population of women forced onto the job market in older years after having worked only in the home. My organization reported last June that the number of displaced homemakers in the United States rose by nearly 12 percent in the 1980's to 15.6 million in 1989. And 22 million married women who are not employed could lose their primary means of support by divorce, or their spouse's disability or death.
There are some favorable signs. With a shrinking supply of young people entering the work force, employers will have to turn to mature workers to fill their rolls. The qualities of mature workers - enthusiasm, longevity on the job, responsibility -will recommend more and more re-entry women to employers.
But, to qualify for the jobs of the 1990's and the next century, displaced homemakers will need training. Congress has before it a displaced homemakers training and economic self-sufficiency bill, which would provide grants to states for education, training, job search and placement, and related services to help displaced homemakers obtain marketable job skills and secure paid employment. Congress can help tomorrow's economy and tomorrow's older displaced homemakers. We hope it doesn't dismiss the Doris Gibsons as too old, unimportant and poor to influence their votes.
 
JILL MILLER
Executive Director, National
Displaced Homemakers Network
 Washington, Sept. 11, 1990

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
America's Last Robot?

 BODY:
Cincinnati Milacron, the last major American maker of heavy robots, is selling its business to a Swiss company. That will leave most of the U.S. robot market in the hands of foreigners. Does it matter that yet another high-tech, American-grown industry is now dominated by foreigners, mostly Japan? 
Conventional wisdom says no: industrial robots have proved less promising than hoped. But the wider point is that yet again Japan has targeted an industry it thinks has an important future, and driven out most major U.S. competitors.
Just as semiconductor chips are the key to all electronics industries, from computers to telecommunications, robots and machine tools are critical to manufacturing industries. Each of these bedrock technologies - robots, machine tools and semiconductors - has been targeted by Japan so successfully that many U.S. companies are under severe pressure.
Japan's formula is not well understood in America. Prevailing economic wisdom, to cite the President's 1990 Economic Report, holds that ''excessive government involvement in the economy leads to unsound decisions . . . slows growth and costs jobs.'' That is indeed Washington's sorry experience in a range of ill-fated projects, from the breeder reactor to synfuels. But it's a fallible leap of logic to suppose that if Washington messes up, Tokyo must inevitably fail too. Tokyo's brand of industrial policy, perfected over six decades, differs from Washington's as much in methods as in results.
Its key ingredient is abundant capital. Tokyo's powerful bureaucrats compel their fellow citizens to save. Those sky-high land prices in Tokyo - the Emperor's palace grounds are worth more than all Florida - are no accident. Japanese must save like fury to be able to afford a house. These savings are then available as cheap capital for industry. Last year Japan, whose economy is half the size, spent an astonishing $549 billion on capital investment, exceeding the $513 billion spent by the U.S.
Unlike their Western counterparts, Tokyo's officials do not try to second-guess the market but let the market define winning industries. When they decided to build up a computer industry, they induced their telecommunications companies to compete vigorously against each other behind protective walls. Tokyo then subsidized research and barred I.B.M. from selling competing products.
After years of failure, these efforts struck technical gold in 1980. By 1992, Japan's share of the world computer market will reach 42 percent, and the near-monopoly once enjoyed by the U.S. will have shrunk to 32 percent.
Against such methods, even the most efficient and innovative American companies are hard pressed to compete. Their Japanese counterparts can sell freely in the U.S. while their domestic market is protected by Tokyo. Many belong to company groups, or keiretsu, whose member bank is ultimately supported by the Bank of Japan. Freed from the fear of bankruptcy, a Japanese company can take a longer-term view than its U.S. competitor.
Moreover, as Japan dominates one manufacturing industry after another, it builds up synergistic strengths. Its chip makers have a vast captive market in Japan's domestic consumer electronics industry; America's chip makers have none.
Washington won't respond because it believes government should not favor one industry over another, and because the U.S. economy is in any case a fertile creator of new industries. But if Japan can consistently dominate industries it deems promising, Americans will be pushed into less desirable ones. Tokyo believes it is far more profitable to produce robots than radishes or rutabagas. The result of this policy, if present trends continue, is that America may soon make its last robot.
 
NICHOLAS WADE

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Bush Sure-Footed on Trail of Money

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 27

 BODY:
He hits the road, sometimes he presses the flesh, but President Bush doesn't really campaign, not in the classic sense. Not like Ronald Reagan or Hubert H. Humphrey or Lyndon B. Johnson.
What he does is raise money - relentlessly, efficiently, rapidly.
He did some Presidential business, of course, as he bustled around the Middle West this week, from Ohio to Illinois to Minnesota to Ohio to Michigan, two long days of politics. 
 
Presidential Business
He announced the sale of five million barrels of crude oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve on Wednesday night in the Chicago suburbs, hailed the Senate Judiciary Committee's endorsement of Judge David H. Souter for the Supreme Court on Thursday in Cleveland and made earnest pitches everywhere for his policy in the Persian Gulf.
Nor did he wholly neglect his role as the cheerleader of the Republican Party. At lunch in Akron, Ohio, on Wednesday, he momentarily shed his patrician restraint and his bipartisan approach. Accusing the Democrats of holding up a budget settlement, promising to ''carry that message to every state in the Union,'' he sounded all hot and bothered, as scrappy as a Republican Harry S. Truman.
In the Chicago suburbs on Wednesday night, speaking for Representative Lynn Martin, the Republican senatorial candidate in Illinois this fall, the President actually tried to make some partisan hay out of the gulf crisis.
''She knows you can't stand up to tyranny and despotism while recklessly slashing military levels,'' Mr. Bush said, adding that Ms. Martin's Democratic opponent, Senator Paul Simon, ''called for bombing Iraqi pipelines on the one hand, and on the other hand, cut defense spending by 50 percent.''
But Mr. Bush finds that kind of thing hard to sustain. He felt compelled to add, ''The two or three top Democratic leaders have tried pretty hard.'' And at every stop, he praised the opposition for its support of his foreign policy, repeatedly citing the maxim of the old Midwestern internationalist Senator Arthur Vandenberg of Michigan: ''Politics stops at the water's edge.''
 
A Familial Touch
In truth, George Bush the national leader and George Bush the party point man took a back seat this week to George Bush the rich uncle, visiting his relatives here and there, spreading the wealth, radiating bonhomie.
Mr. Bush had a homey allusion for everyone: mention of his naval air training in the Twin Cities, of his father's childhood in Columbus, Ohio. In Detroit he made ritual mention of Isaiah Thomas and the champion Detroit Pistons basketball team.
At a luncheon in Cleveland, he spoke of John Kinton, a former star athlete in high school there who now runs a military tent kitchen in Saudi Arabia; in Chicago, the anecdote was about Lorraine Kuryla, a 63-year-old grandmother who volunteered for active duty with an Air Force Reserve unit there.
Candidates, officeholders, party officials, political operatives all get their full measure of praise and applause in the Bush formula. But there is no attempt to transfer his popularity, no appeal to voters to elect this candidate or that because he is a Bush backer, no attempt to frame issues.
The real goal of these travels is dollars. Mr. Bush appeared at five fund-raising meals, held a number of private fund-raising meetings and made no old-fashioned campaign speeches at all where he could appeal to the unconverted. #17 States on Agenda Since taking office 20 months ago, the President has worked the Republican faithful, raising more than $73 million for candidates and state parties. He plans to visit at least 17 states in 10 days of political travel next month, and he will campaign nonstop in the first five days of November.
In less than two hours in Minneapolis on Thursday, Mr. Bush managed to include three meetings that raised close to $1.5 million. He talked for 20 minutes with 29 rich Minnesotans who each gave $25,000 or more to state campaigns for the pleasure of the President's company; he spent 15 more minutes with 100 or so contributors who each gave $2,000, and spoke to about 1,000 people who paid $500 a plate for breakfast.
The figures in Ohio, which formed the focus of this week's travels, are even more breathtaking. In four visits to that pivotal state - to Columbus in February, Cincinnati in April, Akron on Wednesday and Cleveland on Thursday - the President has raised more than $3 million. Joe Rice, the political editor of The Cleveland Plain Dealer, said the Republican nominee for governor, George Voinovich, will have almost $4 million in the bank going into the final month of the campaign, enough for a closing television blitz of a scope that seems beyond the reach of his Democratic rival, Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr. Partly because of his fund-raising advantage, which is largely the work of the President, Mr. Voinovich is now the solid favorite in Ohio.
The technique won't work everywhere, of course; here in Michigan, for example, Representative Bill Schuette, the Republican nominee who hopes to oust Senator Carl Levin, has raised a lot of money but trails badly in the polls. Still, Mr. Bush's aides think it would be a mistake to push harder and try to make the elections a referendum on the President and his policies.
 
'Doesn't Rub Off'
''The Reagan and Carter years showed that Presidential popularity just doesn't rub off or define issues any more,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. ''Reagan would go out on the stump, draw huge throngs and convert no one at all.''
Indeed, Mr. Reagan's appeals to ''win one for the Gipper'' did not prevent his party from losing 26 House seats in the 1982 midterm elections or from losing eight Senate seats and control of that body four years later. In 1978, Jimmy Carter appealed for Democratic votes to help him fight inflation, and his party still lost three seats in the Senate and 11 in the House.
Another point mentioned by the Bush strategists is Mr. Bush's desire to let local candidates define the issues in a way that has local appeal.
''He wants Lynn Martin in the Senate,'' said one strategist. ''She's a Republican, he likes her, she's a strong nominee. But she has one of the most contrary voting records in Congress, she's against the President on abortion and half a dozen other issues and he can hardly go out to Chicago and say, 'Vote for Lynn Martin because you back me and she's like me.' ''
The G.O.P. planners say polls support their arguments. A survey in July, paid for by the National Republican Campaign Committee, asked whether campaign appearances by Mr. Bush for local Congressional candidates would cause them to change their voting plans. Fully 77 percent said not.
So the President raises the money to put the local hopefuls' message on the air, hoping that will help to accomplish his purpose.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
As Gulf Crisis Solidifies the World Order, Cuba Feels Left Out

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 28

 BODY:
The exuberance of Soviet and American officials about the new world order being established after the cold war is not universally embraced at the United Nations.
The Cubans, the lone dissenters in the 15-member Security Council's vote last Tuesday to impose an air embargo against Iraq, watch warily as the vaunted new world order plunges them into economic crisis and diplomatic isolation.
The decisions by the Soviet Union to slash aid to Cuba - in particularly the huge shipments of oil - and to work with the United States to solve regional conflicts have left the Cubans as one of the last standard bearers in the ideological war against what they see as United States imperialism.
As many United Nations members, including the Soviets, edge closer to the tacit acceptance of force to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis, the Cubans are faced with the specter of the United States, a country they have frequently condemned, assuming the mantle of the world's policeman. 
''The U.S. is acting as if they have become the only superpower, the dominant force in the world,'' said Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada, Cuba's chief delegate to the United Nations. ''They are not only doing this unilaterally as a power, but they are using the Security Council for this purpose. This is a very serious development for the entire world.''
 
Scent of a Cigar
Western diplomats, however, see Cuba as a country that is politically ossified and out of touch with the world.
''Cuba is the only country not being pulled into the center now,'' a Western diplomat said. ''Five years ago Cuba and other radical states like Vietnam, Yemen and Algeria, pulled the non-aligned nations to the left. Today nearly everyone, with the exception of Cuba, has moved into the mainstream.''
The new order, adulated by nearly every visiting dignitary to the United Nations this week, is nothing but a headache to the Cubans.
''This so-called new order has not yet benefited the third world,'' Mr. Alarcon said, the acrid scent of a cigar wafting up from between his fingers. ''On the contrary there are many reasons to be afraid that in the way some people conceive this new order we will suffer more.''
The Cubans, while admitting that diplomatic affairs have become more ''complex'' since the end of the cold war, also contend that they will maintain their rigidity against the United States.
 
Use of Force Opposed
''There is a perception that somehow Cuba will not be able to weather the changes that have been taking place in the world,'' said Rene J. Mujica, a member of the Cuban Mission, ''that Cuba will have to adapt and ultimately become pliant to the U.S. This will not be the case.''
The Cubans say they condemn the occupation and annexation of Kuwait by Iraq, along with the taking of hostages and the violations by Iraqi troops of diplomatic missions in Kuwait.
But they say they will never sanction the use of force by the multinational presence in the gulf.
''The resolutions the Council has passed in which we have reservations or objections are those resolutions that deal with U.N. actions to counter Iraq's illegal invasion, occupation and annexation of Kuwait,'' Mr. Mujica said. ''The resolutions in the Council that deal with matters of principle have our full support.''
The Cubans said the language of the eight resolutions condemning the invasion have paved the way for armed intervention by the United States, an intervention they believe would be in violation of the United Nations Charter.
''The Security Council, in accordance with the charter, is authorized to decide when to use military force, but in a very specific manner,'' Mr. Alarcon said. ''This is a very fundamental question of prinicple that goes far beyond this crisis. The Council, in our view, has violated the U.N. Charter. It is extremely dangerous for any member state, particularly for a small state, to have this as a precedent.''
 
'Gave the Green Light'
The Cubans argue that any military action sanctioned by the United Nations can be organized only under United Nations auspices.
''The Council simply gave the green light to the United States and others to do what they were doing already,'' Mr. Alarcon said.
The Cubans, who have been the object of a United States embargo for nearly three decades, say they are especially sensitive to any resolutions that would keep food and medicine from entering Iraq, although food and medicines will be allowed into Iraq and Kuwait under international supervision.
''We cannot accept that economic sanctions can include depriving innocent civilians of their normal food stuffs or medical supplies,'' he said. ''We are perhaps the only country in the world that has been living for almost 30 years under an embargo that has also deprived my people of food and medicines.''
The Cubans also argue that the call for sanctions against any country that violates the embargo is too stringent.
''The resolution threatens specific measures against states that may be, through their nationals or their territory, violating the embargo,'' Mr. Alarcon said. ''I think that this is going very, very, very far.''

HEADLINE: Congress Resists El Salvador's Chief on Aid Cuts

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador impressed several members of Congress during his four-day lobbying visit to Washington this week, but he did not succeed in altering Congressional sentiment on cutting military aid to his country.
A dozen Senators considered undecided on a bill that would withhold 50 percent of the $82.5 million in military aid requested by the Bush Administration have not shifted one way or the other because of President Cristiani's visit, Senate aides said.
The House has already passed a similar measure, which would only restore aid if the guerrillas refused to take part in peace talks or waged an offensive that endangered the Government's survival.
This year's Congressional debate over aid to El Salvador is the most heated since the early 1980's, principally because of the killing of six Jesuit priests, reportedly by an army squad, in November. Congressional staff reports have documented evidence that officers of the Salvadoran Army have blocked an investigation to protect themselves from prosecution, despite the fact that four officers and four privates have been arrested. 
Representative Stephen J. Solarz, a Brooklyn Democrat and member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said: ''I think Cristiani is engaging and persuasive. His sincerity is no longer in question, but I would be amazed if there aren't cuts.''
Mr. Cristiani's visit was further complicated by a stern breakfast meeting with Vice President Dan Quayle on Thursday, in which Mr. Quayle expressed his concern that San Salvador is still moving too slowly on human rights. Mr. Quayle has taken a personal interest in a massacre of 10 peasants in September 1988 in which eight of the nine militarymen originally arrested in the case have been released.
''Vice President Quayle told President Cristiani that Congress would look at this very carefully,'' a White House aide said. ''He said unless there was progress on the human-rights cases, it would be more and more harmful with Congress.''
Mr. Cristiani met with more than 70 members of Congress to assure them that he was committed to prosecute the Jesuit case and to improving his country's human-rights record. He urged that if Congress did withhold aid, it tie any cuts to the requirment that the guerrillas agree to a cease-fire first.
 
Bill Calling for Aid Cuts
''President Cristiani makes a good impression with his integrity,'' said Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona. ''But whether or not he has enough credibility to temper some Congressional conditions on military aid is yet to be seen.''
Long a backer of military aid to El Salvador, Senator DeConcini said he was leaning in favor of the Dodd-Leahy bill cutting aid, which the Senate Appropriations Committee is to consider next week.
Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, said he was undecided on the Dodd-Leahy bill before the Cristiani visit, and he remained undecided because of his concern for several human-rights cases and the lack of judicial revisions.
''I'm listening to President Cristiani,'' he said. ''But I'm more interested in what's happening there. We need to apply the most pressure to bring peace and democracy to that country.'' $4.5 Billion Since 1979 ''I think the President's visit was helpful to his cause,'' said Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island. ''Whether it was helpful enough I do not know.'' Mr. Chafee said he was leaning against the Dodd-Leahy bill before Mr. Cristiani's visit, and he remained undecided.
The United States has sent El Salvador more than $4.5 billion in economic and military aid, as well hundreds of military advisers, since the civil war began in 1979. The United States counterinsurgency program in El Salvador has been the largest since the Vietnam War. More than 75,000 people have died in the fighting.
A senior State Department official who deals with El Salvador policy said he thought Mr. Cristiani's visit was positive because ''he got his message across and heard Congress' concern on the Jesuit case.''

HEADLINE: Japan and North Korea Set Talks on Ties

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 28

 BODY:
After 45 years of hostility, Japan and North Korea agreed today to open talks to establish diplomatic relations ''as soon as possible.'' The Japanese, in return, promised financial compensation for their occupation of the Korean peninsula in the early decades of this century.
The move, which came at the end of an unofficial five-day visit to Pyongyang by a delegation of senior Japanese politicians, was the strongest indication yet that North Korea may be trying to end decades of isolation and hostility toward the West to help boost its lagging economy.
Until today, the most dramatic glimmer of a post-cold-war dawning in northeast Asia appeared in the talks in Seoul this month between the Prime Ministers of North Korea and South Korea, the first such high-level contacts since the end of the Korean War. 
In those negotiations, the two sides failed to resolve any of their longstanding differences, but agreed to meet again in Pyongyang next month. The North Koreans, clearly needing economic help, have asked South Korea for an economic package that Seoul is now considering as part of the negotiations.
 
A Last Flash Point
The Korean peninsula, bristling with weapons and more than 1.5 million Korean soldiers and about 45,000 American troops, remains perhaps the last major flash point left over from the era of East-West confrontation that followed World War II. In 1950 the North Koreans mounted an invasion of South Korea that led to the creation of a United Nations command headed by the United States that battled the North Koreans and the Chinese Communists to a standstill in three years of fighting.
Japanese businessmen say they are eager to get involved in the possible reconstruction of North Korea, but caution that they would be unwilling to do so if state economic controls were retained.
Diplomats warned that it could take years to iron out the differences between North Korea and its Western-directed neighbors, not least because the Pyongyang Government continues to demand reunification of the peninsula on its own terms, dismissing South Korea as a colony of the United States. The Japanese officials also emphasized that they were aware of South Korean sensitivities and would not establish relations with North Korea before South Korea did.
Western diplomats remain uncertain whether to trust a country that earlier this decade was accused of sponsoring terrorist attacks against South Korean diplomats and officials, and is generally seen as trying to destabilize or overthrow the Seoul Government.
 
Talks Between Parties
The meetings in Pyongyang were not conducted on a government-to-government basis. Rather, they were between the leading political parties of both countries. Any negotiations in the future will have to involve professional diplomats in Japan, who may not yield ground to Pyongyang very easily.
The Pyongyang talks did have the support of the political leadership of both countries, however, and they concluded with an eight-point statement declaring that normalizing relations ''would contribute to peace and prosperity of a new Asia and the world.''
Included in the statement was a pledge from Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan to make a formal apology to North Korea, similar to one issued to South Korea this year, for Japan's 35-year occupation of the Korean peninsula that ended with its defeat in World War II.
The statement in Pyongyang from both sides said Japan ''should fully and officially apologize'' for ''the enormous misfortunes and miseries imposed upon the Korean people'' before, during and after World War II.
 
North Korea Needs Money
There was no indication of how much money Japan would pledge in the form of reparations or compensation. But diplomats noted that Japan paid South Korea $500 million in loans and grants in 1965, when ties with Seoul were normalized, the equivalent of several billion dollars today.
North Korea is widely thought to be sorely in need of money. Western analysts say its economy has lagged at a growth rate of about 3 percent a year in the last decade, compared with 9 percent a year for South Korea, and that it is overwhelmed by debts, military expenditures and a lack of hard currency.
In addition, diplomats say North Korea has begun feeling abandoned by its longtime patrons, the Soviet Union and China, both of which have steadily improved their ties with South Korea. Moscow even appears on the verge of establishing diplomatic ties with Seoul.
In the meetings this week in Pyongyang, Kim Il Sung, the aging leader of North Korea, met several times with the Japanese delegation, driving home the point that it was time for the establishment of good relations with Japan.
 
Promise to Free Two Japanese
Japanese officials said the most impressive immediate gesture of good will from North Korea came from Mr. Kim in the form of a promise to free two Japanese seamen seized on espionage charges in 1983. Tokyo has made the release of the men a prerequisite for improving ties with Pyongyang.
On the Japanese side, the delegation was led by Shin Kanemaru, a former Deputy Prime Minister who is a powerful backroom politician and patronage dispenser in the governing Liberal Democratic Party. He is widely regarded as the most important political patron of Prime Minister Kaifu. North Korea reportedly invited him to head the delegation.
The meeting in Pyongyang has been in the works for weeks, but its unusually productive results seemed to take some diplomats by surprise. There was no immediate comment from the United States, but Washington has recently supported efforts to try to end the isolation of Pyongyang.
 
Informal U.S. Contacts
Last year, for instance, Washington authorized the beginning of informal diplomatic contacts with North Korea, and there have been about a dozen meetings in Beijing. North Korean performers, athletes and scholars have also been permitted to visit the United States for the first time.
American officials say that in response, North Korea made a gesture of good will in May by returning the remains of soldiers killed in the Korean War, and that it has indicated that it would be willing to have outside inspections of its two nuclear reactors.
South Korea appeared to be taken aback by the development today and to have mixed feelings. President Roh Tae Woo's Government expressed the hope that North Korea might be persuaded to moderate some of its attitudes.
On the other, South Korean diplomats said they were nervous that Japan might move too hastily, undercutting Seoul's strategy for improving ties with Seoul by building slowly on cultural, economic and family contacts.
South Korea is worried that in a worldwide demand for compromise on the Korean peninsula, Seoul might get pressed into accepting part of the North Korean demands for the expulsion of American troops, a ban on American nuclear weapons and freeing of left-wing South Korean dissidents.
Apparently recognizing South Korea's concerns, Prime Minister Kaifu sought to reassure Seoul this week by reiterating that it remained an important friend and that he planned to visit South Korea in the coming year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Traded Up as Hedge Against a Weekend Crisis

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar gained against all major currencies except its Canadian counterpart in unusually slow United States trading yesterday.
The dollar traded within a narrow band on domestic and foreign markets. And the typically light volume that ordinarily occurs on Fridays was curtailed even further by the approaching end of the month, the calendar year quarter and the half of Japan's fiscal year. All three occur tomorrow. 
The start of the Jewish Yom Kippur observance, which began at sundown yesterday, also lightened liquidity because some dealers left work early.
 
Considered Save Haven
What buying there was in the dollar reflected traders' hedging against a possible intensification of the Middle East conflict over the weekend. The dollar is traditionally considered a safe investment haven at times of international turmoil.
Financial markets regarded the latest United States economic reading merely as confirmation of what has been widely known for some time. The index of leading indicators tumbled 1.2 percent in August, its steepest fall in three years, but the report had virtually no lasting impact on the dollar.
The dollar firmed against the Japanese yen in Tokyo, where another selloff on the stock market chipped away confidence in the country's currency.
The dollar rose 0.45 yen, to a closing 137.95 yen, in the Japanese capital. Later in London, it was quoted at 138.15 yen and at 138.50 yen late in New York, up from 137.98 yen late Thursday.
 
British Pound Rises
The British pound rose in London and traded at $1.8735 late in the session, compared with $1.8690 late Thursday. But the pound lost ground in New York activity and was quoted late in the day at $1.8760, compared with $1.8780 late Thursday.
Other dollar rates late in New York, compared with Thursday's late quotes, included: 1.5670 German marks, up from 1.5610; 2.29735 Swiss francs, up from 1.2925; 5.2455 French francs, up from 5.2250; 1,173.25 Italian lire, up from 1,169.25, and 1.15425 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15495.
Gold prices were mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for October delivery settled at $402.50 a troy ounce, down $2.50 from Thursday's close. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late gold bid of $403 an ounce, $2 lower than Thursday's 4 P.M. bid.
In London, gold fell to a late bid of $404.75 a troy ounce from $405.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $406.25 from $406 late Thursday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $1.10 to close at $403.39 an ounce.
Silver prices fell. On the Comex in New York, silver bullion for October delivery settled at $4.761 a troy ounce compared with the Thursday settlement price of $4.771. The metal fell in London to a late bid of $4.79 a troy ounce from Thursday's $4.80.

HEADLINE: Prices of Securities Rise on Budget Hopes

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities continued to advance yesterday, largely on the belief that the Bush Administration and the Congress will hammer out a budget agreement this weekend.
While an accord is not expected to remedy the nation's economic problems, market analysts said it would remove some of the uncertainty that has perplexed investment portfolio managers.
 
Drop in Paper Narrows
Government securities dealers said a moderate recovery in bank stock prices and a slowing of the cost of oil also improved the mood of investors in long-term fixed-income securities. The rates on short-term Treasury paper posted smaller declines than the day before, reflecting the slowing of the flight of capital from the stock market and other investments. 
''The sharpest drop in the Government's August index of leading economic indicators in more than three years was expected and only gave the bond market a brief positive jolt early in the day,'' said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc.
In late dealings, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in August 2020, were being offered at 97 3/32, up by 27/32 on the day, as its yield dropped to 8.93 percent, from 9.01 percent the day before and from 9.12 percent a week ago.
 
Window Dressing Takes Hold
With the shorter Treasury maturities favored by investment managers seeking to window dress their quarterly statements with large amounts of cash or the equivalent, Mr. Ricchiuto said, ''We wouldn't be surprised if the rates on short paper come down early next week and stay down until the September unemployment figures are released early Friday morning.''
As it was, the demand for window-dressing cash on the last day of the quarter prompted volatile moves in the Federal funds rate, which banks and other financial institutions charge each other for temporary loans. The rate opened at 8 3/8 percent, sank as low as 6 percent and then closed at the opening level. As expected, the Federal Reserve did not intervene to influence the funds rate, as it had done in recent days.
Whether for cosmetics or safety, the continued demand for short-term Treasury bills caused a further drop in discount rates. The rate on the 90-day bills fell by 9 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.13 percent. A week ago, the rate on the 90-day bills was 7.37 percent. The rate on the six-month bills fell by 4 basis points, to 7.16 percent, and the one-year bills lost 3 basis points, at 7.17 percent.
 
Shorter Issues Up
Among the shorter Treasury coupon issues, the new 8 1/8 percent notes of 1992 rose by 2/32, to 100 8/32, as its yield fell to 7.98 percent, from 8.02 percent the day before. The new 8.5 percent notes of 1994 gained 5/32, to 100 17/32, as its yield declined to 8.34 percent, from 8.38 percent.
The Treasury's long notes, the 8.75 percent issue due in August 2000, climbed by 14/32, to 99 23/32.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Underwriting Fees Decline Sharply

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The squeeze on Wall Street profits grew tighter in the last quarter, as fees for underwritings of securities fell by more than half, to their lowest levels in six years, and corporate America began to pull back from raising money in the capital markets.
The bad news for the third quarter ended yesterday was reflected in most types of securities issued. Corporations issued a total of $72.6 billion, down from an anemic $73 billion issued in the third quarter of last year, according to the Securities Data Company. 
The poor showing for the quarter did not drive the underwriting results for the year to date below those for the period last year. Securities Data reported that $238.09 billion has been raised by corporations so far in 1990, compared with $217.18 billion in the first nine months of 1989.
Investment bankers said that the bad results in the third quarter were caused largely by the world events that have thrown the financial markets into turmoil.
''This quarter the new-issue market clearly has been dominated by the events in the Persian Gulf, the increased prospects for a recession and, more recently, problems in the banking system,'' said Mark A. Seigel, a managing director with Morgan Stanley & Company.
 
Industrial Companies Active
Wall Street analysts also said that most issuers were large industrial companies. ''The industrials were the bulk of the issuance,'' said Edson Mitchell, managing director at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. ''The financial issuers were not active.''
In some ways, the appetite among the industrial companies for debt issuance reflected the difficulties of the ''junk bond'' market, which virtually collapsed over the year, underwriters said. With hostile takeover bids financed by junk bonds becoming more a memory than a threat, the investor interest has focused again on investment-grade debt, they said.
Reflecting that change, the demand for private borrowing through the bond market climbed slightly in the third quarter. According to Securities Data, $68.55 billion in debt was issued during the quarter, up from $63.36 billion in the period last year.
But corporations have been much less able to issue debt that is not secured by assets. Only $19.76 billion in unsecured debt was issued in the third quarter, compared with $27.81 billion a year earlier.
That drop has been made up in part by mortgage and asset-backed debt. Such securities were the strongest element of the debt market in the third quarter, with $46.95 billion being issued, compared with $33.64 billion in the period last year.
 
New Stock Issues Drop
The issuance of common stock, which had been growing popular throughout the year, also plunged sharply in the third quarter. Only $3.3 billion in stock was issued in the period, compared with $6.1 billion a year earlier.
Indeed, the difficulties in the financial markets have slowed the trickle of initial public offerings to a near standstill. In the quarter, only $1.55 billion was raised by companies going to the capital markets for the first time, compared with $3.76 billion a year ago.
The difficulty in underwritings has increased the competition among investment banks, helping to drive down fees. The disclosed fees in the third quarter were less than half those a year earlier, with firms getting only $339 million from underwritings, down from $785.6 million.
For the first nine months, Merrill Lynch Capital Markets ranked as the leading underwriter of domestic issues, with $37.5 billion in securities, or 15.8 percent of the total market. It was followed by Goldman, Sachs & Company, with $32.08 billion, or 13.5 percent of the market.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Midway Air Is Cutting Staff

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 28

 BODY:
In another sign of hard times in the nation's airline industry, Midway Airlines Inc. said today that it was cutting its staff by 10 percent, putting about 500 people out of work.
''These actions are necessitated by escalating fuel costs brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis,'' Midway's chairman. 
David Hinson. said in a statement.
Midway, based in Chicago, has already begun cutting staff and said some under-used routes would also be canceled to increase lagging profits.
All flights to Savannah, Ga., will be suspended as of Nov. 1, and Midway will also withdraw from service eight of its aircraft that are the least fuel efficient.
Since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the cost of jet fuel has risen sharply. Most domestic airlines are also struggling with slow ticket sales because of a softening economy.
Midway employs about 5,700 people. About 500 administrative and other staff from across the country will be laid off, a spokeswoman, Sandra Allen, said. She said Midway expects to complete the layoffs within 30 days, but she declined to say how much money the carrier expects to save with the cuts.
 
Midway's hubs are Chicago'
Midway Airport and Philadelphia International.
Midway's stock rose 50 cents today, to $5.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chase Reduces Staff 10% at Unit

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, which last week announced a significant retrenchment, said it had reduced the staff in its North America Corporate Finance unit by 238, or nearly 10 percent. This was the initial step in Chase's plan to slash 5,000 jobs because of a downturn in the banking business. Last week, Chase said it would take a charge of $1 billion in the third quarter and halve its quarterly dividend to 30 cents.
The company said the largest portion of the reduction in the Corporate Finance department was in operations and support personnel. Chase said the cutback had taken place in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Atlanta and Toronto.

HEADLINE: Prices Paid To Farmers Down by 2%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
The prices that farmers receive for raw products declined by 2 percent from August to September, but the overall commodity index was still 3.5 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.
Lower prices were reported for corn, hogs, potatoes and cattle. They more than offset increases for apples, broilers and eggs, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report. 
Milk prices were at a record high for September, but cattle prices were down slightly from the all-time record levels of August. Hog prices were down sharply from August.
''The 25-cents-per-bushel drop in the corn price from August to September was the largest month-to-month decrease since a 28-cent decline during the same two months in 1986,'' the report said.
Wheat prices fell by 10 cents a bushel in September, after a 28-cent decline in August, 29 cents in July and 32 cents in June. At $2.48 a bushel, wheat prices at the farm were down by $1.24 from a year ago.
Most prices are mid-September averages that will be revised next month. The latest report, for example, showed that August prices declined by seven-tenths of a percent, instead of the 1.3 percent drop indicated a month ago.
Consumer food prices, meanwhile, are going up by 5 percent to 7 percent this year, department economists say, compared with 5.8 percent in 1989, the most since 1981.
A recent forecast this week put 1990 net cash income of farmers at a record of $59 billion to $63 billion, up about a tenth from last year. The previous high was $57.2 billion in 1988.
Based on the preliminary figures, the September price index for all crops was down by 2.4 percent from August and was 2.4 percent below a year earlier. Wheat and feed grains were down from August, while soybeans were unchanged.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Ways to Trim Tax Liabilities

BYLINE: Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
Savvy taxpayers will use the last three months of the year to pare their tax liabilities, while strengthening their personal finances. And there are a number of ways to do this, regardless of uncertainty over what Congress may do on the tax front.
''Do what makes economic sense, and don't try to second-guess Congress,'' said John L. Norman Jr., national director of taxation in the Washington office of Pannell Kerr Forster, an accounting firm. There are too many conflicting pressures to predict Washington's direction, he added, citing budget talks, Middle Eastern events and the fear of anti-incumbent feelings, which he said leave ''everyone searching for ways to protect themselves.'' 
Joel S. Isaacson, a partner in Weber Lipshie & Company in New York, offered several pointers that make economic sense. ''This is the time of year when everyone gets forms from companies'' asking them to make choices on cafeteria plans -flexible spending plans that allow pretax money to be used for needs like child care or health care -401(k) tax-deferred retirement plans and other benefits, he said.
By taking some compensation through these company sponsored benefits, rather than as taxable salary, an employee can save money on taxes as well as provide money for important needs. One client is putting $5,000 into a flexible spending plan for child care and will save $2,000 in taxes, Mr. Isaacson noted. Using after-tax dollars and claiming a tax credit for child care was worth only $480 to him.
Self-employed people can make tax-deferred retirement savings through a Keogh plan, he said, but such plans must be set up by the end of the year.
Mr. Isaacson advised taxpayers to ''project income for 1990'' to avoid an I.R.S. underpayment penalty on one hand or paying too much in taxes on the other, which amounts to giving the Government an interest-free loan.
Taxpayers are expected to pay an amount equal to 100 percent of last year's taxes or 90 percent of this year's, through withholdings, quarterly estimated taxes or a combination. People who find they will not meet either standard can avoid the penalty if they can increase withholdings sufficiently in the fourth quarter.
But given the current state of the market, many people may find that they have overpaid in taxes. Those who find they have overpaid by making estimated payments equal to 100 percent of last year's taxes can cut their fourth-quarter payment, due on Jan. 15.
The current state of the market also provides a strong incentive to consider whether to sell holdings, regardless of how Congress responds to the Administration's call for lowering taxes on capital gains or indexing them to inflation.
''Sit down and check what has been realized to date,'' Mr. Isaacson said. ''If there are large gains, people may want to take unrealized losses in their portfolios.''
Often when people have big winners in their portfolios they are reluctant to sell because of the taxes that will be due. Now, with the market's tumble since Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait, they may also have a number of losers, so it might be appropriate to sell both the big winners and the losers, he said.
The decision should be based primarily on an assessment of the stocks, but the important point from a tax perspective is that there is no limit to the amount of capital losses that can be taken against capital gains, but only $3,000 worth of losses can be used to reduce ordinary income. Any excess must be carried forward to future years.
One thing to remember, Mr. Isaacson said, is that mutual funds may generate capital gains distributions, so people with both stocks and funds may want to telephone the funds and find out what their prospects are.
For people who are reluctant to take a capital gain now, just in case Congress reinstates some sort of preferential treatment later, Elliott Eiss, a tax lawyer and senior editor with the J. K. Lasser Institute, said, ''Get your records in shape, so you're in position to make a decision once Congress acts.'' Even if there is agreement on a tax bill, he noted, there could be last-minute changes.
Another important planning point is the alternative minimum tax. Mr. Isaacson recommended that taxpayers make a preliminary calculation to see whether they would be liable.
For those who are not liable, appreciated securities are one way to make a nice contribution to a favorite charity, take a deduction at market value and escape any capital gains tax. Another way to increase deductions is to pay as much state and local tax as possible before the end of the year. But both of these deductions are what are known as A.M.T. preference items, so taxpayers need to know where they stand before acting.
Traditional tax advice is: accelerate deductions, defer income. Mr. Isaacson said that probably holds true for people in the 33 percent marginal bracket, but perhaps not for those in the 28 percent bracket. They may be due for a rate rise next year.

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators In Big Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
The Government index designed to predict turns in the economy dropped 1.2 percent in August, the biggest fall since just after the 1987 stock market crash, the Commerce Department reported today.
While the decline in the measure, the Commerce Department's composite index of leading indicators, was not significantly worse than generally expected, most analysts took it as further evidence that the economy was veering into recession or might already be there.
''Beginning in the fourth quarter, the real gross national product will fall,'' said Lawrence A. Hunter, deputy chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce.
 
Some Not Convinced
But a sizable minority still found reason to contend that a downturn can be avoided, a position that seemed to be supported by a calculation of the National Bureau of Economic Research that the chance of general recession beginning before February was just 3 percent, the same probability it found in July. 
In addition, The Conference Board reported this week that consumer confidence, which plunged in August, remained unchanged in September and that consumer expectations rebounded slightly. Consumer psychology is considered a crucial indicator, since the consumer accounts for two-thirds of the economy, or $3.6 trillion of the $5.4 trillion a year G.N.P.
Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said he remained skeptical about a recession, although he said the economy was doing no better than moving ''sideways'' now and would probably continue to show no growth for the balance of the year. 7 of 11 Components Drop Seven of the 11 components of the leading indicators index contributed to the August decline, with the biggest factors being a drop in consumer expectations and stock prices, both related to the Persian Gulf crisis.
The other negatives were declines in contracts and orders for plant and equipment and in manufacturers' unfilled orders, a rise in initial claims for state unemployment insurance, a drop in building permits and a decline in the M-2 money supply.
Four components made positive contributions but two of them, analysts said, should not be regarded as favorable developments. A rise in the length of the workweek may be showing that employers are working existing employees longer to avoid hiring new workers at an uncertain time, and a rise in sensitive materials prices mainly reflected the surge in oil.
The other two items that moved up were vendor performance - suppliers making slower deliveries, presumably because of better business - and manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods and materials. Failed at Task? The 1.2 percent drop for August followed virtually unchanged readings for July and June, prompting comments that if the economy has already entered a recession, the leading index failed to perform its task of forecasting such economic shifts several months in advance.
The index is regarded as having become quite unreliable over the last decade and some economists believe that efforts to improve it, by adding such new elements as the University of Michigan's survey of consumer expectations, have helped little.
The Commerce Department also reported today that its indexes of coincident and lagging indicators declined five-tenths of 1 percent and three-tenths of 1 percent, respectively. This was the first time since August 1982, in the late stages of the most recent recession, that all three of these indexes fell in the same month.
An alternative predictor, the ratio of the coincident index to the lagging one, fell modestly in August.
A private index constructed by Safian Investment Research fell 2.11 percent in August, the biggest monthly decline since October 1981, when it fell 2.95 percent, but one not as broad as other sharp monthly declines in recent years. Eight of the 23 components rose.
 
Yet Another Index Down
Still another predictor, an index compiled by David B. Bostian Jr. of Jesup, Josephthal & Company, fell to minus 92 from minus 81 last month. A reading of minus 50, reached a year ago, signals recession within six months.
Geoffrey H. Moore, who, as director of the Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University Business School, is perhaps the nation's leading authority on business cycles, told a meeting of business economists here this week that the predictive factors show a mixed pattern and that it was ''very difficult'' to say whether the expansion that began in November 1982 was an end, But if it is, it probably ended in June, he said.
Prof. James H. Stock, an economist for the National Bureau of Economic Research, offered a somewhat optimistic forecast, telling the group that there was less indication of a credit crunch than before the 1973 and 1979 recessions, that the decline in housing had been gradual and not precipitous, that stock prices were an unreliable predictor and that the retail price of gasoline would have to reach $2 a gallon to be as expensive in real terms as it was in 1980.
William C. Melton, chief economist for I.D.S. Financial Services in Minneapolis, said he expected some sort of mild recession but added that so far, for whatever reasons, ''the consumer is hanging in there.''
