HEADLINE: Oil Problem Termed 'Manageable'

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 28

 BODY:
The International Energy Agency said today that while the global oil-supply situation ''is not comfortable,'' it is ''manageable'' enough that there is no need to call on the agency's 21 members to tap their strategic petroleum reserves. But the agency did say its members should be ready to draw on reserves quickly in an emergency.
On Wednesday the United States announced the sale of five million barrels from its strategic reserves, in what was widely seen as a signal that other nations should follow suit.
While the United States had clearly hoped the agency would adopt more vigorous measures today, it became obvious that most members did not plan to dip into their reserves. Still, American representatives here said they were pleased that other members had committed themselves to be ready to act quickly if the need arose. 
 
'Adequately Supplied'
Attributing the sharp rise in oil prices to market speculation, the agency said at the end of a one-day meeting here, ''Eight weeks after Iraq's invasion, world oil markets remain adequately supplied and no product shortfalls have been experienced by I.E.A. countries.''.
After rising sharply on Thursday, oil prices held steady in New York trading today, with crude for November delivery dipping 3 cents a barrel, to $39.51. [Page 33.] The communique from the agency, which represents all industrial democracies, was agreed to by all its members. It also warned that with the world's oil supply system stretched to its limits, any further supply disturbances might well bring about an emergency meeting that would immediately authorize the use of the strategic reserves.
''We will act if necessary but not before,'' said Ulrich Englemann, chairman of the agency's governing board and director general for energy in the West German Ministry of Economics. ''The timing of such an action is crucial.''
John Easton, the United States representative at today's meeting, said: ''We wanted everyone to be prepared to act quickly, and they have said they would. We've cleared the underbush, because we know the system is tight and there is no more flexibility.'' Mr. Easton is Assistant Secretary for International Affairs at the Energy Department.
 
Oil Company Action Urged
Today's communique also said that oil companies should speed releases of oil from their stockpiles to ease the strain on prices.
Various delegates conceded that the fast, steady rise in prices was not likely to encourage many oil companies to unload stocks as long as they thought they could sell them later at higher prices. But they said they hoped the companies would at least refrain from stocking more oil.
''For the time being prices are driven not by fundamentals of the market but by traders' speculation on expected developments in the gulf crisis,'' said Helga Steeg, the agency's executive director.
Asked if the agency would leave the reserves untouched even if prices went above the current $40 a barrel, Mrs. Steeg said: ''It is not that the I.E.A. does not see the burden of higher prices on us and others, but the question is: What can be done about it here? We are not a financial agency. We are concerned with energy demand and supply.''
Together the 21 members have about 1.7 billion barrels of oil in government storage or in oil company stockpiles.
The group said that if any shortfall in supplies occurs at this point it will convene an urgent emergency meeting where representatives will come supplied with ''necessary ministerial authority'' to take binding decisions.
It called on oil companies to ''draw on their commercial stocks and to exercise discretion in purchases in order to reduce uncertainty and volatility'' in world oil markets.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Easton, right, an Assistant Secretary at the Energy Department, and William C. Ramsay of the State Department represented the United States at the International Energy Agency meeting yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Economic Memo;
Quiet Moves at Bank Talks: A Reshaping of East Europe

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
The Middle East crisis dominated the speeches and news conferences at the annual meeting this week of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. But away from the newsmakers, in hotel rooms outfitted with conference tables, Eastern Europe's emerging free market economies were quietly being shaped.
The Eastern Europeans themselves might still be arguing about the pace of transition from central planning to free markets. But for the I.M.F. and the World Bank, the issue is settled: It should be done quickly, with the promise of loans as pressure to speed up the process. 
''If someone comes to us and says, 'We want to do it gradually,' we go a long way to talk them out of a gradual approach,'' said Eugenio F. Lari, the World Bank's European chief.
Last fall, when Eastern Europe threw off Communism en masse, he wasn't so sure of himself. ''We had a fleeting temptation to sit back and see how the transition worked, and then make loans,'' he said. ''But that would have made us irrelevant.''
The Poles and the Hungarians have been big borrowers this year, although the Hungarians have had misgivings about the quick-transition strategy. Their worry was that unemployment, say, would become unbearably high if all price ceilings were removed overnight or state companies were sold too rapidly. But the Hungarians are coming around, Mr. Lari said. ''As of the moment, none of our members are talking gradualism.''
Czechoslovakia, a new World Bank-I.M.F. member, is the next most likely big borrower, and Mr. Lari, greeting visitors in shirt-sleeves and suspenders, got into loan talk with Vaclav Klaus, the Czechoslovak Finance Minister, like him an enthusiast of go-fast transition.
World Bank loans are particularly important for the transition process because they finance projects that help make free markets work: importing machinery, for example, for newly private factories, or financing unemployment insurance.
The I.M.F. has a different sort of leverage: more than $1 billion in loans outstanding in Eastern Europe to provide badly needed hard currency to pay foreign debts and bills.
 
Rival Soviet Delegations
 For the Soviet Union, the issue also was transition economics. The Gorbachev Government, up for I.M.F.-World Bank membership, sent five officials - and found themselves upstaged by a rival Soviet delegation.
The Gorbachev people presented themselves as quiet agnostics on the transition issue, since the Soviet Parliament has not yet decided whether the transition should be a slow process, as Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov advocates, or a speedy one, in accord with the ''500 Day Plan'' of Stanislav S. Shatalin. The 12 unofficial delegates came to sell the Shatalin plan.
George Soros, a Wall Street financier, paid the air fares and hotel expenses of the Shatalin group. And the delegates - six helped to write the 600-page plan - had sessions with anyone whose good opinion of the Shatalin ideas might carry weight with the Soviet Parliament.
The roster included prominent American economists and Congressmen, European central bank chieftains and corporate executives. An Izvestia reporter traveled with the members of the team and sent back dispatches on their salesmanship.
''We seek understanding, and if there is understanding, there will be support,'' said Grigory Yavlinsky, the 37-year-old Deputy Prime Minister of the Russian Republic, a leader of the group. English translations of the 600-page plan were also passed out.
Mr. Yavlinsky's English was weak, and when he got stuck during an interview, Mr. Soros pitched in with the Shatalin plan's virtues and intricacies. Mr. Soros grew up in Hungary, made a fortune on Wall Street in the 1980's and now supports foundations he established in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to promote rapid transition to free markets.
 
Rising Cost of Loans
 With considerable fanfare, I.M.F. officials promised more loans to help offset the cost of higher oil prices. But not much was said about their rising cost for the borrower - usually a poor underdeveloped nation.
The I.M.F. has roughly $10 billion outstanding in short-term credits carrying an interest rate of 9.7 percent a year. The average floating rate in recent years has been 7.5 percent.
The problem is, the I.M.F. is essentially a glorified credit union, and too many of its borrowers today are behind on repayment. What the institution has traditionally done is raise the money it lends at, say, 7.5 percent by borrowing, largely from member nations, at 6.5 percent, and pocketing the percentage point difference to cover administrative expenses.
Now, however, nine borrowing nations are $4 billion in arrears on repayment, depriving the I.M.F. of interest income to cover costs. The temporary solution has been to increase the interest rate spread, partly at the borrower's expense -just when interest rates around the world are rising anyway.
Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director, suggested this week that the major lenders - the United States, West Germany, Japan and other industrial nations - provide special subsidies for third world borrowers, or some other relief.
''There was not a lot of sympathy for his suggestions among the major nations,'' said Ernesto Hernandez-Cata, an I.M.F. senior adviser.

The Economy
 Legislation to regulate the cable TV industry was set back when objections forced supporters of the bill to withdraw it from consideration on the Senate floor. The action was a big blow to consumer groups and aspiring rivals of the cable industry, who had been counting on the measure to help limit price increases for cable service and to foster increased competition. [Page 1.] The Government index designed to predict turns in the economy dropped 1.2 percent in August, the biggest fall since just after the 1987 stock crash, the Commerce Department reported. [31.] The prices that farmers receive for raw products declined by 2 percent from August to September, but the overall commodity index was still 3.5 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said. [33.] White House officials agreed in budget negotiations to a higher income tax on wealthy Americans in return for a lower capital gains tax, officials from both parties said. HEADLINE: Alvin Broido, 85, Dies; Educator in New York

 BODY:
Alvin Broido, a teacher and principal in the New York City public school system for about 45 years, died on Thursday at Scripps Memorial Hospital in Encinitas, Calif. He was 85 years old and had lived in Rancho La Costa, Calif., since retiring in 1970. 
He died of heart failure, his son, Jeffrey, of La Jolla, Calif., said.
Dr. Broido, joined the school system shortly after graduating from City College in 1924. He taught economics at Lafayette High School in Brooklyn and was an assistant principal at Lincoln Junior High School before being appointed principal of Public School 115 in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn in 1952. He held that post for 18 years until he retired.
He also served as president of the New York City Elementary Schools Principals Association and president of the New York State Elementary Schools Principals Association.
He was also a founder of the Canarsie Mental Health Clinic before moving to California where he was a founder of the La Costa Hospice.
Besides his son, Jeffrey, of La Jolla, Calif., he is survived by his wife, June; a daughter, Valerie Kaufman of Hillside, L.I., and four grandchildren.

LENGTH: 1059 words

HEADLINE: An Odd Sort Of Underdog

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 28

 BODY:
From the beginning, Pierre A. Rinfret's blustery and combative persona was well suited to his underdog campaign strategy against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. As an underfinanced and unknown challenger, Mr. Rinfret knew he would need the ''free media'' to bolster his name recognition, and a little outrageousness goes a long way in winning headlines.
Theoretically, the hyperbolic, theatrical style that Mr. Rinfret mastered as an economic consultant could have been used to tap public discontent over taxes and crime.
But during the last two weeks, when Mr. Rinfret has railed not at Mr. Cuomo but at the party that chose him, the Republican candidate has turned the conventional notion of anti-establishment politics on its head. 
 
Different Brand of Rebellion
Mr. Rinfret reversed his position on one campaign issue today, agreeing to two televised debates with Mr. Cuomo and two other candidates for governor. [Page 27.] Political strategists are increasingly convinced that unlike the uprising staged by John R. Silber, another angry outsider who won last week's Democratic gubernatorial primary in Massachusetts, Mr. Rinfret's brand of rebellion cannot succeed.
While Mr. Silber aimed his assault at a discredited political establishment, Mr. Rinfret has focused his attacks on obscure issues that have little resonance with the electorate.
''In a campaign, where you pick your targets carefully, you certainly don't make Mario Cuomo No. 3 on your hit parade behind the press and the Republicans,'' said Robert D. Squier, a consultant for Mr. Silber.
As if to symbolize the last two weeks of his campaign, Mr. Rinfret held a typically argumentative news conference here today. He began by leading reporters through a series of charts documenting New York's economic decline and crime explosion, each bearing the slogan: ''Blame Mario Cuomo.'' But when reporters began asking questions, Mr. Rinfret eagerly ignored his own message and instead revisited his bizarre political demonology, in which a handful of Republican state senators have supplanted Mr. Cuomo.
In the parlance of modern politics, obscuring your own theme is called stepping on your story. It has become a habit for Mr. Rinfret almost since he was nominated, whether when apologizing for attacking Mr. Cuomo's children or proposing to arm 100,000 vigilantes to combat crime.
The pattern continued today. At a business convention in Niagara Falls, he criticized two Republican Presidents - Ronald Reagan for running up large budget deficits and Gerald R. Ford for being unable ''to step off a curb and chew gum at the same time.''
 
Inside Baseball
In his Albany news conference, Mr. Rinfret devoted much of his time to regaling reporters with war stories about his ''battle'' with State Senator Roy M. Goodman of Manhattan, who recruited Mr. Rinfret, and State Senator Guy J. Velella of the Bronx, the chairman of the Republican Senate Campaign Committee.
Unlike the targets of Mr. Silber's campaign, Francis X. Bellotti and the Democratic establishment that he represents, Mr. Goodman and Mr. Velella are hardly household names. And Mr. Rinfret's feud with them over political and financial support is strictly inside baseball, not a debate over visceral issues that affect most New Yorkers.
But that has not deterred Mr. Rinfret. Today he began a comic description of his financial solicitations of the senators, asserting at one point that Mr. Goodman was ''as tight with money as anybody in this world.''
 
Denies a Deliberate Strategy
He said Mr. Goodman, who has at least $1 million in two political accounts, slipped him an envelope during one meeting. ''We opened it up and we almost fainted,'' Mr. Rinfret said mockingly. ''It was enormous, mind boggling, took us by surprise. It was $2,000.''
Mr. Rinfret also declined to shed any new light on his apparent misunderstanding with J. Patrick Barrett, the state's Republican Party chairman. Mr. Rinfret said on Thursday that Mr. Barrett ''hasn't been a leader'' and had offered to resign, a contention that Mr. Barrett denied.
Mr. Rinfret said today that his attacks on his fellow Republicans had not been a deliberate strategy based on the Silber model. And in an interview on Thursday he said that the significance of Mr. Silber's victory as evidence of the country's anti-incumbent mood did not dawn on him until this week.
Rather, he said, he was legitimately angry that he had accepted a Republican Party draft that no one else would take and then could not win support from the party's leaders for his budget proposals or his financial needs.
''It was not a Machiavellian strategy,'' he said today. ''It was simply a case of how do we turn our people on.''
Yet Mr. Rinfret believes that the strategy has been effective. He spoke today of being greeted by cheering crowds and of money that he said is again flowing across his transom. And he clearly relishes being on the attack, even if he might be missing the target.
''I think I've been taking a couple of so-called professionals to the cleaners pretty good lately,'' he said. ''You may disagree with my tactics, but you've got to admit I'm beginning to get my way the way I want it.''
 
Voters' Negative Feelings
The internecine Republican warfare, which has been splashed across front pages, clearly has improved Mr. Rinfret's name recognition. But it almost certainly has also increased voters' negative feelings about him, which even his own polls have shown to be twice as high as his favorable ratings.
Shortly before Mr. Silber's election, polls showed that he had disapproval ratings above 40 percent, a political barrier usually considered too high to hurdle. But Douglas E. Schoen, the New York City pollster hired by Mr. Silber, said Mr. Silber was able to overcome his deficiencies by convincing voters he would be a vehicle for change.
''He had a rationale for his candidacy,'' Mr. Schoen said. ''Pierre Rinfret doesn't represent anything except bombastic rhetoric.''
But Mr. Rinfret clearly thinks he has discovered a successful formula, even if the establishment that he opposes includes his political creators.
''People have come to detest, absolutely detest, politicians,'' he said today. ''They don't want to touch them, they don't want to deal with them. They don't want to believe anything they have to say.''

HEADLINE: BUSH DROPS FIGHT FOR A LOWER TAX ON CAPITAL GAINS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
The White House today dropped its insistence on a tax break for capital gains, opening the way for a compromise with Congress on reducing the Federal budget deficit.
Word of the shift came from people with direct knowledge of the budget talks. With their deadline close at hand, Congressional leaders and White House officials met into the night to lock up the final elements of a deal that would cut the deficit by $50 billion in the new fiscal year and $500 billion over the next five years.
Among the measures in the package are a higher gasoline tax and deep spending cuts in Medicare and other domestic programs. Congress has scheduled an unusual Sunday session so that action can be taken before the fiscal year begins on Monday. 
The capital gains concession is bound to be seen as a political defeat for President Bush, but officials for both parties said the White House preferred no capital gains break to a higher income tax on the wealthy, which Democrats had insisted on as a tradeoff. With the President yielding on capital gains, Democrats were ready to drop their call for higher income taxes on the rich. As of this afternoon, it appeared the final deal would not change tax rates.
 
Recalling Campaign Pledge
The capital gains issue had deadlocked the talks for months. President Bush maintained that lower rates or some other favorable treatment be given for capital gains, which are profits on the sale of investments. He said that was essential to promoting savings and investment and to stimulate the flagging economy. Democrats argued that better treatment for capital gains would be a windfall for the wealthy.
On Friday, Administration officials agreed in negotiations to accept higher tax rates. But in the end, a Republican said, Mr. Bush determined that higher rates would violate the ''no new taxes'' pledge that was the staple of his election campaign.
As for the capital gains break, another Republican official said, ''We just couldn't get it.''
As a concession to the Administration, Democrats agreed today to new tax breaks for science laboratories, investments in small businesses and businesses formed in poor neighborhoods. These steps will allow Republicans to assert that the budget deal is ''growth oriented.''
The loss of the capital gains feature is bound to disappoint Congressional Republicans, even though they felt less strongly about it than did Mr. Bush.
 
Where Spending Will Drop
Even before this step was taken, some Republicans were threatening to vote against any deal that contained higher taxes. The measure under consideration would raise the gasoline tax by 8 cents a gallon to 17 cents, impose a tax on other kinds of fuel and apply higher taxes to alcoholic beverages and some luxury items.
Other deficit-reduction measures tentatively agreed to by the negotiators include an increase in insurance premiums paid by the elderly for doctors' care under Medicare, an increase in the deductible for treatment paid for by Medicare, a five-year limit on all domestic spending to the amount needed to keep pace with inflation and a reduction in military spending.
The purpose is to lower the deficit in the $1.3 trillion Federal budget from the current $250 billion to a level in the low double digits.
The Administration officials and lawmakers have been racing the clock to reach a compromise before across-the-board spending reductions required by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law go into effect automatically on Monday, the beginning of the new fiscal year.
President Bush has promised to veto any measure that extends the deadline unless the outline of an accord is drawn.
 
Devastating Effects Feared
Without new appropriations, the Government would be forced to close down Monday except for a few essential employees like prison guards.
Government workers have been ordered to report to work as usual Monday morning but have been told they will be sent home if the politicians remain deadlocked.
Even if Congress approves an accord in its Sunday session, it is likely to be in the form of a continuing resolution meant to keep the Government functioning on a temporary basis. Lawmakers say it would take days and possibly weeks to enact the tax and spending bills to implement an accord.
The budget law requires that the deficit be reduced to $64 billion in the new fiscal year. Economists and politicians agree that the steps needed to reach a target that low would be devastating to the economy. So part of the deal will be to revise the annual deficit levels over the next five years.
The White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, canceled plans to join President Bush in New York tonight for a reception for a United Nations conference on children.
 
Social Security Discussed
The White House said the President was prepared to return to Washington immediately if he were needed to ratify a budget agreement.
While the top White House officials and Congressional leaders met in the office of Speaker Thomas S. Foley on the second floor of the Capitol, other officials and lawmakers met elsewhere over the other main area of dispute, Social Security.
Both sides have tentatively agreed that Social Security beneficiaries should bear some of the cost of deficit reduction, but they have disagreed over how.
Democrats want to tax a higher portion of the benefits of retirees with moderate and high incomes. Republicans want to delay cost-of-living increases for all Social Security recipients.
 
A Different Perspective
Favorable tax treatment of capital gains has always been more important to President Bush than to Republican leaders in Congress.
Senator Dole and Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader, had suggested that the White House back off its position on the issue. So had Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the top Republican on the Budget Committee.
But the President and his chief negotiators, Mr. Sununu, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Richard G. Darman, the budget director, held fast. Mr. Bush had campaigned for a lower capital gains tax as well as for no tax increases.
Apparently, the White House decided that the capital gains pledge was expendable, while opposing higher tax rates was the last vestige of the President's promise not to raise taxes.
Until 1986, capital gains were taxed at a lower rate than other income. Republicans cite studies showing that a reduction in the capital gains tax is an incentive for investment and entrepreneurship.
The monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986 was based on a compact between the two parties. The top overall tax rate to 28 percent from 50 percent. In return, capital gains were taxed at the same rate as wages and salaries.
 
Preparing for Worst
While lawmakers and Administration officials were working in the Capitol, the managers of Federal departments and agencies were trying to determine what to do if the political deadlock could not be broken. They face at least two alternative circumstances, agency officials said, and they have no way to predict which will occur.
One is that the Government is left entirely without a budget when the fiscal year begins Monday, if Congress fails to pass one or President Bush rejects it. In the other, Congress would pass a temporary budget at the last minute, but with a deficit so big that it would trigger steep automatic spending cuts throughout nearly every agency of government.

HEADLINE: U.S. AND VIETNAM REPORT PROGRESS ON RESTORING TIES

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
In their highest-level discussions in more than a decade, the United States and Vietnam took what appeared to be a significant step toward the resumption of diplomatic relations yesterday.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Nguyen Co Thach, Vietnam's Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, talked for 30 minutes at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in what a senior State Department official said was ''an exceptional meeting.''
The official said the meeting was ''a step in the direction'' of normalization of relations, but that it technically ''did not constitute the commencement of normalization discussions.''
 
Travel Restrictions Waived
The United States has not had normal diplomatic relations with Vietnam since North Vietnam's defeat of the United States-supported South Vietnamese Government in 1975. In the late 1970's, President Carter sent Leonard Woodcock, the head of the United Auto Workers Union, to Hanoi to discuss the renewal of relations, but the effort ended when Vietnam invaded Cambodia at the end of 1978. Since then talks between Washington and Hanoi have been conducted by middle-level officials. 
At the meeting yesterday, Mr. Baker waived the travel restrictions imposed on Vietnamese diplomats to allow the Foreign Minister to travel to Washington to meet with Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., a retired Army general and former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who is the President's special envoy to Hanoi on humanitarian issues. Two Stumbling Blocks The Administration wants the Vietnamese to cooperate more fully on solving the issue of 2,300 servicemen who were listed as missing in the war in Indochina or who failed to return from prisoner-of-war camps. About 70 percent of those men are missing in Vietnam, with the remainder missing in Laos and Cambodia.
That and the Cambodian issue are the two main stumbling blocks to the normalization of relations. The Bush Administration has tied renewed relations to verification of a complete removal of Vietnamese military forces from Cambodia.
At his meeting with Mr. Bush, Mr. Thach promised that Vietnam would withdraw all its troops and advisers from Cambodia and work to solve the conflict.
In a communique after the meeting, the Vietnamese said the two countries agreed ''to take concrete steps that are conducive to the normalization of relations between the two countries.''
The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said, ''The Secretary urged the Vice Premier to accelerate Vietnam's unilateral efforts to resolve the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue, thereby pre-positioning both countries for improved relations once a Cambodian settlement is achieved.''
The Vietnamese, who said that Mr. Thach would travel to Washington in two weeks after meetings with other world leaders in New York, praised the outcome of the meeting.
''Both sides reiterated their support for an early agreement on Cambodia in the Paris International Conference,'' the Vietnamese statement said. ''The two sides also agreed to accelerate the resolution of humanitarian issues of mutual concern, including the M.I.A. and the humanitarian needs of Vietnam.''
 
Prisoner Issue Stressed
The Vietnamese invaded Cambodia, then under the control of the Khmer Rouge, in 1978 and installed the Hun Sen Government. Vietnam announced the withdrawal of its troops last September, but there have been reports that some units and advisers remain to assist the Hun Sen Government in its war against the Khmer Rouge-dominated guerrilla movement.
The Secretary and Foreign Minister began by discussing prisoners of war and the missing in action, State Department officials said.
''The Secretary emphasized his and the President's personal commitment to the fullest possible accounting,'' a senior official said.
''The pace and scope of normalization will be directly effected by progress on this issue,'' the official said. ''To emphasize the priority that the President and the Secretary give to this issue, the Secretary said he was prepared to make an exception to our travel restrictions that normally keep Vietnamese officials within 25 miles of New York City.''
The waiver would allow the Foreign Minister to hold a one-day meeting with General Vessey and Ann Mills Griffith of the National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia.
The Foreign Minister has also received an invitation to meet with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
 
U.S. Stand Reiterated
The second part of the discussion centered on a Vietnamese withdrawal from Cambodia.
''The Secretary reiterated our standing position that normalization of relations with Vietnam could take place only in the context of a political settlement in Cambodia, again with the pace and scope of normalization affected by the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue,'' the senior State Department official said.
The official said progress had been made in the last few weeks on the Cambodian problem.
''Vietnam has played a constructive role in these developments,'' he said. ''Much more remains to be done as we move first to an agreement that would be signed at a Paris conference and beyond that to full implementation of that agreement.''
Mr. Baker told Mr. Thach that he saw a satisfactory conclusion to the Paris conference on Cambodia as an important step toward the establishment of diplomatic relations, State Department officials said.
''The Vietnamese have heard this before, but I think it was important for them to hear it from the Secretary,'' the senior official said.
 
The Next Step to Peace
Vietnam's recent decision to cooperate with the United States in resolving the conflict in Cambodia was a major factor that led to the warming of relations, American officials said.
They said the next step in the peace process there would be final agreement on the composition of a Supreme National Council.
The issue ''hanging up final action'' has been the number of people who should be on the council and who should head it, the senior official said. ''That subject was discussed,'' he added.
Mr. Thach briefly raised the issue of the United States economic embargo against Vietnam, State Department officials said.

HEADLINE: WORLD SUMMIT FOR CHILDREN;
World's Leaders Gather at U.N. for Summit Meeting on Children

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 29

 BODY:
More than 70 world leaders will meet here on Sunday to adopt an ambitious set of goals to improve life for poor children throughout the world.
The first World Summit for Children, the largest gathering ever of heads of state at the United Nations, is to approve a declaration committing their countries to reducing the number of infant deaths in the world by a third by the year 2000. They also plan to halve the number of women who die in childbirth and guarantee that children everywhere will have access to clean water and basic education by the end of the century.
 
Long List of Goals
The leaders, including President Bush and Prime Ministers Toshiki Kaifu of Japan and Margaret Thatcher of Britain, will pledge to achieve a long list of health and education goals that also include reducing malnutrition, raising the average weight of newborn infants, eradicating polio and making prenatal care and family planning advice available to all.
The pledges, which were accepted by participating Governments after weeks of intense negotiations, are described as one of the most ambitious attempts ever made by the international community to address children's needs. Participants are hailing the declaration as a powerful illustration of the growing conviction that improving health and education is one of the keys to reducing third world poverty. 
In the view of many economists and development experts, much of the aid spent on large industrial development projects in the third world has been wasted. The new approach favors making people healthy and giving them the skills to create their own wealth.
The unusual number of ranking leaders and their spouses and retinues in New York for the meeting caused caused headaches for planners and a surge of diplomatic and social activity at the city's hotels and restaurants. [Articles, pages 14 and 17.] The meeting's leaders will also urge all countries to ratify the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which was adopted last year by the United Nations General Assembly after a decade of discussion. Although 109 countries have signed the convention and more than 40 have introduced legislation in their parliaments to ratify it, the United States has done neither. American conservatives have criticized the Convention because it does not condemn abortion and it opposes the executions of people under 18 years of age.
It is unclear whether any of the leaders attending the conference on Sunday will be able to pledge new money toward the costs of meeting the child health goals. The United Nations Children's Fund, which conceived the idea of the summit meeting and played a central role in organizing it, said aid-giving community must channel an additional $4 billion to $6 billion a year to developing countries for the rest of the decade to meet the targets.
Developing and industrial countries wishing to achieve these goals will also need to increase their own domestic spending on child care and educational projects by $14 billion to $16 billion a year during the decade, Unicef says.
Also Implicit in the meeting's timing, at the end of the cold war era, is an understanding that governments will give children the first call on any peace dividends they collect from reduced military spending in a more orderly world. In the third world alone, military spending is now running at more than $200 billion a year.
 
Forces Come Together
''Two separate forces are coming together at the summit. The realization we can save millions of children's lives through underutilized, low-cost technologies,'' James P. Grant, the executive director of Unicef said in a recent interview. '' and the end of the cold war, which should liberate billions of dollars wasted on armaments.''
Organizing so vast a meeting of world leaders as the session on Sunday has meant severe headaches for the New York City authorities and for United Nations officials. For weeks now they have been struggling with the daunting task of preventing enormous traffic snarls as 71 motorcades converge on the United Nations headquarters and protecting this unprecedented gathering of political leaders against possible terrorist attack.
Because of the throngs of diplomats involved, some leaders will leave their hotels as early as 6 A.M. to make it to the United Nations in time for the start of the proceedings at 9:30, officials say.
 
Sensitive to Criticism
The meeting cost $5 million to organize, all of it paid for by individual national donations. The participants are sensitive to the possibility that the elaborate meeting will be criticized as an expensive and unneccessary public-relations exercise by politicians hungry for the favorable publicity they expect to gain from endorsing a series of child-care goals.
But in a recent interview, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, a co-chairman of the meeting, strongly defended the gathering's usefulness as a means of strengthening the participating governments' commitment to these goals and making sure they live up to their commitments in practice.
''The summit has the potential to put children's issues on the top of the international agenda in the same way the Stockholm World Environment Conference of 1972 put environmental problems so firmly on that agenda,'' he said.
''Summits do what nothing else can do: put leaders face to face with each other and raise public awareness of the issue,'' the Canadian Prime Minister added. ''There is nothing like for galvanizing a bureaucracy.''
The idea of a children's summit meeting was proposed by Unicef in September 1988 and won the support of United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, Mr. Grant of Unicef said. The plan was then quickly endorsed by Sweden, Zimbabwe and Canada.
 
Unicef's Earlier Success
What gave Unicef the confidence to propose that the world set new health and educational goals for children. in the 1990's was its success in persuading governments to meet the earlier health goals it set for them in the 1980's together with other interested United Nations agencies.
Unicef's aim in the last decade was to raise the percentage of children in the world who are fully immunized against a number of serious but preventable diseases from 15 percent in 1980 to 80 percent by this year. In fact, Immunization coverage is estimated at around 73 percent today, only slightly short of the target.
''We realized we could get enough support from governments to achieve these goals,'' says Richard Jolly, Unicef's deputy executive director for programs and a noted British delevopment expert.
Another factor encouraging the agency to seek governments' backing for new child health targets was the availability of many relatively inexpensive and simple cures for some of the most lethal children's diseases, and particularly oral hydration techniques for dealing with diarrhea, Dr. Jolly says.
The cost of achieving such goals will not be prohibitive if donor countries put more emphasis on primary health and education care projects by restructuring their aid budgets.
Total world aid to the developing world is currently running at around $50 billion a year and is expected to increase by $1 billion a year, or 2 percent annually, over the next decade.
Of this total only about 3 percent currently goes to primary health, education and sanitation projects. But Unicef calculates that earmarking all of the annual 2 percent annual increment for such projects would double the amount of assistance going to these sectors.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dutch children planting a tree at a ceremony yesterday at the United Nations gardens. At rear was James Grant, the head of Unicef. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hofstra Coach Is Slain on Sidewalk

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
An assistant football coach at Hofstra University was shot to death early yesterday outside a restaurant near the school by a man in what appeared to be a bungled robbery attempt, the police said.
The coach, Harry Healy, 25 years old, was sitting with four friends eating on a curb outside a fast-food restaurant not far from Hofstra's campus in Hempstead, L.I., when the shooting took place about 3:50 A.M., said a spokesman for the Nassau County Police, Officer Andrew DeSimone.
A Nassau County Police Detective, Sgt. Daniel Severin said, ''it appears it was a robbery attempt gone bad.'' 
Mr. Healy had been employed by Hofstra as one of the assistant coaches of the Flying Dutchmen football team at the school since August, said a university spokesman, Michael DeLuise.
Mr. Healy had received a degree in economics from the University of Connecticut in 1987 and was taking graduate courses in economics at Hofstra, but ''wanted to coach football,'' said Mr. DeLuise. ''This was a dream for him.
 
Football Game Dedicated
Later, after word of his death had swept the campus, the football team's game against the University of Buffalo Bisons at Hofstra yesterday afternoon, which Hofstra won 44-0, was dedicated to Mr. Healy's memory.
''The team had chapel service before the game,'' said Jim Sheehan, the director of sports information. ''It was very emotional, to say the least.''
Mr. Healy and four friends had gone to the restaurant, Arby's, at Fulton Street and Duncan Road, for a late-night snack after leaving a popular college hangout, McHebe's Depot, a bar on Fulton Street, shortly before closing time. They ordered food at the walk-up window, the officer said.
As they sat on a curb eating, two men walked up to the group, the officer said. ''There was some brief conversation,'' said Sergeant Severin. ''Exactly what was said - 'Get up, get down, don't move' - we're not 100 percent sure.''
The gunman shot the young man from a distance of about eight feet in ''a deliberate shot,'' Sergeant Severin said, but why he picked out Mr. Healy was unclear.
None of the other students was injured and the two men fled on foot.
Mr. Healy was taken to the Nassau County Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead at 4:21 A.M., said Officer DeSimone.
No gun was recovered and there were no immediate suspects.

HEADLINE: Youth Program's Mixed Day: $100,000 Won, $250,000 Lost

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
A Cambridge, Mass., youth training program hailed as a model for the nation got a dose of good news and a jolt of bad news on the same day last week.
Hours before the program accepted a $100,000 prize from the Ford Foundation and Harvard University, it learned it had lost $250,000 as a result of the budget cuts in Massachusetts.
The program, Work Force Unemployment Prevention, provides counseling, tutoring and jobs in local businesses to teen-agers in the low-income housing projects of the Cambridge Housing Authority. 
It was one of only 10 state- or city-financed programs selected from 1,552 contestants in a national competition by the Ford Foundation and the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. The prizes, the Innovations awards, were created in 1985 to recognize state or local government activities that address social and economic issues. Winners are selected by a committee headed by former Gov. William G. Milliken of Michigan.
 
'We're Going to Fight'
The Cambridge program was part of a $310 million budget cut announced last week by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, a package that included money for adult literacy education and English courses for immigrants. The program had been threatened with elimination in January, but was spared after a campaign led by teen-agers and parents.
At the awards ceremony in New York on Wednesday, Steven J. Swanger, the program's founder, said: ''We're going to fight to be reinstated and get our supporters to write letters. There are thousands of families in Cambridge who know what this program has accomplished.''
Work Force will continue to operate for now and has just registered a new group of 125 teen-agers, Mr. Swanger said. Officials of the Ford Foundation said the awards were not to be used for operating costs, but rather to help educate and train others interested in copying the program.
 
New York to Alaska
Another award winner was Export, a program of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that is the nation's first publicly supported trading company created to help small businesses compete in world markets.
Among the other winners were an Alaska program, Inupiat Ilitqusiat, that seeks to protect the traditional Eskimo culture and curb the high rate of alcoholism and suicide; and a program in Ramsey County, Minn., that for the first time uses automated teller machines to dispense public assistance benefits.
The other winners were Specialized Treatment and Rehabilitation Services for Sexually Abused Boys, of Merced County, Calif.; the Landfill Reclamation Project in Collier County, Fla.; the Farm Family Assistance Program of Iowa; Project Deliver, an obstetrical care program in Montgomery County, Md.; Medical Care for Children, in Fairfax County, Va., and the recycling program in Seattle.

HEADLINE: Old Angers Still Fresh As Indians Meet Lujan

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 28

 BODY:
At one of the largest gatherings of American Indian tribal leaders in recent years, the meeting itself became the most contentious issue, with some Indians raising the oldest charge of all against the Federal Government: trickery.
Nearly 700 tribal leaders gathered here on Friday at the invitation of Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. to join in consultations about a planned reorganization of the Bureau of Indian Affairs.
But as Mr. Lujan and other officials described their plans, many tribal leaders seethed with resentment at being presented with what one called ''a done deal.''
At one point, Wayne Ducheneaux, a Cheyenne River Sioux with a dramatic handlebar mustache, stood up to demand a halt to the entire proceeding, which he said was ignoring the views of the Indians. 
''You say you want consultation with the Indian tribes, but I don't think you truly want it,'' said Mr. Ducheneaux, who is president of the National Congress of American Indians, a major intertribal group.
The main subject of the meeting was the creation of a separate bureau in the Department of the Interior to administer education on Indian reservations, and a resulting realignment of responsibilities within the department's Bureau of Indian Affairs.
A broader context for the discussions was the Federal Government's stated policy to move toward greater autonomy for the more than 500 tribes in this country. A banner in the ballroom of the Four Seasons Hotel read, ''Expanding self-determination: Tribal-Federal partnership.''
For the last century and a half, life on the reservations has been dominated by the Bureau of Indian Affairs, which today oversees schools, law enforcement, courts, social services, forests and fisheries, electric power systems, banks and construction projects. The reservations remain among the most poverty-stricken areas in the country, with unemployment as high as 70 percent.
But at the meeting here, questions of reorganization and self-determination sometimes became lost in the issue of consultation, which seemed to resonate for many with the ancient hurts of their relations with Washington.
''Consultation is one of the code words in a relationship that sums up a set of problems that is hard to define,'' said Sam Deloria, a member of the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe who is an expert on Indian affairs at the University of New Mexico Law School.
''The sense of being aggrieved is part of the nature of the relationship, and it manifests itself in complaints about consultation,'' he said.
 
Complaints Are 100 Years Old
Officials from Washington also brought with them long memories of the difficulties of the relationship. ''These complaints go back 100 years,'' said one.
Responding to Mr. Ducheneaux's comments, Eddie F. Brown, the Assistant Secretary for Indian Affairs, told the leaders, ''I commit to you today that I will be working with area directors and that I will personally be out at major hearings around the country.''
But speaking to a small group of reporters, he said: ''You will never at any time have all of the 500 tribes happy. You will never have maybe 50 percent of the tribes happy.''
Given the history of the relationship, he said: ''The tribes are wary. Is this all part of an agenda for something else, for chopping the budget?''
Although Mr. Lujan repeatedly affirmed his commitment to maintaining the Federal Government's trust responsibilities toward the Indians, the tribal leaders received few details on how the reorganization would affect budgets and funds.
''This is like giving the Indian tribes a Christmas tree'' said Wendell Chino, chairman of the Mescalero Apache tribe. ''It looks very nice, but there are no presents under the tree for the Indian tribes.''
Indeed, there was some poignance to the scene as a series of tribal participants, accepting the invitation for consultation, rose to offer their thoughts on the creation of a Bureau of Indian Education. Just a little while earlier, Mr. Lujan and Mr. Brown had told reporters that plans for the new bureau were complete and were already being presented to Congress.
Ernie Lovato, the chairman of the Santo Domingo tribe, who also heads a group of 10 Pueblo tribes in New Mexico, spoke of the Government's ''one-sided consultations.''
''We are not some little guys any more,'' he told the gathering. ''We've gone through the mill; we've been to the Justice Department, to Congress. We know what we're talking about.'' Tribal leaders have complained for years that a paternalistic bureaucracy holds them back from developing initiative and responsibility, while failing to meet their needs. Thomas Sansonetti, the Interior Department's solicitor, said President Bush wants to develop ''government-to-government'' dealings between the tribes and Washington.
Federal officials estimate that more than $3 billion is spent annually on Indian affairs, most of it going for the more than 330,000 Indians living on 260 reservations. A total of 1.37 million Indians were counted in the 1980 census.
Self-determination, which has been on Washington's agenda for 20 years, would mean a difficult shift that would involve not only complicated bureaucratic readjustments but a maturing of tribal leadership. ''The majority of tribes are not capable of self-governance at this time,'' said Leaford Bearskin, chief of the Wyandotte tribe in Oklahoma.
On Monday, the Quinault Indian Nation of Taholah, Wash., becomes fully independent, one of seven tribes in a project to test self-governance.
''The hardest thing was to convince our own people that we could do it,'' said Joseph De La Cruz, the tribe's chairman. ''Now we don't have all the bureaucrats to go through, all the hoops and the red tape.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
P.L.O. Embarks on Biggest Gamble in Many Years by Moving Closer to Iraq

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 28

 BODY:
As the Persian Gulf crisis drives ever-deeper schisms through Arab ranks, the Palestine Liberation Organization and its chairman, Yasir Arafat, have embarked on a political gamble with stakes as high as any the organization has faced in many years of crisis.
Driven by the pro-Iraqi sentiments in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and among the Palestinian majority in Jordan, Mr. Arafat has deepened already intimate ties with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, condemning the United States military buildup in the region and promoting a settlement that would reward Iraq for its invasion with territorial and economic concessions by Kuwait.
In the process, diplomats, Palestinian officials and other specialists said, Mr. Arafat has moved to secure a constituency on the streets but has lost, probably for a long time, the support of the so-called moderate Arab states, which, a year ago, took his case to Washington, sponsored his avowed peace campaign and represented his only means of bringing diplomatic pressure to bear on Israel.
 
Speaking for Palestinians
His calculation, his supporters say, is that whatever the outcome of the gulf crisis, the Palestinian issue will re-emerge high on the regional agenda and someone will have to speak for the Palestinians, and that he will survive to fulfill that role. 
But the sense of betrayal among the so-called moderate Arabs after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, and the opprobrium Mr. Arafat's close ties to President Hussein have generated in the West, are such that many diplomats, officials and commentators in the region argue that Mr. Arafat is courting hazards as extreme as any in a career marked by a conspicuous ability to invite, then survive disaster.
''No one can totally exclude the possibility that Arafat will re-emerge as someone who has to be taken into account,'' said a Western European diplomat here. ''But he has made it that much more difficult, because he has given the Israelis and others the ammunition to say what they have always said: that he is not a reliable interlocutor.''
 
Nurtured Anti-Americanism
The origins of Mr. Arafat's close ties to Baghdad predate the newest crisis in the Persian Gulf by many months and lie in a tangle of issues that undermined the P.L.O.'s alliance with Egypt and nurtured the profound anti-Americanism around the figure of Saddam Hussein.
In the welter of passions since the invasion, the whole focus of the Arab world has shifted, forcing Arab states to take sides not on the easy issue of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, or even directly on the invasion of Kuwait itself, but on the personality of Saddam Hussein as a champion of Arab rights against the foreign military intrusion.
''Objectivity has become a curse,'' said Assad Abdul Rahman, a prominent P.L.O. analyst and professor of political science in Amman, Jordan. ''If you don't say, 'Long live Saddam,' you are totally blamed by the Iraqis and you will suffer. If you don't say yes to Jaber and the American military interference, then again you are treated badly by the other side.'' Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah is the Emir of Kuwait.
 
Stage Set for Conflict
Yet, since the beginning of the year, diplomats and officials argue, events have set the stage for conflict pitting a Baghdad-led coalition of Palestinians, Jordanians and others against the United States and its Arab allies.
The alarms first came from Jordan, whose leaders expressed concern about the prospect of huge Soviet Jewish immigration to Israel, and sought out Iraq's strength as a counterweight to what King Hussein perceived as an Israeli threat.
At the same time, United States diplomatic efforts to set up a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue in Cairo seemed to slow, even as some Palestinians began to accuse Mr. Arafat of making concessions to the Israelis and Americans while getting nothing in return.
Then, possibly sensing a mood of frustration and worry in the Arab world, President Hussein announced on April 1 that if attacked, he would burn half of Israel with chemical weapons.
 
Sources of Baghdad's Strength
''It contributed to his image as the only guy who has built a credible military force to bring the Israelis to the negotiating table,'' Mr. Abdul Rahman said in a telephone interview from Amman. ''When he stood up to the Americans, that was another source of strength.''
''He represented the only hope for the Palestinian Arab,'' he said, adding that with his attacks on the oil-rich skeikdoms of the gulf, where ruling families wield immense power and wealth. ''Saddam managed to market himself as the Robin Hood who was going to redistribute Arab wealth.''
In May, Mr. Arafat toured the Arab world, drumming up support for an Arab summit meeting in Baghdad on May 28 that produced attacks on Egyptian diplomacy and effectively shifted the center of gravity from Cairo toward the more bellicose Baghdad. An abortive Palestinian terrorist attack on Israeli beaches, staged just as the summit was drawing to a close, finalized the breach between the more radicalized Arabs and the United States. In June, citing the beach assault, Washington severed the dialogue it started with the P.L.O. in December 1988, after Mr. Arafat renounced terrorism and accepted Israel's right to exist.
 
'That Was the Climax'
''That was the climax,'' said Mr. Abdul Rahman, a member of the Palestinian parliament-in-exile, the Palestine National Council, who is not formally aligned with any of the P.L.O.'s factions.
From the West's point of view, and in the view of the so-called moderate Arabs led by Egypt and Saudi Arabia, the invasion of Kuwait is the burning issue of the day. But for Baghdad's allies, the issue is the American buildup in response to the invasion.
''People are not thinking about Kuwait,'' Mr. Abdul Rahman said. ''They say the most important thing is the American invasion of Saudi Arabia and the gulf. Palestinians are saying they will not allow the Americans to destroy the only hope for the Arabs to bring the Israelis to the negotiating table, that is, Saddam Hussein.''
But the invasion also put the the P.L.O. in the difficult position of supporting an action it has long condemned. For decades in the conflict with Israel, the P.L.O. had declared the inadmissiblity of forceful territorial acquisition as an argument against Israel's occupation of the West Bank, Gaza and the Golan Heights.
 
Attempt to Mediate
P.L.O. officials argue that the organization never endorsed the occupation of Kuwait - even though it refused to support an Arab League resolution condemning it - and has sought instead to mediate the dispute so as to persuade Iraq to withdraw, a role the United States and moderate Arabs reject.
''The P.L.O.'s position is simple,'' Nabil Shaath, a leading Cairo-based adviser to Mr. Arafat said. ''If we can help in ending the occupation of Kuwait, then we can move on to ending the occupation of Palestine.''
The P.L.O. position offers concessions to the Iraqi leader. Without offering Iraq incentives, P.L.O. officials argued, it will not leave Kuwait without a fight.
 
Support Is Closed Off
But the concessions are opposed by the West and the bloc of moderate Arabs, and in breaking with the moderate Arabs, Mr. Arafat has closed off powerful channels of diplomatic and financial support.
Shortly after the invasion, the rulers of Qatar and the United Arab Emirates refused him permission to enter their countries. Saudi Arabia has reduced its once substantial aid to his movement. Egypt, whose leader, Hosni Mubarak, has called Saddam Hussein a traitor, has placed restrictions on the entry of Palestinians into the country. Kuwaiti officials say that if they get their country back, there will be no leniency towards those among the 350,000 Palestinians in Kuwait deemed to have helped the invaders in any way. And many Western nations, including the United States, no longer wish to acknowledge Mr. Arafat.
''The whole issue is, who will speak for the Palestinians?'' said a senior Western diplomat. ''At one time, we were getting pretty close to the P.L.O. in disguise at the negotiating table. Now, that is not going to work.'' Offending the Americans An Arab diplomat put it somewhat differently: ''The more Arafat offends the Americans, the less chance he has of getting them to deliver. And he's offended them a lot.''
Many Egyptians, too, have been incensed by the P.L.O.'s shift away from Cairo. ''Egyptians by and large trusted Arafat,'' said Ismail Sabry Abdullah, a left-wing politician and former Cabinet minister. ''Now Egyptians blame him. They don't understand his attitude.'' ''Egypt will never abandon its position of principles on the Palestinian issue,'' he said in an interview. ''But there's a problem of public opinion. That is something very precious. Once diminished, it's hard to correct.''
That assessment seemed reflected the other day in the Government-owned daily newspaper Al Akhbar, which printed a cartoon showing Mr. Arafat embracing a Kuwaiti while holding a dagger to his back. The cartoon illustrated a lengthy article castigating P.L.O. members as duplicitous cowards who had exploited, or turned against, every Arab country that gave them refuge. Such hostility elsewhere in the Arab world leaves the P.L.O. leader with few options for the time being but to stand close to Baghdad.
While some Egyptian newspaper commentators have taken to speaking of Mr. Arafat's imminent demise, there are other arguments. In 1982, the Israeli invasion of Lebanon forced Mr. Arafat out of Beirut. In 1983, Syrian-backed forces drove him out of Tripoli, his last toe-hold in a country bordering Israel. In 1987, at an Arab summit, his cause was all but forgotten as Arab states focused on Iraq's war with Iran. On each of those occasions, his demise was forecast, too.
This time, ''he did not maneuver with his usual skill,'' a West European envoy said. ''But alliances in this part of the world tend to form and re-form, and that could provide other opprtunities for him.''

PUB-DATE: September 30, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 21, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1196 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Kuwaitis Say U.S. Doubts Embargo Will Get Iraq Out

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

 BODY:
Senior Kuwaiti officials say they believe the Bush Administration has concluded that it can no longer rely on the embargo of Iraq to force the Iraqi army out of the Persian Gulf sheikdom.
The officials, who insisted that they not be identified, said that neither President Bush nor Kuwait's Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, specifically mentioned using military force in their two-hour meeting and lunch at the White House on Friday.
''But there was a consensus among us that waiting for the embargo to work would mean the death of Kuwait and that there were few, if any, other options available short of military action,'' one of the officials said.
In interviews, other diplomats, American legislators and a senior Administration official did not dispute the Kuwaitis' impression that the Administration was re-evaluating the embargo. But rather than describe the change as a policy shift, they said the White House was turning up the pressure a notch to make sure that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has gotten the message. 
 
Bleak U.S. Prognosis
The most public expression of the Administration's tougher mood, they said, was the statement by Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, on Friday after the meeting with the Emir that the ''systematic destruction'' of Kuwait was shortening the time that the United States could wait for economic sanctions to force the Iraqis out of Kuwait.
But for at least a week, the Administration has been giving a bleak prognosis in private discussions with Congressional leaders and diplomats. For example, President Bush told a bipartisan meeting of Congressional leaders a week ago Friday that the destruction taking place on the ground in Kuwait, among other factors, would make it difficult to adhere to the Administration's stated goal of squeezing and ultimately forcing Mr. Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait through the sanctions, according to participants at the White House meeting.
Similar sentiments were expressed in the meetings with the Kuwaitis on Friday at the White House. After those sessions, the Bush Administration decided to make public Kuwait's concern and Washington's private impression that there might be nothing left to save in Kuwait if it waited for the sanctions to achieve their stated goal.
''What the Emir's visit has done,'' said Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, ''was enabled the Administration to go public with their private conclusion that there would be no Kuwait left to save if the original timetable - six to eight months - were permitted to play itself out.''
 
U.S. Troops Could Lose Edge
The concern expressed by Kuwaiti officials reinforced other doubts within the Administration, Congressional and Administration officials said. Those include a concern that American military forces, which are expected to be fully deployed within a month, would ''lose their edge'' as time passes, an official said.
A second factor is concern that the United States would be reluctant to engage in military action during Ramadan, Islam's holy month beginning in mid-March, or during the Haj pilgrimage next summer, periods when the effects of the embargo are likely to be widely felt in Iraq.
A third reason is the Administration's concern about intelligence estimates indicating that Iraq might be ready to deploy biological weapons by early next year.
The Administration has not yet officially abandoned its policy of waiting for the embargo to press Iraq into withdrawal. And it has stopped short of an explicit warning of American military action. While it has not explained what other steps in addition to the embargo it is contemplating, Mr. Scowcroft said after the meeting with the Emir that the plundering of Kuwait might prompt the United States to seek another United Nations Security Council resolution, possibly including an explicit mention of military force.
 
Optimistic Kuwaiti Delegation
''In our meeting, President Bush expressed his determination to liberate Kuwait - one way or another,'' said a senior member of the Kuwaiti delegation who insisted on not being identified.
The mood of the 27-member Kuwaiti delegation in New York was optimistic after the standing ovation given to the Emir at the United Nations on Thursday and his visit to Washington on Friday.
''The support was overwhelming,'' said Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, Kuwait's Finance Minister. ''We received a total commitment for the liberation of Kuwait.'' He declined to state whether total meant that President Bush had signaled his determination to use military force. But other delegates said there had been an implicit acknowledgment by American and Kuwaiti officials that the use of force seemed ever more likely.
A senior Administration official who insisted on not being identified said the only differences that emerged during the sessions concerned what he called the timing of stronger measures.
 
U.S. 'Must Be Ready'
''The Kuwaitis would like to have used force yesterday, today or tomorrow,'' the official said. ''But President Bush has other factors that must be taken into consideration - political factors.''
A senior Kuwaiti official said that after Friday's discussions in Washington, ''even differences of timing'' were less consequential than before. ''We know that the Americans must be ready - politically, militarily,'' he said.
Sheik Saud Nasir al-Sabah, Kuwait's Ambassador to the United States, seemed eager to avoid the impression that Kuwait was pushing Washington to use military force. He repeatedly stressed that the Emir had not specifically recommended military action in his meetings with President Bush, senior National Security Council officials, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
''We did urge the Administration to push for the visit of an independent entity - be it the Red Cross or Red Crescent, or even reporters or correspondents - to Kuwait so that the devastation on the ground can be documented,'' he said in an interview Friday.
 
Kuwaiti Base Offer Denied
''The point of these meetings was really to highlight the plight of the people inside Kuwait,'' the Ambassador said. ''That has been our main concern.''
He said that no new commitments had been made and no new groups formed to monitor the situation. ''We've simply agreed to keep in daily and constant touch,'' he said.
Kuwait's Minister of Planning, Sulaiman A. Mutawa, dismissed previously published reports that Kuwait had offered the United States a permanent base in the country when and if the Iraqis were forced out.
''There was never any discussion between us of such an arrangement,'' he said. ''It shouldn't be ruled out and it shouldn't be ruled in. But talk of such arrangements and of other steps that relate to our commitment to democracy are putting the cart before the horse.''
 
'A Bloody Wasteland'
''In the meantime, I'm watching my country die,'' he said. ''The flower that was in bloom is being trampled into a bloody wasteland. The longer it goes on, the less there is of Kuwait.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Soviets Hint at a Role In U.N. Military Action

 BODY:
The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, has indicated that if the United Nations Security Council authorizes a military force to act in the Persian Gulf crisis, Soviet troops might take part.
In a speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday, Mr. Shevardnadze had suggested that if the economic embargo against Iraq failed, Moscow might support a military operation sanctioned by the United Nations. His new remarks appear to be a slight elaboration on that, but they stopped short of promising Soviet troops for such a force.
The remarks, from a taping of the ''Meet the Press'' televison program to be aired today, were made available yesterday without comment by White House officials who were in New York with President Bush.
In the interview, Mr. Shevardnadze was asked, ''If it comes to a military action of some kind, will Soviet troops be participating with the U.N. forces?''
He replied: ''Well, this will all depend on the decision to be taken by the Security Council. We are a permanent member of the Security Council, and we will comply with any decision, with any resolution of the security council.
''This is our position of principle. And that would include anything regarding the involvement of the Soviet troops under flag, under the auspices, of the United Nations,'' he said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.S. Explores New Strategies to Limit Weapons of Mass Destruction

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
Iraq's emergence as a regional superpower, bristling with missiles and chemical arms and close to producing nuclear ones, is prodding the Bush Administration to consider new strategies to stem the worldwide spread of mass-destruction weapons, according to Government officials.
Those strategies, known as fallback positions to some, spring from the growing conviction that some of the basic technologies needed to wage highly destructive wars, like the ability to build ballistic missiles and chemical weapons, have become too widespread to control easily.
Administration officials said the Persian Gulf crisis had led experts to press to achieve two new aims: to keep developing nations from acquiring technologies that could make their existing weapons even more lethal, and to dissuade their leaders from using the advanced arms, such as chemical weapons, that they already have.
''It's no longer enough to try to curb proliferation,'' a senior State Department official said in a recent interview, ''because in a number of cases proliferation has already occurred.'' 
 
Iraq's Strength Cited
While that idea is not novel, the gulf crisis has brought it home to policy makers with new force, officials said. Besides its ballistic missiles, chemical and possibly biological weapons and an active nuclear-bomb program, Iraq has amassed an armed force that experts say is the technological equal of NATO countries such as Italy, a nation with three times Iraq's population and 30 times its gross domestic product.
A chief concern is that technologies with military applications are moving into everyday use faster than the ability of Western nations to control their export. For example, computers used for such diverse purposes as regulating printing presses and reconciling checking accounts can be used to operate missile-launching sites, and guidance systems in commercial aircraft can be modified to guide ballistic missiles.
''The issue isn't really that these people have Scuds,'' said W. Seth Carus, a proliferation expert at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, referring to a crude short-range ballistic missile that the Soviet Union has sold to Iraq and about 20 other developing nations. ''The issue is that they know how to make Scuds. That means they no longer have to rely on Western technology.''
The Central Intelligence Agency has predicted that 20 developing nations will produce their own missiles within a decade. Already, Argentina, Brazil, China, Egypt, India, Iraq, Israel, North Korea, Pakistan and South Africa produce or are close to producing their own missiles. Most also have nuclear weapons or advanced nuclear programs.
 
Nuclear Arms for Iraq
Many private experts and Israeli scientists believe Iraq will be able to produce a crude nuclear weapon in three to five years.
The missiles now in third-world inventories are too inaccurate to threaten specific enemy targets, arms experts say, and for now few such nations are believed able to launch a chemical or nuclear warhead with confidence that it will detonate on impact.
Nevertheless, experts in the transfer of military technology at the Central Intelligence Agency have begun an extensive assessment of the technical and scientific abilities of developing nations, an official said.
The Bush Administration has begun to dust off cold war arms-control policies, such as confidence-building agreements between hostile nuclear powers, for use in trouble spots.
''We need to focus more on what we can do, once weapons of mass destruction have proliferated, to build in fire bricks against their use,'' a senior official said. ''We need to talk more to the Soviets about it, and we need to talk to the Western Europeans about it.''
 
New Alliance Suggested
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d suggested one cold war tack last August when he raised the prospect of a new military security alliance, along the lines of NATO, that would counterbalance Iraq. The Soviet Union proposed another in February 1989, when it called for a military threat-reduction center in the Middle East to detect and defuse potential conflict between Israel and its Arab neighbors.
Some, even within the Administration, question the depth of this newfound devotion to third-world arms control. Those doubts were underscored this month, when the White House approved the export of parts for a new three-stage missile that Brazil is developing, despite compelling evidence that Brazil has shared missile and nuclear technology with Iraq.
Others say the idea that East-West arms control tactics will work in the Middle East is absurd.
 
Mideast Wars 'Endemic'
''There are slight differences between the cold war and the Middle East,'' Mr. Carus said. ''In the worst of the cold war, the United States and the Soviet Union talked to each other. There are a number of countries in this region that don't even talk to each other covertly.''
''And despite our tensions, the U.S. and the Soviets never fought a war,'' he said. ''In the Middle East, wars are endemic.''
Yet the United States has already tried nuclear diplomacy in at least one trouble spot. In March, after intelligence officials warned that India and Pakistan were approaching war over the border state of Kashmir, Robert M. Gates, the deputy national security adviser, flew to both countries on a peace mission.
An Administration official said that Mr. Gates conveyed American worries that the two nations were drifting ''ineluctably toward war, worst-casing each other's intentions,'' without real awareness of the potentially catastrophic consequences.
Mr. Gates suggested that the two sides consider steps long used by the United States and the Soviet Union, including allowing observers at military exercises and creating zones where troop maneuvers are banned, to lessen each side's mistrust of the other. Pakistan and India have since conducted talks on confidence-building measures.
Western nations have cooperated to limit the export of missile technologies since 1987. The Soviet Union pledged to join that effort in February, potentially plugging a large hole in the technology embargo, officials said.
But Administration officials said the effort to curb the trade in weapons technology and components has become increasingly difficult at a time when the West has lowered its own standards for exporting many technologies that have both civilian and military uses.
Cocom, the alliance of American and European nations that regulates the export of technologies to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, decided in June to drop many barriers to the sale of such dual-use items to emerging democracies in Eastern Europe.
That allows American and European firms to sell mid-range computers, aircraft guidance systems, oscilloscopes and other high-technology goods to former Warsaw Pact nations at will, even though such goods can also be used to design, test and navigate missiles and other weapons. Other, more sensitive items can now be approved for export subject to controls on their destinations and uses.
''No one is under the illusion that the Eastern Europeans are going to be able to protect everything they get,'' said one Government expert in technology theft, who declined to be named, referring to losses to smuggling.
''You're going to see a situation where Eastern European intelligence agents who have worked for Qaddafi, Hussein or whoever, including the Soviets, are looking for new work,'' the Government expert said in a recent interview. ''And as new trade opportunities pop up there, the diversion opportunities are going to be great.''
