HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Behind Iraqi's Oratory, Cautious Game Is Seen

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 29

 BODY:
In the city's hotels, officials of President Saddam Hussein's Information Ministry have set out, in several foreign languages, an imposing array of speeches and statements that Mr. Hussein has made since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
The themes running through many of them are that Kuwait's annexation is ''eternal and irreversible'' and that Iraq is ready to fight and prevail in a war against the United States.
Prompted by those statements, and a variety of indications from Kuwait that Mr. Hussein is consolidating his hold, the Bush Administration has tightened military, economic and political pressures on Baghdad and hinted that the crisis may ultimately have to be resolved by war. At the United States Embassy here, diplomats make little secret of their conviction that nothing will budge Mr. Hussein from Kuwait but his military defeat, unless Mr. Hussein unexpectedly loses his position of absolute power. 
 
Steps to Limit Risks
Elsewhere in Baghdad, there are people who are not yet convinced that Mr. Hussein is as implacably committed to his course as he has sounded in his diatribes.
Some oblique hints from senior Iraqi officials have suggested to Western diplomats that Mr. Hussein may have realized that neither Iraq nor his leadership have much chance of winning a war against the United States. Further, the diplomats say, there are signs that Mr. Hussein is taking steps to limit the risks of sliding into a war by accident or by a provocation that would give Washington a reason to strike.
Those who take this view suffer from the same disadvantage as those who believe that Mr. Hussein cannot be dissuaded from a course that will plunge the region into conflict: None of them have talked with the Iraqi leader directly, at least not since Aug. 2, and they thus rely on their reading of Mr. Hussein's character and record. The Iraqi leader operates in tight secrecy and nobody in the capital in recent days has been able to say whether the President is even in Baghdad, much less to avow that they are privy to his thinking. Decision Not Yet Made? Still, the view among the diplomats, who include several Western ambassadors, is that Mr. Hussein has probably not yet made a final decision on what to do about Kuwait, and that much depends on matters that may take weeks or months to become clear.
Among the factors are the impact of the United Nations embargo on Iraq's military effectiveness. The sanctions have cut off badly needed spare military parts. Along with this, there is the possibility of popular discontent over mounting food shortages. Perhaps most important, there is the question of whether the common front mounted against Iraq by the United States and the Soviet Union, along with Western Europe and several important Arab allies, can be maintained.
Attempting to drive wedges into this alliance is likely to be a major preoccupation of Mr. Hussein in the weeks ahead, the diplomats said.
When the diplomats speak of moves by Mr. Hussein that suggest a concern not to provoke a war, they cite several things. One was the Foreign Ministry's rapid backing away from a diplomatic note delivered to Western embassies last weekend in which the ministry appeared to be threatening diplomats with execution by hanging if they persisted in giving sanctuary to Western men who have been declared hostages by Mr. Hussein. About 200 men are staying at the American, British and other missions or in diplomatic homes.
 
Note Withdrawn After Calls
After calls to the Foreign Ministry by Joseph C. Wilson 4th, the American charge d'affaires here, asking whether the ministry intended to hang him, the diplomatic note was withdrawn.
Other recent incidents tend to support a belief that Mr. Hussein might be playing a cautious game behind his oratory. First, there was Baghdad's instruction to the captains of Iraqi ships to comply with orders to submit to inspection by United States naval vessels in the Persian Gulf. The order was given before the United Nations gave its backing to such actions, and was designed, diplomats say, to avoid the risk of a confrontation.
This week, the Information Ministry took steps to ease tensions created when Mr. Hussein implied last Sunday that Iraq might strike first if its population of 18 million people is ''strangled'' by the embargo. Officials drew reporters' attention to an official Iraqi translation of the statement by the ruling Revolutionary Command Council in which the key paragraph in the speech included a phrase not present in Western translations.
 
First-Strike Phrase Omitted
As translated from Arabic by The Associated Press, whose version was widely used by Western newspapers, the statement did not include the qualifying phrase that appeared to make an Iraqi strike contingent on there being ''some who are directing a bloody strike at the Iraqis'' first. The official Iraqi version read: ''If we feel that the people of Iraq are being strangled and that there are some who are directing a bloody strike at the Iraqis, we will strangle all those who are the cause of such a state of affairs.''
The diplomats cautioned that they were far from persuaded by such moves that Mr. Hussein was preparing to relent over Kuwait, only that he was intent for now on avoiding war.
''Saddam is his own worst enemy,'' an envoy said. ''He heads one of the least pleasant regimes in the world, he's offended every single Western sensibility, and he compounds it all by issuing statements that talk about Iraq being ready for war.''
But the diplomat added, ''Nonetheless, I've come around to thinking that the leadership here is fully conscious of what might take place if war were to occur, and what this would mean personally for Saddam.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Urges Nicaragua to Forgive Legal Claim

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 26

 BODY:
With hundreds of millions of dollars of American aid hanging in the balance, the Bush Administration has begun exerting sharp new pressure on President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro to abandon a judgment of as much as $17 billion that Nicaragua won against the United States at the International Court of Justice during the contra war.
Diplomats and Nicaraguan officials say the Administration has given high priority to resolving the court case, which was filed by the leftist Sandinista Government after C.I.A. operatives helped mine Nicaraguan harbors in early 1984. The United States has refused to recognize the court's jurisdiction in the matter, and said it would not pay or negotiate the award.
But the American pressure runs counter to a strong nationalist sentiment among Nicaraguans of all political backgrounds who believe the court decision was an important international victory. That feeling has been fueled by Sandinista leaders, who have portrayed the case as a crucial ''trial by fire'' of Mrs. Chamorro's ability to stand up to the United States. 
''It is a national interest that the United States pay for the damage it caused,'' declared Augusto Zamora Rodriguez, who argued Nicaragua's case as legal director of the Foreign Ministry under the Sandinista Government. ''To say that we must give up that right is to make apologies for violence and to applaud the intervention of the strong against the weak.''
 
Breach of International Law
The court case was first filed by the Sandinista Government in April 1984 after clear evidence emerged of American participation in the rebels' mining of the port of Corinto on Nicaragua's Pacific coast. On June 27, 1986, the court ruled that the United States had breached international law by supporting the contras, and ordered it to pay reparations. Although the amount was not specified, Nicaraguan legal experts say the total has reached as much as $17 billion with interest.
The Reagan Administration and, now, the Bush Administration, have ignored the court's ruling. But Bush Administration officials are said to be anxious to resolve the issue while its leverage over the economically strapped Chamorro Government is still at its height.
Diplomats and Nicaraguan officials here say that the Bush Administration has informed Mrs. Chamorro that future United States aid to Nicaragua will depend on her willingness to abandon the claim.
''The United States wants the matter dropped. That's it, no discussion,'' said one foreign diplomat in Managua.
That message was delivered most clearly earlier this month, when Mrs. Chamorro's chief of staff, Antonio Lacayo Oyanguren, visited the State Department for meetings in which the court case was at the top of his agenda.
Mr. Lacayo, who has resisted intense American pressure on issues such as Mrs. Chamorro's decision to permit Sandinista officers to retain key military posts, returned to Managua in a chastened mood.
''We are analyzing the suitability of establishing a commercial treaty between Nicaragua and the United States,'' Mr. Lacayo said at a news conference upon his return to Managua, ''and within that framework, people in the United States Administration and Congress will find the I.C.J. suit difficult to understand. ''We must decide,'' he added, ''whether we should insist on receiving an indemnity that the United States says it will never pay, or accept the friendship of a nation and people that want to look to the future.''
 
New Action Required
Mr. Lacayo reiterated the Government's position that all foreign policy decisions lie entirely within the authority of the executive branch. But in anticipation of such a move, the Sandinista Government rushed through a special law in its last days of office obliging all future governments to press forward with the claim.
That law could be invalidated through new action by the National Assembly, in which Mrs. Chamorro's coalition holds a majority of seats.

HEADLINE: WORLD SUMMIT FOR CHILDREN;
Bush Is in New York for the U.N. Conference and a Flurry of Gulf Diplomacy

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

 BODY:
Blending humanitarian concerns with military ones, President Bush arrived in New York yesterday to attend an international summit meeting on children and to engage in three days of aerobic diplomacy designed to send President Saddam Hussein of Iraq a signal that the world's patience is running out.
With a diplomatic schedule that rivals the breakneck pace of his golf game, Mr. Bush began a series of meetings with five heads of state at the Waldorf-Astoria only 25 minutes after touching down at the downtown Manhattan heliport at 3:20 P.M.
In sessions lasting from half an hour to 45 minutes, the President was scheduled to meet President Cesar Gaviria of Colombia, Prime Minister Selim al-Hoss of Lebanon, President Violeta Chamorro of Nicaragua, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan.
He had more than 15 other meetings set up this weekend around his attendance at the World Summit for Children at the United Nations today, and his delivery of two speeches on Monday to the United Nations General Assembly and the ministerial meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a 35-nation group that plans a summit meeting in Paris in November. 
 
'All the World Is United'
''The President's bilaterals with leaders are designed to express gratitude for the efforts of countries that have helped us with the Persian Gulf and to send a signal to Saddam Hussein that all the world is united and talking from the same script on the issue of Iraqi agression,'' a top White House official said.
Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, called the weekend ''a welcome opportunity to consult with his colleagues from around the world at really a sort of unprecedented, or at least a dramatic period in world affairs.''
At a White House briefing on Friday, Mr. Scowcroft implied that the ''systematic destruction'' of Kuwait under Iraqi occupation was bringing the United States and its allies closer to military action.
Mr. Scowcroft said ''there is no question that what is happening inside Kuwait affects the timetable'' for the decision to use military force.
He said Mr. Bush, hearing reports of babies being removed from incubators and critically ill patients from life-support systems, was considering returning to the United Nations to seek tougher sanctions, possibly including an explicit mention of military force, against President Hussein.
 
Leaders From 70 Countries
The Iraqi President was not among the kings, presidents and prime ministers from some 70 countries, from Albania to Zimbabwe, scheduled to attend the ceremonies at the United Nations this weekend. The children's event, described by the United Nations as the largest gathering of world leaders in history, is sponsored by the Unicef.
The only three leaders attending children's summit meeting from the Middle East are President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Ahmed al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who met with Mr. Bush at the White House on Friday, and the Lebanese Prime Minister.
At the children's summit meeting on Sunday, Mr. Bush is to endorse a United Nations plan of action that sets many goals for maternal and child health that the United States itself has had problems meeting. He is also to give a speech outlining what he feels are the positive steps the United States has taken in the education and medical care of children.
''There can be no task nobler than giving every child a better future,'' says the declaration that Mr. Bush and other leaders will sign. Administration officials have said the plan calls for reducing infant mortality and poverty among children while increasing access to family planning services and prenatal care for pregnant women.
 
Pledge of Universal Education
In another ambitious promise, the leaders also are to pledge to provide an education for at least 80 percent of all school-age children in the world by the year 2000.
In his address to the opening of the General Assembly on Monday, the first major meeting of the new post-cold-war era, Mr. Bush is expected to discuss the dramatic revival of the United Nations as a mechanism for world security. The President, who served as the chief American delegate to the United Nations for two years in the early 1970's, credits his time there with giving him an interest in foreign affairs and a taste for personal diplomacy.
In his speech to the delegates and heads of state and government, he is expected to discuss how the world has changed and suggest ways that the United Nations can live up the standards that it set for itself at its founding at the end of World War II.
When Mr. Bush addresses the ministerial meeting of the 35-nation security conference later that day, he is expected to suggest that the grouping serve as another vehicle for the economic and political change in Europe.
 
New European Security Sought
The conference is seeking wide-ranging agreement on the shape of the new security structure that Europe wants to establish this year to preserve peace and respect for human rights in the post-cold-war era.
There are also 23 nations in the security conference who are involved in the negotiations on a treaty reducing conventional forces in Europe. The United States and the Soviet Union hope that the treaty can be signed at the Paris summit meeting, but there are still serious problems in working out the treaty, and the Administration has warned that Mr. Bush would cancel his trip to the Paris meeting if the treaty is not ready.
The President is scheduled to meet with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, on Monday afternoon. He will urge Mr. Shevardnadze to redouble his efforts to make sure that the conventional forces treaty comes together, Administration officials said, and he will send his warm regards to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is struggling at home with an economic morass.
Mr. Bush is also scheduled to meet with the leaders of several Latin American countries that he is planning to visit this winter, including Presidents Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil, Luis Alberto Lacalle of Uruguay and Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina.
 
Thanks for Japan's Leader
Mr. Bush did not plan to attend a banquet last night for the children's summit meeting, and instead scheduled a meeting with Prime Minister Kaifu of Japan to thank him for Japan's financial assistance in the Persian Gulf effort.

HEADLINE: WORLD SUMMIT FOR CHILDREN: Reporter's Notebook;
A Protocol Nightmare: Silencing World Leaders

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 29

 BODY:
The biggest problem at the World Summit for Children, quite naturally, came from the adults. ''What do you do,'' an official asked, ''when you have 71 world leaders at the same conference and they all expect time to speak?''
The official, who had helped synchronize the speaking schedule for the summit meeting on Sunday, could not suppress a shudder. ''We lost months of sleep over it,''he said. 
There were many protocol nightmares in arranging the largest summit meeting in history. They ranged from motorcade gridlock, and the shape and size of the conference table (a huge squared-off horseshoe) to who would to sit next to Queen Noor of Jordan at dinner tonight. (None, it turned out, as the Queen was a surprise guest at the dinner for spouses at the World Trade Center.) But no dilemma proved as vexing as the silencing of presidents and kings.
''A head of state is saying to another head of state, in effect, 'Shut up.' '' Yves Fortier, the Canadian representative at the United Nations, was explaining the delicate situation that his Prime Minister, Brian Mulroney, a co-chairman of the summit, would face as he presided over the morning session. Mr. Mulroney would have to enforce time limits of five minutes, or in most cases four and three minutes.
The United Nations is a body where members are accustomed to limitless oratory. Fidel Castro alone, when there in 1960, spoke for several hours.
If Mulroney lost the nerve to interrupt, Mr. Fortier said he himself would not. ''I will personally steer The Prime Minister's arm on the gavel,'' the diplomat said, noting rather gleefully that stopwatches would monitor each speaker and a red light would flash at any errant grandstanders.
All world leaders are equal, but some are more equal than others. The pecking order, hashed out in months of discussions among the six host countries that initiated the summit, was ingenious, if ruthless. Some leaders, like Presidents Bush and Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia, were awarded five-minute introductions. Others, like Prime Minister Michel Rocard of France and President Dawda Kairaba Jawara of Gambia, were alloted four-minute ''commentaries.'' Most, including the leaders of Liechtenstein, Suriname and Papua New Guinea, had to content themselves with three-minute interjections during the discussion period.
''We had to discriminate,'' a conference official said helplessly. ''You have to give Bush five minutes, and then you look at other world regions, and figure out who you have to have.''
In Latin America, Brazil was the obvious choice (five minutes); in southern Africa it was Zimbabwe (four minutes.) There was no hesitation between El Salvador and Nicaragua: ''President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro,'' he said, ''is a woman.''
The official allowed that the decision process proved nasty, brutish and long. ''We were pestered to death,'' he said. ''Diplomats pleading, 'if my man doesn't speak, I'll lose my job.' ''
Constant schedule changes and infinite breaches of United Nations etiquette wrought by summit organizers proved too much for the highly dignified chief of protocol, Aly Teymour. ''The summit is a disaster,'' he said wearily 24 hours before the conference was to open. ''Too many admirals sink a ship.''
 
Bush's Empty Chair
 Summit organizers were thrown into a last-minute swivet when they realized that President Bush, whom they had expected at the first working session of the summit, planned to leave immediately after the opening ceremony in the General Assembly Hall and return to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for private meetings.
The organizers suddenly saw themselves with a gapingly empty seat at the conference table. They were not mollified by a suggestion that another Cabinet officer sit in for Mr. Bush.
''It is not courteous to make heads of state dialogue with cabinet officers,'' one Unicef official said tartly.
Prime Minister Mulroney of Canada, one of the co-chairmen of the summit meeting, met privately with Mr. Bush at the Waldorf late yesterday afernoon to try to persuade him to change his plans.
 
Eager Young Reporters
 There are 3,000 journalists accredited to cover a summit meeting so unprecedented that it will be listed in next year's Guinness Book of Records. There are also more than 60 ''youth journalists,'' many of whom swarmed across the United Nations basement this afternoon, doing television stand-ups with officials wreathed in unctuous smiles.
The four scoop-hungry young reporters from the English weekly children's newspaper Early Times lived up to the reputation of British journalists around the world. ''We went to the riot, it was really good,'' Stan Bright, 13 years old, of Devon, said. The four children spotted a scuffle between anti-Communist Albanian protesters and Albanian Government supporters on Friday and made a beeline for the action.
Dominic Fox, 15, of Kent, red-haired, freckled, and with the angelic look of an English school boy just back from Narnia, climbed onto a railing to take pictures before being pulled off by policemen.
''There were men trying to throw police barricades at each other,'' He said happily, ''I got a really good shot.''
They spent this morning preparing to interview - ''grill'' is what they called it - President Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil.
''I'm going to ask him about the street children who are being killed by police task forces in Brazil,'' Mr. Fox announced.
''I'm going to ask him about what happened to Chico Mendes, and the Government cover-up,'' said Mr. Bright, referring to an environmental activist in the Amazon who was assassinated. ''He'll probably have a heart attack,'' he predicted proudly.
Mr. Fox smiled sweetly. ''That's an even better story.''
 
No Word From Hussein
 Saddam Hussein of Iraq never sent an R.S.V.P. to the summit meeting's sponsors, perhaps because he knew already that he would be busy elsewhere in the Gulf. After the invasion of Kuwait, King Fahd of Saudi Arabia canceled. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan and sent their wives instead. (In official summit parlance, they are known as First Spouses).
Iraq, however, seemed to want a voice at the summit. ''Iraq will be taking part in the World Summit for Children even though they would not let our Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, to come in his plane,'' said Ahmad Sais, a member of the Iraqi mission. The boycott prohibits landing rights for Iraqi aircraft in the United States.
Iraq's delegate to the United Nations said he would attend the summit, but organizers were quick to point out that his was ''the lowliest level of representation.'' Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari has observer status, which means, according to one official, ''He can't even get into the conference room.''

HEADLINE: CONGRESS MAY CUT AFGHAN REBEL AID

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
Congress is moving to cut and place conditions on Bush Administration requests for continued covert military aid to the Afghan rebels.
Reversing a decade of loyal support, the House and Senate Intelligence committees have voted in recent weeks to cut spending for the rebels next year by at least a third. The committees authorize the programs of intelligence agencies.
The Bush Administration has proposed giving the rebels about $300 million in covert aid for 1991, about what it requested and received this year, and opposes any Congressional restrictions or conditions on it. 
A growing weariness with the war is setting in now that Soviet troops are no longer involved, with a new bipartisan coalition forming to change course. The movement away from the Afghan rebels is in part a response to persistent reports of their involvement in heroin trafficking and arms dealing to rebels in Jammu and Kashmir state in India. It is also a result of the guerrillas' seeming unwillingness to support efforts to negotiate a settlement.
 
Aid to Others Questioned
But the shift is also part of broader Congressional skepticism over covert aid to guerrilla movements around the world, including those in Angola and Cambodia.
''There are increasing doubts about United States policy that is made and executed entirely in secret,'' said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, a leading member of the House Foreign Affairs committee.
Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of New York, who was a supporter of the rebels before the Soviets withdrew their military forces early last year, said: ''There's a growing uneasiness about the policy, There's a feeling on the part of many members that we already achieved the bulk of our objectives in Afghanistan.''
Although the Soviet Union has withdrawn its 115,000 troops, fighting between the Government of President Najibullah and the various guerrilla factions, some of whom are Islamic fundamentalist, has continued sporadically. While the Soviet Union and the United States have discussed possible political solutions to the conflict, there is little evidence that the factions are any closer to an agreement.
 
A Change in Attitude
Over the last decade, liberals and conservatives joined to grant tens of millions of dollars more than the estimated $3 billion requested by the Reagan and Bush Administrations for military aid to the rebels.
But in a vote this month, Mr. Solarz helped lead the battle in the House Intelligence Committee to withhold half of the proposed covert aid for a second consideration early next year. In July, the Senate Intelligence Committee cut about a third of the $300 million program, the largest current American covert military program.
A Republican member of the House Intelligence Committee who continues to support the guerrillas said he thought it inevitable that Congress would link aid this year with a rebel agreement to take part in democratic elections and unify their leadership.
The covert program is in further trouble in the House Appropriations defense subcommittee, which is charged with appropriating aid to the Afghan rebels. Subcommittee supporters and opponents appear to be deadlocked, with the chairman, Representative John P. Murtha of Pennsylvania, pushing strongly for a serious cut.
 
'We're Very Unhappy'
''We're just not happy with the mujahedeen,'' Mr. Murtha said. ''We're very unhappy with what we hear about drugs coming back and forth. And they don't seem to have a coordinated effort to win the war, from the intelligence I read.''
The Bush Administration has yet to lobby hard to sustain current aid levels, leading many in Congress to wonder how much the White House remains committed to the program. The conservative wing of the Republican Party, as well as top officials in the National Security Council and Defense Department, have registered their continuing support for the rebels. But there is evidence that the State Department is far less enthusiastic.
''As Islamic fundamentalists, the mujahedeen don't always share our values,'' said a senior State Department official, who spoke on condition he remain anonymous.
The Administration has concentrated on negotiating an arrangement with the Soviet Union under which an interim government would supervise elections. The future role of the Afghan President, Najibullah, in the transitional government is the stumbling block in the discussions.
 
Installed by Moscow
The United States has said that Mr. Najibullah may run as a presidential candidate in future elections, but his grip over the army, security forces and intelligence apparatus must be severed during the campaign. Moscow has officially supported Mr. Najibullah's position that he share power with leaders of various factions during the interim period leading to elections.
The Soviet Union has withdrawn 115,000 troops from Afghanistan, but continues to prop up the Kabul regime with 500 advisers and $5 billion in annual economic and military aid.
Such large levels of Soviet support have stiffened the resolve of those in Congress who want to continue the covert program. ''It is vital for the United States not to pull the rug out from under people who have conducted a valiant defense of their sovereignty,'' said Representative Charles Wilson, Democrat of Texas.

HEADLINE: Pastimes;
Coins

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:
The lowly cent has taken quite a beating in the past few years. Some merchants and others are calling for the end of the least valuable coin. Even Congress has been asked to look into the possibility of minting a new dollar coin and to stop minting the cent. 
Even though a Government Accounting Office report has backed the need for a dollar coin and supported continuation of minting cents, the fray goes on.
One organization, Americans for Common Cents, has commissioned an economic study that points out a few problems that may arise if the cent is eliminated. The most pressing is rounding.
With the nickle being the lowest denomination coin, prices will be rounded to the nearest 5-cent increment. If prices were randomly assigned, then the rounding would sometimes be to the higher figure and sometimes to the lower.
Some suggest that pricing will generally benefit the seller. If that turns out to be the case then a possible 5-cent penalty per transaction becomes a regressive tax. Such penalties fall more heavily on the poorest customers who must bear a fixed cost per transaction.
For example, an item that might normally be priced at $1.07 would be rounded to the lower increment, $1.05. If the seller leaves the price at $1.07, he incurs a two-cent penalty every time he sells the item.
By raising the price to $1.08, the seller is gaining a 2-cent windfall when the rounding takes the price to $1.10. The seller has the choice of losing two cents or gaining three on a one-cent change in price.
Buying two or more of the same article changes things, but the seller may have already raised his price by one cent and that profit will offset any rounding down.
If the amounts involved - a cent here and there - seem small, remember that many volume businesses operate with profits of only three percent per item. If the cent is abolished, we'll have to begin saying, ''A nickle for your thoughts.'' And that's clearly inflationary. Silver Facts The silver of Central and South America facilitated world trade to the point where a global economy became possible. Spanish milled dollars became the currency of choice throughout the Americas and in Europe and Asia.
Our own dollar was based originally on the Mexican dollar and its eight divisions, reales.
Early Americans carved the Mexican dollar into pieces, or bits, for small change. Those eight divisions became the ''two bits, four bits, six bits, a dollar'' of ditty. Chinese merchants preferred the Mexican dollars above all other coins until the mid-19th century.
The Spanish Institute is presenting an exhibition of Mexican numismatics from the collections of the Banco de Mexico and the Mexican Mint. The collection of silver and gold pieces will illustrate the history of those first coins to come out of the New World. It is open through Nov. 8 Monday through Saturday from 11 A.M. until 6 P.M. The institute is at 684 Park Avenue at 68th Street. There is no admission charge.

HEADLINE: MUSIC VIEW;
Operatic Winds Blowing Every Which Way

BYLINE: By Donal Henahan

 BODY:
Never, in the history of any art form, does all creative activity appear to be heading in the same direction at once. That easy truism is vividly illustrated by the confused state of operatic staging and design today. It is as if two warriors were mounted on the same horse facing in opposite directions, both waving swords and crying ''Charge!'' The horse goes its own way, following some mysterious urge known only to its genes. Opera survives, somehow.
It did seem, to cease beating a dead metaphor, that a remarkable and possibly unbridgeable difference existed in approach and intent between two noteworthy opera productions that have already surfaced in this young season: Robert Wilson's modishly eccentric staging of Gluck's ''Alceste'' by Chicago's Lyric Opera and the no less unconventional but more stimulating production of Schoenberg's ''Moses und Aron'' by the New York City Opera. 
The fundamental artistic difference between the two staging concepts might not be immediately apparent. Both productions, after all, originated in the anything-goes atmosphere of contemporary Germany (''Alceste'' in Stuttgart, ''Moses'' in Cologne). Both are pictorially imaginative, fiercely untraditional and, if the term still means anything, ''advanced.'' It was, however, Schoenberg's famously intractable 12-tone work, which is less an opera than a philosophical and theological exploration in the form of an oratorio, that more truly justified importation. It emerged as not only the more serious work - no surprise - but against all expectations as the more theatrically arresting and dramatically absorbing one.
In his design and direction of ''Alceste,'' Mr. Wilson seemed determined not to allude in any recognizable way to the clear intentions of this 18th-century work. His geometrically obsessed stage pictures and perversely comical choreography of hand gestures and body postures seldom related to Gluck's musical drama and never to the philosophy behind it. ''Alceste'' is not the most easily digestible score, in spite of its many happy moments, so perhaps one should have been grateful that Mr. Wilson made the time pass so painlessly. But is visual diversion, which Mr. Wilson surely does provide, why we persist in going to the opera?
''Alceste'' is not just any opera, after all, but the one whose influence on Wagner, in theory if not always in practice, was great. It is the work for which Gluck wrote his famous preface calling for a return to ''simplicity, truth and naturalness'' as an antidote to what he felt were the abuses visited on opera by the distractingly florid vocalism of the Italians. He wanted to restrict music to ''its true office of serving poetry by means of expression and by following the situations of the story, without interrupting the action or stifling it with superfluous ornaments.''
Now, truth in art is not a subject wise people blithely address, but simplicity and naturalness are more easily recognized. Mr. Wilson's ''Alceste'' certainly did not concern itself with either. Opacity and cleverness, rather, seemed the esthetic aims - hardly what Gluck of all people could have had in mind. One of Mr. Wilson's central staging devices summed up his tendency to obscure: throughout the performance boxes and rectangles of various sizes and colors dangled over the singers or rotated slowly across the stage, their Orphic meaning, if any, the director's secret. Perhaps the point was merely ironic: to poke fun of old Gluck's pretensions to simplicity and naturalness of expression and plot. Opera directors don't like to tell stories anymore.
In any event, the effect was no doubt what Mr. Wilson hoped for: opera and staging moving along in parallel, if not divergent, paths. That concept is, if you like, legitimate in its place, though hardly new or shocking. Followers of modern dance will recognize it as the method employed a generation ago by John Cage and Merce Cunningham in many celebrated joint creations. Choreographer and composer made no attempt to coordinate movements and chance-generated sounds: the two activities went on - were meant to go on - in separate compartments. This, however, was at least potentially a liberating concept agreed upon by two contemporary artists, not as in ''Alceste'' the ruthless imposition of a 20th-century concept on a fragile 223-year-old work.
For a better example of what today's directors and designers ought to be up to, turn to ''Moses und Aron,'' a forbidding, unfinished work that never was produced in the composer's lifetime and has achieved the status of legend in 20th-century music. Hans Neugebauer's starkly simple and economical staging is unmistakably of this century but never gives the impression of existing for itself alone. Instead, with the invaluable help of Cori Ellison's English supertitles (the singing is in German), every theatrical device advances and elucidates the intricate philosophical debate between the title characters, and by extension Schoenberg's moral struggle with himself. The development of the opera's argument appears to be the main point, not anyone's career track. (If that is an illusion, it is a welcome one in opera production.) The predominantly beige sets and costumes, designed by Achim Freyer and lighted by Hans Toelstede, though pure 20th century in look and technology, brilliantly evoke the baking sun and sands of biblical Egypt. The use of sodium steam lamps and scrims creates a marvelously hazy atmosphere that intensifies the feeling of historical distance. A black scrim over most of the orchestra pit further enhances the hypnotic power. The two opposing characters, the prophet and the politician, are real but aptly impersonal, too. To depict them more distinctly might clarify their personalities but risk losing sight of the fact that they are two sides of one coin.
More than visually arresting stage pictures are achieved, however: the effect is to allow Schoenberg's dialectical drama to hold the attention on equal terms, if not better, with the operatic action - which includes a highly stylized orgy and a sacrificial ceremony in which four naked maidens have their throats cut by four males. Not the least of the production's wonders is that during these appeals to the senses, the conscientious operagoer may find it possible to keep in mind the spiritual import of it all. ''Moses und Aron,'' 12-tone rows and all, lives and breathes in this production.

HEADLINE: Beneath Faded Glamour, a Real Maestro

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
The public image and historical memory of the conductor Leopold Stokowski are bound up inexorably with the Walt Disney film ''Fantasia.'' He and the music he conducts are impressed all over that 1941 classic, even though Disney's heirs misguidedly re-recorded the soundtrack digitally a few years ago.
The image Stokowski projected, on screen and in life, was a complex one; historians of American music are still sorting it out. Was he a mere sonic sensualist, bereft of the intellectual gravity we expect from great musicians? Was he, even, something of a charlatan, if not in his music then in his partly self-invented persona? (He was always vague, at best, about his ancestry and his age.) Or was he a noble champion of the new, both musical and technological? The answer would seem to be, all of the above. 
During his lifetime (he died in 1977 at the age of 95), it was easy for critics to complain, and complain they did, often vociferously.In ''Fantasia,'' intended to make the classics comprehensible to John Q. Public, Stokowski appears as the great popularizer, grand and refined yet willing to reach out to the little man (or little mouse, in the case of Mickey). He out-Lennied Leonard Bernstein two decades before Mr. Bernstein imprinted himself on the American consciousness through television. Those who disliked the notion of pirouetting hippopotamuses and cutesy fawns cluttering up the landscape of classical music already had cause for complaint.
Stokowski's image was all his own, and sometimes it seemed to swallow up the music he performed. Even in an age when reorchestrations and instrumental touch-ups were more common than they are in our purist time, he offended scholars with his excesses, especially in his grandiose orchestral inflations of Bach's organ music. In his pursuit of sonic sumptuousness, Stokowski perfected what has since been called ''the Philadelphia sound'' during his more than 25 years as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra.
Personally, Stokowski projected an aura of silky sensuality, playing up a spurious exotic ancestry. (He was in fact English, of Polish and Russian descent, and immigrated to the United States in his early 20's.) In 1929, he abandoned the use of a baton, his elegant fingers tracing sonic curves in the air, his hands and face and wavy white-silver hair highlighted by special lighting designed to glamorize him and, it sometimes seemed, him alone.
None of which was lost on the burgeoning American record business and the drumbeaters of Broadway and Hollywood. Stokowski began recording with his Philadelphians as early as 1917, and from the first he was marketed as much as or more than the music he was ostensibly serving. Joseph Horowitz, in his book ''Understanding Toscanini,'' chose that maestro as a symbol for the penchant of American capitalism to turn great music into hucksterism, to exploit and distort the classics for a buck. Stokowski, with his snake-oil charms and unashamed self-promotion, might have been a better example, except that his self-advancement was so naked that attacks against it lost all critical point.
The trouble with these complaints against Stokowski's role in American musical life is not that they are false but that they are incomplete. The problem, in coming to a fair assessment of the Stokowski legacy, is how to reconcile forward-looking aspects of his musical personality that seem so at odds with his undeniable egomania and love of sensual surface. And one must try to understand the context in which his excesses can be better understood.
He was a remarkable champion of contemporary music, for instance. True, he lived in a time when new classical music could still be perceived as romantic or exciting or fashionable. Nonetheless, few conductors of his day managed to match his record of advancing the careers of composers both famous and obscure and of leading the world or American premieres of so many scores that have since entered the repertory or the history books.
In 1971, six years before his death, someone determined that Stokowski had conducted over 2,000 first performances in the course of 7,000 concerts. He led a number of Rachmaninoff world premieres, including the Third Symphony, the Fourth Piano Concerto and the Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini. Music by Varese, Cowell, Griffes and Antheil was high on his list. His American premieres involved even more prestigious music: Stravinksy's ''Sacre du Printemps,'' Mahler's Eighth Symphony, Berg's ''Wozzeck'' and many Schoenberg scores, including ''Gurrelieder.''
The other major impact of Stokowski on classical music was an offshoot of his quest for sonic richness. He was a pioneer in exploiting the latest recording technology and acoustical research, including the use of stereo sound for ''Fantasia'' - a full 15 years before that technique was universally adopted in commercial recording. Compared, say, to the poor sound RCA inflicted on the technologically indifferent Toscanini, the sound of Stokowski's recordings was always state-of-the-art. From the electrical recording system in the mid-1920's to the long-playing disk in the late 40's to quadraphonic sound in the early 70's to the dawn of digital, Stokowski eagerly explored the latest wrinkles in a rapidly evolving technology.
Coupled with that was his involvement with orchestral deployment (endless experiments with seating plans) and playing techniques (letting violinists bow individually to minimize the sonic seams caused when all of them followed the concertmaster's lead, shifting from up-bow to down-bow en masse). He was an inveterate orchestra-founder, from the All-American Youth Orchestra (young people's ensembles were a special concern) to the American Symphony, which lasts to this day. And this doesn't count his extramusical enthusiasms - the signs of a true polymath - for Asian art, medical advances, farming and more.
All well and good, but what kind of musician was he? The answer is, a romantically willful one, on the order of Willem Mengelberg. In a modernist century that has prized brisk, ''objective'' rigidity, Stokowski's interpretive license has slipped from fashion.
The principal intellectually respectable alternative to modernism was Germanic mysticism in the manner of Wilhelm Furtwangler. Stokowski, in his Anglo-Russo/all-American way, anticipated the non-Germans who proliferated on the world's podiums after 1945. He lacked, in image and actuality, the gravity and authority of the central European tradition to buttress his eccentricities. And since his recordings epitomized the latest technology, and recording technology tends to date, his disks haven't held up as sonic spectaculars.
But the man remained a historically crucial, and in the end musically admirable, exemplar of a style of performer-creativity that our modern musical world could well use more of. Whatever else it represented, Stokowski's music-making breathed vitality and personal conviction. The re-release of ''Fantasia,'' a now sonically vivid reminder of his considerable conductorial gifts, will only affirm that memory.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leopold Stokowski-romantically willful and, in the end, admirable (Sonnee Gottlieb/International News Photos) (pg. 20)

HEADLINE: Why the Cutting Edge Has Lost Its Bite

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
Imagine Edouard Manet, that founding figure of modernism, accompanied perhaps by Antonin Artaud, the creator of the post-Surrealist Theater of Cruelty, magically together in the United States and wandering through what is sometimes called the cultural ''cutting edge,'' the present-day avant-garde. What would they find?
If they went to the East Village in Manhattan, they would see artists living economically precarious bohemian lives so as to be able to paint. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the eighth annual Next Wave Festival will open on Tuesday, they would see that ''cutting edge'' theater, still affected by Artaud's experiments in primitiveness and non-narrative, was alive and well. At the Franklin Furnace in lower Manhattan they might have caught ''We Always Keep Our Victims Ready,'' the militantly feminist performance art piece by Karen Finley that has drawn the wrath of conservative and religious groups, just as - improbable as the comparison may seem - Manet's ''Olympia'' outraged the conventionalists of his era.
What the French tourists might first believe, in short, is that the avant-garde still exists, that there is an art that is self-consciously outside the traditional, rebelling against received ideas, roiling the social calm. Artaud once wrote that the theater should turn actors and spectators alike into ''victims burnt at the stake signaling through the flames.'' He might believe that the tradition of an anarchic, defiant art continues. 
But the Monsieurs Manet and Artaud would see, with some puzzlement, that cultural rebels, even bohemians living in walk-ups on Avenue B, receive money from sources ranging from the Ford Foundation to the National Endowment for the Arts. This might astound the visiting avant-garde progenitors, who never expected the establishment they defied and mocked to foot the bill or to give its approval at mainstream sites, such as Lincoln Center (where Ms. Finley recently performed in the Serious Fun Festival). That fact alone might make them ask: Is there an avant-garde at all these days?
The answer is probably yes. But it is very different from the one that formed in the mid-19th century and endured until about the mid-20th century. It is an avant-garde that no longer repudiates the idea of official support or approval but instead demands it in the form of government grants - with all the moral questions that posture raises. It is an avant-garde existing in a far more open environment, in which art's very ability to shock has been swamped by a great sea of tepid tolerance. Finally, it is an avant-garde that is absorbed into the mainstream almost as soon as it appears. It is so susceptible to commercial exploitation that the most daring ideas of one day are on the department store shelves the next. The United States, after all, is a country where Chairman Mao was turned into a fashion statement, where Andrew Dice Clay was an X-rated nightclub comedian one minute and a host on ''Saturday Night Live'' the next.
''There is always something that functions as the leading edge,'' says Christopher Hunt, the director of the Summerfare Festival in Purchase, N.Y., where vanguard productions were staged for a decade ending last year. He likens members of the avant-garde to ''invisible scouts in enemy territory,'' and adds, ''The important work is done by the scouts out ahead, but we don't even know who they are and certainly can't identify them until much later.'' The one thing, he says, ''that the avant-garde suffers from is light. The moment there is too much of it, the avant-garde no longer exists.''
Mr. Hunt cites the operas of Peter Sellars, the plays of Peter Brook, the music of Pierre Boulez and John Cage as examples of a recent avant-garde that, in time-honored fashion, has been embraced by a large, establishment audience. Among the avant-gardists whose work has emerged from the realm of experiment and become well known are the choreographer Pina Bausch, the theater director Robert Wilson, the composer Arvo Part.
And yet, the avant-garde has in at least one important respect been turned on its head. It originated, with the Impressionists in France and the Secessionists in Austria, as a movement in utter opposition to any official governance of the arts, to any political approval. It is now, by contrast, not a movement but a tendency toward experimentation that frequently depends for its survival on support from the public that, in its art, it vilifies. The controversy surrounding the National Endowment, still unresolved, thus reflects how much the self-conception of the members of the avant-garde has altered. And it raises a dilemma.
Is it intellectually consistent for creative artists to take the money of the establishment - indeed to complain of ''censorship'' if Government grants are withheld - and still maintain their identity as rebels, anarchists, enemies of convention? Does government money alter an artist's moral status?
One view is that, after all, artists need to live. Manet and Artaud may not have benefited from a National Endowment for the Arts, but they received money, at least indirectly, from what Mr. Hunt likes to call ''the filthy profits of capitalism.'' The important consideration here is the value of the work, not the source of the artist's livelihood.
Philippe Arnoult, the artistic director of the Baltimore Theater Project, likens government subsidies to the arts to support for the ''research and development arm'' of the culture. It is help that is necessary, he says, particularly in these days when a bohemian life style in the East Village has become far more expensive, relatively speaking, than bohemianism was in Paris in the 1920's. Some argue for a loyal-opposition status for the avant-garde creator.
''The artists today are saying, 'I'm proud of being an American; I pay my taxes; I'm a loyal citizen, and I have a right to be supported as a member of my culture,' '' said Martha Wilson, the director of Franklin Furnace, the avant-garde performance space that until recently received National Endowment grants for every one of its 15 years of existence.
Asked to describe the essential characteristics of the more controversial Franklin Furnace performers, Ms. Wilson said, ''They use nudity, religious imagery, bodily fluids, and references to sex and violence - all the stuff that's supposed to be wrong'' and that flouts what Ms. Wilson called the community standards established by ''guys in three-piece suits.'' If the community that has the standards supports the artists who flout those standards, doesn't that mean that the artists' vision of the community as repressive and intolerant is wrong?
Paradoxically, those who think that there should be an avant-garde may owe a debt of gratitude to the likes of Senator Jesse Helms and Donald E. Wildmon of the American Family Association, who have led the assault on the National Endowment for, in their view, subsidizing pornography and blasphemy. The idea that some art could send people into paroxysms of repressive rage has a strangely atavistic ring, coming after a long period when there seemed to be no outrage expressed at all. The Endowment's detractors have helped restore to artists their role as provocateurs.
Despite this, there are critics who refuse to take a bit of controversy as a general resuscitation of the avant-garde. Some critics maintain, particularly about the artists and performers whose names became familiar in the National Endowment debate, that political radicalism and an exaggerated premium on novelty have replaced artistic brilliance as the criteria by which the avant-garde defines itself.
The Impressionists and Surrealists, for example, began with an esthetic and a political vision that they wanted to develop in their art. The Surrealists introduced into a school of painting the idea of the Freudian unconscious, the interpretation of dreams, a new version of reality. The now-famous photograph by Andres Serrano of a crucifix immersed in urine is an act of taboo-breaking defiance, but perhaps not much of an artistic development. In short, the fact that Mr. Helms and others have unintentionally restored to art its capacity to shock does not mean that the avant-garde has come back from the dead.
''The N.E.A. debate,'' said the cultural historian Roger Shattuck, ''has restored the scandal without restoring the avant-garde.''
Mr. Shattuck, a Boston University professor who has written several books on avant-garde figures of the past, argues that the avant-garde of yesterday produced enduring work because it found a balance between a mastery of the traditional forms and techniques and the capacity to innovate.
Now, he believes, those considered to be avant-garde only innovate for innovation's sake, or shock for the sake of shocking, and are not good enough to endure. Robert Mapplethorpe, for example, whose homoerotic photographs have been at the center of the National Endowment controversy from the beginning, is a rather conventional photographer, in Mr. Shattuck's view, one whose work would not represent an artistic breakthrough were it not for its sometimes shocking subject matter.
''Every institution is calling for something original today,'' Mr. Shattuck said. ''And when originality is the only quality being looked for, there's a great temptation to go out and do something that's political or obscene, and that substitutes for originality in some way. But there's only so much originality lying around.'' There is, of course, still the noncontroversial cutting edge, or at least, the place where, as Mr. Hunt put it, the avant-garde gets absorbed into the establishment, often leaving some of its more experimental, anarchic features behind.
Next week, and for the four weeks after that, the new and the innovative will be on display at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival. Audiences will find lots of bright innovation. They will also find confirmation that a kind of experimental, daring, generally anti-establishment art coexists comfortably with the kind of sponsorship that has changed the identity of the avant-garde.
The opening event, for example, Martha Clarke's ''Endangered Species,'' is a work that, in the words of the program notes, ''explores the bond between man, animals and nature, employing a cast that includes actors, dancers and animals.''
Through such earlier works as ''Vienna: Lusthaus'' and ''Miracolo d'Amore,'' Ms. Clarke has become well-established as one of the leading experimentalists in American theater, and ''Endangered Species'' seems consistent with her reputation. The performance, again in the words of the program notes, does away with ''traditional linear text.'' Instead, Ms. Clarke ''constructs dreamy tableaux, juxtaposing excerpts from Walt Whitman's 'Leaves of Grass' with scenes of dominance and oppression, sex and death, loss and regret.''
Is it avant-garde? Ms. Clarke, discussing the subject the other day, makes no such claim. For one thing, she said, she does not see herself as part of a movement.
''I just go from project to project, looking for new ways to challenge myself and to understand myself,'' she said. She acknowledged that she has never been able to raise money from the usual commercial producers. Her support comes from from foundations and the National Endowment. Philip Morris, the tobacco company, is the major financial benefactor of the entire Next Wave Festival, the same Philip Morris that supports the senatorial candidacy of Jesse Helms.
Harvey Lichtenstein, the director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the guiding spirit behind the Next Wave Festival, points out that state support of non-avant-garde art, long the custom in Europe, is a recent development in this country. The National Endowment itself is only about a quarter of a century old.
''A lot of the art that resulted from government subsidies is pretty establishment,'' Mr. Lichtenstein said, referring to the many grants that go to the major institutions. ''But a lot of it throws mud in the face of the establishment. It deals with the issues of the day, such as gay rights and women's rights.''
Indeed, contemporary issues are certainly the stuff of avant-garde treatment, and, not surprisingly, there seems little question these days that the most avant of the avant-garde is the art centering around homosexual, feminist, sexual or anti-religious themes. In a society that has steadily broken most of its once unbreakable taboos, the few remaining are powerful. That may be one reason why today's version of the avant-garde seems more devoted than the avant-garde of the past to an angry defiance, a breaking of taboos simply because they are there.
Mapplethorpe's controversial photographs, such as the one that shows a man urinating in the mouth of another, are explicitly homoerotic. The performance artist Annie Sprinkle would arouse no storms of protest if she simply talked, as she sometimes does, about her sexuality. It is inviting the audience to examine her vagina through a gynecological instrument - a gesture that has been explained as an attempt to demystify female sexuality - that helped put her on the Endowment hit list.
And yet the few artists who have become well known as a result of the National Endowment disputes do not really signify a flourishing of an avant-garde that Manet might recognize. A photograph of a man urinating in the mouth of another may be a political or a moral statement, but it is hard to conceive of it primarily as an artistic one. And in the America of the late 20th century, it is not even so daring. It appealed to an already existing constituency. Mapplethorpe, who died last year, may have risked his National Endowment grant, but he did not risk his career as a photographer. His photographs are selling briskly at the elite auction houses.
Mr. Shattuck, in a passage in his book ''The Banquet Years,'' an account of the careers of four avant-garde figures in France a century ago, suggests why in the United States the avant-garde is almost a contradiction in terms.
The avant-garde, he writes, could flourish in France because of the conservatism of French society, its susceptibility to outrage. The United States, by contrast, has almost always been so relatively open, so commercially adaptable, that the most shocking product of yesterday will end up for sale tomorrow. The market for the new smothers the shock quality of the avant-garde, virtually precluding the possibility that a genuine avant-garde can exist.
In the past, the avant-garde struggled to nurture the new in the face of a conservatism deeply skeptical about anything daringly different or unconventional. But now, although many Americans hold deeply conservative values, there is also an insatiable thirst for the new. The unconventional is highly prized. Yesterday's taboo-breaking creation is today's fad, written up in People magazine and Vanity Fair, invited onto ''Saturday Night Live,'' optioned by Hollywood.
''The appetite for the new is rabid in this country, and it takes a kind of discipline from the artist not to sell out to that, because it's very seductive,'' Ms. Clarke said. ''Everything is seized and kind of siliconed immediately.''
''We live with a kind of duplicity today because everything is so open,'' she said. ''We don't have to fight the kind of fight of the pioneers, like Isadora Duncan when she came back from Russia. Because everything goes, there are no walls to push over anymore.''

HEADLINE: Climate Change and Coal

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Astonishingly, the recent story on improved prospects for the coal industry (''Will Coal, the Plentiful Old Standby, Pick Up Speed?'' Aug. 26) fails to mention global climate change, arguably the single most important roadblock in coal's future.
Many scientists now believe that changes in the Earth's atmosphere caused by increased emissions of heat-trapping ''greenhouse gases'' from human activities will alter the climate over the next century, with potentially serious environmental and economic consequences. The most important greenhouse gas is carbon dioxide emitted from the burning of fossil fuels, particularly coal, which contains more carbon than either oil or natural gas.
Utilities in the United States already depend on coal for more than half of all the electric power they produce. Thanks to that dependence, the United States leads the world in emissions of carbon dioxide, and the utility sector leads the United States economy, producing nearly 1.9 billion tons yearly, which is more than seven tons for every American.
We have failed to take action to protect our energy security by finding alternatives to oil over the past decade. As a result, we find ourselves today contemplating war over oil in the Middle East.
If we ignore global climate change and increase our dependence on coal as an energy source, we may soon arrive at a similar policy dead end, in which we are forced to undergo severe economic disruption in order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
 
THOMAS O. GRAY
Washington, Aug. 2

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Don't Knock the Soviet Manager

BYLINE: By ELISE WALTON; Elise Walton is director of the Delta Consulting Group in New York.

 BODY:
Until recently, Americans have had little chance to watch Soviet managers at work in their own environment while interacting with colleagues. I was afforded this opportunity during a joint research project under the direction of Prof. Paul Lawrence of the Harvard Business School and Igor Faminsky of the Soviet Institute for External Economic Affairs. Four of us - two Americans and two Russians - spent four months visiting manufacturing plants in the United States and the Soviet Union. We interviewed people on production floors and in senior management positions. We attended plant management meetings and planning sessions. From all of this emerged an image quite different from the prevailing stereotype.
The Soviet manager in action demonstrates plenty of the nerve and verve that we expect of American line managers. The Sovietmanagers make split-second decisions in production crises, deal decisively with difficult people issues and energize their work force through commitment and vision. In almost every case they exhibited great pride in their ability to make things happen in the face of daunting, if not overwhelming, odds. 
Alexander Sergeovich Gorian, plant manager of a large engine manufacturing plant in Moscow, is a good example. Arriving at the plant about 7:15 A.M., he checks the night shift's production and then tours the plant for an hour. Although some 2,000 people work for him, he knows many by name. As he moves through the shop he answers questions, jokes, and alerts the managers and workers to upcoming issues. At 9 o'clock, all shop managers and staff heads attend Mr. Gorian's staff meeting.
Mr. Gorian opens the meeting with a review of yesterday's production and with each manager's reports. The head of personnel discusses which workers will be leaving to help the agricultural collectives with the upcoming harvest. The Communist Party representative discusses which section has performed best in the ''socialist competition.'' Far from apathetic and passive, Mr. Gorian's style is direct, confrontational and humorous - a blend of charisma and autocracy. He demands accountability. Why have the shop foremen allowed their areas to become so messy? He chides one shop head for his treatment of a worker. Soviet managers must post open office hours, and workers can complain to them during these mandatory hours. The various exchanges are vigorous and candid.
In this plant, as in organizations everywhere, shop managers are quick to blame upstream suppliers for problems and failures. Mr. Gorian says, ''It's not important whose fault it is. What is important is that there is a manager and he is here to solve the problem. A way out must be found, not just who is right and who is wrong. It is for managers to solve their specific problem and not to hide behind some general problem that they can do nothing about.''
Mr. Gorian's day will end about 8 P.M. If there is a company event - if the soccer team has a game, for example - he attends, but returns to the plant before going home for the night. For his efforts, he recieves a salary of 350 rubles a month, plus a year-end bonus of as much as 20 percent of his salary based on the productivity of the factory. A typical assembly worker makes about 210 rubles a month.
There are a lot of similarities between Soviet and American plant managers. In both countries managers complain that the annual plan figures, ''rolling down from the top,'' are changed too frequently during the year. They admit to taking action before receiving the formally required approvals, because the bureaucracy is too slow to handle some crises. They also admit to passing misleading financial information up the hierarchy. A manager restricted by executive fiat from increasing the size of his plant, but having valuable machine tools to house, soon has a new warehouse which has not been revealed to headquarters. Human nature prevails across borders.
The American practice is to hand out reams of printed information in which many of the meaningful numbers had been omitted so they won't end up in the hands of the competition. In the Soviet Union, in part because paper shortages are not unheard of, but also because copy machines must be supervised by a state employee who tracks who copied what, we relied more on the spoken word. With persistence, we found the Soviets open and helpful. Although we got less paper than an American company would provide, we often received more information.
The good news is that there are plenty of bright, energetic line managers in the Soviet Union - managers who expect to be held accountable, who provide innovative solutions to problems and who will apparently thrive in a market economy.
However, they may not have the best connections. American companies preparing to do business in the Soviet Union will have to learn to distinguish the politically well-connected bureaucrat from the less political, highly motivated, results-oriented manager. These line managers have been burdened by state administrative orders across a spectrum of activities. Once they are freed from centralized decision making and political interference, they have the potential to perform well and make a difference.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Stubbing a Toe on Primerica

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
The markets are clearly of two minds about the Primerica Corporation, the financial conglomerate that owns Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, the Commercial Credit Company and the A. L. Williams insurance operation.
The stock market, to judge by the drubbing the company's shares have taken in the past two months, thinks that Primerica is a poor bet, in part because of emerging problems at the A. L. Williams unit. The bond market's opinion, expressed last week when Commercial Credit sold $100 million in three-year notes, is that Commercial Credit - the bedrock on which Primerica is built - is only slightly less creditworthy than Uncle Sam himself. The odds are, the bond market goofed. The corporate bond market typically classifies borrowers by how much more they pay to borrow than the United States Treasury pays. The gap is measured in basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Thus, traders speak of a bond as being priced to yield, say, 150 basis points over Treasuries - that is, 1.5 percentage points more than the Treasury bond yield for the same maturity. Of course, if the borrower offers some sort of collateral, its borrowing costs are likely to be closer to the Treasury rates than if it does not. 
Last Monday, the day the Commercial Credit notes were priced, Norwest Bank sold an issue of three-year secured notes, carrying a glittering triple-A by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's. Norwest's interest rate was 75 basis points over Treasury's.
Commercial Credit has a single-A rating from Standard & Poor's. As for collateral, it offered nothing but its good name.
So how did Commercial Credit fare? Remarkably well. The company paid just 78 basis points over three-year Treasury notes. In other words, the bond market was willing to lend money to Commercial Credit, despite a lower rating and the lack of collateral, for only three basis points more in interest than it was getting from a secured, triple-A borrower like Norwest.
Firoz Tarapore, assistant treasurer of both Primerica and Commercial Credit, said the company was the beneficiary of ''fortunate timing,'' selling the notes early in the week, before unrest in the Middle East caused spreads in the bond market to widen. As for the rate, he deemed it to be ''right in with the pack'' of similar issues.
Myron Picoult, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company, may not be an expert on corporate bond spreads but he has made a thorough study of Primerica for his stock-market clients. On the question of whether one should invest in the company these days, his advice is succinct: don't.
''The stock has clearly broken down, and investor confidence has been shaken,'' he said. ''We would continue to avoid the stock and believe that there is still some downside risk.''
One thing that worries Mr. Picoult is the unfolding drama at Williams, which Primerica purchased in 1988 from its controversial founder and self-styled ''coach,'' Art Williams. For years, Mr. Williams's aggressive selling style has made him a hero to his 190,000 agents and a thorn in the flesh of his industry rivals. After the Primerica buyout, he stayed on as a sales consultant and de facto leader of the insurance operation, which produces almost a quarter of Primerica's profits.
On July 20, Mr. Williams stunned his followers by tearfully announcing that he was taking a leave of absence to deal with a Federal grand jury investigation in Florida. The probe, according to the company, focuses on allegations of unspecified ''bad practices'' by a Williams marketing unit; others involved in the case say prosecutors are examining whether Mr. Williams or his associates played a role in fraudulently undermining a rival's business.
Primerica's fans among Wall Street analysts say the A. L. Williams issue is an ''aberration'' and ''an irrelevancy.'' But Mr. Picoult points out that Primerica's promising plan to use Mr. Williams's aggressive disciples to sell the products and services of other subsidiaries, including Commercial Credit, could be derailed by the current turmoil.
Moreover, he said, ''one wonders whether the United States Attorney's investigation could lead to review of the A. L. Williams operation in other jurisdictions by various state insurance departments, given past complaints about the company.''
Commercial Credit's own market niche is hardly worry-free these days. Of its $4.7 billion portfolio of loans, about 45 percent is secured by real estate - not as much of a comfort as it was before real estate prices started to soften.
Another 45 percent of its portfolio consists of unsecured loans to consumers. And how's that business? Andrew Silver, a senior analyst and economist at Moody's Investors Service, warned in a report last week that the borrowing binge of the 1980's has seriously eroded the consumer's creditworthiness.
It is possible, though unlikely, that both the stock market and the bond market are correct about Primerica - that Commercial Credit can somehow remain a rock-solid borrower throughout the pending business slump, while its parent company nevertheless confirms the stock market's worst fears. It is also possible that the stock market is wrongly punishing Primerica for the A. L. Williams affair, and that the bond market was right to ascribe so little risk to those Commercial Credit notes.
But, possibilities aside, it is certain that Commercial Credit is in the business of lending money to real estate buyers and consumers. It is equally certain that the nation's real estate sector is ailing and it is becoming harder for consumers to pay their debts.
All of which suggests a final possibility: That when bond market investors take a closer look at how little they are being paid to lend money to the Commercial Credit unit of Primerica, a lot of them will wish they had listened to the stock market.
