LENGTH: 2073 words

HEADLINE: Television's Independents: Working on a Slippery Slope

BYLINE: By NEAL KOCH; Neal Koch is a senior editor of Channels magazine.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Critics and viewers have embraced NBC's new Monday night situation comedy, ''Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' about a streetwise teen-age rap artist from Philadelphia transplanted to a wealthy section of Los Angeles. But the show is notable for another reason as well - one that is giving the shakes to independent television producers, and might give pause to viewers, too.
''Fresh Prince'' is one of the latest examples of how independent producers are getting squeezed out as suppliers of prime-time series programming to the major networks: The show is not only aired by NBC, but also produced by the network. It is one reason that independents command only about 14 percent of the prime-time schedule this fall on ABC, CBS, Fox and NBC, down from about 57 percent two years ago.
''The little guys are getting hammered,'' said Michael Mellon, vice president of media strategy for Buena Vista Television, a division of the Walt Disney Company. 
There is no shortage of reasons for the decline of the independents - producers who do not rely on major studios, networks or large diversified media companies for financing. The networks have stepped up in-house production, in part to cut costs. At the same time, Hollywood's rapidly consolidating major studios have been using their growing clout to grab more and more prime-time slots. The nine ''majors'' account for about 70 percent of the fall lineup.
The studios have also been bidding up the price of key talent, the writer-producers, making it harder for new competitors to break in. And broad changes in industry economics have made it difficult for veteran independents to survive on their own.
Industry executives say the situation is likely to get worse for the independents. ''Within the next five years or so,'' predicts Scott Siegler, president of Columbia Pictures Television, ''the bulk of the programming will be provided by four or five major studios.''
Critics warn that this trend could lead to a loss of innovation in an industry built by maverick entrepreneurs. Viewers could lose out, they argue, if the diversity of voices broadcast over the airwaves diminishes.
''Because there are fewer and increasingly similar corporate entities that supply programs, the range of shows that will get on the networks will be increasingly narrow,'' said Charles Slocum, director of industry analysis for the Writers Guild of America, West.
Throughout the history of television programming, said David Marc, visiting professor at the University of Southern California's Annenberg School for Communications, ''independents made important changes.'' Breakthrough series like ''All in the Family'' and ''Hill Street Blues'' were the work of independents, for example. ''Who is going to take the risks now if the quality-control boys are going to be able to nix projects?'' Professor Marc asked.
But studio and network executives maintain that their growing power makes little difference in a world exploding with new viewing choices - cable, satellite-delivered channels and videocassette recorders.
As powerful as they have become, their influence is exaggerated by critics, the executives also contend. In entertainment television, they say, writer-producers are so highly valued that some have their choice of studios and networks with which to work. Some are powerful enough to secure large measures of creative freedom. For instance, two of the biggest hits distributed by Disney, ''Golden Girls'' and ''Empty Nest,'' come from a boutique outfit, Witt-Thomas-Harris Productions, whose contracts have kept Disney from exercising creative control over those shows. And, the executives say, two of the most popular series on television these days, ''Roseanne'' and ''The Cosby Show,'' are made by an independent producer, the Carsey-Werner Company.
''I don't think creativity has suffered,'' said Leslie Moonves, executive vice president of Lorimar Television, formerly the largest independent and now part of Time Warner Inc.
But the critics reply by pointing out that the new cable and satellite channels tend to be owned by the same media giants that already own the big studios and broadcast networks. With some notable exceptions, the critics say, these new outlets have not brought diversity to programming so much as a resting place for old movies and reruns of situation comedies.
As for writer-producers, they may indeed be highly sought after, the critics acknowledge. But, they argue, industry economics still leave few writers with much choice other than to decide which of the major studios or networks they prefer to have bankroll their projects. For example, Steven Bochco (''Hill Street Blues'') and James L. Brooks (''The Simpsons''), by all signs the two most coveted writer-producers, have chosen to tie themselves to studios and networks.
Perhaps the last time independents found themselves so overshadowed was in the mid-to-late 1950's as the major studios made their first big move into television. With their superior financial resources, the studios bid up production costs, in the process forcing out or buying up smaller suppliers like Jack Webb and Desilu, said Thomas Schatz, professor of film and television at the University of Texas at Austin.
But the balance of power shifted following the quiz show scandals of the late 50's. With the backing of the Federal Communications Commission, the networks took greater control of their programming.
As a result, in the 60's, some independents, like Danny Thomas, grew quite powerful. But life still wasn't perfect. The networks hamstrung their outside suppliers by demanding equity interests in shows, as well as the right to syndicate the series, in return for putting them on the air. The F.C.C. stepped in again, this time issuing rules restricting the networks' ability to own the programming they aired, and barring the networks from sharing in profits from the sale of reruns to local stations. In addition, the Justice Department obtained consent decrees restricting network in-house production.
With that, independents entered their golden age in the 70's. Norman Lear (''All in the Family''), Grant Tinker (''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'') and Lee Rich (''The Waltons''), among others, became leading program suppliers, in the process dramatically expanding the acceptable limits of program content.
But that prosperity began to fade in the 80's. Rather than making a profit on each episode they produced, independents began losing money as the networks decided not to underwrite their program suppliers' full costs of production, let alone pay them a profit. The networks were feeling pinched as growth in advertising revenue slowed with the decline in audience share precipitated by new competitors - more independent TV stations, cable and VCR's.
As all this was happening, production costs skyrocketed. This hit independents particularly hard, compounded by a contraction in the syndication market.
Caught between these pressures, many independent producers merged, sold themselves or closed up shop. Most that survived signed on with major studios or networks willing to pick up their deficits.
''Only the biggest majors can afford the float until you get a hit,'' says Valerie Cavanaugh, executive vice president of Gracie Films, the production company of James L. Brooks, now associated with Columbia.
Now, few new independents are emerging, presumably because the financial barriers to entry are so high. ''And the hurdles are getting higher every day,'' says Perry Simon, executive vice president of prime-time programs at NBC.
The surviving independents are also finding it increasingly hard to get their shows on the air because there are fewer and fewer available time slots. Privately, industry executives say the shrinking shelf space for independents is partly because of the majors' use of their growing concentration of power to secure as much of that space as possible. The most powerful form of pressure available to the studios is a threat to move a hit show to another network or to take future projects elsewhere.
The dickering usually occurs over the size of production fees the network will pay, whether a marginally performing show will be renewed and which time slot a show will receive.
The majors ''have a certain ability to deal that I don't,'' says Richard Reisberg, president of Reeves Entertainment, now an American unit of the British-based Thames Television Company and producer of ''Doctor, Doctor,'' on CBS. Added one former network executive, ''When a guy can get a leg up and put a foot on a network guy's throat, he does it.''
To be sure, a studio's influence should not be overstated. A network has little incentive to buy a show that won't draw viewers. But it is just as clear that in a close call, a studio is more likely to get the benefit of the doubt than an independent.
And now independents are increasingly losing out to the networks' own production units. In-house production not only saves the networks money, but also gives them a shot at creating their own hit series. That has become more important as the F.C.C. has begun to review whether to relax or even eliminate the rules that bar the networks from syndicating programs. (The limits imposed by the consent decrees on the networks' ability to produce their own shows began to wane in the late 80's and are set to expire in November.) ''The small production companies are in a lot of trouble today,'' said Allan Burns, the independent producer best known for co-creating ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and ''Lou Grant.'' ''It's a shame. It eliminates the competition.''
 
THE INSUPERABLE NETWORKS
Given the increasing concentration of clout in television program production, are there specific shows that have clearly lost out to programs from more successful producers capable of pressuring the networks?
''It's unprovable,'' says one network programming executive, ''but undeniable.''
Such proof is hard to muster in any creative business requiring endless subjective judgments. But one recent example clearly raises the issue even though it pits one independent against another and a major studio is not involved.
''FM,'' a sophisticated comedy from struggling independent MTM Enterprises and producers Allan Burns and Burt Metcalfe, was tried out in several time periods last season by NBC. The sitcom received generally favorable reviews, and it beat the competition each of the three times it followed ''Cheers'' at 9:30 P.M. on Thursdays, one of the most desired prime-time slots.
More mixed were the reviews of ''Grand,'' an ensemble comedy from the Carsey-Werner Company, producer of ''Roseanne'' and ''The Cosby Show'' and one of the few independents left with real clout. ''Grand's'' ratings for its first three times following ''Cheers'' rivaled those of ''FM'' in that slot. But overall, ''Grand'' lost slightly more of the ''Cheers'' audience share than ''FM'' did. A dropoff in share points - the percentage of all TV sets in use watching a particular program - is a key measure networks use to evaluate shows.
Nonetheless, ''FM'' was dropped from this fall's lineup while ''Grand'' was included.
Mr. Burns, the ''FM'' producer, says NBC told him he would lose out to ''Grand'' because the network had promised the slot following ''Cheers'' to Carsey-Werner as part of a deal to hold on to ''The Cosby Show.'' Privately, many executives say they also believe the ''Grand'' deal was part of the price for ''Cosby.'' Carsey-Werner executives declined to comment.
Mr. Burns said NBC then told him it would not be able to find any slot for ''FM'' because of promises it had made to producers with more clout who wanted to get new shows on the air.
One recent arrival is ''Wings,'' from Paramount Pictures and some of the former producers of Paramount's ''Cheers,'' perhaps NBC's most important show after ''Cosby.'' A second new series, ''Down Home,'' is also from Paramount and the production company of ''Cheers'' star Ted Danson, whose contract was recently renewed. ''Down Home'' is expected to bow in January.
Asked about ''Down Home,'' ''Wings'' and ''Grand,'' Perry Simon, NBC's executive vice president for prime-time programs, said, ''None of those shows are on the air solely because of the producer relationship.''
But did NBC's desire to keep ''Cosby'' and ''Cheers'' play at least a substantial role? Mr. Simon declined to say.

HEADLINE: Managing;
Corporate Donations Under Attack

BYLINE: By DEBORAH L. JACOBS; Deborah L. Jacobs is a Brooklyn-based writer.

 BODY:
From Philip Morris to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, some of America's biggest companies are being attacked by special-interest groups for donating money to causes the critics simply don't like. As a result, companies are growing more frightened of controversy and are reassessing their donations, turning philanthropy into a image-boosting tool instead.
''Corporate giving has become more bottom-line oriented and related to the selling of the product,'' said Pablo Eisenberg, president of the Center for Community Change, a nonprofit public policy group in Washington. Although companies have always had their own agenda for charitable donations, experts say they are now so squeezed for profits, and blasted by critics, that they are less willing to give without getting something in return. And a treacherous economy ''diminishes a company's willingness'' to risk controversy, said Kenneth Albrecht, president of the National Charities Information Bureau, a nonprofit watchdog group in New York. 
The desire to avoid controversy is everywhere in corporate America. ''We stay as far away from controversial issues as we possibly can,'' said Donald W. Larson, president of the 3M Foundation and director of community affairs for the 3M Company in St. Paul, Minn.
''If we get involved in a controversial issue we're going to be in trouble with 50 percent of the people who are important to us.''
Abortion is one of the toughest issues facing corporate foundations. The Dayton Hudson Corporation, for example, decided to withdraw its funding of Planned Parenthood in August, under pressure from the Christian Action Council, an anti-abortion group. But seven weeks later, after more than 200 customers who supported abortion rights cut up their charge cards in protest, it reversed that decision.
A company spokeswoman, Ann Barkkelew, said the protests did not have ''any bottom-line impact,'' but the company agreed to resume its $18,000 grant only after being assured the money would not be used to advocate abortion, she said.
The A.T.& T. Foundation, another target of the Christian Action Council, withdrew its support from Planned Parenthood in March. That decision prompted several dozen protesters to picket the company's annual meeting in April, but did not persuade the foundation to change its position, said Burke Stinson, an A.T.& T. spokesman. He said Planned Parenthood is ''a player in the divisive abortion issue,'' and A.T.& T. did not want to be associated with it.
Companies are also finding that less direct support can cause trouble too. Arco Foundation officials had no record of a contribution to Planned Parenthood when they received a scathing letter recently from a group attacking Arco for its support of the organization. Eugene R. Wilson, the foundation's president, eventually traced the complaint: as part of its $16 million annual budget for philanthropy, Arco had helped finance a community symphony in the Southwest, which in turn had sent a brass ensemble to perform at a local Planned Parenthood benefit.
But the complaints come from all fronts. Arco's matching grant program for charitable donations, for example, came under fire recently from some employees for making donations to abortion-rights groups, and from others for gifts to anti-abortion groups.
Not surprisingly, Planned Parenthood finds this all distressing. ''The boardroom influence of small extremist groups is a danger to corporate philanthropy,'' said Peter Wilderotter, vice president of resources.
Abortion, however, is not the only issue that prompts complaints. Earlier this year, Arco was attacked by conservative groups that opposed its increased support of low-income housing, arguing that the company was interfering with free enterprise.
And the Philip Morris Companies' pledge of $200,000 to a repository for the papers of Senator Jesse Helms last spring spurred protest from a New York group, Act-Up, or the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power. The conservative North Carolina Senator, a staunch supporter of the tobacco lobby, has long offended gay-rights activists. So after the grant was announced last spring, Act-Up called for a boycott - now under way - of Marlboro cigarettes and Miller Beer, both owned by Philip Morris. The company, however, has refused to change its plans. ''Our main business is to tend to our business,'' said Posie DiSesa, manager for media relations at Philip Morris ''We're not a public policy organization.''
To stay on the safe side, more and more companies are linking their charitable giving to a clearly articulated corporate purpose. In recent years, for example, Fannie Mae has concentrated its charitable efforts on issues related to housing and homelessness. ''That's what we do and we know a lot about it,'' said David Maxwell, the company's chairman and chief executive.
The Aetna Foundation focuses on services to youth, civil justice reform and urban neighborhood revitalization, said Sanford Cloud Jr., vice president of corporate public involvement at the company. ''When society is healthy and prosperous our own company's chances of success are enhanced,'' he said. ''We can sell products to receptive markets and find people to fill jobs.''

HEADLINE: All About/Corporate Jets;
The Ultimate Status Symbol Still Sells

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
People who sell corporate jets can talk a transcontinental streak about the security, convenience and flexibility their products afford. What they don't need to say is that these particular corporate assets are 600 mile-per-hour odes to success - faster than airliners, with interiors that make first class seem like steerage.
With a recession looming, more companies might decide to save their money for debt payments or other essentials. A recent drop in fuel sales for corporate aviation suggests that companies are already using their jets less. ''If companies aren't spending on plants and equipment, they aren't spending on airplanes,'' said Angelo Fiataruolo, president of Premier Aircraft, a jet-brokerage firm in Westport, Conn.
After a surge of sales in the 1970's, especially to prosperous oil companies, the corporate jet business nose-dived, as cost-conscious companies turned to used models. The industry rebounded in the late 1980's; manufacturers sold 263 new jets last year, compared with 182 in 1987. And American companies using private jets increased from 2,862 in 1986 to 3,032 last year. This year, sales of new jets are stable, but used plane sales are down. 
American jet makers have held foreign companies to about half of worldwide sales. Canadair Aerospace Group, British Aerospace P.L.C., and Electronique Serge Dassault, a French company, are among the major competitors. Attracted by a weak dollar, more foreign companies - in Brazil, Venezuela and Mexico - are buying American jets. Japan and West Germany have until recently bought very few. Both nations have prompt, reliable, often luxurious trains.
 
Winning Formulas
In Pricing, Fly Either High or Low
 If a company wants to succeed in the private-jet business, it should try to be either the cheapest or the most expensive. Cessna, once best known for its small, propeller-driven planes, now makes almost all its money from one jet, the Citation. Cessna controls 62 percent of the worldwide market for light and medium business jets, with a backlog of 70 jets ordered that will keep the assembly line humming through 1992. Cessna's jets are considered relatively inexpensive by the industry's standards, with prices ranging from $2.5 million to $7 million. Profits at Cessna, a division of the defense giant General Dynamics, rose in the first half of the year to $39.1 million, up from $13.6 million for the same period last year.
Gulfstream sells far fewer jets but is successful nonetheless. Allen E. Paulson, Gulfstream's former owner, joined with Forstman Little & Company this year to buy Gulfstream back from the Chrysler Corporation for $825 million.
The Gulfstream G-IV sells for about $25 million and costs $2,500 per hour to fly. Some buyers have installed beds, showers and sculpture collections. The plane can carry 19 people from Atlanta to Paris, nonstop, more than 50 miles per hour faster than the airlines. Gulfstream delivered 41 last year, down from 49 the year before. Sales are surprisingly steady during economic declines. ''If you have $25 million to buy a G-IV, you have it whether there is a recession or not,'' said Alan Staats, president of Flight Level Design, an advertising agency specializing in aviation.
Jet operating costs that usually exceed $1,000 an hour seem a small worry compared to the initial cost. Higher fuel prices that have left the airlines reeling have scarcely been noticed by companies that fly business jets. ''If you can afford to buy and fly a jet aircraft, you don't worry that much about fuel costs,'' Mr. Humphrey said. Few, if any, corporate jet makers are on fuel efficiency drives.
 
That Snazzy Image
It Draws Buyers, but It May Attract Taxes
Let nobody within earshot of Dean Humphrey call corporate jets luxuries. ''We're lumped with fur coats and jewelry and yachts,'' said Mr. Humphrey, a Cessna spokesman. ''Nothing could be further from the truth.''
Mr. Humphrey and others in his industry might have a hard time getting Congress to see the point. A pending bill would add a 10-percent ''luxury tax'' to the purchase of a new corporate jet. Jonathan How, president of the National Business Aircraft Association, opposes the bill, but said that during the 1980's, ''There were a few unhappy examples of abuse.'' Far from showing off their fleets, most companies wish they could apply Stealth technology to make the jets invisible to shareholders. Few corporate jets boast company logos.
Some major airports that want to reserve runway space for the airlines are discouraging corporate aviation. To steer small planes away from Boston's Logan Airport, the state's Port Authority hit them with large landing fees that, under court challenge, were recently dropped.
Business-jet merchants respond to criticism by saying that, for many executives, their planes are indispensable. First, for security, to keep executives far from terrorists and industrial spies. On a private jet, ''executives can go through financial statements without being overheard,'' said John House, spokesman for Falcon Jet, a subsidiary of Dassault. ''You can't do that in the first-class section of Pan Am or British Airways.'' For security, some corporations prohibit top executives from flying the airlines overseas.
Next, sellers of jets rhapsodize about the ability to zip straight to destinations without circuitous routing that airline hub-and-spoke systems entail. On the airlines, ''you can't get from point A to B without going through C, D and sometimes E,'' said Henry Ogrodzinski, spokesman for the General Aviation Manufacturers Association. And because private jets can land at thousands of small airports, they enable executives to reach cities the airlines do not serve. ''Business is reaching farther out off the beaten path,'' said Baron Thomas, a jet broker in Dallas. ''The airplane is the only way to get there.''
Mr. Paulson, with a sales pitch for every season, argues that deliveries of private jets should increase when the economy slows because companies have to chase more customers and clients. ''When business is bad, you need the aircraft all the more,'' he said.
 
Learjet's Fall
A Resurgence Under New Owner?
The sales updraft has not raised all jets. The Learjet Corporation has proven that a renowned brand name, long synonomous with its product, is no guarantee of eternal success. In 1962, the company introduced what became the industry's best-selling jet, the Lear 23, and the company's animated chairman, Bill Lear, emerged as a celebrity. Yet in the last five years, Learjet has been bought and sold three times, with most of the buyers financial holding companies more interested in writing off losses on their taxes than in building airplanes.
The company developed few new models, and its sales plummeted from 134 planes in 1981 to 16 in 1987. Earlier this year, the company was bought by Bombardier Inc., a Canadian company that makes snowmobiles and industrial equipment and that owns Canadair, for $75 million. The new owners pledge to turn Learjet around. In fact, the company recently introduced a new, aerodynamically improved model, the Lear 31, to help recoup some of the company's status.
 
A DELUXE JETFROM RUSSIA
Aeronautics inspires strange alliances. Sukhoi, a Soviet company best known for the Su-27, a supersonic fighter used in Afghanistan, has teamed up with Gulfstream Aerospace to build the world's first supersonic business jet.
The project - the first joint aviation venture between the Soviets and the United States - still faces many obstacles beyond the mating of capitalist entrepreneurship and socialist planning. At $50 million, the plane would cost about twice as much as Gulfstream's G-IV, now the world's most expensive business jet. And the new plane might seldom fly at top speed; to avoid sonic booms, civilian planes are prohibited from flying faster than the speed of sound over the United States.
Allen Paulson, the chairman of Gulfstream, said the plane's design can muffle the sonic boom. He is confident of finding customers. Skeptics once questioned whether anybody would shell out $25 million for a private jet, he said.
Gulfstream envisions a plane that could carry 15 to 20 passengers and fly at Mach 2, or about 1,500 miles per hour, slightly faster than the Anglo-French Concorde, the only other civilian supersonic plane in the air. The Soviets would handle the bulk of the design work and the $1 billion development cost. Gulfstream plans to provide the cockpit electronics and marketing.
The venture began last spring, when Mr. Paulson met for several hours with Mikhail P. Simonov, chief of Sukhoi, at the Paris Air Show. By the next morning they had signed a memorandum of understanding. Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the British engine manufacturer, has joined Soviet Lyulka Design Bureau to build the plane's engine.
After several meetings, Soviet and American engineers produced a mock- up of the plane that was displayed at the Farnborough air show in Britain earlier this month. A first flight is planned for 1994.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Good Health in a Bad Market

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Celebration and chaos drove the stock market in the third quarter as the Dow Jones industrial average flirted with 3,000 in July only to nosedive after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Stock funds followed suit, with the average fund losing 15.5 percent for the quarter ended Sept. 27, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc..
The obvious winners were gold funds (up 4.2 percent). Utilities funds gave their usual defensive play during the market turmoil and were down 6.34 percent. Natural resources held steady, down only .16 percent. All the other stock funds succumbed to the blood bath, but health and biotechnology funds (down 11.9 percent) had less of a drop than the others. In a market like this, they're one of the hottest sectors. 
As a group, the nine health and biotechnology funds held up because of strong sales and excellent prospects, fund managers say. ''People are excited about the group so they didn't sell out,'' said Michael S. Gordon, who manages the $185 million Fidelity Select Biotechnology Fund.
The weakening dollar helped the group because overseas divisions of American health and biotech companies generated hefty foreign earnings in the quarter. And many companies' earnings are tied more closely to new products than to the overall health of the economy, which protected the group from the worst of the market rout.
All of this makes the health and biotech funds a good place for investors to park their money in a bear market. But shop carefully. Many stocks sell at a premium now. The group's prospects are strong over the long term, too. Health care is one of the largest sectors in the American economy, and spending is rising as a percentage of gross national product. The reasons: a growing elderly population, big jumps in research and development spending, and the coming to market of many new products financed by venture capital in the 1980's.
Among the products coming on stream is Neupogen, which stimulates white blood cells to fight infection. Its manufacturer, Amgen Inc. of Thousand Oaks, Calif., hopes it will be approved from the Food and Drug Administration in the next six months. The drug should double Amgen's earnings in the current fiscal year, said Mr. Gordon. Amgen is one of his favorite companies.
Activase, a new drug that dissolves blood clots in heart attack victims, is driving the earnings of another one of Mr. Gordon's favorites, Genentech Inc., in South San Francisco. The company recently sold a controlling interest to Hoffman LaRoche.
One stock selling inexpensively now is C.R. Bard Inc., a Murray Hill N.J.-based medical supply manufacturer whose coronary angioplasty line was recently recalled. Its stock plummeted as a result and is now an excellent buy, said Andrew S. Offit, who manages Fidelity's $305 million Select Health Care Fund. He said the recalled line represented only 15 to 20 percent of Bard's business and earnings should jump 40 percent in 1991.
One of the hot industries of the 1990's will be discount mail-order pharmaceuticals, according to John J. Kaweske, manager of the $91 million Financial Health Science Strategic Portfolio, in Denver. His favorite stock is Albuquerque-based Diagnostik Inc., which began trading on the New York Stock Exchange earlier this month. Mail-order drugs sell for 15 to 20 percent less than they would at the local pharmacy, so Diagnostik should benefit from greater emphasis on cost-containment and should grow at 35 to 40 percent annually over the next four or five years, Mr. Kaweske said.
Animal health care is a favorite category of Edward P. Owens, who manages the $125 million Vanguard Specialized Portfolios - Healthcare. He likes the Northbrook, Ill.-based Imcera Group, a recently repositioned chemical company that is now a large international animal health care company and a major player in diagnostic pharmaceuticals for people. He said its Optiray, which makes blood opaque and thus clarifies X-ray pictures, should help Imcera grow 30 percent annually for the next three or four years.
He also likes Beckman Instruments, of Fullerton, Calif., which makes medical instruments. It was spun off from SmithKline about two years ago and virtually ignored in the marketplace because of flat earnings. But Mr. Owens expects earnings to pick up because of its Syncron line of clinical diagnostic instruments, and then to grow by 15 to 20 percent for five years.
Cheryl N. Alexander, manager of the $330 million Putnam Health Sciences Trust, likes Schering-Plough, of Madison, N.J., whichmakes Intron, a form of alpha-interferon approved for use by cancer patients.
 
FLIGHT FROM 'JUNK BONDS' PICKS UP
The flight from ''junk bond'' mutual funds seems to be picking up steam again. After several months' respite, in August money began flowing out of the nearly 100 funds. The funds lost $994 million last month, according to figures released last week by the Investment Company Institute. So far this year junk-bond defaults have jumped past the $10 billion mark, with no signs of slowing. In August, junk-bond prices suffered the worst one-month decline on record, a sharp contrast to the price rally that began in May and continued through July.
In September, junk-bond funds ''had net outflows of cash and suffered more than other categories of bond funds,'' said Michael Hines, a vice president at Fidelity Investments in Boston.CAROLE GOULD

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Shopping for British Stock Bargains

BYLINE: By Steven Prokesch

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
To many investors, Paul Walton may sound like a crazy optimist when he gives his opinion on British stocks. ''We're saying buy, buy and buy some more,'' said the equities strategist at James Capel & Company, the brokerage.
Mr. Walton is not living in never-never land. He knows about all the grim news on the British economy in recent weeks. 
Inflation hit 10.6 percent. Unemployment, although only 5.8 percent, is rising. The manufacturing sector is entering a recession, according to a survey of members of the Confederation of British Industry. And John Major, Chancellor of the Exchequer, has vowed not to cut the nation's base interest rate of 15 percent until it is clear that the battle against inflation is being won.
These developments - coupled with soaring oil prices and fears of a scandal at a former high-flying British company, Polly Peck International P.L.C. - caused The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading British stocks to plunge to 1,990.2 on Friday, a low for the year. That was 19.2 percent below its record high of 2,463.7 on Jan. 3.
While not necessarily as enthusiastic about British stocks as Mr. Walton, strategists at other large securities firms also say investors should be making selective purchases. Barring a catastrophe, they say, Britain's economy has just about bottomed out.
Many analysts believe that inflation is at or near its peak and that the Government will begin to cut interest rates late this year or in early 1991. Peter Sullivan, European investment strategist at Merrill Lynch Europe Ltd., noted that in the recessions of the mid-1970's and early 80's, the London stock market jumped 12 percent in the month interest rates began to fall.
Institutional investors, who have been building their cash position over the last year or so, will soon start putting that money into stocks in anticipation of rates falling, Mr. Walton predicts. He expects the market to rise 15 percent in the fourth quarter and the FT-SE 100 to end the year at about 2,300.
Analysts say British stocks are a bargain by several measures. The price-earnings multiple of the FT-SE 100, now about 10.3, is below the 10.6 multiple that followed the 1987 market crash. The dividend yield for the FT-SE all-share index of 678 stocks is 5.9 percent, an eight-year high. And the ratio of bond to stock yields has fallen below 2, which is historically low.
''The bottom line is that on all valuation yardsticks, the U.K. market is now cheap,'' said Paul Turnbull, an economist at Smith New Court Securities P.L.C. He thinks the Japanese and West German stocks are relatively expensive and American stocks are in the middle. Although the FT-SE 100 index could fall as low as 1,850 in coming months, he said, ''the time to be buying is now.''
Because of the London market's current level and because Britain, thanks to its North Sea oil, is a small net oil exporter, even bearish analysts say the London market would fare better than other major markets if the Middle East crisis drags on or worsens. Still, that's small consolation for British companies that must pay more for energy.
British stocks are especially attractive for Americans, some analysts add. They note that the dollar is widely expected to weaken over the next 6 to 12 months, which would mean that British stocks bought now will be worth that much more in dollars later.
As a hedge against the Middle East crisis and the world oil situation worsening, Merrill Lynch recommends that shares of oil companies - especially those dominated by exploration and production - account for 20 percent of a British stock portfolio. Mr. Sullivan declined to cite stocks, but likely candidates are Enterprise, London & Scottish Marine Oil and British Petroleum.
The remaining 80 percent of the portfolio, he said, should be interest-rate-sensitive shares - like those of companies in construction or with relatively high debts - that will rebound when rates drop.
Richard A. Kersley, equities strategist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Ltd., is becoming more pessimistic that interest rates will be cut this year and recommends caution about buying stocks. But he says there are some investors should consider.
He favors companies with resilient earnings like General Electric of Britain; Wellcome, the drug company; Reckitt & Colman, a food, household products and drug company, and Tesco, a food retailer.
Smith New Court's pick of recession-resistant stocks that would benefit from falling interest rates include Kingfisher, a diversified retailer; Land Securities and British Land, real estate companies; Barclays, the financial services concern, and Blue Circle, a building-materials company.
Mr. Walton of James Capel recommends 10 stocks whose high yields, he reasons, will attract buyers, causing their prices to rise: British Steel; Barclays; United Newspapers; Sedgwick Group, an insurance brokerage; BET, a services company; Sears, the British retailer; Imperial Chemical; Lloyds Bank; General Action, an insurer, and B.A.T., the tobacco and insurance concern.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 23-28

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

 
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Traders Unfazed by Sale of Oil in Strategic Reserve
 
He produced a trickle and then threatened a flood. Oil traders were immensely unimpressed. President Bush announced on Wednesday evening that the nation would sell five million barrels from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve as a rebuke to speculators who had pushed oil prices too high. ''I'm prepared to take additional steps, if necessary, to insure that America stays strong at home,'' he said. On Thursday morning, traders hesitated. For a few minutes, they sent oil down. Then they shrugged and dismissed the President's threats. ''OPEC exports about 22 to 24 million barrels a day, and he's releasing about five million,'' said Brian Tagler, a crude-oil trader at Shearson Lehman Hutton. He added that the heavy, high-sulfur crude in the reserve can be difficult to refine, and that the condition of pipes and pumps is questionable. As oil prices climbed higher than before the President spoke, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins urged the sale of three times as much oil. The Administration is not trying to force prices down , he said, but is just testing the system. 
 
Crude Prices Shoot Up Fast
 
Fears of winter shortages and war in the gulf caused oil prices to rise last week to the highest levels in a decade. A barrel of crude closed on Friday at $39.51, up $4.08 for the week. ''Oil has definitely gone higher, faster than most people expected,'' said Paul D. Mlotok, an energy analyst at Morgan Stanley.
 
The Economy Heads South
 
When even the White House admits the possibility of a recession, the nation must be in for hard times. The gross national product grew just four-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, according to a Commerce Department estimate last week that brought on the Administration's gloom. Then came reports that personal income and spending for August both failed to keep up with inflation. Most economists predict that in the fourth quarter spending will evaporate and the economy will shrink. As Stephen S. Roach, the senior economist at Morgan Stanley, put it, ''The consumer is heading south.''
 
Liberation and Regulation
 
L. William Seidman's latest project is no less than the rebuilding of the rickety banking industry. Mr. Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, asked Congress on Tuesday to repeal laws that keep banks from diversifying into new businesses and regions. He wants to continue regulating commercial banks while letting them pursue more investment banking and interstate expansion. He would also like to let other industries buy banks. ''We can only hold the fort if we do substantial restructuring of the industry,'' Mr. Seidman said. The next day, the Bush Administration suggested restricting bank deposit insurance, since the insurance fund is rapidly dwindling. On Thursday, the F.D.I.C. doubled its estimate for the year's losses, to more than $3 billion - suggesting that the Seidman rebuilding crews had better work overtime.
 
Medicine for Detroit
 
Before the decade is over, electric cars may be a California reality - and a Detroit migraine. The state with the nation's toughest air-quality rules approved even stricter ones Friday to create cleaner fuels and vehicles, including electric cars. Auto makers carp that the technology does not exist to achieve the reduction - of 50 to 84 percent - in California's automobile pollution that the new rules require by 2003. But some economists say the forced improvements will make Detroit more competitive with Japan - if the sticker price of progressive transport is right.
 
Bond Game Moves Abroad
 
More Americans are playing the bond market abroad. Investments in foreign bonds of about $10.3 billion in this year's first half surpassed the total for any full year, according to Salomon Brothers. Bond experts point to a weakening dollar and to Japanese and German interest rates that have approached those in the United States - though American inflation has been more rapid. Nicholas Sargen, Salomon's director of research, says long-term investors like pension funds are looking overseas, too. ''The diversification argument has begun to influence them,'' he said. ''They realize the U.S. economy is not closed.''
 
COMPANIES
 
Real Estate Goes to the Dogs
 
Maybe the slowdown in real estate has become more severe than everyone thought: Several prominent architects have turned to designing doghouses. At the Cooper-Hewitt Museum on Fifth Avenue in New York, 24 houses - dog palaces, some - decorate the back lawn. There are the Trojan Dog - dog-shaped, with ramp and canine frieze; the Lap Dog Pool House, boasting sun deck and circular pool; the Bauwauhaus, incorporating a Marcel Breuer table turned upside down; and the Lassie Come Home, crafted from a television console. Each designer got $1,000 from the museum, and, from the looks of things, many shot way over budget, as architects sometimes will.
 
 Wall Street Applauds Matsushita
 
In a lackluster fall season, with investors staying away, the New York Stock Exchange finally has a hit - MCA Inc., which rose $19.50 a share to $54 on Tuesday on word that Matsushita Electric is a prospective buyer. Matsushita, Japan's largest consumer electronics company, is said to be offering as much as $7.5 billion, or more than $85 a share. An expensive ticket, but good for admission to the American entertainment market. Matsushita would take a seat next to its archrival, Sony, which bought Columbia Pictures for $5 billion last year. Can MCA's Universal Pictures, Universal Television and Motown Records still deliver the entertainment that Matsushita craves? Universal has brought out all-time hits like ''E.T.'', ''Jaws,'' ''Back to the Future'' and ''The Sting.'' But most of the company's greatest films are old properties that stopped filling theaters years ago.
 
In Brief
 
Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood delayed the sentencing of Michael R. Milken from tomorrow and may hold a hearing on crimes the Government has alleged but that the ''junk bond'' financier denies.
 
Wall Street's underwriting fees during the third quarter fell to their lowest level in six years.They fell to $339 million, from $785.6 million in the comparable period last year.
 
Neil Bush acknowledged last week that he stood to gain from dealings between his business partners and the defunct Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, where he was a director. Mr. Bush, charged with conflicts of interest by the Office of Thrift Supervision, said at a public hearing that he did no wrong.
 
Marvin Davis has offered to buy UAL Inc., then give employees two years to raise financing to buy it from him.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Soviet Power and Potatoes
 
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union has won the power to set wages and prices, shape the budget, enforce law and order, devise a compromise between two rival economic plans - and, he hopes, motivate more workers to dig potatoes. The Soviet Parliament voted on Monday to give him emergency authority for 18 months. Although progress toward free markets seems to require looser controls, Mr. Gorbachev wants more power to rescue the Soviet economy. He might need all the power he can muster merely to keep potatoes on Soviet plates.
 
 Pressure on Brazil
 
 President Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil says he respects American calls for lower trade barriers and protection of the rain forests, but bank debts are another matter. Brazil, the largest debtor in the third world, begins talks next month on the $57 billion it owes to foreign private banks. On a visit to New York last week, Mr. Collor was unyielding. ''We do not feel it is a logical stance to make demands that will keep Brazil from growing and which will keep Brazil from paying in the future,'' he said. Asked whether Brazil would make any payments to the banks this year, he said: ''That is an answer they are eager to hear.''

936 of 966 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 30, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3007 words

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
Philip H. Geier Jr. has become a kind of corporate psychiatrist treating a case of schizophrenia at the Interpublic Group of Companies, the largest and oldest advertising conglomerate in the United States. And at least for the present the treatment seems to be working beautifully.
Interpublic, which Mr. Geier leads as chairman and chief executive, had until recently owned two international advertising networks. One, McCann-Erickson Worldwide, was pulling the corporation in one direction, and the other, Lintas Worldwide, in another.
Mr. Geier's solution: Invite a third patient into the mix. He announced 10 days ago that Interpublic would acquire all of the Lowe Group of Britain, a collection of feisty agencies that may pull it in a bit wackier, more creative direction. (See story on page 6.) For all its internal contradictions, Interpublic is making the rest of the industry look a bit sickly. Saatchi & Saatchi, the British company that used to be the world's largest advertising conglomerate, is struggling under the crush of debt. The WPP Group P.L.C. - another British ad company, which is now the world's largest largest after having seized the American giants J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy Group in 1987 and 1989 - is seeing its share price plummet. 
But Interpublic, the company that put tigers in our tanks for Exxon and told women how to be ''Cover Girl Clean,'' just grows and grows. Its net income increased last year by 17 percent and its earnings per share grew by 15 percent, while domestic advertising expenditures rose only 5.8 percent, the smallest increase in two decades. In the process, Interpublic's agencies added half a billion dollars in net new business, increasing their worldwide billings to more than $9 billion.
''It's the best-run of the large advertising networks,'' said James Dougherty, a communications analyst with County Natwest Securities. ''In fact, it's kind of surprising to me they've been able to do as well as they have, given the environment.''
 
Struggling for Redefinition
Yet despite its extraordinary growth, Interpublic is not without its problems. It is, in fact, struggling to redefine itself, apparently caught between advertising's past and what many think should be its future. McCann, whose clients range from the populist (Coca-Cola) to the elitist (Brooks Brothers) seems convinced that advertising agencies will profit primarily by dispensing television commercials and print ads. Lintas, which turned stodgy old Chevrolet into the pulsating ''heartbeat of America,'' sees its future in the New Advertising. This is the theory that customers can no longer be drawn to products and services merely by TV and print ads, but that a complex combination sales promotion, public relations, package design and direct marketing are required.
Interpublic is also fighting a reputation as the least creative of the world's advertising empires. Acquiring the Lowe Group, renowned in Britain for its work for Heineken beer, may help counteract that. But the company still must battle a legacy of caution that experts say could stall its upward trend.
Supervising this divided realm is Mr. Geier, an arrogant, blustery 55-year-old who bristles when people question his agencies' creativity and thinks nothing of making screaming 7:30 A.M. telephone calls to ad executives whose public comments have offended him. But for a man who takes nothing lightly, Mr. Geier appears untroubled about his empire's contradictions.
''I think we've got the best of both worlds going for us,'' he said. ''We've got one agency doing it one way and another agency doing it the other. We'll learn in this process.''
Most advertising agencies proudly line their walls with ads. Not Interpublic. The halls of its headquarters on the 44th floor of the Time and Life Building in Manhattan are lined with a museum's cache of modern art.
Phil Geier, a former executive on the Coca-Cola account who has been Interpublic's chairman since 1979, strutted proudly past the Cindy Sherman photograph and the Bruce Nauman neon sculpture before settling on a couch in his conference room, near a mural painted by Sol LeWitt, and explained the presence of the art. ''People told me it looked like a bank up here, so we invested in leading edge contemporary artists. We're not a bank,'' he said. ''We're in the advertising business.''
Mr. Geier laughed. The irony was intended. Because, to the advertising world, Interpublic is a bank, a money machine fueled in large part by a series of intelligent acquisitions.
As an undergraduate at Colgate University, Mr. Geier earned the nickname Deals when he bought out competing fraternity food concessionaires to assemble a profitable monopoly.
But for all his bluster and cockiness Mr. Geier also shows himself to be fairly pliable.
Whereas once he denigrated the idea of the New Advertising, now he muses thoughtfully about it: ''You've got to operate with your clients' way of doing business and slowly get it to change. Where an agency can be most helpful, I think, is it can be a catalyst. It can put together a total communications plan and use some of its own resources and some outside resources.''
 
A Clash of Styles
 Mr. Geier's two agencies, McCann and Lintas, share several multinational clients, among them General Motors and Coca-Cola, but their different corporate styles are otherwise clearly personified in the the men who run them.
McCann's chief executive, Robert L. James, a 54-year-old former fraternity brother of Mr. Geier's at Colgate, is a short, pugnacious type man whose office is decorated with nautical artifacts, a testament to his passion for sailboat racing. His own description of McCann fits him, too: ''a street-smart, aggressive, no-holds-barred scrambler.'' In contrast, he terms Lintas ''reserved, cool.''
Mr. Weithas, chief executive of Lintas, agrees. ''Our culture is a more European culture,'' said the tailored, formal 60 year old, ''where McCann's is more. . . .'' He paused. ''American.''
Perhaps because of its relative gentility, but more likely because of plain bad luck, Lintas has suffered a streak of high-profile account losses in recent years. Last year, it lost the Noxell Corporation, for which it had created the ''Cover Girl Clean'' makeup campaign, after a 43-year relationship. The agency's crime: Its largest client is Unilever, archcompetitor to Procter & Gamble, which had acquired Noxell. And earlier this year, Eastern Airlines fired the agency - which had served the troubled carrier through its bankruptcy proceedings - because Eastern's court-appointed administrator was friendly with executives at Ogilvy & Mather.
Jim Dougherty, the County Natwest analyst, attributes Interpublic's success despite its problems to its vast web of agencies.
McCann has 8,000 people in 71 countries, and Lintas, 6,000 in 48 countries. This network contributes fully two-thirds of the company's revenues and has insulated it from the general slowdown the American economy.
An Area of Vulnerability
 Alan J. Gottesman, a communications analyst at Paine Webber Inc., says credit must also go to the company's genius at controlling costs for such items as real estate and personnel. Interpublic handles all its mergers and acquisitions itself, for example, saving an estimated $15 million in investment banking fees for the more than 80 acquisitions it has made since 1982, according to Eugene P. Beard, the company's chief financial officer.
''They've gone along for the past couple of years with no really significant bad events,'' said Dougherty. ''That's lulled us into a sense of security that nothing bad can happen. But it can.'' Indeed, it can. Creativity, for example, has been an area of vulnerability. Interpublic's two giant advertising networks rarely figure in discussions about the industry's most creative agencies.
Neither McCann nor Lintas was named among the best agencies in last year's survey of 207 advertising executives by Advertising Age, the trade magazine. Ogilvy and J. Walter Thompson, two other multinational agencies serving equally large clients, finished among the top six.
McCann is widely perceived as one of Madison Avenue's least creative large agencies.
''In the 70's and early 80's, McCann's image was as the only creative big shop around,'' said Penny Hawkey, a former creative executive. ''That's no longer true.''
Many assign responsibility for McCann's image problems to the revolving door on the company's office of creative director in New York, where eight people have come and gone in the last decade. Executives cite the difficulty creative people have working with Bob James, McCann's chairman, and John Dooner, head of its North American operations. Without affection, Mrs. Hawkey calls the two men ''very powerful suits''- ad lingo for executives who lack appreciation for creativity.
But most say the creative problems stem from what they call ''the system'' - a kind of all-powerful, transcendent bureaucracy. The problem, say executives, is that Interpublic is structured to serve massive clients like Unilever and General Motors, who use it primarily for its vast network of offices and people. That bureaucracy, critics claim, is stifling. ''You cannot be a creatively driven agency on a growth pattern within the I.P.G. system, where the system is more important than anything else,'' said a former executive.
Nor has there been much impetus to change. As one current executive said, ''To big-bucks clients, advertising is a commodity. Advertising is filling in a need in the business marketing process. When a Coke moves around the world, it wants control over its image. How much does creativity really matter?''
 
The Cycle of Mediocrity
 But it does matter - especially to top writers and art directors who won't go to an agency with a reputation for lackluster creativity. That creates a cycle of mediocrity that can hinder an agency's efforts to recruit top creative people.
In an unusual breaching of the wall that separates his agencies, Mr. Geier - who professes a hands-off attitude toward his agencies' management but, by most accounts, is intimately involved with them - personally drew Sean K. Fitzpatrick from Lintas's Detroit office, where he led the ''heartbeat of America'' campaign for Chevrolet, to become McCann's top creative officer.
A bearded bear of a man, Fitzpatrick, who is 49, may be exactly what McCann needs. An outspoken former Hollywood screenwriter, he loves advertising awards shows - ceremonies that can be critically important in boosting a creative department's morale and reputation, but events from which McCann has been noticeably absent for many years.
''I looked around when I got here and it was like 13th-century Japan, with all these warlords in separate fiefdoms fighting each other,'' Fitzpatrick said with characteristic candor. ''I found sloppiness. I found a lot of commercials were coming through that weren't timed to 30 seconds. I found you couldn't find how many ads were being done in the place at any given moment. I don't think anybody listened to the creative director at all.''
The general consensus is that Fitzpatrick has made a difference. Some of McCann's work has even begun to show up in awards shows again. But it clearly still has a ways go.
Although Interpublic is the model for modern advertising companies, its brush with bankruptcy in the mid-1960's left a legacy that afflicts it to this day. The near-bankruptcy ''is the reason we didn't go pell-mell into ancillary services,'' said Bob James of McCann-Erickson. ''We learned 25 years ago that you can't run it if you don't know it. We have been chastened and prudent since.''
 
Diverse Services
 But companies like Young & Rubicam and WPP and, increasingly, their clients, are acting from the belief that information about products and services is communicated in many ways, not just through television commercials and print ads. ''We believe market share gains will be rooted in agencies' abilities to serve their clients across a range of marketing services,'' wrote Laurie Goldberger, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton, in a widely distributed report last year.
But at Interpublic it's clear that Mr. Geier has not resolved all the in-house conflict over the issue. In 1988, 95 percent of Interpublic's revenues still came from mainstream advertising. By contrast, only 49 percent of the revenues of the WPP Group derived from mainstream advertising; the rest came from public relations, market research, direct marketing, events marketing and the like.
And at McCann, executives vehemently affirm that the status quo will remain intact. His anger rising, James called the New Advertising ''smoke.''
Some clients agree with the criticism of Interpublic. The Sony Corporation of America gradually took more than $20 million in billings away from McCann and gave the accounts to smaller agencies because of McCann's inability to mount effective, coordinated communications campaigns, said Jeffrey S. Brooks, Sony's vice president of advertising.
But by and large, McCann has not thus far been hurt by its resistance to New Advertising. Already this year, it has won more than $200 million in new business in the United States, including the $70 million advertising account for Tri-Star Pictures - paradoxically, a subsidiary of Sony. And Interpublic's largest clients, like General Motors, say they are satisfied.
In Europe, Interpublic has quietly developed capabilities that lie outside the realm of mainstream advertising. And in the United States, through the Lintas network, Interpublic, is pushing ahead with myriad disciplines and integrated marketing. In the spring, to the advertising industry's surprise, Lintas's approach paid off. The Sara Lee Corporation consolidated $100 million worth of marketing spending at the Interpublic unit - $45 million of it in direct marketing - expressly because of Lintas's New Advertising expertise.
Such fiesty contrarianism may be the true hallmark of Interpublic's style. Demean the competition, denigrate their strategies, but if study proves they might be onto something, quietly move in their direction. That has been Interpublic's approach to the New Advertising, a higher creative profile and the acquisition of a third international agency network, and it seems to be working.
''Everybody gave me a lot of heat in the mid-80's for not making big deals,'' Phil Geier last week, basking in the afterglow of the Lowe Group acquisition. ''But we're in it for the long term, not the short term. We have some standards.''
 
A ZEST FOR THE DEAL
Deals Geier is still living up to his nickname, his associates say, constantly exploiting others' weaknesses for Interpublic's gain.
When Martin Sorrell of the WPP Group made his run on Ogilvy last year, Phil Geier thought nothing of publicly pronouncing the British acquisitor a ''predator'' - and then turning around to make his own offer.
His single-mindedness is legendary inside Interpublic's agencies. William V. Weithas, who heads the Lintas network, recalls that his wife would have to force Mr. Geier to exchange even minimal social niceties when he called their home to talk business.
The collapse of the British advertising market has provided opportunities for Mr. Geier and his surprisingly lean holding-company staff. The Lowe Group, for example, found itself unable to realize its vision of becoming an international advertising empire, unable to raise enough money for acquisitions. Mr. Geier was waiting in the wings. Earlier this month he made a successful stock and cash offer to buy the 65 percent of Lowe that Interpublic did not already own.
Deals Geier's deal has been applauded by industry analysts. Adding Lowe will increase Interpublic's networth by $1.4 billion, leave it with about a $235 million debt - only a quarter of Saatchi & Saatchi's - and enhance its creative reputation.
 
AN EMPIRE LINKED BY AN 'ECONOMIC UMBILICAL CORD'
McCANN-ERICKSON, the foundation upon which the Interpublic Group of Companies was built, was founded in 1902 by Harrison King McCann, a former advertising manager for Standard Oil of New Jersey, to be a house agency for Standard Oil. For decades, when J. Walter Thompson was bravely establishing outposts around the world to prospect for clients, McCann was growing carefully and methodically , following its multinational clients as they expanded.
But by 1960, McCann's leader, a Yale-educated Oklahoman named Marion Harper Jr., had a better idea. Harper, who died last year, understood that impediments to growth were conflicts of interest that prevent it from accepting business from competing companies. Harper's vision was to assemble a group of ostensibly independent agencies under the umbrella of a benign financial holding company. Connected only by an economic umbilical cord, they would be free to compete with each other, the way General Motors's Buick and Oldsmobile divisions did.
Harper's notion was ridiculed - wisecrackers said it was appropriate that the first office of his holding company, Interpublic, was located in the same building as Mad magazine - but he persevered, acquiring a series of venerable, sometimes competing agencies. The only thing that stood in Harper's way was his own profligacy. ''Marion was a pioneer,'' recalled Carl Spielvogel, for many years a Harper protege at Interpublic and now the chairman of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide, a subsidiary of the Saatchi & Saatchi advertising conglomerate. ''Unfortunately, he got involved in unrelated acquisitions that caused the company to teeter on the brink of bankruptcy - an airline, a fashion information company, some research companies, even a dude ranch on Long Island.''
In 1965, desperately in need of $5 million to keep Interpublic afloat, its board of directors acceded to a demand from its banks that it unseat Harper. A year later, the board took the company public to gain access to much-needed capital.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Will Landlords Desert Their Buildings Again?

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
For much of the 1970's, landlords abandoned thousands of apartment buildings each year in New York City's poorest neighborhoods, producing a real-estate and social disaster of major proportions. More than 200,000 apartments were lost,and the burned-out shells that marred huge swaths of the South Bronx, Harlem and central Brooklyn became potent symbols of urban despair.
There is growing concern today among landlords, bankers and city officials that some of the same conditions that led to the wave of abandonment may be coalescing again.
The downturn in the city's real estate market has diminished the value of rental apartment buildings, finding renters has become a bit harder and the chances to convert to co-ops have faded, and many owners who overfinanced their buildings in the giddy 1980's are having trouble keeping up with their mortgages. Foreclosures are rising. Operating costs have soared in the last two years, owners say, particularly sewer and water bills and property taxes. Now the price of oil has skyrocketed too. 
''This is very reminiscent of the 1970's,'' said Michael D. Lappin, the president of the Community Preservation Corporation, a nonprofit company created by more than two dozen New York banks to lend money for housing renovation in poor neighborhoods.
The number of buildings actually abandoned, which shrank to a trickle in the 1980's, has not increased much this year, city officials say. But warning signs are abundant.
The number of buildings seized by the city because the owners fell behind on their tax payments did increase, from 804 last year to 1,409 so far this year. Such seizures begin the process under which the city takes over tax-delinquent properties. Owners then get several chances to reclaim their buildings by paying the back taxes and interest, so it is too soon to know how many will ultimately abandon their buildings.
Some buildings that had been profitable for years have begun to run deficits, landlord representatives and building owners say. R. Bonnie Haber, the president of the RBH Management Corporation, manages a six-story building with working-class and middle-class tenants in Jackson Heights, Queens. The building has long been profitable, and showed a net income of $20,000 in 1988, Ms. Haber said. She estimates that it will show a $60,000 loss this year.
Water and sewer bills are up $8,840, or 38 percent, this year, compared to 1988, Ms. Haber said. Real estate taxes increased $26,932, or 31 percent. Repair and maintenance costs went up $26,000, or 32 percent, she said. Salaries, heating oil and other expenses also shot up.
Rents increased too, under guidelines for rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments. The total increase for 1988-1990 was $60,000, or 14 percent. It could have been higher, but for the changes in New York's economy. Vacant apartments now take longer to rent, Ms. Haber said, and sometimes even the legally authorized rents are not attainable. A two-bedroom apartment that could be rented for a maximum of $856 a month was rented, after it remained vacant for three months, for $800, she said.
''The only reason people are holding on right now is that they have other properties which are doing better, and they can cover the cost,'' she said. ''They are hoping things will turn around.''
But profit and loss is only one factor in whether a building will be abandoned. The owner's sense of the building's potential for resale or co-op conversion, confidence in the neighborhood, a boom in the city's economy or in the incomes of the building's tenants can favorably dispose a landlord toward a building that is temporarily losing money.
Dan Margulies, executive director of the Community Housing Improvement Program, an owners group, said increased costs could threaten many buildings. He cited a city study of income and expense statements that large landlords are required to file as part of the tax-assessment process. Forty-six of the 500 buildings studied reported operating expenses greater than income. And those did not include mortgage costs.
''You could easily see abandonment reaching the proportions of the mid-70's in another year or two, unless something dramatic changes,'' Mr. Margulies said. Tenant representatives agreed that a surge was possible, but they disputed both the causes and the suggested remedies.
Michael McKee, executive director of the Community Training and Resource Center, a nonprofit group that trains tenant organizers, said the unaudited statements filed by landlords were unreliable.
Owners say the filings are just like income-tax returns and carry penalities for lying.
Mr. McKee also said operating costs have not increased significantly, and blamed owners' problems on inflated mortgages they obtained in the 1980's. ''Banks were willing to underwrite absurd packages,'' he said. ''But times have changed, and now there is this big whine and moan.''
A landlord unable to keep up on a mortgage ''should eat it,'' Mr. McKee said. An abandoned building ''can be an opportunity, where government is concerned.''
Owners and real-estate executives argued that the city could not afford to run all the buildings it would take over for taxes. Because two-thirds of New York's poor live in private housing, the city should help owners keep their properties, they said.
Mr. Margulies said the city should consider raising the lowest rents on regulated apartments, so more rent for $400 to $500 a month.
Mr. Lappin called for more subsidies for owners who improve their buildings.
''There is always this pitting of owner and tenant,'' he said. ''But if you look at it, they are really in the same boat, aren't they? There are real economic issues here and they are difficult issues. There are no great winners when this thing goes down the tubes.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Troubles of South Asia Take Over on Campus

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: NEW DELHI

 BODY:
Struggling to exist on meager budgets while fighting perennial battles to stay open through bouts of political turmoil and violence, the universities of South Asia are in trouble.
In grimy, cheerless lecture halls and bare-bones science labs across the region - in Pakistan, India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and Nepal - underpaid professors face hundreds of thousands of students who know that graduation will bring only a long, soul-destroying search for a job, any job, to match their qualifications.
To add to the unhappy atmosphere, weapons are proliferating on many campuses, often at the service of political parties or ethnic factions that use students as private armies. Dormitories, student unions and other organizations have become sharply politicized. Gun battles erupt. Bombs are thrown. Precious equipment gets destroyed. Young lives are jeopardized. Students who can afford it want to go abroad - particularly to the United States - for the luxury of an uninterrupted higher education. Many never return. In South Asia in 1990, this is not a simple story of young rebels confronting despotic governments. All of the region's countries have democratic institutions, however flawed or misused. Because the roots of campus malaise are varied, solutions are especially hard to find. 
There are exceptions, often in unlikely places. At the vortex of Afghan intrigue in Pakistan, Peshawar University functions productively. Many campuses in India are peaceful, even if as deprived as Jawaharlal Nehru University, a leading center for the social sciences where a political scientist said he could not afford to subscribe to basic scholarly journals.
This is, above all, a region of high illiteracy, overpopulation and extreme poverty, where the development of human resources is crucial to social and economic growth. This makes the stagnation and deterioration of universities especially worrisome for educators and the public.
When young people began to set themselves on fire here last week to protest the extension of a sweeping affirmative action program designed to help more disadvantaged Indians, teachers and political commentators saw in the action a cry of despair among the barely privileged, now fearful of losing what little they have. The Government's reaction was one familiar to South Asia: Close the campuses first, and talk to the students later. Delhi University has been ordered shut until Oct. 15.
Student politicking and campus unrest, now and then exploding into violence, are not unknown in more prosperous and developed countries, including the United States.
In South Asia, however, the concern is that the politicization of universities is more pervasive and permanent. The process began years ago, often with independence movements.
Today in Karachi, Pakistan's largest city, and Sind, the surrounding province, students have sophisticated arsenals. In the last few years, surplus weapons from Afghanistan have been spilling into neighborhoods and campuses along with narcotics, which also come across the Afghan border.
Ethnicity has also been a major factor in campus warfare, as illustrated by Altaf Hussain, leader of the Mohajir Qaumi Movement, a new Pakistani party that says it speaks for the Muslim families who migrated here from India at partition in 1947. He said in an interview that he began to think in ethnic terms as a student nearly 20 years ago, when he found himself isolated on a campus where Pathans, Baluchis, Punjabis and Sindhis all had exclusive political organizations. His movement now has its own armed student wing.
 
 Shutting Classrooms
In Sri Lanka, university campuses were closed for most of last year because they had become recruiting centers for the People's Liberation Front, a radical organization drawn from the majority Sinhalese community. The group opposes both autonomy for the Tamil minority and the presence of Indian peace-keeping troops. The front also appeals to students from the lower middle class, who feel socially and intellectually intimidated by the country's sizable educated elite. Education Minister Lalith Athulathmudali said in an interview that the experience of 1989 could cause the Government to abandon the concept of residential campuses in favor of a system in which students live at home until graduate school. ''The tension between the haves and have nots is just too great,'' he said. ''By postgraduate level, we can smooth this out.''
In Bangladesh, political parties have used students for street demonstrations since independence in 1971. So powerful are the campus political groups, now almost all in opposition to President H. M. Ershad, that the President's party recently dissolved its own fledgling campus group, which was constantly under attack. All six universities have armed student groups, and they have become adept at blockading streets or closing shopping areas with threats of violence on issues that have nothing to do with education.
In Nepal last winter, when protests against the ban on political parties began, the country's premier university, Tribhuvan, was closed after a raid by armed policemen in search of student and faculty radicals.
''Nepal's higher education is in a tailspin,'' an article in Himal, a journal of Himalayan studies, said in 1988, adding a pithy description of the situation that could apply across the region: ''The teachers are underpaid and untrained, the facilities are deplorable, the students unmotivated, and the administration drifts aimlessly, like a ship without a rudder.''
