HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Reunification II: This Time, No Hobnail Boots

BYLINE: By JOSEOH JOFFE; Josef Joffe, on leave from the Suddeutsche Zeitung, is the Visiting Beton Michael Kaneb Professor of National Security Affairs at Harvard.

 BODY:
In 1871, Germany was unified, and a few years later, The Times of London editorialized darkly: ''We feel that an enormous power for good or evil has risen up somewhat suddenly in the midst of us, and we watch with interested attention for signs of its character and intention.''
On Wednesday, the world will watch ''Reunification II'' - and as anxiously as 120 years ago. Will the sequel be a repeat performance, starring a restless giant who has become too big for his turf? Will Germany '90 move from strength to arrogance, again bringing grief to Europe and the rest of the world?
The Bismarck-to-Hitler analogy is tempting but misleading. Just compare the opening scenes. In 1871, Germany was unified by ''blood and iron'' - in a war of aggression launched against France. Today, Germans and French are no longer archenemies but the best of friends. On Wednesday, the loudest sounds to be heard in Berlin will be the whistling of fireworks, not the rumble of artillery. Reunification will be a thoroughly peaceful affair. 
Not only is the overture different this time; the stage, script and actors have also changed beyond recognition. Take the lead player. In the Bismarckian Reich, democracy was shouldered aside by a Prussian-dominated state that unleashed an economic revolution while chaining down liberty and dissent. The Kaiser's message to the rising middle classes was: Go ahead and enrich yourselves, but leave the driving to us.
In the Weimar Republic, born in defeat and disgrace after World War I, democracy never had a chance. Yes, there was a parliamentary regime, but it was ground down in a two-pronged attack by Communists and Nazis who flourished because millions were caught in the maw of the Great Depression. And in 1933, when Hitler came to power, democracy was simply torn to shreds.
After 1945 democracy could at last sink its roots into fertile soil, and in many ways the postwar political miracle in Germany even dwarfed its vaunted economic twin. This time, thanks to generous American help, democracy was not associated with economic misery and humiliation. Instead of reparations, there was Marshall Plan aid; instead of towering tariffs, there was free trade; instead of encirclement, there was NATO and the European Community, extending to the Germans a shelter and a role.
At last, then, German democracy was off to a good start, and today the Cassandras of 1945 have fallen silent. The parties of the extreme right and left have all but vanished, leaving in place a sluggishly centrist regime that is almost boring in its normalcy. The democratic system has weathered every political crisis: neo-Nazis and terrorists, insubordinate generals and rebellious students, large-scale unemployment and mass protests.
In many respects, the political system looks like America writ small. Federalism works, and so does the separation of powers. Compared with the ''republican monarchy'' that is France, the Federal Republic is a political free-for-all. Nor is there an Official Secrets Act that so hampers the freedom of the press in Britain. State secrets in Bonn last about as long as in Washington - until tomorrow's edition.
The point is not that today's Germans are ''good'' whereas their grandfathers were thoroughbred authoritarians. The point is that after World War II the stage changed. Flawed as it was in the past, the drama of German history at last could unfold before a benign backdrop. Consider the ugly brew of paranoia and chauvinism that had poisoned the body politic before. The Bismarck Reich, a late arrival in the great power club, was bound to threaten all of its neighbors - and in turn to be threatened by them. The Weimar Republic was a pariah among nations and a target of endless distrust - a perfect breeding ground for the enemies of peace and democracy. It was ''us against them'' and ''Deutschland Uber Alles.''
Reunified Germany, by contrast, will be embedded in a larger community, surrounded by friends and not by resentful neighbors. The Federal Republic grew up in security, provided courtesy of the United States, and this cut down the business opportunities of the Pied Pipers. Try as they may, right-wing parties, hawking their message of hate, have never established a foothold in the Federal Parliament.
But, so the skeptics will demur, that wonderful edifice is collapsing before our own eyes. With the Soviet surrender in the Cold War, the Atlantic alliance is fading and the Americans are going home. Won't Germany, finally unshackled from its postwar fetters, again be tempted by sheer strength and the heady lure of aggrandizement?
True, waning dependence equals less deference. Absent the Soviet threat, Bonn-Berlin might be less hesitant to convert economic muscle into political clout. But to argue that Reunification II will turn into a remake of the 1871 original is to ignore how much the script itself has changed.
The rivalry of nations in the democratic-industrial world has moved from the battlefield into the economic arena, and it promises to stay there as long as the marvelous economic community Europeans have built persists. Nobody expects the Germans to invade Alsace again; now they pay for the pleasure of owning the choice plots there, just as the Japanese are buying, not bombing, Pearl Harbor.
Power in Europe (as opposed to Saddam Hussein's neighborhood) is measured not by conquest but by capital surpluses. Not booty and glory define the stakes, but questions such as: ''Who determines currency parities?'' It so happens that the Bundesbank calls the shots, which understandably grates hard on the French. But worlds separate this contest from the game played out with German jackboots in Paris 50 years ago. The battle lines are drawn in the balance-of-payments ledgers, and the accounts are settled with dollars and Deutsche marks, not blood and iron. The rivalry is about joint welfare, not this or that province; both sides lose or win together. (American victims of Sony resent cheap VCRs made in Japan, but who would go to war over the privilege of buying worse-quality goods at higher prices?) Still, might not Bonn-Berlin hanker after nuclear weapons and push for revision of its eastern borders? What for? The new, more civilized and civilianized game of nations offers the largest payoffs to nations such as Germany and Japan. The game has devalued the military chips, delivering power and prestige to those who can back up their bets with investments and loans. Why, then, should they forego their advantage by changing the rules? In the attempt, they would certainly revive the hostile coalitions that proved their undoing in 1945. Also, well-settled democracies are more sensible about such risks than were the Hohenzollerns and Hitlerites.
On Wednesday, Bonn Inc. will take over bankrupt Prusso-Marx, a k a East Germany. But the remake of 1871 will not be shot with a cast of latter-day Erich von Stroheims. The soundtrack will not be ''Deutschland Uber Alles,'' but Beethoven's ''Ode to Joy,'' Europe's unofficial anthem. Walking alone in the distant past, Germans easily fell for the mesmerizing music of the Pied Pipers. But in the meantime Europe has changed, and so has Germany. Hamburg and Rome, Munich and Marseilles have been listening to the same tune for a long time; adding Dresden and Leipzig should not ruin that score.

LENGTH: 986 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Australia Wants Asia to Come A-Waltzing

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN

DATELINE: BRISBANE, Australia

 BODY:
For years, this outpost of Europe behaved like a standoffish neighbor to the Asian community it lived in. Instead of cultivating ties with the community, it relied on its own natural wealth and its political, economic and cultural links to Europe.
But now, fearful that it will lose European markets after the European Community is fully established in 1992 and aware that its Asian neighbors' economies are flourishing, Australia is accepting, even embracing, its geographic location, hoping to share in the regional growth.
''In the sense of being a true part of the growth in this region, developing ourselves in the rapid pace of Southeast Asia, we're a sort of hanger-on-er, rather than a full participant in the growth,'' said Paul W. McCarthy, chief economist at Commonwealth Bank of Australia. 
In the two years since Prime Minister Bob Hawke traveled to Seoul and announced a drive for closer economic cooperation within the Pacific region, Australians have been shaking the hands of more Asian officials, business executives and tourists than ever before. There are more Hong Kong Chinese immigrants mingling in Australian society, and in the last three years Australia has run trade surpluses with Japan, which now accounts for more than one-fifth of Australia's total trade.
Japanese investment, which exceeded $26 billion in the end of the 1989 fiscal year, has been the fastest growing source of foreign investment in the country. Britain and the United States, however, still have higher levels of investment.
Yet many Australians say more needs to be done, especially economically, to integrate their island with Asia. Trade with Southeast Asia, for instance, has grown only slightly in the last three years.
While Australians still crave American imports, Japanese businesses have become such a dominant influence in trade that 4 of the top 10 largest Australian exporters are Japanese companies. After Broken Hill Property Group, Australia's largest industrial corporation, the No. 2 exporter is Mitsui & Company (Australia) Ltd. Most of the exports are commodities, such as wood chips, ore and coal, and many of them go straight to Japan, which receives more than twice the value of exports of Australia's second-largest market, the United States. For Australia to become a larger force in Asia, many economists and business executives say, the country must restructure its own economy.
 
Plyboard, Not Chips
''Instead of sending wood chips, we should be sending plyboard, and where they take paper pulp, we should send paper,'' said Paul A. Everingham, a corporate lawyer.
He said one concern is the Australian view of Asia. ''One of our problems is that Australians think of Asia in terms of Japan and China, and they think of the other countries as places they can go to for holidays.''
Japan and China have been the focus of Australia's ties to Asia. In a dramatic turnaround from the White Australia policy, which essentially shut out Asian immigrants until the early 1970's, Mr. Hawke this June granted 19,000 Chinese students the right to stay for four years in Australia. And Australian businesses have called on China for years.
Japan, on the other hand, sends not migrants but money. Japanese companies operate throughout Australian financial and trading circles, and more and more Japanese honeymooners are coming to Australia to eat steak and play golf. In Brisbane and the nearby sunny Gold Coast, Japanese corporations have purchased nearly a dozen resort hotels to cater to large Japanese tour groups. In 1989, nearly 350,000 Japanese tourists came to Australia, buying large blocks of seats on the planes and paying for spaces on the golf courses.
The area has always been a Shangri-la for Australian retirees, but now some Australians are finding that the Japanese presence involves a price: some Australians are priced out of the market as purchases by Japanese companies push up property values.
While some Australians fear or criticize the influx of foreign capital, others are calling for measures to develop the export of services in which Australia is strong, such as education, health and advanced technology. These may be areas of opportunity for trade with neighbors like Indonesia and Malaysia.
 
A Joint Venture
In Adelaide, Japanese and Australian business executives and politicians are planning together the construction of a high-tech metropolis, where tiny villages would be linked to a modern network of communications, a research university, a science and industrial park and other commercial facilities that would attract investors.
But the move toward Asia has been bumpy, because Australia still values its historic ties to Europe. More students are studying Japanese, but many Australians still aspire to attend Oxford. More trade delegations are going to Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore, but the country remains part of the Commonwealth and Australians still celebrate the Queen's birthday.
''No doubt we have to come to grips with becoming a part of Asia,'' said William J. Shields, executive director of Macquarie Bank Ltd. ''But it's dangerous to see us as an Asian country. Culturally we have other links.''
Some Australian companies find it difficult to break into Asian markets, and many do not speak the languages or know the local customs. Moreover, most of the economies are still viewed as developing ones, compared with Australia's rather mature economy, where per capita gross domestic product was $17,100 in the last fiscal year. Australia is trying to develop its manufacturing base and looks upon certain Asian countries as stronger competitors, with their cheap labor.
''A lot of people claim that Japan, Hong Kong and Taiwan are catching up to us'' in output, said Saul Eslake, chief economist at McIntosh Hamson Hoare Govett Ltd., an investment firm in Melbourne. ''And there's a lot of angst about all that.''

LENGTH: 1000 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Budget Battle Spatters Politicians

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As the Federal budget deficit threatens to choke the economy, the most powerful men in Government, meeting week after week, hour after hour, have found it far easier to bash each other for inaction than to find common ground.
Faced with a widespread shutdown of Government offices and activities in the absence of a budget agreement, Congress has scheduled sessions for today to revise the deadlines of the Federal budget-balancing law to avoid automatic multi-billion dollar program cuts on Monday. After a compromise between White House and Congressional negotiators late Friday night, it appeared the way was open for a deal that would keep the Government functioning.
But in an atmosphere of growing disgust at debacles such as the savings and loan collapse and the ethical missteps on Capitol Hill, the budget quagmire is for many Americans the most telling evidence yet that the nation's leaders are sacrificing the public interest for their own. 
''The mood is almost 100 percent 'the hell with them all,' '' said Larry King, the national radio and television call-in host. ''I don't remember any time quite like this. Out of 300 calls in the last two weeks, 130 have been on Congress and the deficit. I haven't gotten one call that George Bush is correct and Congress is wrong, or that Congress is correct and George Bush is wrong. There's a 'damn both thy houses' attitude.''
Some politicians are equally harsh, among them Representative Lee Hamilton of Indiana. ''The most serious consequence of the budget deficit may be that we've lost our credibility,'' said Mr. Hamilton, one of the most respected House Democrats. ''No party, no leader, no member is going to come out of this looking very good. We're letting the country down.''
Much of the country would seem to agree. A recent New York Times/CBS News poll showed that 59 percent of those surveyed said they did not believe that President Bush and Congressional leaders were making a serious effort to reduce the deficit. Only about half that number said Mr. Bush and Congress were really making a serious effort.
In follow-up interviews last week, poll respondents said they were fed up like never before. ''They're just fighting each other on the news,'' said Merry Snyder, a 57-year-old care worker for the developmentally disabled in Arlington, Washington. ''They're not putting the American people first. They're putting themselves first. They're not thinking about us at all.'' Wanda Johnston, an 84-year-old retired real estate broker in Phoenix, said that Congress and the White House don't seem ''even interested in trying'' to remedy the deficit. ''They are simply sitting there like two dogs fighting over a bone.''
That's the way it seemed last week. Mr. Bush started the latest round of recriminations as he traveled to high-roller Republican fund-raising gatherings in the Middle West warning that if automatic spending cuts take effect Monday, ''the Democratic Congress knows that it will be held accountable.''
The Democratic Congress was furious. Brandishing a milk carton on the House floor, Representative Bob Wise, a West Virginia Democrat, mocked the President for staying out of Washington at a crucial time in the talks. He said: ''There is a face that is soon going to be appearing on the grocery shelves if he does not get back to Washington pretty soon. Come home, President Bush. Call a toll-free number. We will pick you up. Get to the summit where you belong!''
It was not supposed to happen this way. To harness the massive Reagan-era deficits, Congress in 1985 passed the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law, which called for steady reductions in red ink. Each year since then, Congress and the White House negotiated, only to wind up with a compromise that put off tough decisions for yet another year through budgetary tricks like revising the deficit reduction targets.
This year, with the economy appearing on the brink of recession, the stakes were even higher. But both sides remained adamant in their opposition over one issue in particular, Mr. Bush's proposal to lower the capital gains tax. It was an issue more of symbol than substance - many economists say it would have only a minor impact on the deficit -but it was anathema to Democrats, who note that it benefits mainly the wealthy, and unwaveringly demanded by Mr. Bush, perhaps to ease the pain of his broken pledge of no new taxes. In a compromise late Friday night, the Democrats yielded on capital gains and the White House agreed to a higher income tax for wealthy Americans.
No matter what the final package is, the deficit is not about to disappear. There are no quick fixes in the world of budget making. Senator Warren B. Rudman, a New Hampshire Republican and an author of the deficit-reduction law, suggests that the American system of Government is the core problem.
''I really wonder whether we have reached a stage in our history where the three branches of Government are really working any more,'' he said. ''It's getting to be a formula for gridlock with no accountability, with the American people not knowing whether to blame the President, the Republicans, the Democrats or just everybody.''
Of course, if the backroom budget talks result in a breakthrough, it probably won't take long for the warring factions to close ranks: Mr. Bush and Congressional leaders will no doubt gather under bright television lights at the White House to congratulate each other, proclaiming that they have saved the country from what some commentators call ''Beltway Armageddon.''
For a while, at least, praise will substitute for the back-biting. But it is unlikely to be genuine. As Representative Jim Lightfoot, an Iowa Republican, put it in a tongue-lashing he delivered from the House floor last week:
''I would suggest to my colleagues that many Republicans and good conservative Democrats are sick and tired of being cast and forced into the role of playing the clown. It is time that this circus closed and left town.''

HEADLINE: Where to Find Aerodynamic Inspiration

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''New Plane Wing Design Greatly Cuts Drag to Save Fuel'' (Science Times, Sept. 11) reports that the performance of airplane wings has been improved by incorporating small holes to draw off air where the wings are subject to turbulence.
This surprising recipe reminds me of a story that Vladimir Engelhardt, the leading Soviet biochemist, told our biochemical delegation to the Soviet Union in 1960. Today's news reports of Soviet economic problems may give the story added interest. 
It seems that a newly designed plane lost its right wing in its first test flight. In a test of a second prototype of the same design, the left wing broke off at the same position. The manager of the factory consulted the wisest, oldest plane designer in the Soviet Union, who pondered the problem and advised drilling small holes through both wings, at 10-centimeter intervals, along the line of cleavage. The plane then flew successfully. When asked how he knew that the holes would balance the forces and strengthen rather than weaken the wings, the consultant explained that some problems are too complex to solve by direct analysis and hence must be approached by analogy. He built on the analogy that Soviet toilet paper never tears along the line of perforations.
 
BERNARD D. DAVIS
Boston, Sept. 12, 1990
 
The writer retired as the Adele Lehman Professor of Bacterial Physiology at Harvard Medical School.

HEADLINE: If Only the Retired Were Healthy and Wealthy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''No Special Favors on Medicare'' (editorial, Sept. 15), you show your unswerving antipathy against the middle-income retired on Social Security and Medicare. You state that if Part B Medicare premiums of the middle- and high-income retired are increased to eliminate Government costs, the saving would be ''$70 billion over five years.'' Actually, Richard G. Darman, the President's budget director, finds that increases of only $40 billion over five years are all that is necessary to eliminate the Government subsidy (front page, Sept. 12). Annually, the saving would be $8 billion. 
It is time to end the manipulative practice of showing budget savings in totals for multiple years (five) while showing the taxpayer's costs of increased taxes (or premiums) in monthly amounts. What should be shown is annual budget saving versus increased annual taxes or premiums. You should not fall prey to this self-serving trick of mixing time frames.
The middle-income retired on Medicare are angry when budget negotiators seek to cut taxes on the very rich by capital gains reductions for stock market killings while hurting the middle-income elderly retired on fixed incomes. Why go after the middle-income retired while refusing to increase the taxes of the very rich?
It isn't fair to change the rules of Medicare after the retired have entered the Medicare system. It may be feasible and desirable for the middle-income retired to drop out of Part B and pay as they go much more cheaply for private coverage of physicians' bills. But the Government would have to subsidize the costs of the low-income retired by itself.
What is overlooked is that inflation, over five years, reduces the fixed incomes of the middle-income retired by 25 percent to 50 percent to low-income levels. What is also overlooked is that the middle-income retired have to pay enormous additional insurance premiums for nursing-home coverage or try to save funds for such expenses, about $40,000 a year and increasing continually. People who are employed often receive increases in salary and bonuses to cover higher taxes and inflation. The retired over 65 do not get similar increases from their savings income, but do have the sword of Damocles of infirmity, stroke, Alzheimer's disease, which may cost $40,000 a year for nursing home care. It hardly seems appropriate to repeat simplistic arguments that presuppose the middle-income and well-to-do elderly retired are and will be rolling in money and good health for the rest of their few remaining years.
 
SEYMOUR SIMON
Tucson, Ariz., Sept. 17, 1990

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
New Federal Law Encourages Fire Safety in Hotels

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
The fire safety of American hotels is taking a big step forward. This month brought the enactment of a law that will eventually require that 90 percent of civilians traveling on Federal Government business in the United States and its territories stay in hotels with sprinklers and smoke alarms if the Government is to pay the hotel bill. While the law does not mandate the installation of sprinklers, Federal employees are estimated to be worth $1.6 billion a year to the hotel industry, a big incentive.
If enough ordinary travelers learn about the law, the greater purpose of its sponsors will be realized: Americans will stop assuming that all hotels have sprinklers and begin asking travel agents, tour operators and sales people about sprinklers in hotels as well as smoke alarms in rooms. Although the law does not deal with foreign hotels, if the same questions are raised about overseas accommodations, there may be a long-term impact.
A 90-member Smithsonian tour was due at the Heliopolis Sheraton in Cairo just after 17 people died in a fire there in March, and the people who made the arrangements said that the sprinkler question had not been asked. The group was switched to the Ramses Hilton. 
Research for this column has established that operators booking large groups seldom ask the question, not because they are careless, but because they wrongly assume that hotels have sprinkler systems as a matter of course. The best estimates are that half of the 44,300 American hotels and motels have sprinkler systems, and that a third of their total of three million rooms have smoke detectors or sprinklers. Some of the remaining two-thirds will probably not be affected since lodging places of three stories or less are exempted on the premise - which some experts dispute - that in the event of fire lower floors are safer than those higher up.
The law took three years to get through Congress, but it was finally approved in both houses on a voice vote: ''How can you be against the Hotel and Motel Fire Safety Act?'' the Holiday Inn lobbyist asked after it was all over. It will take six years for the law to become fully implemented.
A leading sponsor of the bill, Representative Sherwood L. Boehlert of Utica, N.Y., a Republican, believes that in the interim the law will improve safety through education of travelers. Calling the bill a landmark, he said it was probably the first time that the Federal Government ''has taken direct action to protect the public at large from the danger of fire.''
Here are the provisions of the law. Within two years, the 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands and other specified places must submit to the Government lists of their privately owned hotels and motels that meet fire safety standards, which include sprinklers and smoke detectors in guest rooms. Two months later, the Federal Government is to compile a master list for periodic revision. Subsequently, the Federal Travel Directory, which is used to make travel arrangements for Government employees, would only include those accommodations that qualify, and per-diem expense allowances would be granted only for stays at qualifying hotels.
A year and two months after the master list appears, federally financed meetings or conferences would be restricted to qualifying hotels unless the head of the agency making the arrangements granted a waiver. Announcements of meetings would have to specify that the hotel or hotels involved met the rules.
Four years from now, each Federal agency would have to insure that 65 percent of its employees' nights on the road were spent in qualifying motels. In five years, the percentage would be 75 percent and in six years, 90 percent. Older Buildings Targeted As provisions of the law are phased in, the impact will be almost entirely on older properties, because in most areas of the United States contractors are already required by law to include sprinklers when they build motels and hotels, but only Puerto Rico and five states - Connecticut, Florida, Hawaii, Massachusetts and Nevada - have laws requiring all hotels to have sprinklers in guest rooms.
Choice Hotels, formerly Quality International, now bills itself as the world's largest franchise hotel company; it comprises Comfort Inns, Quality Inns, Clarion Hotels, Sleep Inns, Econo Lodges, Rodeway and Friendship Inns. Gerald Petitt, the president, testified against the sprinkler bill in the Senate but said that the law as adopted, excluding buildings of three stories or lower, was acceptable. He said that his company would soon develop a policy on what to do about older hostelries in its chains that would be affected by the law.
Holiday Inns, which also supports the law as it was revised but fought it on the basis of cost while it was pending before Congress, estimates that 200 of its 1,500 inns - franchised or owned - would have to be modified to meet the sprinkler law, at a cost of $70 million to $80 million. In its original form, the bill exempted only buildings of one and two stories, and according to the lobbyist for the chain, Michael E. Grisso, that would have meant retrofitting 560 Holiday Inns at a cost of $170 million.
There is another set of numbers, however - insurance premiums - and they may change the minds of chains or individual motels that decide that retrofitting is not worth the expense because they do not get enough Federal business. Raymond C. Ellis Jr., director of risk management and operations for the American Hotel and Motel Association, said one chain was saving $2 million a year on fire insurance by adding sprinkler systems to just two hotels, albeit big ones. Conversely, he said, insurers are already refusing to provide coverage for some hotels they consider unsafe.
''I wouldn't be surprised if by 1996, insurers will be saying, 'No sprinklers, no insurance,' '' Mr. Ellis said.
Mr. Ellis said that the industry was pleased with its progress in fire safety. There were 35 deaths in fires in United States hotels and motels in 1989, with a total of 6,500 fires reported, including small fires in wastebaskets, and the like. From 1983 to 1988, the total number of nonfirefighter deaths in United States hotels and motels was 350, including the 97 deaths in the DuPont Plaza in San Juan, P.R., in 1986. Part of the reduction in 1989 may have come from the decrease in smokers; Mr. Ellis said that 21 percent of motel fires were still linked to smoking.
For comparison, 800 people died in fires in apartments in 1989, according to Mr. Ellis, and fire killed 4,000 people in one- and two-family homes. Aiming for Total Sprinklering Sheraton Hotels, which established a program for all 450 or so Sheratons worldwide to have sprinklers in the guest rooms by last June 30, did not entirely make its deadline but is continuing on course, according to John Veelenturf, vice president, director of fire, life safety and environmental health. He said that only a small group of cleanup problems remained in the 58 corporately owned properties in the United States and that perhaps 75 of the 300 franchised domestic properties were still in the process of meeting the requirements.
Overseas, he said, the situation was the same with the corporate properties, but the franchised establishments were lagging more. The work in some of the hotels in the Middle East was stalled in some cases, Kuwait, for instance, and Eastern Europe was not so far along as Western Europe.
Mr. Veelenturf said that the corporation had not changed its goals and expected that 95 percent of its hotels in 68 countries would meet the target by the end of the year.
Asked about the Federal fire safety law, Mr. Veelenturf said that Sheraton was installing sprinklers even in properties with only three floors because he believed safety should extend to the ground, but ''that's not a position everyone agrees with.''

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory

 BODY:

U.S. TouristsShun RussiaAs Crime Rises Put off by reports of street crime and ethnic violence, the number of Americans visiting the Soviet Union has plummeted this year, Soviet tourism officials and American tour operators say.
Vladimir A. Malinin, the director of Intourist, the Soviet state-run travel company, said that 40 percent of its bookings this year had been canceled. He estimated that 100,000 American tourists would visit this year, compared with the 180,000 that Intourist handled in 1989.
American companies specializing in travel to the Soviet Union cite crime and ethnic violence as reasons for their slow business. 
''There's no question that there has been an increase in crime,'' said Sydney Reiner, president of Cosmos Travel. ''But it has been exaggerated. And as far as I know, American tourists are not affected by the shortage of bread.''
Mr. Malinin, speaking at a recent news conference in New York, also said the Soviet Government had begun allowing individual republics to develop their own tourism programs.
Local authorities will have the right to regulate travel companies in their own regions, although a joint national council will oversee local regulators.
How quickly the increased competition would bring prices down was not immediately clear.
''The more decentralization that takes place, the more prices will come down,'' said Jay Schaffer of Anniversary Tours, another American tour operator.
 
Opera Gala
A gala concert celebrating the 40th anniversary of the debut of the French opera singer Regine Crespin will be held at the old Paris Opera house, the Palais Garnier, on Oct. 8. Eighteen opera stars will take part. Tickets, from $600 to $60, are available from the Association Pour le Rayonnement de l'Opera de Paris, 8 Rue Scribe, 75009 Paris; telephone 42.66.59.79. Gala tickets, at $600 and $400, are available from American Friends of the Paris Opera and Ballet, 972 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10021; 212-439-1400.
 
How Travelers Rate Hotels
Satisfaction does not have to cost a fortune, at least when it comes to hotels, according to a survey published in the September issue of Consumer Reports magazine. In a poll of more than 100,000 readers, economy hotels, on average, rated a higher overall level of guest satisfaction than all of the moderately priced hotels and scored as well asmany higher-priced hotels.
The survey divided hotels into four categories based on price - economy, moderate, high priced and luxury - and rated them on everything from cleanliness and the quality of food to staff performance and bed comfort.
The highest marks were received in the luxury category, with Four Seasons achieving an overall satisfaction rating of 92 percent, followed by Embassy Suites with 85 percent and Inter-Continental with 83 percent. Other leaders were Residence Inn (86 percent, high-priced), Best Western (76 percent, moderate) and Hampton Inn (85 percent, economy). Poor food quality, defective climate control and the lack of helpfulness and efficiency of the staff headed the list of complaints. At the pricier hotels, almost 1 in 10 complained about excessive phone charges, while 20 percent reported some problem with checking out.
 
Jaws Clenched At Universal
It's safe to go back in the water again, but the closing of the Jaws ride at Universal Studios theme park in Orlando has disappointed visitors and riled park officials.
The ride, based on the movie in which a giant shark stalks unsuspecting boaters and swimmers, is expected to remain closed for redesigning until 1991. The park has filed a lawsuit against the ride's designer, but Universal Studios officials declined to discuss specifics of the case.
The problem with the fleet of 24-foot-long mechanical Great White Sharks that make up the ride is one of several to hit attractions at the $363 million high-tech amusement park since it opened June 7.
This summer difficulties with two other rides, Kongfrontation (in which a lifelike King Kong terrorizes riders on an aerial tram) and Earthquake, prompted park officials to issue a voucher to visitors that can be redeemed for a free admission once all the rides become fully operational. But with the park's 14 other major rides and shows functioning normally, and Kongfrontation and Earthquake now operating with the ''utmost of consistency,'' park officials expect to discontinue the free pass policy soon.
 
San Francisco Hotel Break
Holiday and business visitors looking for hotel bargains in San Francisco may wish to consult San Francisco Reservations, a three-year-old central hotel reservation service. Working with 90 percent of the hotels in the city, the company says it is able to pass on discounts of from 5 to 50 percent because of the volume of customers the service supplies.
Travelers can call the number for vacationers (800-677-1550) or business clients (800-333-8996) and tell the agent the location, price range and style of accommodations sought. The agent will try to provide a selection of at least three hotels that most closely meet these specifications.
Business travelers can receive preferred corporate rates that represent a savings of over 35 percent at some of the city's most elegant hotels, including the Four Seasons Clift, the Campton Palace and the Mark Hopkins Inter-Continental. Vacationers may be able to take advantage of reduced rates in the smaller ''boutique'' hotels that are springing uparound the city.
 
NEW BEATLES SHOW IN LIVERPOOL
The rise to fame of the Beatles is brought to life in a new exhibition, ''The Beatles Story,'' in Liverpool, the hometown of the four musicians and where the group first performed. The exhibition is housed at the re stored Albert Dock, already home to the Tate Gallery Liverpool, with its changing displays of modern art, and the Liverpool Maritime Museum.
The exhibit offers re-creations of the Cavern Club, in Liverpool, where the group performed 292 times; the Star Club in Hamburg; the record shop owned by the group's manager, Brian Epstein, and Abbey Road Studios in London.
Visitors can be taken back to the psychedelic era by boarding a yellow submarine with fish swimming past the portholes, before finding out about the breakup of the group and their solo careers. Visitors are invited to challenge the Beatlebrain computer, whose questions get progressively tougher. The exhibit is open daily. Admission is about $5.50 and $4 for children.
For fans still hungry for more information about Liverpool's most famous sons, there is a daily Magical History Tour from the tourist information center on Clayton Square. The two-hour tour, which costs $7.50, passes the hospital where John Lennon was born; the first place in which Ringo Starr played drums (also a hospital); the ornate Philharmonic public house, one of the Beatles haunts, and the Liverpool Institute, which Paul McCartney and George Harrison attended.
The tour also goes to one of John Lennon's favorite places, Strawberry Fields, a home for orphan children; and Penny Lane, with its bank and other places mentioned in the song of the same name. The Penny Lane Wine Bar has become a popular meeting place among local musicians, students and Beatle people.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 30, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 29, Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5579 words

HEADLINE: California Showdown

BYLINE: BY Robin Toner; Robin Toner is a national political correspondent for The New York Times based in Washington.

 BODY:
It is 110 degrees in Sacramento on this August afternoon, and probably hotter here on the runway of a local airport, and probably hotter still in the long-sleeved black dress that Dianne Feinstein is wearing as she paces the tarmac near her chartered plane.
The Democratic candidate for Governor of California is waiting for one last member of her entourage before her plane can take off for a fund-raising event in the hills just southwest of here. He is late. Feinstein is not a happy candidate. Her staff gives her wide berth as she stalks the tarmac, the three-inch heels of her spectator pumps crunching into the asphalt. Her husband, Richard C. Blum, tries to jolly her up. ''Cheer up,'' he says. ''I'm so hot I could die,'' she replies. She seems preoccupied, tired.
In the last three days she has denounced offshore oil drilling on the beach in Santa Barbara, questioned the Supreme Court nomination of David Souter in Los Angeles, pledged her commitment to organized labor in Ventura and asked for money almost everywhere. She needs campaign money, badly. She needs to be seen, everywhere. She needs to escalate the increasingly brutal television war against her opponent, Senator Pete Wilson. She needs to be careful not to make a mistake. 
This is her moment in history, if she can rise to it. If she wins the governorship of California this November, the 57-year-old Feinstein will, indeed, become the ''most powerful woman in politics in America,'' as one man introduced her the other day. As Mayor of San Francisco for nine years, as one of the contenders for the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination in 1984, she is already known as one of American politics' breakthrough women.
Now, in a year when many analysts were predicting that gender politics could be more powerful than ever, when Supreme Court decisions have reopened the struggle over abortion rights and, in some ways, feminized American politics, Feinstein is riding a new wave. When she talks of legalized abortion as a fundamental civil right, the women in her audiences respond with hard, disgusted little nods. ''That's right,'' they say. ''That's right.''
When she faltered early in the race for the Democratic nomination against Attorney General John K. Van de Kamp, her support among women helped pick her up. ''It gives me a resiliency and an adrenaline and a commitment that I'm even surprised at myself for having,'' she says. Even some of the feminists who found fault with her record as Mayor of San Francisco - and there were many - have swallowed hard and climbed on board.
Feinstein's critics portray her as just another politician, an opportunist trying to catch the prevailing winds of history. ''I find any number of women, including Democratic women, who say they're insulted by an appeal that says, 'I'm a woman, you're a woman, vote for me,' '' says Pete Wilson.
Already, by summer's end, she had lost some of the glamour, some of the glory of the days last spring when she crisscrossed the state with her joyous appeal to ''make history.'' Today the polls show that the race is dead even and that Feinstein's negative ratings have jumped significantly.
There are costs to being a breakthrough woman. ''The first anything in a situation is put through a whole host of litmus tests,'' Feinstein says. ''And you have a feeling, once you get there, that your back is always against the wall and people are coming at you.'' Her smooth and confident manner slips at moments like that, as it does sometimes toward the end of news conferences, when the questioning goes on a little too long and she suddenly turns skittish, defensive.
''There's always, I feel, this testing of me, this testing, testing, testing,'' she says later.
Indeed, everyone in politics is watching this race. For the two national parties, it may mean nothing less than control of the House of Representatives through the year 2000. After the 1991 redistricting, California will have a Congressional delegation of as many as 52 - by far the largest of any state - and the party that controls the governorship will have enormous influence over the makeup of that delegation.
All that aside, California is simply the biggest game around in a non-Presidential year, with 11 percent of the nation's population and the tendency of political movements, like cultural ones, to travel West to East - from tax rebellions to Reaganism to the resurgence of environmentalism. As the 1990's begin, public-opinion polls show the electorate is stirring, anxious, discontented, and the voting here in November will give the first intimations of this inchoate mood. Will Feinstein be able to capture it, to embody the yearning for change?
Coming off their third straight Presidential defeat, Democrats around the country are longing for new stars and new messages, and they see Feinstein as a comer. They gush over her telegenic presence. After watching their party devastated in the 1988 Presidential campaign over the issue of crime, some Democrats take a dirty little pleasure in her full-throated support of the death penalty. ''Tough and caring'' is her slogan, one that confronts the doubts about both women and Democrats, the doubts that show up in survey after survey: Are they tough enough to lead?
Some analysts, including Mervin Field, a veteran California poll taker, were suggesting earlier this year that the zeitgeist of the 1990's would benefit female candidates. Voters tend to associate women with certain qualities, like honesty and compassion, and certain issues, such as education and the environment, which were high on the voters' agenda for much of this year. But, with the crisis in the Persian Gulf and the effects of rising oil prices on an already strained economy, the political landscape has changed dramatically. This bodes ill for the so-called women's advantage, Field says. Moreover, for all the national hype about Feinstein, Democrats in California worry. Pete Wilson began the general election campaign with $3.9 million in the bank; Feinstein had $645,000. Wilson is solidly based in Southern California, a rich lode of votes and money; Feinstein is of the less populous North. Wilson is on his fourth statewide campaign; this is Feinstein's first outside the nurturing hills of her native San Francisco. ''Whatever you say about Pete Wilson, he's a shrewd player at this level,'' says one Democratic consultant in California. ''Dianne, we just don't know yet.''
The woman on the tarmac in Sacramento, pacing and brooding, is at the center of all of this. She has a warm manner, a bawdy laugh and an intensely intimate gaze for a politician, but at moments like this on the campaign trail she seems aloof and alone. She says she is fatalistic about politics and about life. She shrinks from any talk of ambition. But she knows the stakes, knows the moment in time on which she stands, knows how politics can open a door and just as quickly close it.
She stepped up to the moment in late November of 1978. Her husband of 16 years, Bertram Feinstein, had died of cancer in April, and Feinstein herself, having twice run for Mayor and twice been defeated, feeling burned out and ready for a change, had decided to finish up her term on the Board of Supervisors and leave politics. On Nov. 27, 1978, she told a group of reporters of her decision in the press room of City Hall. Later that morning, Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk were shot and killed. She heard the shots, raced into Milk's office just down the hall, reached for a pulse and felt only a bullet hole.
Feinstein, then president of the board, assumed the Mayor's job. The image, played over and over again in her campaign commercials this year, is almost mythic: the dark-haired woman, tall and still and strong in the center of chaos and grief, announcing the deaths, taking over, restoring order.
Can she seize the moment in 1990? She must play to the strengths that voters associate with women and ease their fears of the weaknesses. She must wage a tactically masterful campaign but try to seem more than a politician. She is riding those treacherous currents where politics and culture and what men and women think about themselves - and each other - all merge in unknowable ways.
Many Californians never expected her to get this far. She had moved quickly when Gov. George Deukmejian, the Republican incumbent, announced in January 1989 that he would not run again. But after taking an early lead in the polls over Attorney General Van de Kamp, she quickly began to fade.
By that summer, there was a buzz in political circles: Did Feinstein have the stomach for the race? Was she willing to leave the comforts of San Francisco to do the organizing and fund raising that were necessary?
Feinstein says, with a trace of bitterness, that she was ailing for much of early 1989 because of a chronic problem with fibroid tumors. She decided to have a long-delayed hysterectomy in July, which took her off the political circuit for weeks. Then, in August 1989, her campaign suffered a humiliating - some thought mortal - blow.
Clinton Reilly, her longtime consultant, quit, faxing a press release to newspapers around the state, announcing that Feinstein ''has been unwilling to commit to a schedule, an organization and a budget capable of electing her Governor.'' Feinstein says they had been quarreling for some time over the terms of Reilly's contract and over questions of control. She says she was looking for some way to end the relationship.
''Hell hath no fury like a man fired by a woman,'' Feinstein says with a small smile. Still, it was Reilly who did the firing on the front pages of newspapers around the state that August.
Reilly says he and Feinstein had a number of fundamental disagreements. ''I believed during the early stages of her campaign that she wasn't truly committed to running, but she certainly proved she was,'' Reilly said. ''The proof was in the pudding and I doff my hat to her.''
After Reilly's departure, the Feinstein campaign continued to drift. By November, she was 18 points down in the polls and widely expected to withdraw. ''We were really nowhere,'' recalls her husband, Richard Blum, a wealthy investment banker she married in 1980. ''We were not only the gang that couldn't shoot straight, we couldn't get our gun out of the holster. So I finally said, 'Do you want to run for Governor or do you want to go to Hawaii?' ''
She dug in. Equally important, she and her husband began pumping $3 million of their own money into the race. Bill Carrick, a South Carolinian seasoned by many campaigns, signed on as campaign manager, and with his partner, Hank Morris, headed to San Francisco to gather material for her first television commercial. Morris started yelling with excitement when he saw the old videotape of Feinstein taking charge after the assassinations. That footage would open the television commercial nicknamed ''the Grabber,'' the commercial that reinserted the Feinstein mystique into the consciousness of Californians, sent her soaring in the polls, and helped secure her the nomination last June.
 
Feinstein would not be the first woman to govern a state, of course; that was Nellie Tayloe Ross of Wyoming, elected to replace her dead husband in 1924. Eight other women have served as governors, five of them elected in their own right. The governorship has been one of the most difficult offices for women to break into. Many political analysts say people can accept women in legislative positions, associated with the skills of conciliation and compromise, far easier than as chief executives.
Still, the 1990 campaign has produced a significant field of female gubernatorial candidates, a reflection of the steady, step-by-step progress made by women in politics over the last 20 years. Besides Feinstein, women hold major-party nominations in Alaska, Nebraska (where Gov. Kay Orr is seeking re-election), Oregon, Kansas, Wyoming, Pennsylvania and Texas.
They are, in a way, inventing themselves, creating a tradition - an image of the female chief executive in a political culture that is still inherently male. ''We're now on our third generation of male politicians who want to be Kennedyesque - take off your coat, sling it over your shoulder, walk on the beach,'' says Ann Lewis, a longtime Democratic strategist. ''There is no comparable identity for women. We are our own role models.''
''That's the hard part,'' Feinstein says. ''I made a real effort to meet Margaret Thatcher, Indira Gandhi, Corazon Aquino - just to touch, just to sense, just to have a feeling of them.''
The Feinstein appeal is built on the premise that this candidate is different - in gender, style, philosophy. A woman urging voters to make history. A politician assailing the political establishment in Sacramento. (Even while relying on the support of Assembly Speaker Willie L. Brown Jr., a formidable power broker.) A Democrat who talks with equal gusto about the need for early childhood education and the need to execute people. A forceful woman in pastel Ultrasuede in a field of middle-aged white men in dark suits.
The day after the primary, Pete Wilson, a man repeatedly described by reporters as colorless, recognized the charisma gap and announced that in the months to come he would be ''just as charismatic as hell.''
Many politicians work a room with antiseptic handshakes and guarded eyes. Feinstein strides in, nearly six feet tall in the high heels she usually wears, beaming, leaning into people and locking eyes. A young advance man at her elbow ushers up one grinning handshaker after another. The advance man also holds the purse. ''It's kind of like training to carry the suitcase for the President,'' says Jonas Hanelin, holding a delicate gray suede number.
Feinstein is expert at creating an aura of intimacy, of emotional connection; with a reporter, she gushes out the details of her personal life as if for the first time, though clearly she has gushed out these details many times before, with the same, fresh, I-shouldn't-be-telling-you-this air.
She is an almost defiantly feminine dresser - big bows, big scarves, bright colors, jewelry. ''People always have a comment to make and it used to really bother me,'' she says. ''Your skirts are too short, your skirts are too long. Do this with your hair, do that with your hair. Your lipsticks are too dark, you shouldn't wear lipstick. ''Comments you'd never make to a man about his bald spot,'' she adds. ''No one would ever go up to a man and say, 'You should have a hair transplant.' ''
Sensitive to the criticism that her primary campaign was long on style and short on substance, she often packs her basic stump speech with a checklist of positions - the need for better toxic waste disposal in California, the dropout rate for 10th graders, the intricacies of water policy. But she adds an emotional charge with the issues of abortion and crime.
Feinstein is midway through a speech to the Los Angeles County Federation of Labor one night when she begins to recite the career of Robert Alton Harris, awaiting execution for the murder of two San Diego teen-agers. ''He blew their brains out,'' she says. ''And then he ate their hamburgers.'' The audience is in her thrall, awash in disgust and indignation, by the time she closes with a pledge: ''I feel it down to my boots: If I do nothing else, I'm going to make this a safe state.''
It is the kind of visceral message that Republicans perfected in the 1980's, different because it comes in a woman's voice, but not softened. It is the voice of a powerful and avenging mother, come to discipline, punish, restore order. The nickname within her campaign for two of the commercials where she speaks head-on to the camera is ''Church Lady I and II.''
She delivers this message almost everywhere she goes, recalling the days before drive-by killings and serial murders in California, asking a 1990's version of the old question posed by Ronald Reagan: ''Is there anyone here who feels safer in your home, in your workplace, cashing a check at a Versa-teller, than you did 10 years ago?'' The audience invariably murmurs ''no.''
Wilson is working the same political turf, a reflection of how close the two are on the hot-button issues. ''We are sick of excuses; we will not accept them,'' the Republican declared on Labor Day. ''We cannot have a California, in which we call ourselves a civilized state, where women fear the night.''
The crime issue is just part of the general frustration in California with highways that are too crowded, air and water too polluted, communities too developed, a dream that somehow went awry. ''People want to kill people because they don't want them out on the street again,'' says Pat Caddell, the longtime Democratic poll taker who has relocated to Los Angeles. ''It frustrates people beyond belief, this sense that we cannot be protected.''
Feinstein, who opposed the death penalty for years, says she changed her mind because she came to believe it was a deterrent. ''I believe you do everything you can in society to provide the carrot, the other options, and at the same time, there has to be the penalty,'' she says. ''If you play, you pay. And by your acts, you also can forfeit your life.''
Some of her critics describe her as ''pro-death,'' since she campaigns so hard for abortion rights and the death penalty. Some Democrats see Feinstein as the embodiment of a new centrism, a way of rebuilding their electoral coalition and driving cracks into the Republicans' ranks (although Pete Wilson is also a supporter of abortion rights and the death penalty). Her strategists see her place on the political spectrum as a sure path to votes. ''The only Democrat for Governor for the death penalty,'' proudly declared one of her ads during the primary. Feinstein's campaign manager, Bill Carrick, asserts: ''Pro-choice, pro-death penalty is where the voters are - as opposed to where the elites are.''
In some ways, Feinstein is a richer, more complicated figure than most career politicians. Her life defies the tidy biographies of those bright young men; it is an almost operatic mixture of tragedy and privilege, love and death.
Much of it seemed golden. Dianne Goldman came of age in Presidio Terrace, an affluent enclave of San Francisco, the eldest of three daughters of a respected physician. She had a doting uncle in the garment business, a man with a passion for politics who regularly took her to meetings of the city's Board of Supervisors. ''Her uncle Morrie would always talk about Dianne as mayor,'' recalls Morris Bernstein, president of San Francisco's Airports Commission and a longtime friend of the family. She was pretty and bright. Her father wanted her to be a doctor, but accepted the inevitable when she went off to Stanford, got a D in genetics and an A-plus in American political thought.
But there were darker currents. Her mother suffered from a chronic brain syndrome that was never diagnosed until the invention of the CAT scan, long after the children were grown. ''She was prone to great bouts of hostility, irrationality, that sometimes manifested themselves in really undeserved punishments for us,'' Feinstein says. The night before Feinstein was to take her S.A.T.'s, her mother kicked her out of the house; she had to sleep in the car.
Feinstein's mother was Russian Orthodox, her father Jewish, and she was raised in both traditions, going to Jewish services while attending high school at the Convent of the Sacred Heart. As a teen-ager, the only Jewish girl at her school, she briefly flirted with the idea of converting to Catholicism. ''My father said you are what you are and you can never change that,'' she says.
Not long after college, Feinstein married a young lawyer, Jack Berman, who is today a San Francisco Superior Court judge. They had a daughter, Katherine, but the marriage ended after three years, and Feinstein set about raising her child and pursuing her career in politics and government. She remarried, to a man named Bert Feinstein, 19 years her senior. She also ran for the Board of Supervisors and succeeded on her first try.
Feinstein is sitting in the Washington Square Bar & Grill, a San Francisco landmark, rattling off the story of her life with practiced ease until a reporter asks her about her second husband. ''Bert was - well - the sun, the moon and the stars,'' she says. She smiles brightly, then suddenly struggles for composure, loses the battle and wipes away tears.
''Let's stop one minute, alright?'' she says. ''Now you know why I don't like to do personal stuff.''
Feinstein has the psyche of a mayor - the obsession with detail, the proprietary attitude toward streets and vistas and public works. The city is full of stories about her hands-on approach: the way she habitually monitored the police radio and kept watch on the streets.
Appearances count. She made staff members start wearing suits and ties again after the laid-back administration of George Moscone. She still chides her husband, who has a long interest in the culture of the Himalayas, about the faded Tibetan prayer flags that hang off the patio of his office near the TransAmerica building; she worries that they look bad from the street, he says. Her husband compares her to a Tibetan goddess of mercy who has eight arms at work in the world; her critics might quarrel with the mercy part but not with the number of arms.
She led San Francisco during a time of extraordinary turmoil. The 1970's were the era of the Symbionese Liberation Army, the Zebra killings, Jim Jones's People's Temple. The era exploded, in a way, with the mass suicides and killings in Jonestown, Guyana, followed nine days later by the assassinations of Moscone and Milk. Feinstein took over as Mayor of a city in shock, declaring: ''I feel a very great need to heal and bind.'' She was widely given high marks for doing it.
Feinstein was clearly haunted at first by the way she had gained a job denied her twice by the voters. She says she gained new confidence after winning her first mayoral election in 1979 and surviving a recall in 1983. She was never able to sit in the chair where Moscone had been killed, ''which, for some reason, I also couldn't take out of the office, either.''
She had her share of critics as Mayor. Many faulted her for being too pro-business, too lenient with the developers who created what has been called the ''Manhattanization'' of the city. She clashed with the city's powerful gay community, vetoing a domestic partners bills that would have extended to live-in lovers the health-insurance benefits available to the spouses of city employees. Her early drive to close the bathhouses because of the AIDS epidemic earned her considerable criticism at the time, although she now cites her administrations's approach to the disease as a model.
She also antagonized some feminists, notably by vetoing an early comparable-worth measure, which was billed as correcting pay inequities for many of the city's female and minority employees. She contends frostily that it was a flawed piece of legislation that would not have achieved its intended purpose. One sign of her less-than-perfect relations with the organized feminist community could be seen in the primary, when the California chapter of the National Organization for Women was unable to reach a consensus and make an endorsement. Representative Barbara Boxer, a California Democrat, campaigned hard for Van de Kamp as ''the best feminist in the race.''
''Her record as Mayor was mixed,'' says Linda Joplin, state coordinator for NOW, which has since endorsed Feinstein in the general election. Joplin discusses Feinstein's earlier record with considerable diplomacy. ''She has come to a better understanding of some of the issues since the time she was Mayor.''
In the current campaign, the greatest vulnerability in Feinstein's record may be her handling of the city budget. She prides herself on fiscal responsibility, saying she balanced budgets and improved services during an era of extraordinary constraints because of Proposition 13, which forced down property taxes. But when Mayor Art Agnos took over in 1988, he announced he was facing a projected $172 million deficit, and he faulted Feinstein's fiscal management for helping to create it. Feinstein said that the shortfall resulted from unexpected revenue drops and cost increases and that she would have resolved it had she been in office.
The Wilson campaign clearly sees rich opportunity in the deficit issue, a chance to portray Feinstein as just another tax-and-spend Democrat who should not be trusted at the helm of a state government already buffeted by budgetary problems. ''She not only left Art Agnos with the legacy of a $172 million deficit,'' Wilson says, ''but she did it after instituting new taxes and increasing old ones.''
This fits into a broader strategic imperative: To win, analysts in both parties say, Wilson must make Feinstein look like just another politician, and just another Democratic politician to boot.
It is mid-August, midway through a month of withering crossfire between Feinstein and Wilson. Wilson runs television commercials assailing Feinstein's promise to appoint women and members of minority groups in proportion to their share of the population - just another liberal quota, the ads say. She fires back, attacking Wilson for accepting more contributions from the savings and loan industry than any other Senator.
Wilson counters with a spot that accuses her of hypocrisy, charging that she and her husband ''own'' a savings and loan that received a healthy Federal bailout. She fumes that her husband owns less than 1 percent of the institution and that she owns none of it.
The polls show the race is neck and neck, and the negatives for both candidates are climbing. Feinstein keeps a note in her office from Ann Richards, the Democratic nominee for Governor in Texas, advising her not to watch television or read the newspapers in the heat of the campaign.
The Wilson camp is closely watching her reactions. ''You get a sense of a very defensive person who can be prone to make mistakes,'' says Don Sipple, Wilson's media consultant. ''There is this whole pattern of reacting, and from our standpoint, that ain't all bad.''
There should be no shortage of issues for debate in the Governor's race, many political observers say. California has serious budget problems, is struggling with the fallout from rapid growth and a growing strain on its environment and schools. But both candidates are trying to hug the center. The remarkably personal tone of the campaign thus far reflects the absence of great ideological differences between the two. Indeed, they often seem to be arguing over degree: Who is more supportive of abortion rights? Who is more committed to the death penalty? Who has a stronger record on the environment?
Feinstein needs to hold the traditional Democratic base, to come up with strong showings in the San Francisco Bay Area and Los Angeles County. She also needs to reach out to the more conservative voters of the Central Valley, a heavily agricultural area where she could be hurt by her support for the ''Big Green'' environmental initiative, which restricts the use of pesticides. (Wilson opposes the initiative, saying its creation of an independent environment czar would undercut the power of the governor.) And she needs to hold down the expected big margins for Wilson in such Republican strongholds as Orange and San Diego Counties.
After Feinstein won by a commanding 11 points in the primary, John Van de Kamp, who had considerable support among party regulars, as well as organized labor, moved quickly to embrace her candidacy and unite the party. Her longtime friendship with the powerful Assembly Speaker, Willie Brown, who is from San Francisco, is another key alliance for her, and there is already some speculation about how much influence Brown will wield in a Feinstein administration. But Feinstein is still considered something of an outsider in state political circles. ''She's not one of my favorite people, but I have great respect for her,'' said one powerful California Democrat. Said another: ''She can be very demanding and fairly dogmatic.''
All of this has been overshadowed, however, in the fierce thrust and parry of the campaign so far, the whip-saw exchange of charge and countercharge. As the questions and controversies mount over the finances of her husband, Richard Blum, Feinstein shows the strain. She holds a news conference in Los Angeles to accept the endorsement of the California Association of Highway Patrolmen; almost all of the questions are about savings and loans and whether her husband shouldn't provide more information on his holdings, or even put them in a blind trust.
''I am very proud of my husband,'' she says, a very hard edge in her voice. She grows increasingly testy as the news conference continues. Her aides watch nervously, wincing as she once again mistakes the female reporter from The San Francisco Chronicle for the female reporter from The Los Angeles Times. Later, in the car, Feinstein seems angry and rattled. ''Technically, no woman married to an investment banker then could ever be in public life,'' she says. ''This is all his business. I have nothing to do with it. It's his - and it was before we were married. A woman marries a man as she finds him.''
The husband issue is one of the givens for female candidates in the post-Ferraro era; it gains a particular edge in the Feinstein race because she and her husband have loaned so much of their own money into her campaign. (The two of them reported income of $7.4 million last year.) ''It would be totally unimportant except for the fact that he's put $3 million into her campaign in the primary,'' says Wilson.
Sitting in his office in San Francisco's financial district one afternoon, Blum says: ''I'd love to debate Pete Wilson, I'd love to have him, one on one, going through these charges. Clearly there's a strategy here that's really basically pretty sexist. It's sort of implicit that somehow the woman can't be doing all this by herself.''
Blum, who married Feinstein when she was already Mayor, when she was widowed and he was divorced, is passionately devoted to her career. By the end of August, after considerable resistance, he would release his firm's client list, which the Wilson campaign had been demanding. The scrutiny of Blum's finances only grows through September. In 1984, when Feinstein was under consideration for the Vice Presidential slot, Blum went through an extensive review of his records with Walter Mondale's investigators, and he still bristles at the rumors that there was something in his finances that might have cost her the place on the ticket - rumors that Mondale says are totally unfounded.
On this day, Blum was trying hard to be philosphical, sitting there in his office decorated with a huge oil painting of the Tibetan Wheel of Life. But there was a distinctly non-Zen-like feeling in the room. ''I'm kind of going through the triathlon of politics,'' he said. ''No. 1, we get to see on a regular basis everything she's ever done and I've ever done distorted in the newspapers. No. 2, we get to share 17 years of our tax returns on an intimate basis with 30 million people. And three, I get to pay to watch all this happen.''
He started to laugh, ''You gotta say, why are they doing this?''
Maybe part of it is this: There is no headier moment in politics than when a candidate transcends his or her foibles, failings and ego needs and comes to stand for something larger. It happened in the summer of 1983, when the Rev. Jesse Jackson was first floating the idea of a run for the Presidency, and traveled the black churches of the Mississippi Delta preaching a politics of possibilities. It happened in the summer of 1984, when Geraldine Ferraro first took the stage of the Democratic National Convention in San Francisco. And it happens, sometimes, when Dianne Feinstein connects with her audience.
There are women - like Dorene Gee, a preschool teacher in Salinas, and Bernice Boyd, a military retiree in Seaside - who look at Feinstein and see a reflection of their own struggles, their own lives. The connection brings an element of magic to Feinstein's candidacy, but also an element of risk: the possibility of disillusionment. Is she really big enough, good enough, for the moment? Is she really different?
If she wins the governorship, ''the day after the election she'll be on the front page of every newspaper and every magazine, and she is automatically considered at that point part of the Democratic ticket'' in 1992, asserted one California Democratic politician. If she loses, there would be other political options open to her; she is, after all, only 57. But whether another moment will come that could catapult her so far, so fast, is probably unlikely.
In the meantime, in the vaporous realm of public attitudes and beliefs, she is helping to invent something new: This is what a powerful woman running for Governor of the biggest state in the union looks like. This is how she talks. This is how she wants to be perceived: tough and caring. In a campaign carefully scripted by consultants, that was a phrase that was written by the candidate herself.

LENGTH: 777 words

HEADLINE: Design;
COMING OF AGE

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:
Last year, it was the new kid on the block. This year, the International Antique Dealers Show is seen as the first indicator of the direction that the art market will take. Although only in its second year, the show has fast eclipsed all the other American antiques events with its seriousness and its outstanding quality of offerings.
Indeed, when the doors to the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue and 67th Street open for a round of preview parties this Friday night, some of the world's finest antiques will be on view. And some of the most expensive. For the average consumer, this is not a place to bargain-hunt; rather, it should be seen as a museum, a place to look and learn and meet some of the leading antiques experts. 
''It's a show designed for serious collectors,'' says Stephen Burton, who runs Young & Stephens, the London-based specialists in antique jewelry. ''Everything here is of the highest quality.'' Most dealers spend months scouring private collections and auction houses around the world looking for exemplary objects.
''It's crucial that we offer collectors surprises, objects that haven't been on the market for years,'' says Khalil Rizk, a co-owner of the New York-based Chinese Porcelain Company. And like at the European antiques shows, the objects are vetted for authenticity by a committee composed of curators, scholars and dealers.
The result is a collection of the top dealers' most prized possessions. Rizk, for example, will be showing a pair of Chinese export porcelain soup tureens in the form of geese. ''They would be the crowning glory of any major export porcelain collection,'' he says. ''You can't find anything better.'' Axel Vervoordt, a dealer from Antwerp, Belgium, will transform his booth into a collector's den to display an amazing mixture of objects. ''There will be all kinds of things from rare silver to unusual furniture, and even an early 16th-century statue,'' says Vervoordt.
Often these dealers spin quite elaborate tales about their objects. Vervoordt will be featuring a pair of rare porphyry vases that he says he believes were made for the Duke of Nemours and intended for the Palace of Versailles. A George IV silver gilt presentation cup and cover, made by Robert Hennell in London in 1824, will be prominently displayed by ADC Heritage, which has galleries in New York City and London. An inscription on the cover reads: ''Presented to the Highland Society of London by Colonel James Hamilton, of the Order of Liberators of Venezuela, One of the Vice Presidents of the Society, to Commemorate . . . his return to his Native Country after an absence of Seven Years . . .''. ''It's one of those extraordinary decorative objects,'' says Francis Raeymaekers, the gallery's owner. ''I would love it to end up in a museum.''
Ariane Dandois, the owner of a Parisian gallery that bears her name, is showing a German mahogany desk dated 1795. ''I bought the desk in London,'' says Dandois. ''Often I find the best pieces out of their country of origin. The owners of the grand houses, say, in England or France, which had the most beautiful furniture and objects, brought back things from all over the world. And they've been kept in the same family for hundreds of years.''
Such rarities come with staggering price tags, something that none of the dealers dispute. Many worry just how the show will fare this fall, given the softening auction prices last spring and the precarious economic climate in the country. ''There are a lot of gray clouds hanging over this show,'' says Herve Aaron, who runs the New York branch of Didier Aaron. ''But our business is peculiar. It doesn't always repond the way the rest of the economy does.'' According to Garrick Stephenson, who owns a gallery in New York: ''The massive spending spree of the 1980's is over. The attitude is very different right now - it's far more conservative. Certainly we won't see an avalanche of buying.''
Not everyone agrees. ''Collecting art is a kind of disease - once you have it, it's for life,'' says Dandois. ''My clients are highly sophisticated, and they know when a piece is too rare to pass up.'' According to Peter L. Schaffer, a co-owner of the Fifth Avenue gallery A La Vieille Russie: ''The boom is not over. Certainly there is a shakedown, which is long overdue. But people are finally realizing that buying art should not be just for investment purposes.''
Doris Leslie Blau, an antique-rug specialist, sees today's market in spiritual terms. ''We show fantasy, and fantasy sells, no matter what the world conditions,'' she says. ''It helps block out the harsh realities surrounding our lives.''
