HEADLINE: How the Spin Doctors Operate

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS LEMANN; Nicholas Lemann is a national correspondent for The Atlantic.

 BODY:

ROAD SHOW
In America, Anyone Can Become President.
It's One of the Risks We Take.
By Roger Simon.
356 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.
Most Presidential campaign books fall into one of two lines of descent: they are the offspring either of Theodore H. White's ''Making of the President 1960'' and its successors, or of Joe McGinniss's ''Selling of the President.'' White's books were serious, comprehensive, grand and elaborately respectful of both democracy and authority in America - the work of a man who cut his teeth at Time Inc. in its American Century days. Mr. McGinniss's book, in title and spirit explicitly a rebellion against the White approach, was cynical, very tightly focused on the world of political advertising and written mostly in dialogue and deadpan narration. 
Roger Simon's ''Road Show'' is much closer in spirit to Joe McGinniss than to Theodore H. White. Mr. Simon writes from the perspective of a front-line journalistic foot soldier in the long slog from the Iowa caucuses to Election Day: he is amiable but not ingenuous, he does not treat the question of which of the 1988 candidates will become President as a matter of the utmost gravity, and he concentrates on the texture of daily life in the campaign rather than pulling back to survey the national landscape.
Mr. Simon probably didn't have to agonize much over whether or not to take this approach - it is the natural outgrowth of his work as a columnist for The Baltimore Sun - but if it was a conscious decision, it was a smart one. In an age when Presidential campaigns are so intensively covered by the daily press that it may be impossible for a book writer to come up with something truly revelatory, Mr. Simon's technique is low-risk. Like a candidate who has artfully lowered expectations before a primary, he suffers no penalty for not having produced a sensational blockbuster, and he wins our admiration for whatever nuggets he manages to extract from this already much-mined story.
And there are nuggets. The one that will attract the most attention is an interview with a former mistress of Gary Hart's, in which she gives a detailed account of their affair, which took place just before Mr. Hart's involvement with Donna Rice. Since the woman is unnamed and Mr. Hart is now a private citizen, there will be much for journalistic ethicists to chew over here, but her story is irresistibly fascinating as a look at Gary Hart in action, so to speak, and at the heretofore insufficiently explored question of how these things are managed logistically in official Washington. Mr. Simon has also got meaty postgame interviews with Vice President Dan Quayle, Jesse Jackson and the Republican campaign strategists Lee Atwater and Roger Ailes, and he achieves some McGinniss-like effects by following around a television producer named Warren Steibel as he films Republican candidates' self-introductions to be broadcast before a primary debate. Another interesting detail is that after the election, President Bush took Bernard Shaw, the Cable News Network anchorman whose opening question in the fall campaign's second debate threw Michael Dukakis off, out to dinner and offered him a job (Mr. Shaw turned it down).
With every major figure he discusses - Mr. Jackson, Mr. Quayle, Mr. Bush, Mr. Dukakis, Albert Gore, Robert Dole and Alexander Haig - Mr. Simon manages to come up with some bit of material, some nuance, that provides at least a hint of what is behind the facade. Mr. Bush likes to tell dirty jokes, is driven to a state of what seems to be genuine despair by the application to him of the word ''wimp'' and can be instantly made to abandon his usual niceness by the suggestion that he is being unfairly attacked, or that he might lose some kind of competition. Mr. Dukakis is a cold fish who is so unwilling to listen to advice that his aides stopped trying to give him any. Mr. Quayle has a bedrock sense of entitlement that leads him to speak about everybody, including George Bush, in an unconsciously patronizing tone. Mr. Jackson, the candidate who spent the most time with Mr. Simon, comes across as a far more attractive figure than the press usually makes him out to be - smart, funny and possessed of a sure political vision, though also in the grip of a perpetual feeling of having been slighted.
These are only glimpses, though. For the most part, ''Road Show'' is about the increasingly bizarre campaign subculture, in which, by now, everything revolves around the conventions of television coverage, and hired image consultants, rather than the candidates themselves, are the true primary objects of the print reporters' journalistic energies. Mr. Simon himself ruefully admits at one point, ''As the candidates retreated farther and farther away from the press, the role of the handlers became more visible. The handlers were the guys who talked to the reporters. And reporters write about the people they talk to.''
Reporters who are self-possessed enough not to discuss the handlers in tones of utter breathlessness tend to strike a delicate balance in writing about them: disapproving of the state of Presidential campaigns in general but admiring of the handler's exploits in particular. This is what Mr. Simon does. Roger Ailes claims credit here for all of Mr. Bush's best bons mots and artfully distances himself from his most famous former client, Richard Nixon; even Mr. Ailes's I'm-an-obnoxious-jerk persona seems designed to attract future business from politicians who know they won't have to worry about his pulling punches or secretly favoring reporters over the people who pay his fees.
The most optimistic thought about the campaign system that comes to mind from Mr. Simon's description of it is that we might be in a temporary crisis that exists because most of the people now of Presidential-candidate age are too old to have learned their political skills in the television era. That's why they need so much handling - in the pages of ''Road Show,'' it's continually striking how bad most of them are at campaigning in the modern manner. There doesn't seem to be a chance that television will stop dominating Presidential politics; the best we can hope for is that aspiring politicians of the future will learn to master television fairly effortlessly as part of their early training, in the same way that politicians of Abraham Lincoln's generation all had to learn how to perform the unnatural act of speaking from lecterns for hours on end in stentorian tones and flowery phrases. That way voters could pick among several equally television-adept candidates who don't need constant coaching about how to interact with the camera.
If that day ever comes, it will become possible for campaign reporters to pull back a little from the daily minuet of the strategists. The dramatic events of the 1988 campaign - among them the withdrawals of Gary Hart, Joseph Biden and John Sasso, Mr. Dukakis's campaign manager - all transfixed the country as they unfolded, but they were so extensively chronicled, and so quickly forgotten, that when recounted two years after the fact they have an old and trivial feeling. Mr. Simon's achievement is akin to that of the wildcatter who drills one last producing well in a field everybody thought was dried up: it's amazing that he got a good book out of the quotidian reality of the Presidential election, but it's doubtful that there is a lot more great material for future authors.
Next time around, we might be due for a revival of the Theodore H. White tradition - a book that uses the Presidential campaign as an excuse to discuss the life of the United States in an election year, and that makes it clear which great economic interests, regions, ethnic groups, social classes and ideas were playing out their struggles through the thrust and parry of the race. The 1988 campaign, for example, plainly took place in the shadow of the Reagan era, with its economic ups and downs, its tax cuts, its aggressive conservatism and its racial tensions all strongly asserting themselves. Toward the end of ''Road Show,'' Mr. Simon writes, by way of criticizing Mr. Dukakis, ''Presidential elections aren't about competence or about ideology. They are about campaigning.'' The truth is that they're about much more.

HEADLINE: About Cars;
Will Saturn Weather Geo's Storm?

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
It will be interesting to see what happens when General Motors finally gives birth to its new baby, the Saturn. Will buyers flock to ooh and ahh. To coo, perhaps to buy?
The product of the new corporation, five years or more in gestation, will make its debut Oct. 11, and those who have driven it say it has the heft and buzz of . . . well, of a Japanese car. 
That, of course, has been the point all along. Build an automobile that will push the invaders back to the sea by using their own wonderful tricks. General Motors has tried it over and over, without great success. But maybe - just maybe - the All-American product of Spring Hill, Tenn., will be a winner.
In the long meanwhile, however, G.M. has played out the same battle strategy as the rest of Detroit, putting its nameplates on small Japanese cars and selling them as its own. Decrying the aliens from one side of its mouth while touting them from the other.
There is really nothing wrong with that, because it has worked. But now there is the infant Saturn, and it is said to look like nothing so much as an Isuzu Impulse. And that is probably O.K., too. The Impulse, built by G.M.'s longtime affiliate in Fujisawa, Japan, is the latest addition to Chevrolet's Geo line, disguised by the nameplate that dubs it a Geo Storm.
Geo came into being in 1989 as Chevy's ''international vehicle line,'' and it now has more than 4,000 dealers across the country, selling four models: Tracker, Metro, Prizm and Storm, the latter replacing a car that had been called Spectrum.
For 1991, the front-wheel-drive Storm is the big news, and it comes as a hatchback coupe, a two-plus-two, and a sports model called GSi.
Base or sporty, though, the car is sleek, with aerodynamic lines, flush glass and little details such as hidden door handles that give it a wind-cheating .31 coefficient of drag. The body is very short, with almost no overhang behind the rear wheels, a design aspect that translates into further efficiency when you are looking for a place to park.
The tester was a GSi in ''flash yellow,'' a color bright enough to make the car all but throb, and the top-of-the-line coupe adds a more potent engine, power brakes, fatter tires on 15-inch wheels, a molded-in spoiler on the hatch, foglamps and other amenities.
At the stern, lights and dark glass span the little boat's transom, and the hatch button raises the glass on gas struts. One problem is the waist-high liftover, but the rudimentary rear seat does fold down, allowing added cargo space between the intrusive wheelwells.
The interior's swoop matches that of the exterior, with door panels and armrests flowing in a series of structural curves. With this car, in fact, curves are the order of the day, and the whole thing adds up to a rather pleasant space capsule.
The front buckets, upholstered in cloth, are molded and smooth, with little fussiness. The instrument panel juts out on a pod and contains full gauges, including a 9,000-r.p.m. tachometer and a 120-m.p.h. speedometer. There are the usual useful bins, a holder for toll change and a glovebox that is surprisingly large in such a compact car.
Residing in the hub of the wheel is an air bag, and that allows manual seat belts, far better than the mechanized shoulder monsters that choke you, startle your passengers, and lull you into forgetting to buckle the necessary lap belt.
While the base coupe carries a 95-horsepower 1.6-liter four with 12 valves and a single camshaft, the GSi's engine has 16 valves driven by twin cams, and it puts out 130 horses. A five-speed manual transmission is standard, and an electronic four-speed automatic can be had for an extra $700 and change.
The engine, while less muscular than the turbo version that is available in the Isuzu Impulse, is certainly adequate, and the 2,371-pound GSi accelerates strongly, doing zero-to-60 in a bit more than nine seconds and cruising easily at speeds that will get the driver unwelcome notice.
There is handling to match the performance and, despite it all, the Storm manages to pull good economy out of its 12.4-gallon tank. With the smaller engine and manual transmission, mileage ranges from 30, city, to 36, highway, and the GSi's figures are 25 and 33.
As usual, the figures are lower with the automatic, but they are still quite good for a car that wraps up so much fun with a bit of utility in a package that is both small and inexpensive. The base two-plus-two has a sticker of $10,670, and the GSi starts at $12,395.
The Saturn is going to have to be a very good car indeed.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1026 words

HEADLINE: In the Region: New Jersey;
JUMP Program Aids Low-Cost Rentals By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
Even during the construction boom of the mid-80's, new rental projects in the state were rare. Now two New Jersey developers and one from Manhattan are building rental housing under a state program meant to produce urban units for low-income families.
The three projects will create a total of 231 new and rehabilitated apartments in Newark, Hoboken and Carteret - 51 of them for low-income tenants.
The projects will be among the first to be realized under the state program, Jersey Urban Multifamily Production Program, known as JUMP. Since JUMP began two years ago the state has committed $18 million to nine projects totaling 623 rentals. 
Developers in the program must agree to set aside for 15 years at least 20 percent of the units for low-income families - those earning no more than 50 percent of the county median income - with a rent cap of 30 percent of income.
In Middlesex County, for example, a family of four earning no more than $24,500 would qualify for a low-income unit and pay about $600 a month.
In exchange, said William Rainwater, who supervises the program for the Division of Housing in the State Department of Community Affairs, the state provides an annual operating loan at 1 percent interest to keep the building from going into the red. The loan decreases each year, for a maximium of 15 years, until the building is self-sufficient.
Once having received a JUMP loan to get a project started, Mr. Rainwater said, developers apply for 30-year, tax-exempt mortgages from the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency. In addition, by meeting JUMP's rules, developers can apply for Federal housing tax credits, which reduce the taxes a developer would pay on his profits over a 10-year period. The credits may be sold to investors.
Of the three developments under way, the largest, costing $21.75 million, is in Hoboken. There, Applied Development Associates is erecting a 12-story rental building with 150 units that is expected to be completed by December 1991. Hoboken officials view the project, Hudson Square North, as an opportunity to provide much-needed affordable housing in the mile-square city. The JUMP loan totals $3.7 million.
Joseph Barry, president of Applied Development, said the project is also benefiting from a $2 million Federal Urban Development Action grant. And the company is selling housing tax credits to Boston Financial Group, a syndicate.
The 30 one- to three-bedroom, low-income units will rent for $300 to $500 a month and, to comply with a city requirement, will remain affordable, relative to the cost of living, for 40 years. The anticipated market-rate rents will fall between $875 and $1,650.
Albert Alpert and Sons, a Manhattan development company, is taking advantage of a $1.7 million loan from the program to rehabilitate a vacant building on Elizabeth Avenue in Newark's South Ward, with completion expected next spring. Of the 49 one- to three-bedroom rental apartments to be created, 10 will be for low-income families. Market-rate rents are expected to range from $625 to $775. Joseph Alpert, the project manager, said the state funds ''limited the risks'' and made rentals economically feasible.
In Carteret, two private developers who got $900,000 from JUMP plan to remodel and put an addition on a vacant school at Pershing and Pulaski Avenues, creating 32 apartments at a cost of $2.7 million.
The project, being developed by Frank Raiae and Anthony Sirignano, also received a $950,000 grant from the Middlesex County Housing and Community Development Agency as well as a tax abatement from the borough, which effectively halves the real estate taxes on the property.
Mayor Peter Sica said that for Carteret, which has few rentals, the project ''will help keep families in the community who otherwise could not afford to stay.'' He said it also puts fallow property to use and brings in tax revenue.
Eleven of the one- and two-bedroom units will be reserved for low-income families. The rest will be $600 to $675 a month. Mr. Raia said construction is expected to begin soon and the project to be completed a year later.
The need for rental apartments has been mounting in New Jersey, and the Department of Community Affairs estimates that 70,000 affordable rental units are needed.
One reason for the shortage, many state officials say, is that over the last decade some 70,000 apartments were converted into condominiums or co-ops. Also, the scarcity and rising cost of land, changes in the Federal tax law and rent-control ordinances - in effect since 1973 - have thwarted the production of apartments.
New Jersey started a limited number of programs to spur rental housing. But those, like JUMP, that have counted on state appropriations, have been suspended as the administration of Gov. Jim Florio seeks to balance the budget.
Funds were not set aside in this year's budget for JUMP, and the long-term future of the program is uncertain.
''It's impossible to talk about affordable rentals without Federal or state subsidies,'' said Jacque Eaker, executive vice president of the New Jersey Council of the Multifamily Industry.
''The demand for such housing is great,'' he said. ''It is not the place to attempt to balance the budget.''
Charles Richman, assistant commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs, said that ''the creation of affordable rentals is a state priority'' and that if the JUMP program ceases the concept of rental subsidies is not dead.
He and other state leaders are pinning their hope on a $135 million affordable- housing bond issue that New Jersey residents will vote on in November. Several components of the bond issue set aside funds for rental apartments.
There is also the state's four-year-old Balanced Housing Program, which relies on the realty transfer tax for financing and therefore was not dropped.
But the program has been affected by the soft real estate market. This year's pool of money is about $19 million, said Mr. Richman. For now, the $18 million committed to JUMP is safe.
Mr. Rainwater said he expects six other projects financed under the program to go into construction next year.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2298 words

HEADLINE: New Housing Outlook For New York Is Gloomy

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Production of new housing in New York City rode a strong economy to a 14-year high last year, but the good news for a housing-starved city will probably not last long. Developers say that with inventories of market-rate housing high and buyers scarce, the city's private home-building sector will soon be as quiet as a vacant apartment.
Instead of building, the city's traditional housing developers say, they are sitting tight or looking for projects in other states until demand catches up with the supply of market-rate housing.
''For the first time since we went into business, we're looking at other parts of the country,'' said Donald Zucker, head of the Zucker Organization, which has built about 3,000 new apartments in the city in the last decade. ''I don't know anyone who is going ahead with new private construction projects in Manhattan. It's going to be a very quiet year next year from everyone's point of view.'' 
Mr. Zucker and other developers reported that the best investment today was in rental buildings, where demand has probably been increased by reluctant buyers looking for a place to live until the outlook for the sales market clears.
According to a recent report of the Department of City Planning, 14,680 new units were built last year, up from 1988's 13,222 and the highest number since 1976, when the 23,917 new housing units were completed. Last year was also the fourth in a row to show an increase in production.
Manhattan was the biggest winner, followed by Queens, Staten Island and Brooklyn. The Bronx was the only borough in which new-housing production declined from the year before.
All but a handful of last year's housing completions were privately built market-rate housing, and experts say that slow housing development rates at the top of the market translate into less choice and higher prices for everyone.
Looking ahead, Yale Robbins - the real estate research, consulting and publishing concern whose reports on apartments sales prices are widely followed in the industry - reports that 2,501 privately built apartments are scheduled for completion in Manhattan this year, 2,507 next year and 604 in 1992. Manhattan was the only borough for which the company could gather figures, but as the bellwether for the city's housing market, its trend should match the rest of the city's, said Henry Robbins, the president.
The current issue of the Yale Robbins Guide to Construction Activity projected that besides the new market-rate housing production through 1992, there would be 2,674 privately financed renovated units and 5,678 subsidized new or renovated units completed in Manhattan. Most of the latter, it reported, would be under the city's ambitious 10-year plan to produce 83,000 new or renovated housing units for poor and middle-income tenants. In addition, it projected new financing or moderate rehabilitation for 140,000 additional units under the ten year plan.
An analysis by the Real Estate Board of New York of new housing permit applications seems to support the Yale Robbins figures and the city Planning Department's projections for lower housing growth in the city.
Although different from the Planning Department figures, which are based on the number of certificates of occupancy issued, the board's figures project falling completions in Manhattan over the next few years. From 5,924 units in 49 projects counted for 1989, the board projects completions of 2,879 units in 41 projects this year, 4107 units in 27 projects in 1991 and 2,104 units in 16 projects in 1992.
The Planning Department acknowledges that the city is not likely to see last year's level of housing production again soon.
''The city's economy has been depressed by cutbacks in manufacturing and financial services employment and a higher general unemployment rate,'' the department declared in its housing report. ''Realtors report that prices have fallen and that vacancies have risen in new luxury housing. New construction in 1990 is therefore unlikely to match recent levels.''
While encouraging, last year's level of construction was modest by past standards. In the 60's, spurred by government programs, the city averaged 38,000 new housing units a year; in the 70's this dropped to 16,500, a level considered all but catastrophic at the time, but good by today's standards.
By far the largest city in the country, New York now ranks 26th among cities in the number of new housing permits issued in the first six months of this year, behind such cities as Portland, Ore., Columbus, Ohio, and Baltimore, according to the Census Bureau. When ranked by housing permits per 1,000 population, the city is tied for last place with San Antonio among the 53 largest cities.
Housing experts are disheartened by the building of so few units in so large a city.
''This is one of the final nails in the coffin,'' said Peter Salins, chairman of the department of urban affairs and planning at Hunter College, ''because when you have a slowdown in production for the middle class, in the long run that means less choice and lower quality and higher prices for the poor.''
In the mid-80's, market-rate apartment construction in Manhattan was spurred by the 421a program, which granted builders 10-year tax abatements on new housing. The program expired late in 1985 in Manhattan for projects built south of 96th Street. Since then, builders have been able to get the abatements for projects below 96th Street only by investing in other developers' low-cost housing in the city and transferring the tax incentives to their market-rate projects.
But the drop in demand for market-rate housing has also dried up interest in such credit exchanges.
Several Manhattan builders have called for a renewal of the tax-abatement program for projects south of 96th Street as an antidote to the slack construction market.
Builders in New York City tend to specialize in geographic and market segments of the industry, and each has its reason for caution in today's market. But they seem to agree that prices for new housing have grown beyond the reach of too many New Yorkers.
At best, they say, several years will have to pass before the current supply of expensive and unsold apartments is absorbed, while at worst, the high housing prices will drive people away and leave the city with a smaller cohort ofstable middle class families.
''My biggest concern is that if we don't construct more housing, we are not going to have low-priced housing, by simple supply and demand,'' said Arthur Zeckendorf, a managing partner in the Zeckendorf Company, one of the city's oldest and best-known developers. ''At some point, demand is going to pick up, and then we will not be competitive with other areas.''
Without a new supply of housing to meet the demand, he said, prices will rise and the city's workforce will be forced out of the city.
''Exxon or Mobil or Penney's only pay their guys $50,000, and you cannot buy a place in a decent neighborhood with that,'' Mr. Zeckendorf said. ''So they move out, and that means less advertising, fewer newspapers, less work for developers.''
The Zeckendorfs' latest project nearing completion, the 202-unit Alexandria condominium at 72d Street and Broadway, has fared well in this market, the builder said. About 45 percent of the apartments have been sold since pre-completion sales began last spring, but at prices far beyond the average middle-manager's salary. Apartments are selling for about $430 a square foot - about $330,000 for a one-bedroom unit.
South of there, the 347-unit Three Lincoln Center development reported 80 apartments sold so far, with occupancy scheduled for November. The project, put up by the Stillman Group, is selling at about $660 a square foot, the developers said.
Some builders also reveal that they are having greater difficulties than ever before in getting construction loans, part of a credit squeeze that has put house building nationwide into six months of falling production.
''The reason you're not going to see a lot of new housing activity is that the banks have gone out of the business,'' said Dan Brodsky, a builder on Manhattan's West Side. ''You can't get a construction loan from a U.S. bank, or if you can, the terms are so onerous you can't do it. I don't think in the year 1990 all of the big banks in New York have made more than a half-dozen construction loans among them.''
Mr. Brodsky is currently building a new multi purpose commercial, institutional and rental apartment tower at 200 West 60th street. Besides the retail space on the lower floors, it will contain 132 units for St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital staff members, and, above them, 250 rental units ranging in size from studios to three bedroom apartments.
The project is being built with a construction loan that Mr. Brodsky lined up several years ago. ''I don't we could get the money today to build anything like it,'' he said.
Apartment developers guard their inventory carefully, but falling sales prices speak of plentiful demand.
''Everybody's looking for buyers,'' said Mr. Robbins, head of Yale Robbins, whose figures show what the city cocktail chatter has been reporting for months: the fewer the rooms, the greater the loss in value in today's market. Average prices per square foot for studio apartments dropped from $340 to $270 from July of last year to June of this year, he reported, while prices for one-bedroom apartments in his sample declined from from $370 to $350.
Robert Esnard, a deputy mayor in Edward I. Koch's administration and now vice president of the Zucker Organization, explained that single men and women, who might normally buy a small apartment, have either left the city or are renting, while families, especially those with children, will continue to buy because most prefer to own a home.
''The $40,000, $50,000 yuppies don't exist anymore the way they did,'' he said, ''but the family needs of middle- and upper-income people are still there.''
According to the Planning Department's housing production figures, Manhattan remained the center of new-housing construction in the city, with 5,979 units - 40 percent of the total - completed last year. Most new housing was built south of 96th Street, with a heavy concentration in Murray Hill, where Mr. Zucker has been active, the Upper East and West Sides, Chelsea and Chinatown and Little Italy.
Queens, with its appeal to small-lot builders, its relatively low density and its attraction to thrifty, hard-working immigrant families, came in second in new housing production, with 3,555 units completed last year, a 69 percent increase over the previous year.
Staten Island, the only city housing market where one-family homes still dominate the construction scene, was third in housing production, with 2,201 new units, about half of them on the island's southern end.
Brooklyn reported 2,098 new homes completed last year, a 28 percent increase over the year before. About 39 percent were in the downtown, East New York and Fort Greene areas, with the rest scattered evenly throughout the remainder of the borough.
The Bronx, the only borough to report a decline in housing production, went from 1,248 units in 1988 to 847 last year. About half were built in the West Farms and Eastchester sections.
The Real Estate Board's comparison of housing construction permits for the first halves of 1989 and 90 indicate that the building slowdown forecast for the coming years has already started. In the first half of last year, developers applied to build 7,706 units in 3,207 projects, the large number of projects reflecting the popularity of two- , three- and four-unit projects outside Manhattan.
In the absence of a strong sales market, some condominium and co-op builders have resorted to renting their space, recalling the wry adage that a long-term investment is only a short-term speculation that did not pan out.
This strategy allows builders to retain the expected increase in value of their apartments, and cash in by converting them into cooperatives or condominiumks at the right moment. The Boulevard, a new co-op at 2373 Broadway, at 87th street started accepting rentals to fill unsold apartments, and in Queens, dozens of two- , three- and four-family projects are being rented rather than sold.
For small builders, an inability to sell translates into an inability to build further.
''In terms of taking your investment and turning it back into more housing, it's hard to do if you're stuck with a rental,'' said a Manhattan architect who works mainly with a small Queens builder, and who asked that he not be identified.
''Most of these small builders do a project at a time and take the money and do another one,'' he went on. ''But if they can't sell, they have to stop producing.''
Some builders think renting is the best strategy in a soft sales market anyway.
''The rental market is strong,'' said Mr. Brodsky, the West Side builder. ''Maybe more people are renting because they're afraid to buy, so they rent and wait to see what happens to the market.''
Mr. Brodsky built the 31-story condominium at 45 West 67th Street, at the corner of Columbus, a few years ago and made a discovery about the sales.
''The sales market is very dependent on the timing of when you come out,'' he said, ''which is something that you cannot control. The rental housing market is not so specific. You have more time to make your money.'' Mr. Zucker says he is glad to be back in the rental business. ''I hate sales,'' he declared.
What about his condominium at 30 East 85th Street, on the corner of Madison - a select Manhattan address if ever there was one?
''I only do it because the market makes me do it,'' he said. ''But I'd rather own what I build.''

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY GUIDE

 BODY:

 
P. D. Q. BACH
P. D. Q. Bach, who has announced that his current concert tour will be his last, will be on stage at the Jewish Community Center in West Orange next Sunday, spoofing serious music as irreverently as ever.
The purported prodigal, and youngest, son of Johann Sebastian Bach, he is also known as Prof. Peter Schickele, a composer of more than 100 pieces of bona fide serious music who has won recognition in his own right.
The invented Bach is a hard act to follow, however. ''P.D.Q. Bach: 1712 Overture and Other Musical Assaults,'' a debut album, won the Grammy in 1989 for best comedy recording of the year, and a new album is out with obviously immortal pieces like ''Oedipus Tex,'' ''Classical Rap'' and ''Birthday Ode to Big Daddy Bach.''
In addition, P. D. Q. Bach has appeared on many television shows, and Professor Schickele has written ''The Definitive Biography of P.D.Q. Bach,'' published by Random House. 
Those assisting the classical music satirist in the performance are billed as the Semi-Pro Musica Antigua, Dana Krueger, mezzanine-soprano, and Peter Lurye, pianoer. Ms. Krueger is a mezzo-soprano who performs regularly with the Opera Festival in Central City, Colo., and is on the opera faculty at the Banff School of Fine Arts in Canada. Mr. Lurye writes and produces music for television and is principal pianist for the New Jersey Symphony and the Northeastern Pennsylvania Philharmonic.
The program will include ''The Magic Bassoon,'' with Mr. Schickele dressed as a fur-legged Pan and Ms. Krueger as a sylvan nymph. It will begin at 8 P.M. at the center, 760 Northfield Avenue. Tickets are $25, or $23 for students and the elderly, and may be ordered by calling (201) 480-4200.
Information: (201) 736-3200, extension 251.
 
WRITERS' DAY
Music, mystery and poetry - even architecture and astrophysics - will be on the program for the New Jersey Writers' Day at Bloomfield College on Saturday.
Lynn Wenzel will read selections from her new book, ''I Hear America Singing,'' and Diana Weber will sing selections that were popular from Colonial days to the 1930's. The book is a cultural history traced through sheet music.
The artist Harry Devlin will read from his recent best seller, ''Portraits of American Architecture: Monument to a Romantic Mood 1830-1900,'' which is illustrated with his renditions of outstanding American buildings and examines the economic, artistic and social factors that led to the architectural style of the period.
Eric J. Lerner, a physicist who has abandoned mainstream thinking on the origins of the universe, will read from his book, ''The Big Bang Never Happened,'' which is to be published soon.
Caroline Crane will read from her latest mystery novel, and poetry will be served up by Madeline Tiger, Penny Harter, Penelope Schott, Norma Sheard, Joan Handler and Mika Applebaum. William Higginson, a haiku expert, will also read from his works.
The event, sponsored by the New Jersey local of the National Writers Union, will be held from 1 to 5 P.M. in the faculty meeting room of the arts building. The campus is off Broad Street in Bloomfield.
Admission is $5. There will be a cocktail hour at the end of the afternoon when the audience can meet the writers.
Information: (609) 883-8878.
 
TONY BENNETT
Tony Bennett, whose voice and style have mellowed without faltering during a career of more than 40 years, will star in the Friday Evening Club's 90th gala anniversary celebration on Saturday in Denville.
The master of the romantic ballad, Mr. Bennett is also an accomplished painter whose works have been exhibited around the world. After he performs, the singer will attend the gala's supper dance at the Mountain Lakes Club, 18 Lake Drive.
The concert will be held from 8 to 10 P.M. in the auditorium of Morris Knolls High School in Denville. Tickets for only the concert are $25, $30 and $35.
Tickets including the black-tie supper dance are $150, $250 and $500. The Friday Evening Club, based in Morristown, will use the proceeds to enhance the enjoyment of its concerts by those who are hearing or sight impaired. The deadline for reservations is tomorrow.
Information: (201) 538-6413.
 
ARTISTS' HOUSE TOUR
A tour of artists' houses and studios in Englewood, Tenafly and Englewood Cliffs on Thursday will include the opportunity to meet the artists and see them at work.
Robert Glaisek, painter; Coco Schoenberg, ceramist; Joan Fine, sculptor; Ina Chappler, ceramist; Imari Nacht, graphic designer, and Peggy Silverstein, sculptor, are among the artists opening their houses and studios for the event.
The Studio of Fine and Decorative Arts, where the artists Marguerite MacFarlane, Peter Cozzolino and John Merlino have their workshop, will also be included in the tour.
Participants may visit any or all of the sites during the self-guided tour from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.
The tour is sponsored by Salute to Women in the Arts of Emerson. Tickets, which are $15. may be reserved or purchased the day of the tour at Jewel Spiegel Galleries, 30 North Dean Street, in Englewood, where refreshments will be served.
Information: (201) 568-0159 or (201) 568-1616.
 
PHOTO SLIDE TALK
''People Outside the Mainstream'' will be the subject of a slide talk by the photographer Claudio Edinger on Tuesday as his exhibition carrying the same title opens at Drew University on Route 24 in Madison.
In his talk, Mr. Edinger will concentrate on people truly living on the edge, but the show of 30 black-and- white and 10 color photographs encompasses a wide spectrum. Hasidic Jews, stock exchange traders in Brazil, people living at the Chelsea Hotel in Manhattan and personalities from Venice Beach, Calif., are among the subjects in the show.
The photographer was born in Brazil and now lives in New York City, where he teaches at the New School. The talk will be at 7:30 P.M. in the University Center, Room 107; the exhibition is in Room 104 and admission to both is free. The hours for viewing are 12:30 to 2 P.M. and 7:30 to 10:30 P.M. Monday through Friday.
Information: (201) 408-3456.
 
AIDS BENEFIT
The New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's final performance of ''Measure for Measure'' at Drew University on Saturday will be a benefit for the Hyacinth Foundation, which assists AIDS patients in New Jersey.
Tickets are $30. The performance will be at 8 P.M. in the Bowne Theater on the campus.
Information: (201) 408-3278 (10 A.M. to 6 P.M.).

LENGTH: 1821 words

HEADLINE: Rutgers, Confronts A Crossroads

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
ACROSS from Old Queens here, workers are completing a $9.6 million renovation of Winants Hall, a stately 100-year-old building, in preparation for its dedication in November as a new administrative center. With the building refurbished inside and out and with the lawn freshly sodded, Winants is yet another example of Rutgers's decade-long drive to transform itself from a tired state university into a first-class institution of higher education and research.
But Winants Hall is also a symbol of frustration. Faced with a reduction of $26 million, or nearly 11 percent, in state aid this year, the university has had to take a number of economies, including postponing the use of its new administrative center until next year to save several hundred thousand dollars in operating expenses.
The budget cut, following a $7.9 million reduction in state aid last year, has been felt by students and faculty alike. Tuition has risen 10.8 percent, to $2,856, for full-time undergraduates; lightweight football and women's lacrosse have been dropped as intercollegiate sports, and the student health service is now closed between midnight and 8 A.M. There is a greater reliance on part-time instructors, and the full-time faculty members, including administrators, are carrying heavier teaching loads. 
While Rutgers officials say the quality of instruction has so far not been affected, there are concerns that the momentum toward academic excellence will be undermined if budget cutbacks continue. Like other New Jersey state colleges and departments of state government, Rutgers has been told to plan for a further 8 percent reduction in state aid next year.
''Everybody's worried, and you need to be,'' said Dr. Francis L. Lawrence, who starts work tomorrow as Rutgers's 18th president. ''I'm concerned about maintaining faculty salaries and raising tuition. It's not just our reputation, but I'm concerned for New Jersey because this is the source of future leaders for the state.''
Whether Dr. Lawrence's leadership will be substantially different from that of his predecessor, the late Edward Bloustein, remains to be seen, but he is expected to focus much of his attention on the Rutgers undergraduate.
''What I'd like Rutgers to be is a complete paradigm - research, teaching, learning and public service,'' Dr. Lawrence said. ''We're all going to have to focus more on undergraduate instruction. In a sense, it's the highest pinnacle to which we should aspire.''
Academic deans at Rutgers have been told to make classroom instruction their highest priority, an action that, while applauded by most in the university community, may take its toll on the quality of the future faculty. ''It has been quite serious,'' said Dr. Richard McCormick, dean of the faculty of arts and sciences on the university's New Brunswick campus. ''The pain has been inflicted on research and the ability to attract new people to the faculty. I've warned all the department chairs that they may begin searches for faculty, but there's no assurance that they can consummate those searches with actual appointments.''
The financial difficulties at Rutgers came at a time when the institution seemed to be making significant strides in gaining the respect it so covets. Dr. McCormick said that the departments of political science, chemistry, psychology and computer science were on the brink of achieving the national prominence already enjoyed by its departments of English, history, philosophy, physics and astronomy, and mathematics, and that many others had well-developed plans in place to make the leap.
''This is the shame of it all,'' he said. ''There are a number of departments that are in that position. They have every legitimate academic reason to make that jump in the early 90's, but the dollars aren't there.''
The budget cuts have also created a $50 million backlog of maintenance projects, as money that had been earmarked for repairs has had to be applied to the library and to preserving classes.
In the wake of the nearly completed $600 million capital construction program, the deferred maintenance strikes an odd contrast to the many modern buildings that have appeared since the construction program began in 1986. Next to the glistening new fiber optics center in New Brunswick stands an engineering complex with doors that do not shut and a ventilation system badly in need of repair. Nearby, on the top floor of the Rieman chemistry laboratory, a pan collects water from a leaky roof.
While most state universities are facing budget problems, the situation at Rutgers seems particularly acute because of its relatively recent resolve to join the top ranks of state research universities.
''There is a delicacy about our new identity,'' said Susan Cole, vice president of administration and personnel. ''People would be perhaps less concerned about it if we had been here longer. Rutgers is such a young university to begin with, and its current identity is even younger.''
Compounding the sense of uncertainty on campus is the arrival of Dr. Lawrence, formerly academic vice president and provost of Tulane University in New Orleans, who has his own vision of what a state university, and Rutgers in particular, should be. It was under Dr. Bloustein, who served as president from 1971 until his death from a heart attack last December, that Rutgers began its effort to become a premier research center. New centers in medicine, biotechnology, fiber optics and other areas of research were developed, and the university was invited in 1989 to join the Association of American Universities, a group of leading research universities in the United States and Canada.
But the heavy focus on research has led to complaints that undergraduate education and the humanities at Rutgers have been neglected. The new president sees no inherent conflict between his emphasis on teaching and learning and the university's research endeavors. He said he had been most successful as a French teacher when immersed in research and could impart some of the excitement of new insights.
To enhance learning at Rutgers, Dr. Lawrence said, he would like to see a resource center for students with peer tutoring, computer-assisted instruction and workshops on learning skills. He would also like to insure that the university's teaching assistants, who are often foreign, be fluent in English and aware of cultural differences.
For the faculty, he suggested there might be lectures on effective teaching and lunchtime seminars led by colleagues on what works and does not work in the classroom.
 
Videotaping of Instructors
He also supports the idea of videotaping instructors in class. ''That's bound to be controversial, but it's really to tell whether they speak loudly enough or look at the rostrum instead of the kids,'' he said.
In addition, Dr. Lawrence said he has been reading about New Jersey's 30 most distressed urban school districts and would seek to strengthen public service efforts, like possibly offering a contract to ninth-grade students from those districts that would guarantee admission to Rutgers and adequate financial aid if they successfully followed a prescribed curriculum Dr. Lawrence acknowledged that he was relatively unfamiliar with New Jersey and its politics of higher education and said he hoped to soon become better acquainted with Gov. Jim Florio and state legislators. The time he has spent in the state has been primarily limited to recruiting students for Tulane. ''I was a good recruiter, but I'm going to stop that now,'' he said.
One of the biggest changes Dr. Lawrence is expected to bring to the presidency is in terms of management style. Dr. Bloustein, a man of strongly held convictions, earned a reputation for occasional abrasiveness and intractability and, at times, alienated segments of the Rutgers and higher education community.
Dr. Lawrence, in contrast, is viewed as a conciliator with a soft touch who prefers to reach a consensus before making a decision. A Moliere scholar known for his wit and easy manner, he was particularly popular among students at Tulane, who once affectionately honored him as ''Hullabaloo Man of the Year.''
 
Study Committees Appointed
Concern about undergraduate education at state universities is not a new subject. Dr. Bloustein was troubled enough by charges that undergraduates were being neglected in the university's pursuit of research and graduate education that he appointed three provost committees on the New Brunswick, Camden and Newark campuses to examine the issue.
The New Brunswick report, the only one so far released, concluded that there was ''no inherent conflict'' between the two missions and recommended a number of ways to strengthen undergraduate education.
Dave Pantos, a student representative to the board of governors, said he agreed with the report's recommendations but feared that they might turn out to be ''administrative lip service.''
''Students are beginning to realize that they don't have to have 500-person classrooms with no discussion sessions, they don't have to be taught by teaching assistants or part-time lecturers, and they don't have to be working with 30-year-old microscopes,'' he said.
Mr. Pantos said Rutgers would be represented at a rally of state colleges in Trenton in November to call for greater state support for higher education.
 
Former Chancellor's View
Dr. T. Edward Hollander, former New Jersey Chancellor of Higher Education and now a professor at Rutgers-Newark's Graduate School of Management, said Rutgers would be hard pressed to continue its forward movement with a continued reduction in resources.
''One can absorb a 1 percent or 2 percent cut by simply deferring or rearranging,'' he said. ''When you reach a level of 10 percent or 11 percent, you're changing expectations about the future in a way that is demoralizing to the staff and faculty. That, I think, is what Rutgers should most fear and probably does most fear.''
Dr. Hollander, who was Chancellor during the Byrne and Kean administrations before resigning in June, said he was not certain where higher education fit in Governor Florio's priorities.
''He's not clarified his goals with respect to the higher education system,'' Dr. Hollander said. ''The budget reductions, which were especially sharp in higher education, were not encouraging.''
 
'We Were Treated Fairly'
But other Rutgers officials are more sanguine.
''We were treated fairly in the budget process last year,'' said Donald Edwards, vice president of public affairs and development. ''We took our lumps along with everyone else.''
Mr. Edwards said this was his third state budget crisis since coming to Rutgers in the 1970's.
''I guess when you've been around as long as I have, you know there are bad years and good years,'' he said. ''Nothing lasts forever, including the bad times.''

HEADLINE: RACE RELATIONS;
Hard-Headed Detente

BYLINE: By Richard M. Nixon; Richard M. Nixon, the former President, recently completed ''Leaders,'' a book of profiles and reminiscences.

 BODY:
The debate over detente has become so charged with emotion that substance gives way to semantics.
To many Americans, detente has become a dirty word, virtually synonymous with appeasement. To most Europeans, it is a good word. To them it describes a period in the early and middle 1970's when tensions between East and West were lessened and when there was more trade, more contact, some liberalization in Eastern Europe, and, above all, a reduced danger of nuclear war. 
American critics of detente, by contrast, look with horror at all the Soviet advances of the last decade. They argue, correctly, that the Soviet leaders lie, cheat, steal and are out to impose their oppressive system on the whole world, and from this they conclude that the only safe course is to restore United States nuclear superiority, cut back contacts and attempt to strangle the Soviet Union economically.
This argument misses the point of detente, it misreads history and it would deprive the West of some of our most potent weapons in the East-West struggle. First, let us be clear about what detente is and is not.
There are two concepts of detente, which I call hard-headed and soft-headed. Soft-headed detente - appeasement in disguise -invites Soviet expansionism by reducing its cost. Hard-headed detente raises the cost of adventurism and thus encourages the Russians to negotiate.
This hard-headed detente is not a love affair. It does not mean that we and the Soviet Union agree. Rather, it means that we profoundly disagree. What it provides is a means of peacefully resolving those disagreements that can be resolved and of living with those that cannot.
Whether or not we agree with Clausewitz that war is the carrying on of political relations by other means, in a nuclear age the two principal competing powers must channel their competition into other means than war. That competition will continue. It is in our interest to direct it into those arenas in which we are strongest. We no longer outgun the Russians, but we do outproduce them, and we clearly outdo them in providing what people all over the world want: freedom, abundance, the chance to live in peace and let the human spirit thrive.
The more we retreat into an angry cold war confrontation, the more we reduce the competition to those levels on which the Soviet Union is strongest. The one thing the Kremlin is good at is wielding raw power, through military might and terror tactics. Where the contest is waged on that ground, Moscow has the advantage. Where we shift it to other grounds, we have the advantage.
The Soviet Union has desperate economic problems. Looking at these, some analysts argue that if we just squeeze the Russians economically the regime will collapse and will be replaced by a less oppressive one. This misreads history, and it misreads the nature of the Soviet dictatorship. Rather than decreasing repression, it would increase it. An oppressive dictatorship is strengthened, not weakened, by external confrontation.
We can call this peaceful competition. We can call it waging a struggle by nonmilitary means. We can call it detente. Whatever we call it, it is better than the alternatives of either sterile confrontation or nuclear conflict.
 
(Aug. 18, 1982)

HEADLINE: RACE RELATIONS;
Howard Beach, U.S.A.

BYLINE: By ROGER WILKINS; Roger Wilkins is a senior fellow at the Institute for Policy Studies, a public-policy organization.

 BODY:
Although Mayor Koch's intentions in visiting Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church were laudable, the anger with which he was met by its Howard Beach parishioners was totally understandable. The people there figure they're not very different from those in any other all-white neighborhood and thus should not be singled out for deviating from the national norm.
And why shouldn't they take that position? More often than not in our history, racism has been explicitly supported by our leaders, and at other times it has been sanctioned by winks and by nods. National leadership of the kind that helped enact the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is rare. 
Howard Beach is a lot like Little Rock, where in 1957 Gov. Orval Faubus's resistance to school desegregation forced the Government to deploy troops just to permit a handful of black children to enter Central High School. If President Eisenhower had applauded the decision in Brown v. Board of Education instead of distancing himself from it by asserting that you cannot legislate for the hearts and minds of Americans, Mr. Faubus might not have had the nerve to mount a rear-guard fight for segregation.
Had President Reagan and his Administration not signaled in hundreds of different ways that racism was not only permissible but could be officially sanctioned - as with providing tax breaks to schools that segregate - then the white Howard Beach youngsters might not have acted as they did.
In such a context, youngsters are emboldened to chase blacks at midnight, real estate agents keep neighborhoods segregated, personnel officers find reasons not to hire or promote blacks, academics develop theories to prove that Federal programs incapacitate poor blacks, Congress retreats from the economic problems of race, and aspirants for the Presidency flee from the issue entirely.
At such a juncture in our national consciousness, why shouldn't people of Howard Beach feel aggrieved to be singled out? Some youths simply acted out the national mood and things got a little out of hand.
People's lives are horribly stunted when, by virtue of their color, they are denied adquate education, decent jobs, suitable housing and a sustaining hope. We need national and local leaders who will fight those evils daily, not posturers who don't raise their voices until somebody has been killed for being lost and lonely in the wrong neighborhood.
 
(Jan. 5, 1987)

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON AND MOSCOW;
A Blueprint For U.S. Forces

SERIES: Is the cold war over? An occasional series

BYLINE: By John Lehman; John Lehman was Secretary of the Navy from 1981 to 1987.

 BODY:
The new Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, has hardly settled in his seat and already the civilian and uniformed sachems of the military tribe are leaping about him with their hair on fire, urging immediate decisions. He should refuse - until he has made his most important choice.
That choice is this: Should we accept a military of roughly the same proportions as today's, but drastically compromised in effectiveness by cuts in operations, maintenance, training and modernization? Or, should we create a fundamentally different military establishment that has fewer but more effective active forces and greatly expanded reserves, which could be quickly mobilized? 
The second alternative won't appear in the bureaucrats' option papers, but it's the only logical choice.
Two facts argue for a new approach. First, the immediate Soviet threat is much diminished. Mikhail Gorbachev's realism, Soviet economic decline, ethnic strife and the very success of the Reagan military buildup have turned the Soviets away from an unwinnable arms race.
Is it tactical retreat or strategic change? We don't yet know. For the foreseeable future, however, the Soviets will invade neither the oil producers of the Persian Gulf nor the allies of NATO.
Whatever the reality, Wetern perception of the Soviet threat, especially in Europe, has dissipated. That leads to the second reality, which is the certainty of deep cuts below current Pentagon plans.
If the Administration chooses to continue down the road of orthodoxy - the only road the bureaucracy will present as a choice -then we will repeat the peacetime collapse of our military in the 70's, or even the 30's. In the defense industries, competition will disappear, economies of scale will be lost and unit costs will explode. Morale in the armed forces will collapse. A few big-ticket weapons will be canceled, but herds of cripples will be continued. Moreover, since land troops outnumber seamen by 4 to 1, the sea services will suffer disproportionately.
The alternative, which will horrify the 90,000 defense bureaucrats, is to shift perhaps a third of our force structure from full-time regulars to the ready reserve. This plan would cut overall defense costs by 10 to 15 percent, or $30 billion to $45 billion. The only loss of military capability would be the need for additional weeks or even months to mobilize fully for all-out war.
To fill the expanded reserves, we must pay reservists more, especially at the lower ranks. Even if we doubled current pay, the average cost of a reserve soldier would still be about one-eighth that of a regular.
Since the costs of active manpower now eat up about half of the defense budget, the cuts that are almost certainly coming could easily be absorbed without reducing our forces or falling behind in military technology - if this path is chosen.
We would not have to withdraw forces from Europe or South Korea, and the Navy could still keep its battle groups forward.
The tradition of this country is the citizen soldier and sailor, not the large, professional standing force. American privateers captured nearly 100 times more British ships in the War of Independence than did the Continental Navy, and the ratio of reservists to regulars in World War II was about 70 to 1. Let us make a virtue of budget necessity and global relaxation, and shift back toward that tradition. (March 26, 1989)

HEADLINE: COUNTERPOINT;
Ignorant Drug Policy

BYLINE: By Lester C. Thurow; Lester C. Thurow is dean of the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T.

 BODY:
The United States' war on drugs has led to the attempted ouster of Panama's leader, the virtual kidnapping of a Honduran, new efforts to burn crops in Bolivia and a proposed Congressional resolution accusing Mexican officials of accepting bribes. A short time ago, similar actions were directed at Pakistan, Colombia, Peru, Turkey and Thailand.
Before we further damage our foreign relations, we should admit the failure of efforts to interdict drug supplies abroad and focus instead on reducing demand at home. 
The current approach has led us to demand actions of others that we would not for a moment tolerate if asked of us. Consider what we would do if a foreign government kidnapped one of our citizens or if its parliament passed a resolution accusing us of complicity with drug dealers.
Drug sellers face what in the jargon of the economics profession is known as an inelastic demand curve. This means that if supplies are cut back by 10 percent, prices rise by more than 10 percent, leaving the seller with higher profits than before the cutback.
If our goal is to deprive criminals of large profits from selling drugs, economic theory and history teach us that legalization is the only answer. When liquor sales were legalized after Prohibition, criminals left the bootleg liquor industry because the huge profits available while the Government was attempting to stop liquor sales vanished.
If we do not legalize products for which there is a huge demand, profits will remain enormous and suppliers will always come forward. Individual sellers can be arrested, but others will take their place.
A demand-side solution would be expensive. Jailing buyers, educating addicts and changing the conditions that lead to pathological behavior - none of these are cheap. But effective interdiction of drugs at our borders would require an army of guards. Foreign interdiction is often advocated as a cheap alternative to expensive, politically divisive policies at home, but that view is a mirage.
 
(May 8, 1988)

LENGTH: 742 words

HEADLINE: RACE RELATIONS;
King's Heritage

BYLINE: By TAYLOR BRANCH; Taylor Branch wrote ''Parting the Waters: America in the King Years, 1954-63.''

 BODY:
In death, as in life, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has been plastered over thickly with labels: Christian martyr, dreamer, Communist, the black Moses, De Lawd, national hero, womanizer and saint, among others. A multiplicity of names carries great meaning. It is significant that Dr. King's formal birth name, Michael, was changed to Martin Luther in 1934, when he was 5 years old, and it is also significant that the name of his people is once more the subject of internal debate - this time whether ''black'' should give way to ''African-American'' as ''Negro'' gave way to ''black'' some 22 years ago.
Unfortunately, labeling can block rather than facilitate discovery. We label things in order to blot them out. Because race can be so unbearably sensitive, admirers as well as detractors of the civil rights cause use names for self-protection - ''racist,'' ''militant,'' ''Uncle Tom.'' There is no explanation, resolution, satisfaction or atonement - only a banishment whose very swiftness suggests a fear of candid discussion. 
Segregationists controlled most of the labeling machinery during the early years of Dr. King's brief career.
The civil rights movement took us deep into fundamental questions about democratic practice. That is why we honor Dr. King, its leader, with a national holiday, and on this fourth observance, around what would have been his 60th birthday, we ought to try to apply the depth of his democratic commitment to our own times.
We need to ask ourselves: What does it mean that many whites of good will privately feel no hope for, nor empathy with, the urban black poor, and that many black politicians themselves are baffled by the underclass? Can a nation founded on self-government conclude that the pleasures and profits of drugs are irresistible to human nature?
Can we seriously believe that we may become the world's first nation to suffer economic decline from excessive generosity to its poor? Why is it that blacks and Jews, two peoples commonly devoted to the justice of the Mosaic prophets, are seen to be at one another's throats? Why is there virtually no competition in elections for the House of Representatives? Why are these issues absent from our recent campaigns?
Dr. King's life offers instruction in the underlying principles of democracy. As a schoolboy, he survived a bout of skepticism largely by adopting theologian Reinhold Niebuhr's theories of justice. Mr. Niebuhr defined justice as society's best approximation of perfect love.
Dr. King grounded his religious faith close to the Jeffersonian intuition on the equality of human spirits. ''We will win our freedom,'' he wrote in his ''Letter From Birmingham Jail'' in 1963, ''because the sacred heritage of our nation and the eternal will of God are embodied in our echoing demands.''
On a more practical plane, Dr. King and some of the early members of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee engaged in a classic debate over the appropriateness of princely leadership in a democratic cause. Often Dr. King confessed himself to be too caught up in the ramifications of his position, far behind the students in willingness to advance the cause by sacrifice or innovation.
At other times it was the students who were paralyzed, whereas Dr. King faced his casualties. He went straight to the families of the four girls killed in the Birmingham church bombing in 1963 and demanded that he be allowed to preach over the caskets. ''At times life is hard,'' he said at the group funeral, ''as hard as crucible steel.''
 
While the F.B.I. and several
Southern states collected thick political files on Dr. King's 1957 visit to Highlander [Folk School, in Tennessee, where blacks and whites were committed to social advancement], they failed to preserve a word of what he said. They should have, however, for those words still ring true today.
He spoke of a skittish nation in which the best people, ''for fear of what they will be labeled,'' avoid discussion of the most vital questions. ''Channels of communication between whites and Negroes are now closed,'' said Dr. King, who was then 28. ''Certainly this is tragic. Men hate each other because they fear each other. They fear each other because they don't know each other. They don't know each other because they can't communicate with each other. They can't communicate with each other because they are separated from each other.''
 
(Jan. 16, 1989)

HEADLINE: RACE RELATIONS/VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
Wrong on the Berlin Wall - And Most Else

BYLINE: By Eric Alterman; Eric Alterman, a senior fellow of the World Policy Institute, is writing a book about Washington pundits.

 BODY:
It has been a long and rocky road for America's foreign policy elite since Mikhail Gorbachev came to power in 1985.
Not since Copernicus, perhaps, have so many been so wrong so frequently with so little humility.
''He has no new ideas,'' assured Carnegie Endowment Sovietologist Dimitri Simes when Mr. Gorbachev was named General Secretary. ''In many respects, more dangerous,'' warned Zbigniew Brzezinski. It will be ''two to four years'' before he can consolidate his power, noted Henry Kissinger. While blinding us with perestroika, insisted Mr. Brzezinski, the Soviets were actually pursuing peredyshka - a breathing spell. Richard Nixon rehabilitated himself in the Establishment's eyes with the view that ''under Gorbachev, the Soviet Union's foreign policy . . . has been more aggressive, not less.'' 
In Eastern Europe we were told to expect more of the same. Seweryn Bialer of Columbia University wrote in 1986 that the ''main thrust of Gorbachev's Eastern European policy is to strengthen the Soviet hold on its empire and to control the satellite parties more tightly.'' As late as February 1988, Mr. Bialer was still insisting that ''the Soviet leadership . . . has no intention of transforming the major national institutions.''
Once Mr. Gorbachev's seriousness became undeniable, this chorus of disapproval grew cacophonous. ''Gorby'' may be worthy of our sympathy, but he was likely to be overthrown by hard-liners. The Harvard Sovietologist and frequently televised expert Marshall Goldman was remarkably consistent in predicting Mr. Gorbachev's imminent demise.
As Poland sped toward democracy, the same hypercaution reared its head. In February 1989, Mr. Brzezinski said that further events in Poland could spark a Soviet military takeover in Moscow.
Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger seems to prefer the ''remarkably stable and predictable'' atmosphere of the cold war to the uncertainty of a thaw. (When Mr. Gorbachev proposed visionary arms cuts at the U.N., Mr. Eagleburger complained about the timing of the speech.) The current establishment line on Mr. Gorbachev is that while he will survive Kremlin challenges, national animosities and economic inefficiencies will probably do him in. The prescription: Our sincere best wishes, but of course we must be prudent and cautious. No change in policy.
The Establishment has been singing this do-nothing tune for nearly five years now. The question Americans should ask as they watch the walls of arrogance reduced to dust in Eastern Europe: How long can we afford to keep listening?
 
(Nov. 12, 1989)

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 2, Column 3; Op-Ed at 20 Supplement

LENGTH: 447 words

HEADLINE: THE LITERARY EYE;
Happy Families Are Alike

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GASS; William Gass is professor of philosophy at Washington University in St. Louis.

 BODY:
In olden days. two lovers, when they died, in honor of the love they had for one another were often buried together. Nowadays, instead, they marry. Children, cars and houses stand above them, mark their place, for there they lie, beneath six feet of mortgage and insurance, locked in an eternal institutional embrace, their shrouds the slick white silk of ''shared experience.''
R.I.P. - the Rent Is Paid. This, indeed, is often just what love seems for: it multiplies the suburbs, paves the streets; it makes scout leaders, clubby women, choirboys, caddies; it fuels, in fact, our whole society, for how is so much of its work to be accomplished except by these domesticated pairs, hauling Brand Names docilely across the shelf-lined reaches of the American Dream. 
Once we thought that sturdy independence was one admirable consequence of the ownership of land; but what, in time, has come to be hatched behind the drawn draperies of the housing tracts? An insularity and narrowness of spirit.
Birth, marriage, death, the years and years of Christmas, are almost wholly economic occasions; purchase is the family's single public purpose. We and the world both know we have a baby - look at what we've bought. Yet what we've bought buys us.
The family is the center of our lives, yet is expected to deal with - what? The husband putters, the wife gardens. Happiness is somewhere near. Work is where the money's made the family spends on family happiness. What, then, is possible? Only a rich intimacy. But how can this be achieved when the basic things (eating, sleeping, loving) are cut off so completely from the world, surrounded with insignificance, and defended with hypocritical lies which doom it to exchanges of spirit exclusively trivial?
Unless you are going to abandon the family as a center value (there is every reason for doing so, but this means opposing the whole social and economic direction of our culture), you must give the home importance by doing your real-life work there.
To freely give and freely to receive, to live an open life with at least one another is in atmosphere of acceptance and trust - secretless - imagine what that entails; what an extraordinary achievement it would be; what confidence it would require and give; what knowledge of oneself, and in general of man; and what large social lies would have to be erased from one's conscience for truth to become conscious in such precious company; what exhilaration to have one's spirit finally freed; and what a priceless gift - to hold like a wild young animal another's safety in one's hand, or to place your soul in just such jeopardy, and still to be loved.
 
(Aug. 1, 1977)
