PUB-DATE: September 30, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 1; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 1714 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
OIL SHOCK RAISES GLOBAL ECONOMY'S UNCERTAINTY INDEX

BYLINE: By LEONARD SILK

 BODY:
 But another worry rose with the soaring price of oil, especially in the United States: the threat of a recession that would impose new strains on financial institutions, real estate developers and corporations laboring under the unusually heavy burdens of debt contracted in the borrowing binge of the 1980's. The biggest borrower was the United States Government, and last week, with the economic scene darkening, budget negotiators from the Administration and Congress struggled to make a deal on how to cut federal deficits by $500 billion over the next few years.
 Above all else, financial markets hate uncertainty -- and the most impenetrable uncertainty troubling the markets today is how high the price of oil will go, for how long, and how much damage it will inflict on the closely interdependent national and world incomes.
 What would a serious oil price shock do? First, it would increase the costs of producing virtually everything: automobiles, steel, plastics, clothing, fertilizer -- and hence farm products -- trucking, air fares, truck fares, bus fares. Those industries that use the most energy would suffer the biggest rises in costs, and the biggest squeeze on their profits if they could not pass the rising costs along. 
 The overall inflationary pressure from the oil price increase could be counteracted by tightening monetary policy -- but that in turn would drive up interest rates, making it tougher for consumers to buy houses, cars, and any other big items they would buy on time. It would make the charges on their credit cards bigger and cause many to cut back their spending on soft goods as well.
 Or, the central bank, in an effort to ease the squeeze of rising oil prices, could make too much money available, and that would drive up interest rates anyway, because loans would be repaid with dollars that were worth less.
 Higher interest rates, higher energy costs and squeezed profits would cause many businesses to cut back on new plant and equipment, research and development, advertising -- and labor. That would increase unemployment, which would mean another twist to spending and business sales. The danger to corporate solvency would intensify, and many businesses would go bankrupt, laying off still more employees. The failing businesses and dismissed workers would then be unable to pay off their loans to the banks, which would grow insolvent and, unless bailed out, fail.
 Such is the nature of a real recession -- one that "feeds on itself," as Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, put it. Even worse, the feeding frenzy can become worldwide. As each nation gets into trouble it imports less, and the exporting nations suffer. Commonly, they try to find ways to protect their own businesses, through import quotas or higher tariffs. That messes up world trade, hurting rich countries and poor -- though the poor, living close to the edge even before the slump, have nothing to fall back on, of their own or from their governments. Anger rises, political revolts fester, and wars may follow.
 But there are less frightening possibilities for what the gulf cisis portends. In a study aimed at applying some perspective and concreteness to the speculations, economists of the World Bank have laid out four scenarios for the world economy. (See charts at right).
 The first scenario, a rapid return to normalcy, assumes that the crisis will be over by the end of this year, or soon afterward. After a spike, oil prices would drop as economic growth slowed and the flow of oil returned to normal levels. With oil already at $40, this scenario looks unrealistic. But expectations, rather than actual shortages, have set oil prices soaring. If fears of war end, expectations would turn around and drive prices back down.
 The second scenario, short-term uncertainty, sees no resolution to the Middle East crisis for another year to 18 months. World demand for oil holds constant but world supply drops by as much as 2 million barrels a day. Even with peaceful resolution of the gulf crisis, market insecurity lingers. Expectations that Saddam Hussein will not soon march out of Kuwait, that United States forces will not pull out of Saudi Arabia, and the United Nations will not cancel its embargo on Iraq make this stalemate scenario more credible, thouigh persistent anxieties make the oil price assumptions still look low. The drag on economic growth and the pressures on inflation could be even greater.
 The third scenario, prolonged uncertainty, assumes that the crisis is not resolved for several years. In real terms, oil prices would decline steadily, reflecting gradual increases in world oil supplies and a slowdown in the growth of world oil demand. Given the assumption that risks of hostilities persist, the study's statement that oil prices will "Fluctuate around $29 a barrel" sounds as euphemistic as J. P. Morgan's famous prediction that "Stocks will fluctuate." When the risks of war are high, oil prices will shoot up; when they fall, oil prices may fall (but not necessarily as much). In this climate, it seems unlikely that a steady $29 price will prevail.
 The final scenario is war. "If efforts to defuse the existing crisis fail and war breaks out in the Middle East," says the World Bank study, "Iraqi, Kuwaiti and Saudi oilfields could suffer long-lasting damage, effectively removing up to 10 million barrels a day from the world market." and causing a huge price increase. Once the war ended, prices would moderate as oil-importing countries cut consumption by conservation measures, improvements in fuel efficiency and substituion of non-oil fuels, and as exploration and development reached new heights and gulf producers reconstructed their damaged oilfields.
 But the war scenario is even more of a guessing game than the others. The World Bank's construct, which assumes a quick and decisive defeat of Iraq, focuses on the immediate impact on oil capacity but ignores the potential destruction of other physical facilities, including factories, equipment, dams, highways, airports, and most important, human lives. It leaves out the possible spreading of the war to other Middle East countries.
 Some analysts, politicians and oil ministers (notably the former OPEC leader, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani of Saudi Arabia) are writing much more disastrous war scenarios, pushing the oil price to $80, $100, or still higher, with a devastating effect on the developing countries, Eastern Eruope, indeed, the entire world economy. In that light the World Bank study is neither far-fetched nor hysterical.
 There is genuine danger of war as long as Saddam Hussein refuses to pull his forces out of Kuwait and President Bush refuses to negotiate until he does. The United States has sought to make clear that it is not bluffing when it says that Iraq would face utter destruction if it launched a war, or severe retaliation if it engaged in terrorism. American officials contend that the more seriously their threat is taken, the greater the hopes for peace.
 Nevertheless, anxieties stemming from this game of chicken are reverberating through financial markets all over the world. With investors digesting all the news they can assimilate and putting their money where their mouths are, in New York, Frankfurt and Tokyo, the financial capitals of the 'Tri-piolar" Capitalist world, the securities markets have all turned bearish.
 The Tokyo stock market has plunged the most -- with the Nikkei 225 average falling more than 40 percent. The exchange had undoubtedly been overbuilt more than the others, as money made in Japan's wildly booming real estate market poured over into the stock market. The gulf crisis and fears about the consequences of the oil shock on Japan, totally dependent on imported oil, sent the Tokyo market plummeting. Similar fears have haunted the other major markets. already preoccupied with domestic issues.
 
A Replay of '87?
 But stocks also crashed in 1987, and the real world economy was not knocked off its expanding course. Will the script be repeated this time? The "wealth effect" of the last crash, which was expected to hurt the real economy by inflicting psychological pain on consumers and businesses, causing them to tighten expenditures, did not work that way. But the oil shock hits the real economy more directly by forcing higher outlays on fuel, and less on other goods and services. If governments and central banks seek to cushion the oil shock by simply making more money available, it would not change the relative-price effect resulting from more costly oil but only cause overall prices to rise faster.
 
Deficit Budgeting
 In the United States, a resolution of that other stalemate -- between the President and the Democrats over the swelling budget deficit -- would set the stage for lower interest rates that might stave off recession without unleashing inflation. That step would improve the chances that this country can weather the oil-price storm and not sail into a financial hurricane behind it.
 But economists say any budget agreement would have to be followed with more sweeping action. A stronger energy policy aimed at conservation and production of alternative fuels, for example, would help reduce dependence on unstable Middle Eastern sources and ward off threats to the environment. Strengthening and closely monitoring the American financial structure could help prevent the kind of highly risky behavior that produced the savings and loan debacle.
 Economists also see the need to keep the world economy from splitting into hostile trade blocs and to make world markets more open to trade not only in manufactured goods but in farm products, intellectual property and services. That is among the goals of the current Uruguay Round of talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
 With the threat of nuclear war with the Soviet Untion diminished, a shift in the balance of United States military forces toward coping with the sort of threats that Iraq or other rogue states may pose might help prevent these situations.
 Collective security and world economic growth may be the best antidote against future wars, now that the axis of greatest danger has shifted from East- West to North-South.

HEADLINE: VIETNAM;
Who Profits? Not Us

BYLINE: By Oskar Morgenstern; Oskar Morgenstern is professor of economics at New York University

 BODY:
 Since January 1961, we have lost 44,000 dead, 288,000 wounded and many missing. Yet there is no record of any Soviet or Chinese soldiers killed or wounded except perhaps in accide4nts. We have lost more than 1,390 fixed-wing airplanes and 1,800 helicopters. Form these planes, we ahve dropped more bomb tonnage than rained on Nazi Germany - yet without decisive results.
 Over the last five fiscal years, we have spent $104 billion on that war - more than 12 percent of our national income in 1968. Day after day during the last four fiscal years we have paid an average of $65 million for Vietnam, and this rate is only slowly-decreasing.
 What a drain on our resources with the complex consequences of stock market boom and bust, uncontrolled inflation with its inherent danger of hyperinflation, chronic balance3 of payment troubles, the highest interest rates in decades, high unemployment, all accompanied by profound social and racial unrest, by turmoil on the campuses, on the streets; by the alienation of large parts of youth from flag and country. And the Communist powers? Can there be a more ideal situation for them, totally devoid of risk?
 So the profit of the war has accrued over years and continues to accrue to precisely those two countries whose ideology and physical power the U.S. is trying to stem in the preposterously inefficent manner of fighting their satellites on their own terms.
 Those who in this country have been pushing the war are achieving the exact opposite of what, in good faith, they are striving for: a strong and solidly prosperous U.S., the prevailing peaceful force in this troubled world.
Nov. 7, 1970

HEADLINE: FOCUS: Massachusetts;
Affordable Starter Homes Do Well in Weak Market

BYLINE: By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE

 BODY:
 Although central Massachussetts and Plymouth, like the rest of the state and of the Northeast generally, have lost jobs and shown a rise in unemployment over the last two years, some builders have been successfully cultivating a niche they found and occupied even before the economy started sliding.
Statewide, unemployment went from 4.6 percent in 1989 to 6.7 percent this August, according to the state Department of Employment and Training.
The builders who can take advantage of the current demand despite that slippage are those who can get low-cost land and construction loans.
In Gardner, for example, in the central part of the state, land costs about $25,000 to $40,000 an acre, compared with $80,000 to $150,000 in the suburbs close to Boston, said Conrad J. Donell, president of C. D. Homes in Ayer, about 50 miles west of Boston. 
 Professor Case, who is also a visiting scholar at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, said that because many banks are troubled by bad real estate loans, they are making construction loans only to builders who are well established in the area, who have built other successful developments in the last 10 years and who propose projects judged especially salable.
"Those getting the loans were a success before the boom and didn't let it get to their head by overexpanding," he said.
One development that has succeeded in the current market is Deerberry Ridge, a subdivision of 100 single-family homes that Mr. Donell's company is building in Gardner, a small, old industrial city in a generally rural area about 60 miles west of Boston.
Sales of the two- and three-bedroom homes, which range from 998 to 1,600 square feet, began late in 1988. So far, 67 have been sold, at an average price of $138,000, Mr. Donell said, adding that he expected to sell 30 to 35 more by the end of the year.
"Sales aren't really any slower than they were last year," said Mr. Donell, whose family has been building entry-level housing in the area for two generations. In 1986, Mr. Donell said, he built and sold 25 units and last year he built and sold 42.
About five miles south, in Fitchburg, a city of 40,000, Mr. Donell's brother, Robert, president of the Donell Corporation of Ayer, is building Westbrooke Commons, a $6 million project of 50 detached single-family condominiums priced from $97,000 to $125,500. Nine have been completed or are under construction, and six of those have been sold since marketing began in June. The development is on a 17-acre wooded hillside within walking distance of downtown Fitchburg.
The cedar-sided two- and three-bedroom homes, some with unfinished second floors, range from 860 to 1,344 square feet. All have full basements, two-car garages, fireplaces and patios.
Last year, Robert Donell sold out a $17 million subdivision of 102 single-family homes in Leominster, another small city, about five miles east of Fitchburg. The homes, in a development called Jamestown Commons, were priced from $119,000 to $149,000 and included fireplaces, oak kitchen cabinets, plaster walls and rear decks.
By October, Robert Donell expects to break ground on Shawsheen Commons, a $26.5 million, 220-unit project of single-family homes and two- , three- and four-family dwellings in Wilmington, 20 minutes north of Boston. The multifamily dwellings will start at $129,000 per unit, with the single-family homes priced from $159,999 to $169,000.
The Donells can get construction loans because of their companies' track records and the family's reputation as builders of quality starter homes. Even in the mid-80's residential building boom they built such homes. "Our market is first-time buyers and it is always there," Robert Donell said.
Another subdivision of starter homes has been under construction since 1987 in Plymouth, an hour south of Boston and the last town before Cape Cod. So far, 207 of the 837 single-family homes have been built and sold at $117,000 to $149,000.
The houses range from 1,400 to 1,800 square feet and some are on a pond, hence the name of the development, the Ponds of Plymouth. Kevin B. Sweeney, a partner of the developer, L & S Builders Corporation of Pepperell, said he sold 43 Ponds units in 1987 and 43 last year and expects to sell 70 this year. Between 1987 and this year, he said, prices were lowered 5 percent.
Mr. Sweeney said he was able to produce low-cost starter homes because "I bought the 1,200-acre site from six to 10 years ago for $1 million and was able to hang onto it."
"The people who are building in this market," he said, "are geared to small homes for first-time or move-down buyers and were able to get cheap land."
"Most of the country is down," said Dean Crist, a research economist for the National Association of Home Builders in Washington, "but there are places that are doing well."
A relatively small number of new homes, including single-family and multifamily units, are being built in Massachusetts compared with a few years ago. Michael DiBitetto, president of the Massachusetts Homebuilders' Association, said he expected 16,000 to 18,000 housing starts in 1990, down from the 1986 peak of about 40,000. In the eastern part of the state, which has about half the population, starts are down to under 6,000 units this year, from about 24,000 in 1987, Professor Case said.
With an unsold inventory of about 55,000 units statewide and banks reluctant to extend construction loans, "the mid-priced spec house is just a memory," said Joseph C. Polcaro, president of the Polcaro Construction Company in Sandwich, on Cape Cod. "Activity here is mostly lower-end and some upper-end custom houses."
Little in the way of multifamily housing is being produced, except for projects that were started a few years ago. Joseph E. Corcoran, general partner of Corcoran Jennison Companies of Quincy, just south of Boston, which has built approximately 8,000 condominium and rental units in the state, has not started a new multifamily project in at least two years. The company is finishing projects started before 1988.
"With the 1986 changes in the tax law that discouraged investor ownership of condominiums, there was a glut of unsold condominiums that weakened rental prices," Mr. Corcoran said. "Although the condo glut is just about absorbed, you still can't charge enough rent to cover construction and operation unless you have very low land and infrastructure costs."
Many projects now being built were started a few years ago as developments of mid-priced and more expensive homes, but were taken back by the construction lender, Mr. Corcoran said. The homes are coming on market now at up to half the original target price, he said.
Although Massachusetts is in a recession, with housing prices down an average of 15 percent, homes are selling. Professor Case estimated that about 75,000 would sell this year, down from 85,000 in 1989 and 100,500 in the peak year of 1987. In another recession year, 1982, 42,500 homes sold.

PUB-DATE: September 30, 1990

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 17, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1790 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
New Season: Audacious, Varied and Vital

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
WHAT are the consequences of the austere economic outlook and the precarious state of the arts for the new season? Conservative? Perhaps compromised and curtailed theater fare? Not so. Consider the audaciousness, variety, vitality - and sheer bounty - of the theater season just begun in Connecticut's regional playhouses. A survey of the repertories of the state's professional companies affirms the freeing power of the playwright's art. If it is to reflect reality, it is also reflecting upon it, making statements of defiance and transcendence.
Instead of the sort of escapist entertainment people are said to crave during stressful times, audiences will be in for explorations of economic and ethical issues, moral dilemmas, value systems in disarray and the suppression of the individual. What ails us is being confronted, not camouflaged, and it's being done with a heady sense of cosmic consciousness.
Responsibility, identity and survival are to be examined at New Haven's Yale Repertory by international voices like Vaclav Havel (''Largo Desolato,'' which the President of Czechoslovakia wrote after he had been incarcerated as a political dissenter) and the Israeli playwright Joshua Sobol (''Underground,'' which takes place during the Nazi occupation of Lithuania). 
Artistic freedom in Czechoslovakia is also the subject of ''Wenceslas Square,'' a relatively unacknowledged work by Larry Shue, who was known for flightier things like ''The Nerd'' and ''The Foreigner.''
The ramifications of financial pressures are variously investigated in four plays at the Long Wharf Theater, in New Haven. ''The Voysey Inheritance,'' now playing, is about the ethics of investing at the turn of the century in Boston. In ''Valued Friends,'' four roommates measure their relationship against a real estate speculator's offer. And ''The Baby Dance'' is about the selling of an infant by impoverished parents to an upscale couple.
Offstage, a resourceful way of dealing with a forbidding economy can involve a collaboration between two theaters.
Hartford Stage and the Old Globe Theater, in San Diego, for example, are sharing the costs of the world premiere of the prolific A. R. Gurney's newest work, ''The Snow Ball,'' which has 15 actors and ballroom dancing yet, choreographed by Graciela Daniele. The play moves to the theater in California immediately following its Connecticut engagement.
The first play of the season at Stamford Theater Works, ''Remembrance,'' represents a similar alliance between the company and Off Broadway's Irish Arts Center. And Samm-Art Williams's ''Home'' is to be presented in January by the Stamford Center for the Arts and the Black Artists Theater Company, a new organization in Stamford.
 
'Laboratory' for New Works
Instead of a falloff in theater activity, another addition to Connecticut's professional producing organizations may be noted. Aptly called the American Premiere Theater Series and described as a laboratory for the development of new plays and musicals, the company is about to spring forth in Fairfield, with the promise of new works by playwrights like D. L. Coburn, who wrote ''The Gin Game.''
The works of playwrights heretofore pronounced as promising are also awaited: Suzan-Lori Parks's new work is ''Betting on the Dust Commander,'' an interweaving of African and American traditions of jazz and storytelling to be seen at Company One in Hartford. Similarly awaited is Howard Korder's ''Search and Destroy,'' a dark comedy about a modern American everyman scheduled for the Yale Repertory season.
Those who require the classics won't be shortchanged. Look to Chekov (''Ivanov'') and Moliere (''Scapin'') in Yale Rep's 25th-anniversary season. Look also to Ibsen (''Master Builder'') and Shakespeare (''Julius Caesar'') at Hartford Stage, and Ibsen again, as adapted by Arthur Miller (''An Enemy of the People'') at Long Wharf.
And for a touch of Broadway glitz, with a box office star or two, the perennial road companies passing through the Bushnell in Hartford, the Shubert in New Haven and the Stamford Center for the Arts include a full-blown production of ''The Fantasticks'' (starring Robert Goulet) and ''Mame'' (starring Juliet Prowse). The capstone of such traveling Broadway showmanship is likely to be ''Grand Hotel'' with Tommy Tune's Tony Award winning and inseparable direction and dances recreated.
And in a season rife with significance, don't forget that ''Grand Hotel'' is awhirl in the decadent - and ominous - splendor of pre-war Berlin, mixing portents and pertinence with instant musical theater gratification.
Following are the theatrical offerings that have been scheduled. In some cases the companies have not completed their calendars, and theatergoers should call to confirm a play's run.

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 8, Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1143 words

HEADLINE: Voters Keep Rejecting Their Towns' Budgets

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
OXFORD'S First Selectman, Raymond L. Drapko, will be spending the next several days cutting the budget that the voters sent back to him.
Mr. Drapko said that he was disappointed that the budget had failed to pass in a referendum last week, but that he was getting used to going back to the budget-making starting line. He has done it six times now.
Part of the problem in getting a budget passed, Mr. Drapko said, is that this is the first year in which residents will be paying for bonds for a $16 million capital-improvement program. The bond payments alone would have raised taxes by almost 25 percent if other adjustments had not been made, he said. 
''It's kind of like using a new credit card,'' Mr. Drapko said. 'You go out and buy and buy and buy, and then when the first bill comes in you say, 'Oh my gosh, what have I done?' ''
 
Fears About State Aid>
In addition, Mr. Drapko said, state financing for education and other programs fell short of what was promised, and with a $1 billion state deficit predicted next year, aid could decline more. The result could be that the budget difficulties this year could turn into open revolt in 1991.
''In Oxford, the individual homeowner is going to have a hard time if the state reduces aid to towns,'' Mr. Drapko said.
An increasing number of towns in the state have rejected budget proposals in multiple referendums this year. According to a study last week by the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, 72 of Connecticut's 169 towns held referendums this year, rather than passing the budgets at town meetings, a much simpler process. A budget goes to referendum either because of a petition filed with the town clerk or because the town meeting adjourns to a referendum.
Of those 72 towns, 28 had 2 referendums, 12 had 3, 6 had 4, 1 had 6, and 5 towns - Bethlehem, Bridgewater, Roxbury, Washington and Woodbury - had to go to the polls seven times to pass a budget.
The study noted that three other towns besides Oxford - Coventry, Old Saybrook and West Hartford - had not passed budgets more than two months into their fiscal years.
''It's the highest number of budget referenda that's ever taken place,'' said James J. Finley, legislative services director for the Conference of Municipalities. And, he said, the conference has no records of any town having to go through six or seven votes on a single budget.
 
'Have to Be a Magician'
Mr. Finley said the number would probably have been higher, but cities usually have no provision for a budget referendum. Still, some cities, like Hartford, faced tax protests nonetheless, he said.
''The polls are telling us people want more services and lower taxes,'' Mr. Finley said. ''You almost have to be a magician to accomplish those dual purposes.''
Mr. Finley said grand lists, tallies of all taxable property, grew an average of only 3.2 percent this year, while state aid to towns increased only 3.6 percent. The two sources account for more than 75 percent of town revenues. Inflation was running at least 5 percent, and spending increases were greater than that for towns that have been granting large teacher salary increases this year, Mr. Finley said.
As a result, more than 70 percent of Connecticut towns had to raise taxes this year, Mr. Finley said, and that led to the worst budget battles the conference has seen.
The conference is concerned that the state budget next year will be balanced by reducing aid to towns, Mr. Finley said.
''Our pitch to the legislature and gubernatorial candidates is going to be, 'Don't shift the deficit to the cities and towns,' '' he said. ''It's going to be the toughest challenge we've faced in more than a decade.''
 
Only Postponing Problems>
In Woodbury, a budget that was passed on the seventh try contained no tax increase, ''but that will not be possible next year,'' said First Selectman Katherine H. Campbell.
She said that the taxes were kept in place by reducing the number of capital projects from the year before, but that can be a problem in the long run.
''Every time you knock $50,000 off the road budget, you've only postponed your problem,'' Ms. Campbell said. ''If you put those things off too long, you face million-dollar repair projects in a few years.''
Next year, municipalities are expected to face the toughest budget preparation in a decade, and they will be doing it with a new governor and probably no idea what to expect in state aid. Gov. William A. O'Neill is not seeking re-election.
''No matter who is elected,'' Ms. Campbell said, ''there will have to be a shakedown period as they settle in, and it will come at the height of our budget-making time.''
Ms. Campbell said another problem was the increasing state requirements for in areas like special education and recycling of solid waste.
''We all agree recycling is a wonderful idea,'' she said. ''But it's going to cost us all a lot of money. And the state's telling us to do it without giving us the money to do it with.''
 
A Budget Decrease
In Oxford, Mr. Drapko said, the original budget would have increased taxes to 43.6 mills from 34.3 mills. A mill equals $1 in taxes for every $1,000 in assessed value of property.
With an eight-mill increase built into the budget for the principle and interest due on bond payments for an elementary school and sewer and water lines, Mr. Drapko said, only 1.3 mills of the increase could be attributed to new taxes. But the voters would not buy it.
The budget defeated on Tuesday called for taxes of 39.1 mills, which means that after accounting for the bond payments, the budget actually decreased. That was done by eliminating a constable position and cutting jobs and material from the public works budget.
''It would depend on having a mild winter,'' Mr. Drapko said. ''If we have a lot of snow, we've definitely got a problem.''
George C. Eggert, First Selectman in Bethlehem, where the budget took seven tries to pass because of concerns over education spending, said town government spending increased 5 percent, which he called inadequate.
''We cannot increase it enough to cover things we really should be doing,'' Mr. Eggert said. ''We have a serious problem keeping our roads up. We have a tough time finding money for fire equipment.''
But Mr. Eggert said more disturbing is taxpayer talk of withdrawing from the Region 14 school district, which includes neighboring Woodbury, because it would be more costly for Bethlehem to operate its own school system.
But Woodbury has twice the population of Bethlehem, and this year Woodbury residents turned out in sufficient numbers to pass the school budget despite a ''no'' vote in Bethlehem.
''We all have to pull together if we're going to get through this,'' Mr. Eggert said. ''It's not a them-versus-us issue. It's the whole state that has a problem.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 21, Column 3; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 706 words

HEADLINE: Why Limit Indexing to Capital Gains?

BYLINE: By GEORGE NASTAS 3D; George Nastas 3d is a marketing and financial consultant.

DATELINE: HASLETT, Mich.

 BODY:
As a compromise in the tortuous budget negotiations, the Bush Administration has sensibly suggested the indexing of capital gains, so that we don't pay taxes on gains that are attributable solely to inflation. Indexing of capital gains probably will stimulate investment, at least moderately. But why stop there?
There is one major flaw with the Bush proposal, as a prominent tax expert, Henry Aaron of the Brookings Institution, was quick to point out. By indexing capital gains alone, the Government would create an enormous incentive to shift money from interest-yielding investments, like savings accounts and bonds, to capital assets, primarily stocks. Among other things, this shift would hurt hard-pressed banks and S.& L.'s. 
But that's not the only reason to extend indexing to other investments.
Over the years, business and government leaders and economists have chastised Americans for ''saving too little.'' They lecture that our low savings rate and the consequent lower availability (and higher cost) of investment capital puts industry at a competitive disadvantage.
What they don't talk much about are the motivation and incentives for saving, how the system seems designed to persuade Americans to consume now rather than save. This, far more than a capital gains tax, inhibits savings and investment.
When people save or invest, they are postponing consumption until sometime in the future. For this, they demand compensation - interest, dividend or capital gain. Naturally, a rational person will save more as the return increases.
What is the reward in the U.S. for postponing consumption? Consider the following example, in which a person invests $10,000 in a relatively risk-free instrument, such as a certificate of deposit or a Government bond.
If the investment earns 8.5 percent, the investor would receive $850 at year's end. If inflation is running at about 5 percent, however, the return declines by 5 percent of $10,000, or $500, during the year.
If the investor is in the 33 percent Federal tax bracket and, as in Michigan, is subject to a 4.6 percent state income tax, he or she pays 37.6 percent of the $850, or $319.60, as a tax penalty for investing. (Obviously, the loss would be higher if the state tax rate were higher or if there were additional taxes on investment income.) So, for a one-year investment of $10,000 at an 8.5 percent return, our saver receives a real, after-tax return of $30.40. ($850 minus $500 for inflation minus $319.60 for taxes.) This is hardly an incentive that is going to persuade anyone to postpone consumption.
Even if the investor was taxed only on the real gain - in other words, if the gain was indexed for inflation -he or she would pay tax on only $350 ($850 minus $500). His tax would be 37.6 percent or $131.60 of the $850. His real return would be $218.40 or 2.184 percent after tax and inflation on the $10,000. Still not much of an incentive to save or postpone consumption.
Note that, under the current system, Federal and state governments receive $319.60 from the savings effort of this investor, who gets only $30.40. There's little mystery about who gains the most from saving.
Clearly, the return to the saver is inadequate to justify savings or investing. Americans are acting rationally when they bias their spending toward current consumption, rather than saving for the future.
If America is serious about encouraging investment and savings, there must be more incentive for Americans to save. Certainly, indexing of capital gains doesn't go far enough.
Eliminating taxes on investment income (interest, dividends and capital gains) or adjusting all investment income for inflation before calculating income taxes would be a step in the right direction. More encouraging - though, admittedly, no more of a political possibility - is an investment tax credit for consumers. A credit of 10 percent of the investment amount against current personal taxes made available to all Americans, perhaps with a reasonable upper limit of $1,000 per person per year, would stimulate savings.
But we have to ask ourselves whether a country that rewards a saver with a $30.40 annual return on $10,000 is really serious about increasing saving.
